DOC.HEAD: Students Protest University Conditions With Sit-In
DOC.TEXT: State legislators met Tuesday with four of 200 students on the seventh day of their sit-in to protest conditions at East Tennessee State University. Rep. Roscoe Dixon, chairman of the Legislature's black caucus, said three of the school's administrators and three of the student protesters agreed to meet to resolve the impasse. The caucus met with four of the protesting students from the historically black school. The students, who began the sit-in last Wednesday, said they are protesting dilapidated classrooms and dormitories. ``I wouldn't allow my pet dog to live in the dormitories out there,'' said Sen. John Ford, a member of the caucus. Ford said $60 million was added to the Nashville school's operating budget a few years ago, ``but essentially a lot of things have not been done.'' ``It's going to take a lot of time,'' he said. ``You can't tear down a dormitory in one day. The process is slow and long.'' Some of the protesters have left the sit-in periodically to attend classes. The university has an enrollment of 3,800 students.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find No Explanation for Fatal Shooting Spree
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `Harper used ...,' to UPDATE with Lacock's condition; picks up 5th graf, `Harper had ...'
DOC.TEXT: A man sat in an all-night restaurant for three hours Tuesday before drawing a pistol without warning, shooting an employee to death and critically wounding a customer, police said. Police shot and killed Clifford James Harper, 39, when he stepped out of the 4B's Restaurant and ignored repeated orders to drop his weapon, said police Chief Don Millhouse. ``The first thing I heard was the police yelling `freeze,''' said Paul Richards, who was spending the night at a cultural center a half a block away. ``There was some type of guttural response ... then pop, pop, real quick shots.'' Harper used a .41-caliber Magnum pistol to kill George Loewen, 64, who had been vacuuming the restaurant, and to wound Larry Lacock, 40, a customer sitting at the counter, Millhouse said. Lacock, hit in both arms and grazed across the chest, was initially listed in critical condition at St. Patrick Hospital, but his condition was upgraded to good following surgery Tuesday evening, said an evening supervisor who condition of anonymity. Harper had been staying in a motel in this secluded college town of 35,000 in western Montana, Millhouse said. He apparently entered the restaurant about 1 a.m. and stayed three hours. Two police officers and a Missoula County sheriff's deputy confronted Harper when he exited the restaurant, Millhouse said. Despite several warnings, Harper advanced and continued pointing his weapon at the officers, who shot him, the police chief said. The shooting was justified, and no criminal charges will be filed, said Fred Van Valkenburg, a deputy county attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Farrakhan Says He's No Enemy Of White People Or Jews
DOC.TEXT: Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan says he is no enemy of white people or the Jews, but he claims the U.S. government has plotted to kill him, according to an interview published Thursday. ``To say that Louis Farrakhan is antisemitic is an unfair characterization of me,'' he said in an interview with The Washington Post. Farrakhan, leader of the 10,000-member black organization who has given few interviews, has been criticized for his outspoken views, particularly about Jews and Israel. In his interview, he said his statements have been distorted by the news media. ``Louis Farrakhan is not an enemy of America, not an enemy of Jews, not an enemy of white people,'' he said. Asked about a 1984 statement in which he was reported to have called Judiasm a ``dirty religion,'' Farrakhan said he was ``referring to the actions of the stte of Israel using God and religion as a cover for what I said was lying, stealing, murder.'' ``And I said ... that Jews, some of them, practice dirty religion; some Muslems practice dirty religion; some Christians practice dirty religion, and that's why we're in America in the condition that we're in,'' he said. A city council resolution last year honoring anti-drug efforts of the Nation of Islam at a Washington housing project was criticized by Jewish groups as an implicit endorsement of Farrakhan's views. Farrakhan accused the government of orchestrating the assassinations of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X. He said the federal government had plotted to kill him and that the CIA and other government operatives harass him both in and out of the country. He was not specific, and said those operatives will meet the wrath of a ``higher power.''

DOC.HEAD: Next Question: Where Can You Rent Some Squirrels?
DOC.TEXT: There's a new park planned downtown _ but it will be so temporary they might rent the trees. ``This just sounds crazy,'' City Councilwoman Jane Noland said Monday after Metro officials briefed the council on their plans to spend $400,000 to $600,000 to build a temporary park at a bus station entrance. Metro, the regional agency that operates the transit and sewer systems for Seattle and surrounding King County, has used the privately owned 144,000-square-foot property for the past three years to store equipment during construction of a bus tunnel. It received permission from the city to do so with the understanding that once construction was completed, the block would be made presentable. Intrawest Corp., which wants to build a retail and office building on the site, recently took an option to buy the land from Marathon U.S. Realty Inc. Metro officials say landscaping the property into a park is one of the cheapest ways to spruce up the land until Intrawest gets the city permits it needs and is ready to build. Because it's not clear how long that might take, Metro is considering leasing the trees that will be in the park. ``We'll just send 'em back when the park moves,'' said Gary Hartnett, a design consultant. Robert Holmes, Intrawest president and chief executive officer, said he hopes to start construction early next year. But City Councilman Jim Street said it could be two years or more before the city gives its go-ahead.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Prosecutors Didn't Prove Case
DOC.TEXT: A state social worker has been cleared of a charge of failing to report suspected abuse in the weeks before a 2-year-old was fatally thrust headfirst into a toilet for soiling his pants. Judge Jesse Barber on Tuesday threw out the misdemeanor charge against Kenneth Houk, saying the prosecution hadn't proved its case. Barber granted the acquittal two hours into the trial and before the defense even presented its side. Houk was the first of three Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services workers to be tried in the case arising from the death of Bradley McGee. ``It's over,'' said Houk, who had faced up to 60 days in jail if convicted. ``I don't even want to think about it anymore.'' Prosecutors contended Houk twice failed to notify the state child abuse registry after receiving reports about Bradley's case. The last call came weeks before the toddler's July 28 death from head injuries when the child was repeatedly thrust into a toilet for soiling his pants, authorities said. Bradley's mother and stepfather _ Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, and Thomas Coe, 22, of Lakeland _ face trial this summer on murder and aggravated child abuse charges. Bradley was abandoned at a shopping mall when he was 3 months old and lived most of his life in foster care until the state gave him back to the mother and stepfather two months before his death. The prosecution's case hinged on a July 3 report relayed to Houk in which a family friend said Bradley's mother had forced the child to eat feces for violating potty training. Theresa Jacobs, a prosecution witness who originally reported the feces complaint, told the jury Houk had urged her numerous times to telephone the child abuse registry when she had something to report. She said she didn't follow his advice because she ``never got any satisfaction from the registry.'' She also said she did not have firsthand knowledge of the alleged abuse. Case worker Judy Ross was called by the state to confirm reports that she relayed the feces complaint to Houk. But she wavered when asked whether she thought such a secondhand report warranted a call to the HRS hotline. After the acquittal, defense attorney Jack Wilkins said, ``Hopefully this will lead to a different wording of the law. ... People who work for HRS must be given the freedom to make judgment calls.'' Assistant State Attorney John Aguero stalked out of the courtroom, refusing to comment. Case workers Margaret Barber and Shirley Duboise also are charged with failing to report child abuse. Ms. Barber, who had been assigned the Bradley case, also is charged with child abuse, which carries up to five years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Frankly, My Dear, I've Got You in a Headlock
DOC.TEXT: Could Rhett Butler pin ``Nature Boy'' Ric Flair? Could Dorothy put the Wicked Witch of the West in a half-Nelson? Wrestling fans may be betting on such questions if Jim Herd, executive vice president of World Championship Wrestling Inc., gets permission from his boss, media mogul Ted Turner, to borrow wrestlers' names from classic films. Turner owns both the wrestling organization and the rights to such movies as ``The Wizard of Oz'' and ``Gone With the Wind.'' ``That would be a plus if we had characters patterned after these larger-than-life individuals,'' Herd said Tuesday at the new $2 million World Championship Wrestling post-production studio in Turner's CNN Center. Herd said his first attempt would be to have Long John Silver, the one-legged buccaneer of ``Treasure Island,'' swagger into the ring. ``I personally think we should approach wrestling from a historical viewpoint,'' Herd said. ``If I find a 270-pound, 6-foot-5 one-legged wrestler, I'd have Long John Silver.'' Turner was out of town Tuesday and could not be reached for comment, but Herd said he thinks he'll go for the idea. ``He's told me personally he likes what he's seeing, and if he doesn't, he'll say so,'' he said. Herd isn't worried that controversy, similar to that engendered when Turner began colorizing black-and-white films, could erupt over use of the fictional characters. ``We introduce controversy every day,'' Herd said. ``And Robert Louis Stevenson won't get mad at us.'' The four hours of wrestling on Turner Broadcasting System's cable Superstation each week are among TBS' highest rated programs, Herd said. With the studio, WCW will improve the production quality of its wrestling programs to ``compete in today's glitzy atmosphere'' and do interviews with wrestlers to ``let fans see their human side,'' he said. The new facility, complete with wrestlers' dressing rooms, replaced dubbing studios in Charlotte, N.C., and Dallas and contains state-of-the-art equipment to provide programming to 178 TV stations. The studio and WCW's ``human'' approach will help the company gain a projected $60 million share of the $300 million wresting industry in 1990, Herd said.

DOC.HEAD: Marina Builder Accused of Destroying 1,500 Mangrove Trees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dumfounding is cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A developer that illegally bulldozed more than 1,500 soil-conserving mangrove trees to make way for a marina-condominium project could be fined up to $25,000 per tree, or $37.5 million, officials said. The mangroves, which play a vital role in Florida's rapidly disappearing wetlands, occupied a 1,700-foot stretch along a drainage ditch next to Dumfounding Bay, part of the Intracoastal Waterway north of Miami. ``This is probably the largest mangrove destruction case in Dade County history,'' said Robert Karafel, a code enforcement officer for 17 years. The bulldozing was discovered Jan. 25 after an anonymous tip to the Metro-Dade Department of Environmental Resources, authorities said Monday. Officials at Glendale Federal Bank, backers of the project, do not deny the bulldozing and said they are trying to resolve the situation. Glendale is responsible for any penalty, Karafel said. ``Even though we don't believe some of the mangroves were significant to the ecosystem, we recognize they were removed illegally,'' said Stanley Price, an attorney for the thrift. ``It's just an unfortunate event, it really is.'' One settlement under discussion would have Glendale pay a fine, reimburse the agency for administrative costs and plant 22,680 mangrove seedlings. The mangroves, which grow along salt water, create land by trapping soil and provide a haven for sea life in its roots. The trees are best known for their curly above-ground root system and grow to about 25 feet high. ``In maybe 25 years, you might see what was destroyed,'' Karafel said. ``When you cut off that food source, it has longstanding impact on the entire food chain in the bay.'' The contractor, Ryan Construction Co. of Sessner, had a permit to clear only 100 feet of mangroves, the thrift said. In all, about 1,890 trees were destroyed, including some buttonwoods, inspectors said.

DOC.HEAD: Modern U.S. Monitoring System Joins Fight To Save Sphinx
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Egypt is combining old photographs and American high technology in the most comprehensive save-the-Sphinx campaign in 3,400 years. Such an ambitious project was last undertaken in ancient Egypt's New Kingdom after _ legend has it _ a young prince fell asleep in the shadow of the Sphinx and heard it whisper: ``Save me.'' The new campaign, announced this week by Culture Minister Farouk Hosni, follows years of delay and disagreement over how to save the crumbling monument, a half-man, half-lion sculpted 4,600 years ago. The Egyptian Antiquities Organization launched an emergency conservation project last year to remove and replace concrete blocks and mortar from the Sphinx's front paws and haunches. The new project combines the Egyptians' restoration work with modern monitoring equipment from the United States to discover why the Sphinx is deteriorating and what to do about it. Protective wooden scaffolding already climbs from the statue's chest to the top of its cobra-adorned headdress. The famous piercing eyes and subtle smile barely show through. ``I must find a way to save it,'' said Sayed Tawfik, Egyptian antiquities chairman, inspecting the monument Tuesday. ``Not just for my lifetime, but for the next 2,000 years.'' Tawfik contacted the Getty Conservation Institute, which provided the monitoring equipment. The Marina Del Ray, Calif. institute will pay about $200,000 for a year of monitoring and pick up some of the preservation costs. ``People, institutions, everybody was afraid to touch the Sphinx, afraid they'd be blamed if something went wrong,'' Tawfik said. ``We have a nickname for it, `Father of Terror.' Everybody was terrified to help us, because the Sphinx is so big and so famous. Luis Monreal, the Getty institute's director, said he's ready for the challenge. ``You have to imagine that although the Sphinx has been around almost 5,000 years, it's been covered with sand for all but about 500,'' he said. Since the Sphinx was last uncovered in 1925, it ``has been exposed to the modern world 24 hours a day.'' ``We cannot return the Sphinx to the way it would have looked to the pharaohs, but we are confident we can return it to the pristine look it had in 1925, if that's the look the Egyptians want.'' A 200-pound, 6{-foot-tall meteorological station will be perched atop the Sphinx's back, anchored by sandbags. Capable of recording data for one year, the solar-powered monitor will record traffic vibrations, changes in moisture, temperature and wind direction and the effects of sand, salt, water and earthquakes. Erosion has gutted almost every part of the mammoth limestone statue, and experts predict the decay will increase dramatically as Cairo's 14 million population continues to expand. The first major campaign to save the Sphinx was the project of the young prince who later became Pharaoh Tuthmosis IV. Asleep in the shadow of the sand-covered Sphinx, traditon holds that he saw the beast come to him in a dream and heard its promise to lead him to the throne if he would free it. After he became pharaoh, Tuthmosos had his artisans restore the statue. About 1,400 years later, Greeks and Romans also repaired the sacred Sphinx with small blocks similiar to those the Egyptians are inserting today. Monreal said his team has gathered the available literature on the Sphinx's history including all restoration attempts and ideas on how to save it. He has collected photographs from as early as the mid-1800s, when only the Sphinx's head protruded from the sand. He said the pictures will enable the team to create a computer model of what has happened, when, what could happen and what can be done about it. The important thing, Monreal said, is ``the Egyptians have decided the Sphinx must be saved. We agree.''

DOC.HEAD: Miss USA Pageant Judging Begins; Telecast Finals Are Friday
DOC.TEXT: The Miss USA beauty pageant got under way Tuesday evening as 51 contestants flashing bright smiles and sporting mid-winter tans competed in swimsuits and evening gowns. About 3,000 people gathered at Century II's Convention Hall for the competition by contestants from all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Each category contributes a third of the score that will determine the 12 finalists, who will be announced Friday in a national telecast of the pageant on CBS. The other third will come from personal interviews with an 11-judge panel. In Tuesday night's opening, the contestants _ all wearing short, black cocktail dresses _ sang about being ``right in the middle'' of the United States as they danced and strutted in front of a U.S. map with Wichita marked with a neon star. Contestants said hello to the audience with brief statements, many of them on their aspirations. Two contestants said they wanted to someday win the Academy Award for best actress; nearly a dozen said they are planning careers as broadcast journalists or television personalities. One contestant who survived an automobile crash endorsed seat belts. In the swimsuit competition, contestants wore identical pink, one-piece suits. They posed in front of a neon rainbow with puffy clouds projected behind it as the Top 40 song ``Blame It on The Rain'' played. Two preliminary awards were announced. Photographers covering the pageant picked Miss Mississippi-USA Stephanie TenEyck as 1990's most photogenic delegate. She is a 20-year-old University of Mississippi student from Laurel, Miss. Miss Minnesota-USA, Janet Tveita, was selected by a vote of all the contestants as the nicest, most enthusiastic and friendliest of the 51 women. She is a 21-year-old from Brooklyn Park, Minn., and attends North Hennepin Community College. Judges for this year's pageant include former Olympian and professional ice skater Robin Cousins and retired astronaut Gordon Cooper. The pageant finals hosts will be Dick Clark and Leeza Gibbons, co-host of the syndicated television show ``Entertainment Tonight.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: A screenwriter who claims his ideas were stolen for the movie ``Harlem Nights'' has filed a $35 million lawsuit against Eddie Murphy, who lost a similar case in January over ``Coming to America.'' Michael Greene, 35, charged Tuesday that ``Harlem Nights'' contains material lifted from a screenplay Greene wrote for Murphy called ``A Halloween to Remember.'' When he saw ``Harlem Nights'' in November, he was astounded at the similarities _ some 100 in all, Greene said. ``My film was a lot better than what was made,'' he added. Both scripts were about 8-year-old orphans being raised by underworld characters, both were set in the 1930s and both had a corrupt Italian plainclothes cop _ Sgt. Pallone in Greene's version and Sgt. Cantone in the movie, Greene said. Named as defendants in the suit are Murphy, Paramount Pictures Corp., the William Morris Agency and Steven Weiss. A lawyer for Paramount, Les Fagen, denied the charge of copyright infringement, saying the scripts contained motifs common to hundreds of movies. Greene said he submitted his script to Murphy in January 1989 and was advised it had been rejected. The script was never returned, he said. In January, a judge ruled that Paramount Pictures had to pay humorist Art Buchwald for a script idea he claimed was the basis for Murphy's hit 1988 movie ``Coming to America.'' The amount of the payment has not been settled.

Hazel N. Dukes, who has overseen New York branches of the NAACP since 1977, has been elected as the organization's national president. Dukes is executive director of administration services of the New York City Off-Track Betting Corp. She also serves on numerous governmental and corporate boards, including the State University of New York board of trustees. She replaces Enolia P. McMillan of Baltimore, where the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has its headquarters. McMillan had served the maximum term of six years. Dukes was elected Feb. 17 by the 64-member national board at its annual meeting here, NAACP spokesman Jim Williams said Tuesday.

Janet Jackson gave an unscheduled benefit concert for homeless people and other charities in Pensacola, where she has been rehearsing for her first world tour. ``Janet ... has gotten such a tremendous amount of work done that she feels ready to perform,'' said Lee Esckilsen, director of the Pensacola Civic Center, where the rock singer's concert was held Tuesday night. Ms. Jackson had used the arena to practice for a tour that opens Thursday in Miami. ``She is a generous person,'' Esckilsen said. ``She wants to give something back to the civic center and Pensacola for allowing her to work here comfortably.'' The concert was announced only a day ahead of time. All 7,600 of the $10 tickets were sold within three hours. An additional 1,000 tickets were given to charity.

A former mayor says he rues the day he dedicated a city park in the name of Kirk Douglas, who described Amsterdam as a ``dirty mill town'' in his 1988 autobiography. ``I will go to my grave regretting my part in putting a park in his honor here,'' Mario Villa, a city ward supervisor, said Monday. Kirk Douglas Park was dedicated in a 1985 ceremony attended by Douglas and thousands of well-wishers, including Villa, then mayor. In ``The Ragman's Son,'' Douglas says his neighbors in the town near Albany discriminated against him when he was growing up here because he was the son of poor Russian Jewish immigrants. Douglas claimed he was beaten and denied jobs because he was Jewish. Villa said the claims of discrimination were false, and he decried Douglas as ``nothing but a hollow, phony individual'' with little concern for his hometown. Douglas' book already had drawn criticism from residents of this town of 22,000. In a letter recently to The Recorder, the daily newspaper in Amsterdam, Douglas refused to retract anything he wrote.

``There's a Tear in My Beer,'' a melancholy country song, helped Hank Williams Jr. and his father earn 11 Academy of Country Music Award nominations 37 years after the elder Williams' death. Williams got six nominations, including entertainer of the year, and the Grammy-winning song collaboration led to five nominations for his father, who died in 1953. ``The ones for daddy are particularly important. I want to see daddy shine after these 37 years,'' Williams said Tuesday. Clint Black also got six nominations, including best album and song for ``Killin' Time,'' and five went to Grammy-winning singer Rodney Crowell for ``After All This Time.'' The 25th edition of the academy's two-hour awards show take place April 25 at the Pantages Theater in Hollywood and will be televised by NBC.

Actor-director Ron Howard joined his neighbors fighting the installation of a microwave radio tower on the grounds of a closed school. Howard, 36, known for his roles on television's ``Happy Days'' and ``The Andy Griffith Show,'' said microwave transmissions from the 180-foot tower at the Parkway School could harm children if the school ever reopened. ``A couple of physicians I talked to said, `You better be careful,''' Howard said at a town meeting Monday night. Town officials say they need the tower to improve radio communications for police and fire departments. Howard's four children attend private school.

DOC.HEAD: Valet Parkers Hold All the Important Keys in the City
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: No man is a hero to his parking valet, especially if he's a congressman. ``Politicians are the worst tippers,'' says Adam Greenberg, an American University student who earns living expenses as a parking valet for black-tie galas and Georgetown dinner parties several nights every week. ``They drive up and say, `I'm a congressman _ park it close.' They go to five parties a night, stay for 15 minutes and leave. I guess they only have so much money to go around for tips,'' he says. Greenberg is one of about 170 part-time employees _ most of them college students _ who hustle cars for Atlantic Valet Parking, which handles more than 1,000 Washington social events to the tune of $1 million each year. It's tough work, waiting outside for hours in rain, snow and numbing winds, only to be stiffed by an abusive drunk whose Mercedes wasn't purring at the front door the moment he staggers out. ``Then surprise _ along comes an old Chevy Nova who pulls out a ten-spot,'' says Marty Janis, the company's 26-year-old executive director and part owner, who got his start as a valet parker during his senior year at Georgetown University six years ago. Finding a safe, nearby place to park in a hurry isn't the valet's only worry, Janis said. Although car keys are kept on a locator board at big parties to avoid mishaps, an occasional key is lost or misplaced in the rush. It becomes a nightmare when the missing keys belong to a VIP, which happened to Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor and former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara. ``It was very late, and McNamara wasn't at all happy,'' Janis said. ``We drove him home, got his spare keys and went back. When our guys finally delivered his car, he thanked them and gave them a big tip.'' Janis gets headaches from limousine chauffeurs who block traffic, and high anxiety from little fender scrapes. ``It's always a lawyer's car, and they'll kill you,'' he says. ``They'll sue for everything, including mental strain.'' Atlantic, the biggest valet parking company in Washington, handles everything from glitzy charity balls for 3,000 guests to one dinner party where the hosts invited another couple and, eager to impress, hired a valet to park their car. Greenberg, a two-year veteran who works as many as four parties a week, receives a $5 hourly wage and averages $10 in tips for a night's work. Valet parkers are instructed to obey parking regulations at all times. Joyriding is forbidden. So is shoving out a hand for a tip. They are coached to respond to cursing with a courteous smile and an apology. And they must run _ never walk _ to retrieve a car. ``They're trained to drive slow and run fast,'' Janis says. For all its drawbacks, says Greenberg, ``it's a great job _ flexible hours, good exercise, good money and plenty of entertainment.'' They might glimpse Prince Charles or Brooke Shields at a black-tie banquet. Or watch well-heeled, well-oiled couples fighting over the keys to drive home. Or shake hands with a tipsy Tip O'Neill, the former House speaker who once rolled out of a party and grandly introduced himself to every parking valet on the sidewalk. One of their favorites is Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who hires them for parties at his suburban Virginia home overlooking the Potomac River. ``Sen. Kennedy always talks to us if he can, and he makes sure we get a bite to eat while we're waiting outside,'' Greenberg said. ``He's one of the best hosts in town.'' Janis recalls one woman who arrived without an escort for an elegant bash, and left her car with a valet. ``The guy was looking for a parking space on the street when the car phone rang. He picked it up and said, `Hello,' and a man's voice said, `Who's this?' He answered, `The valet parker.' The man said, `Oh, yeah, sure.' Then CLICK.'' ``When we told the lady who owned the car, she laughed,'' Janis said. ``She said, `Oh, that must have been my husband. I came alone because we just had a big fight.'''

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Joins Ortega In Demanding Contras Disband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Chamorro calling for Contras to disband. Picks up 11th pvs, `The statement...' Minor editing to CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: Both President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and the Sandinistas demanded Tuesday that the Contra rebels immediately disband, but the defeated ruling party set tough conditions for a peaceful transition of power. ``The causes that started the civil war in Nicaragua have disappeared,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in a radio broadcast. ``That's why those who took to the hills should now lay down their guns and return peacefully to Nicaragua with their families to work for the reconstruction of our motherland.'' Earlier, the top Contra leader, Israel Galeano, said from Tegucigalpa, Honduras, that the rebels would not disband until after Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated April 25 for a six-year term. The Sandinistas, defeated two days early by an opposition coalition in a stunnign upset, insisted Tuesday that industries remain nationalized, land seized from largeholders remain in peasant hands and the U.S.-bcked Contras disband immediately. ``A change of government does not mean the end of the revolution,'' President Daniel Ortega told a cheering crowd of thousands after a meeting of Sandinista party leaders. He read a statement from the party leadership that said it would turn power over to the United National Opposition (UNO) but still had ``the responsibility to watch over and guarantee the continuity of the revolutionary process.'' Ortega's speech came before the chiefs of both sides' transition teams had their first meeting. Former President Jimmy Carter, who is acting as a mediator for Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro, also attended. The private, pro-coalition Radio Corp. said working session were to begin Wednesday. Mrs. Chamorro accused the Sandinistas of using state Radio Sandino to stir up the population, referring to the station's transmission Monday of hundreds of calls from supporters who expressed opposition to her victory. She said she agreed with Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, who asked the news media during a Mass to publicize the idea of ``reconciliation because if they don't, God save Nicaragua.'' In a radio broadcast later, Mrs. Chamorro called for the ``immediate demobilization'' of the rebels and promised to respect the rights of the roughly 40 percent of the electorate that voted for the Sandinistas. The Sandinista statement said the party, as the strongest, most cohesive political force in the country, would oppose any change in its agrarian reform, nationalization of banks and foreign trade. The statement also demanded the jobs of all public workers be guaranteed. Privatization is a fundamental part of UNO's economic program. The opposition hopes to reduce the public sector and return inefficient state-owned industries to the private sector. The statement also said the Sandinistas would ``defend the integrity and professionalism of the army and the police forces.'' Control of military and police forces is considered the most delicate issue in negotiating a transfer of power. They are closely identified with the Sandinista party, and the army is known as the Sandinista People's Army, not the Nicaraguan army. UNO has promised to eliminate the draft and reduce the size of the armed forces. Sandinista officials have insisted they cannot give up control of the army or the police until the guerrilla war, financed mainly by the former Reagan administration, is definitively ended. Carter told reporters he believed the Sandinista concerns about the Contras and the military were reasonable. ``They have expressed their conviction that this has got to be done before they are willing in effect to leave the country defenseless or to turn over their ability to defend the country from an attacking army from Honduras. I think this is a reasonable statement of fact, it's not an ultimatum or demand,'' said Carter. After he read his statement, Ortega emphasized that the party planned to turn over the reins of power to UNO, but said UNO voters would soon discover their mistake. ``Everyone who voted for UNO will vote for the (Sandinista) Front in the future,'' he said. ``The ball is in the other court.'' UNO officials seemed unworried by Ortega's speech. ``Like we say here, this is just the drowning man kicking. But we're not worried about it. Even though it's not in our hands (to demobilize the Contras), there are ways, political ways, to let them know how we feel,'' said Gilberto Cuadra, a Chamorro adviser and prominent businessman. Azucena Ferrey, a former member of the Contra directorate, also seemed unconcerned about demobilization. ``There's no problem with that,'' she said. But Galeano said the Contras wouldn't disband until after the inauguration of Mrs. Chamorro, publisher of the opposition newspaper La Prensa. ``We are a cancer that no one wants. That is why we should act with caution,'' said Galeano. Carter, however, said he was trying to help the parties define the issues and find a common ground. At the transition team meeting, Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and campaign manager, Antonio Lacayo, led her team and Ortega's brother Humberto, the defense minister, led the Sandinista team, Radio Corp. reported. Carter said prior to the meeting that Humberto Ortega, and Interior Minister Tomas Borge, in charge of police forces, had agreed to give up their posts. One concern for UNO, he said, was that the Sandinista army is written into the constitution, and UNO will be several votes short of a two-third majority, even if they maintain their unity. Complete elections results for the National Assembly were not in but the pro-government newspaper El Nuevo Diario said it estimated UNO would win 52 seats, the Sandinistas 38 and the Social Christian party one. As the defeat of Ortega sinked in Tuesday, about 15,000 Sandinista loyalists showed up in front of the Olof Palme Convention Center after word spread that 1,500 Sandinista national, regional and local leaders were meeting. ``We will give up the government, but not our weapons,'' said Lester Rivera, a member of the Sandinista Youth. The general election was monitored by more than 3,000 international observers, including the United Nations, the Organization of American States and a delegation led by Carter. They all pronounced the voting free and fair and the count clean. According to the latest preliminary returns, Mrs. Chamorro took 55 percent of the vote to Ortega's 40 percent with 82 percent of the precincts counted.

DOC.HEAD: AARP Argues Against Cutting Social Security Taxes Now
DOC.TEXT: The largest organization of older Americans says an ill-timed cut in Social Security taxes could destroy confidence in the pension system and make it harder to reduce the federal deficit. But unless government officials can significantly reduce the deficit, a tax cut may be a good idea once Social Security surpluses are sufficient to cover benefits for 18 to 24 months, the American Association of Retired Persons said Tuesday. AARP and two smaller organizations of senior citizens agreed in testimony before the Senate Finance Committee that the government must stop using surplus Social Security taxes to hide the size of the overall deficit. The House Ways and Means Committee took a step in that direction Tuesday by recommending that Social Security revenues not be considered when the overall deficit is calculated. The Finance Committee is considering a bill by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., that would reduce Social Security taxes for workers and employers so that surpluses could no longer be available to mask the deficit. ``The current system creates the illusion that the (Social Security) surplus can be used to pay for general government expenditures,'' said Lawrence T. Smedley, executive director of the National Council of Senior Citizens. ``In a word, the current budget system is dishonest.'' Smedley said taxes could be cut once reserves are sufficient to cover 15 to 18 months of benefits, which probably would not be before 1993. Martha McSteen, president of the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare, said that since the budget is unlikely to be balanced soon, the other way to keep government from spending surplus Social Security taxes is to eliminate them with a tax cut. ``It's much like getting rid of the ice cream and doughnuts before you go on a diet,'' she said. ``You remove the temptation and force yourself to make tough decisions.'' AARP Director Judith N. Brown told the Finance Committee that cutting Social Security taxes ``just when the system is building needed reserves could weaken public confidence and support.'' But she said a tax cut may be advisable once the reserves are built up, so Social Security revenues aren't used to reduce the deficit. She said that unless other taxes were raised or spending cut to make up for the $55 billion a year that Moynihan's bill would lose, the overall deficit would rise, further increasing government debt and slowing the economy. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan advised against cutting Social Security taxes or taking the system out of the budget. ``The current structure of Social Security may not be appropriate in all circumstances,'' he said. ``But, at present, it is still the best option.'' Greenspan said proposals to cut taxes and take Social Security out of the deficit calculation could reduce pressure for real cuts in the deficit and increase ``the difficulty of providing for the needs of an aging population in a way that is equitable across generations.'' Greenspan's contention that a Social Security tax cut might destabilize the economy conflicts with a new study by two former Treasury Department officials. Economists Aldona Robbins and Gary Robbins argue that over 10 years, Moynihan's tax cut would increase the gross national product by $346 billion, create 930,000 jobs and raise investment capital by $162 billion. Unless the Social Security system is changed, the Robbinses wrote: _``Today's average 30-year-old worker who will retire in 2025 could see his income taxes rise by 20 percent if the government is to meet its Social Security promises. _``These higher taxes will be equivalent to a 7 percent reduction in his or her Social Security benefits. What the government gives with one hand it will be taking away with the other.'' The study was done for the Institute for Policy Innovation, a Dallas research organization.

DOC.HEAD: Civic Group Organizes to Combat Rudeness
DOC.TEXT: High above mean city streets _ territory ruled by surly cabbies, kamikaze bicycle messengers and pushy pedestrians _ a group of civic leaders asked New Yorkers to embrace a revolutionary concept. Good manners. ``There is no reason for us to accept the breakdown in this city,'' Herbert Rickman said Tuesday as he announced the formation of New York Pride, a foundation described as a citizen's army whose objective is ``to make New York liveable once again.'' Their theme song: ``Try A Little Tenderness.'' The pervasive nastiness, Rickman said, threatens the city's No. 1 growth industry, tourism. ``When you look at exit surveys and people are asked, `Why don't you want to come back?' one of the reasons is the rudeness and the mean spiritedness,'' said Rickman, a lawyer who was former Mayor Edward I. Koch's special assistant. The campaign's TV ads will feature rude cabbies and ruthless bicyclists with the ``Try a Little Tenderness'' tune in the background. A soothing voice admonishes, ``Come on New York, ease up. Let's keep this the world's greatest city.'' The foundation also plans to plant 30,000 trees this year and produce a weekly radio talk show beginning next month. Other projects include anti-litter and anti-graffiti campaigns in every neighborhood, said Ralph Destino, chairman of Cartier and co-chairman of New York Pride. The New York Pride campaign was launched in Rockefeller Center's plush Rainbow Room, 65 stories above the streets. Conductor Zubin Mehta, one of the celebrities on hand, said he wasn't sure at first the effort was necessary. ``When you come from Bombay, New York is pristine,'' Mehta said. But Mehta allowed that New York would be nicer if cabbies smiled. ``They should say thank you when you tip them,'' said the leader of the New York Philharmonic, who paused for a beat, and added: ``And they should know where they are going.'' New York Pride will operate on about $250,000 and donated office space. Its ads are being created gratis by a member agency. Radio and TV time and print space will be sought on a public-service basis _ dependent on the media's good will.

DOC.HEAD: US, Soviets Report Progress Toward Freer Exchange of Information
DOC.TEXT: When Bruce Gelb traveled to Moscow 30 years ago as a businessman, the Russian phrase he heard most often was ``It's impossible.'' Now, as director of the U.S. Information Agency and chief U.S. negotiator in talks aimed at increasing the flow of information between the superpowers, the Russian phrase he hears most often is ``Why not?'' Gelb and Soviet deputy foreign minister Vladimir Petrovsky say the latest round of U.S.-Soviet information talks, which opened Monday, have cleared the way for signing two cultural agreements at the superpower summit planned for June in the United States. One deal would allow the U.S. and Soviet governments to open cultural centers in each other's capitals, Petrovsky said. The second, on President Bush's ``open lands'' proposal, would reduce restrictions on U.S. and Soviet diplomats and journalists working in each other's countries, Gelb said in an interview in his office Tuesday. The mood of the current information talks is considerably friendlier than the first round two years ago when Gelb's predecessor, Charles Wick, stormed out of a meeting in Moscow after Soviets accused U.S. scientists of inventing AIDS. U.S. officials have complained for years that Soviet media carried ``disinformation,'' of which the AIDS allegation was the most famous example. Gelb says such Soviet activities ``have dropped down to an extremely low level.'' Mutual recriminations have not disappeared from the talks, but ``virtually every one of the problems here has been described as a mosquito that should be swatted,'' Gelb said. During this round, the Soviets complained that Voice of America, a USIA radio station, broadcast inflammatory remarks in January during unrest in Azerbaijan, a mostly Moslem republic on the Soviet border with Iran. ``We are looking into it,'' Gelb said. Soviet officials want to remove barriers to information from the West because ``they now realize that they can't keep information out,'' Gelb said. Moreover, they want to learn how the West works. The information talks this week included a working group on U.S. public opinion surveys, and the Soviets have asked to send observers to a meeting of the U.S. National Association of Broadcasters later this year, Gelb said. The thirst for knowledge in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe is straining U.S. resources. USIA runs a $6 million program to foster democracy and capitalism in Poland and Hungary, but that is far from enough. ``Right now, we have the resources to get halfway across the ditch. We must scramble up the other side,'' Gelb said. Among the other developments at the information talks, the Soviets have agreed to stop unlicensed medium-wave broadcasts from Cuba to the United States and are ready to lift a ceiling of 150,000 on copies of the USIA Russian-language magazine ``America'' distributed in the Soviet Union. The Soviets also appear ready to allow a second VOA correspondent to work in Moscow, said Gelb. Before the reforms, VOA reporters were not allowed in the Soviet Union, and the radio station was regularly condemned by official Soviet media.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: International Issues Dominate `Passport Presidency'
DOC.TEXT: It's an administration where even the agriculture secretary and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers are well advised to keep their passports handy. It's a presidency where domestic issues sprout international wings and golfing weekends turn into summits. Foreign policy dominates the presidency of George Bush, while domestic issues usually get second billing. That's partly because of the breathtaking march of world events and partly because a still-growing economy has taken some of the rough edges off many homegrown problems. But it's also because Bush, despite his protests of wanting to be remembered as the ``education president'' and the ``environmental president,'' seems to be most content when he's immersed in foreign policy. ``This has been a very unconventional presidency. Everything's upside down,'' said Mitch Daniels, a White House aide in the Reagan administration. ``The old rule was: You worked the domestic agenda until you ran out of steam, then gassed up the plane and went abroad and made headlines,'' said Daniels, who heads the Hudson Institute, a conservative Indianapolis think tank. ``It is striking at how different a pattern it is from the one we have become accustomed to.'' Bush, a restless man, is even turning what was planned as a golfing vacation in Palm Springs, Calif., into a two-day working session with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Bush, a former U.N. ambassador, China envoy and CIA chief, was leaving today for the six-day Western trip that includes the Kaifu meeting. Not only has Bush spent most of his time focusing on foreign policy, but much of his domestic agenda has assumed international dimensions. Thus, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and Michael Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, were dispatched to Poland recently to instruct Poles on the ways of free-market economies. Boskin got another international assignment this week. He was named by Bush to help oversee an upcoming international conference on global warming. The war on crime, one of the most domestic of all issues, has been largely overshadowed by the war on drugs, a battle with a major international component. Bush and national drug policy director William Bennett recently attended a daylong four-nation drug summit in violence-torn Colombia to discuss ways to stem the flood of South American drugs into the United States. A follow-up meeting is expected in the summer, and Bush has talked about convening another drug summit next year that will include European nations. Bush has been to 16 countries as president. Members of his Cabinet are not far behind. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is on the road constantly. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady today was wrapping up a four-nation swing through Europe. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was in Moscow in October and earlier visited Spain and Uruguay. Louis Sullivan, secretary of health and human services, was in Israel and Egypt meeting with health officials last month. Last May he went to Geneva for a World Health Organization meeting. And he's scheduled to go to London April 7-10 for a conference on drug abuse. Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos was sent by Bush to Bolivia last August for the swearing-in of President Jaime Paz Zamora. And Bush himself plans to get some more visa stamps on his passport, USA No. 1. Aides said Bush is considering a trip in September to Argentina and Chile and likely will go to Australia, Africa and Asia within the next year or two. Is Bush giving undue attention to foreign policy? No, says Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``I think the dynamics of world events have given no one any choice _ not the president, the Congress nor the media,'' Fascell said in an interview. ``After all, when Nicaraguans went to bed on Sunday, it was under a Marxist regime. They woke up in a democracy. And that's remarkable,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: US Credits Soviets With Encouraging Democracy in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, with strong backing from the United States, played an effective behind-the-scenes role in encouraging Nicaragua's leftist government to hold an honest election last Sunday, a senior official says. The official listed the Soviet role among a number of key elements which persuaded the Sandinista authorities that free elections were their best hope for obtaining legitimacy and international economic support. The source spoke to reporters Tuesday after President Bush conferred with congressional leaders about his plans for a ``significant and meaningful'' assistance program for Nicaragua in the approaching post-Sandinista era. President-elect Violeta Chamorro takes office April 25. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said aid for Nicaragua probably would run into hundreds of millions of dollars over five years, and he suggested the creation of an ``emerging democracy account'' to help Nicaragua, Panama and the East European countries. The White House said it liked the idea if it meant the administration would have more flexibility in dispensing U.S. foreign aid. At present, Congress earmarks almost all aid for specific countries, leaving the administration with few discretionary funds for unexpected developments. Mrs. Chamorro's chief economic adviser, Francisco Mayorga, arrives in Washington on Monday to discuss U.S. economic cooperation with Nicaragua. For most of the Sandinista rule in Nicaragua, the Soviets were widely portrayed in Washington as intent on establishing a ``communist beachhead'' there for promoting subversion and engaging in other activities hostile to U.S. interests. But a far different picture of Soviet behavior emerged Tuesday from the State Department briefer, who spoke to reporters on condition of anonymity. Much of what he said had been reported previously. But taken together, the Soviet activities in some ways suggested a strong commitment to a peaceful settlement in Central America. As described by the official, the United States invariably raised the Central America issue at high-level meetings with the Soviets throughout 1989. There were ``some anomalies'' to the Soviet behavior, the official said, noting that Moscow sent high-performance helicopters to the Sandinistas last month and has continued to provide large-scale assistance to Cuba. Cuba, in turn, has continued to support the leftist insurgency in El Salvador, the official added. The official recalled that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev informed Bush last May that the Kremlin was no longer providing direct military assistance to the Sandinistas. In August, he said, the Soviets were instrumental in persuading the Sandinistas to make concessions to opposition groups that enabled them to campaign freely for votes in Sunday's election. Last September, the official added, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze committed themselves to support a halt in the use of Central America for subversion, and they called for an end to outside aid to rebel forces. At their most recent meeting two weeks ago, Baker and Shevardnadze stressed the importance of impartial and effective international observation of the electoral process and promised to respect the outcome of the election. ``We believe that the Soviet Union played a constructive role in encouraging the Sandinista government to hold these elections,'' the official said. Hours before the official spoke, a Soviet Foreign Ministry official in Moscow told a news conference that the Kremlin recognizes the results of the Nicaraguan election and is prepared to negotiate with the new leadership about future relations. Ion Burlaia, the deputy chief for Latin America in the Foreign Ministry, said the Soviets would continue to give non-military aid to Nicaragua if the new government wants it, and also was prepared to negotiate future trade and military cooperation.

DOC.HEAD: Changes in Nicaragua, Warsaw Pact Fuel Exiles' Dreams of a Free Cuba
LaserPhoto MH2
DOC.TEXT: In the cafes, meeting rooms and streets of Little Havana, Cuban exiles say the election-booth ouster of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega shows Fidel Castro's fall is finally within reach. Euphoria took hold here as democratic changes began sweeping Eastern Europe. Now that a domino effect has put Panama's Manuel Noriega in jail and appears to have knocked Ortega from power, many exiles say Castro's downfall is inevitable. ``In the streets, the Cubans are saying `Yesterday was Manuel. Today is Daniel. And tomorrow is Fidel.' That is the popular joke,'' said Tomas Garcia Fuste, a commentator at the Spanish-language radio station WQBA. ``Never before have we been so close. ``I have convinced myself that we'll have a chance to go to Cuba within the year.'' The stunning upset by the opposition in Nicaragua shows it is impossible to predict the amount of support a dictator enjoys from his people, said Jorge Mas Canosa, director of the right-wing Cuban American National Foundation. ``Cuban people love democracy and freedom as much as their neighbor,'' Mas Canosa said Tuesday. ``Most Cubans must be asking why not in Cuba? Why not on the island?'' In Miami, business owners are preparing to cash in the untapped consumer demand of 10 million people if the United States renews trade with a democratic Cuba. Some of the city's estimated 700,000 Cuban exiles are delaying vacations and putting off buying houses, hoping their decades-old refrain, ``Next year in Havana,'' might come true. ``It's not only our feeling. Castro is in his countdown,'' said Modesto Castaner, a veteran of the ill-fated Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961. ``The Cuban people are standing by for something to happen.'' The excitement among exiles is growing stronger despite evidence that Castro, 62, remains as strong as ever. Cuba's communist leadership, facing widespread food shortages and possible cuts in the $5 billion in annual aid the country gets from the Soviet Union, rejected multiparty rule at a meeting Feb. 16 while calling for some reforms to ``perfect'' the revolution Castro led 31 years ago. About 5,000 people ready to go to work in a new Cuba have signed on with the group called Cuban Municipalities in Exile in a project begun several weeks ago. The names on the list include builders, doctors, plumbers, teachers and farmers, said Roberto Rodriguez Aragon, the group's president. Mas Canosa's group has arranged for conservative economists Milton Friedman and Arthur Laffer to help prepare a plan to transform Cuba to a free-market economy. Gov. Bob Martinez has appointed a commission to study the impact on Florida of an end to Castro's rule. Even Miami police are preparing _ for a huge party. ``If tomorrow Castro dies, you will see the greatest day in Miami since its foundation. Everything will come to a stop. It will be a tremendous celebration,'' said Castaner. ``Cuba is close to hitting rock bottom,'' said Maria Christina Herrera, head of the Institute for Cuban Studies, which has advocated dialogue with Castro's government. ``It can move no further backward. It can move forward or else.'' Some right-wing Cuban exiles say they'll do whatever they can to make the change come soon. After training for years in isolated military camps in the Everglades, Castaner says his group is just waiting for the right signal. But ``we don't want to create a situation where people think we're going to invade tomorrow,'' Castaner said from the headquarters of Brigade 2506 in Little Havana. ``We're collecting names and phone numbers should anything happen immediately.'' It's unclear how many exiles would return to the island to stay. For a generation of Cuban-Americans, living in Cuba has been just a dream kept alive by older relatives and politicians. Exiles have fostered a thriving culture in Miami, where the Cuban lifestyle is prevalent, speaking English isn't necessary and many government services are available for the asking. ``The emotion will bring them over there, but the reality will bring them back,'' said Horatio Villazon, 71, as he played cards in Maximo Gomez Park, a street corner in Little Havana named for a hero of the Cuban independence movement. ``They are dreaming and playing politics.''

DOC.HEAD: VA Considers Changing Benefits, Including Uniform Death Benefit
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Veterans' Affairs says it is considering several changes in benefits, including a stricter definition of service-connected disability and a uniform death benefit. Other possible changes include an extension of psychiatric disability payments for disturbed veterans while they try to get jobs and a shorter waiting period before people can claim total service-connected disability. VA said Tuesday the possible changes are part of an effort to put more emphasis on less expensive outpatient care and expand eligibility for nursing home care. Undersecretary Anthony Principi, who heads the group studying the changes, said the VA is trying to bring the system up to date with the ``trend in modern medicine to more ambulatory care.'' He said VA wants more emphasis on prevention and more use of alternatives to hospitals, such as hospice care, for the terminally ill. Any proposal to change service-connected disabilities is bound to be controversial. Nearly 2.2 million veterans receive such payments, ranging from $67 to $1,500 and even higher for some of the totally disabled. The total annual cost is close to $9 billion. Currently, any disability that arises during military service is considered to be service-connected, entitling the veteran to compensation payments based on the degree of disability. The possible tightening would rule out disability payments _ but not VA medical care _ for ``disabilities that would have arisen regardless of the individual's vocation.'' Diabetes, for example, would be excluded. So, too, would AIDS if contracted from injecting drugs. The VA released details of the proposal after a veterans' group released details during a congressional hearing on Tuesday. VA said some of the proposals released by the Disabled American Veterans had been abandoned, such as the proposed elimination of cost-of-living allowances for certain disabled veterans and for different disability payments for wartime and peacetime veterans. Any proposed changes would have to be approved by the Office of Management and Budget before being sent to Congress. VA said the proposals being considered would not be retroactive. The only exception would be to increase the death benefit retroactively for survivors of lower-ranked veterans. Benefits range from $539 a month for survivors of privates and corporals to $1,381 for survivors of generals and admirals. The possible change would create a uniform payment of $700 to $750 a month. Those benefits cost about $2.3 billion a year, with the largest share going to the lower ranks. Another possible change would be to shorten a veteran's wait from 20 years to 10 years before being able to receive the permanent disability classification. Principi said that paying psychiatric disability payments for a year while a person tried to hold down a job would pay for itself by encouraging people to get better.

DOC.HEAD: Managua Is Nervous, Angry, and Full of the Voices of Pain
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: On the streets of Sandinista defeat, the red-and-black banners still flutter defiantly from almost every lamppost. The blue-and-white of the victorious United National Opposition is visible only in flashes _ the blue-and-white cap on the driver as a pickup truck goes by; a few posters on a wall that doesn't face the street. Many people believe Nicaragua became a democracy at 6 a.m. Monday, when President Daniel Ortega, tired, eloquent, defiant, said his Sandinista party would obey the will of the voters. But the victors are just beginning to emerge from their shell shock, and the losers are holding their breath. It is two months to April 25, when Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the symbol of resistance to 10{ years of Sandinismo, is sworn in as president. ``I still can't believe that UNO won,'' Maritza Arguello, wife of a coffee grower, said Tuesday. ``I'm just sitting quietly until it actually happens.'' ``They didn't dare celebrate in the streets. They're cockroaches that are staying hidden,'' said Mercado Gonzalez de Lopez, a member of a Sandinista women's group. She and five friends had come from a poor neighborhood to stand in front of the government radio station and demonstrate their support for their beloved Daniel. This Managua of defeat and victory is also a city of pain. Everyone has a story, a story that makes them fearful or cautiously optimistic about the future. The pain of defeat can leap out unexpectedly, even for the sufferer, as it did in a party official who was asked to move his car so that another could be moved in a jammed parking lot. ``You're a foreigner. You're a foreigner. Have a little respect,'' the man suddenly yelled furiously. Karina Quiroz de Marin is one of the happy fearful. ``I'm happy, but the people aren't celebrating because they fear the turbinas,'' she said. The turbinas or turbas, the disturbers, are the violent crowds of young Sandinistas that were used for so long to awe or cow the opposition. There was a time when Ortega called them divine, but now he is working for reconciliation, hugging his opponent, telling his supporters they must defend the achievements of the revolution but respect the vote. Mrs. Marin's story begins with a traffic accident. Her husband-to-be was hit by a car running a red light. The car belonged to a high government official's escort. Her fiance was beaten and suffered broken facial bones, she said. Mrs. Marin saved the bills, including the bills for repairs to the official car, in case there was a day she could present them. ``Not for payment,'' she said. ``Just so people will know.'' What she is now is a black market money-changer; as her pink Polo shirt shows, the profession has been good to her despite the risk of jail. Amanda Pinero, also at the Voice of Nicaragua, said she feared a return of dictator Anastasio Somoza's National Guard. That fear may owe something to Sandinista campaign strategy of linking the guard to U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas and the opposition coalition. The long Contra war caused enough pain on both sides to fill an ocean. It ended in military victory for the Sandinistas at a cost of 60,000 lives in a nation of 3 million. But now, suddenly, it seems to many that the Contras somehow won. ``The guard threw me out of my house,'' said Pinero, a 66-year-old widow. ``It's hard for me to see the guard return, they (the Contras) killed my only son.'' She stops, it's the pain. ``He was the only thing I had.'' For many, the radio stations have been an outlet. While a station that supports UNO broadcasts rousing songs about Violeta and seldom-founded rumors that a Sandinista crowd is gathering, the Sandinista airwaves resound with fury and sorrow. Callers urge Daniel to ignore the vote because it was stolen or bought; they accuse international observers and journalists of ignoring their complaints; they say they will do what the party says and stand by Daniel forever. Former President Jimmy Carter said UNO was concerned about the violent sentiments expressed. ``Although I regret it, maybe that's a good way to let them vent their feelings and let off steam,'' he told a small group of reporters Tuesday. Thousands of Sandinistas vented their steam at an impromptu rally Tuesday outside the Olof Palme Convention Center, when the Sandinista party called its leadership from city, town and country to explain how the party would conduct itself as an opposition _ a powerful opposition, but an opposition nonetheless. Like many government workers at the rally, Angel Madrona said he was thinking about a new job. ``We'll see what the directorate says,'' he said. ``If they want me to work for the UNO government, I will. But I don't want to.'' Madrona, a public relations worker at the Ministry of Foreign Cooperation, which coordinates foreign aid to Nicaragua, said he would probably do the previously unthinkable and move to the private sector. The crowd gathered through the afternoon as word spread that the leadership was meeting. The old chants and cheers echoed until late afternoon, when Ortega finally spoke. Treading carefully between militancy and conciliation, he said the revolution would not end. ``A change of government does not mean the end of the revolution,'' he told the crowd, which cheered and started to march through town. Ortega suggested they go to Carlos Fonseca Plaza, an out-of-the-way location on the lakeshore where Ortega spoke in pre-election triumph only Wednesday to 300,000 people. But minutes later one of Managua's heavy rainstorms broke, and though a small cohort marched on, most of the crowd leaked away in search of shelter from the storm.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Advocates Say They'll Continue to Fight Drug Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Prisoner-rights advocates disappointed by a Supreme Court decision say they'll continue to fight on the state level to assure inmates are not given anti-psychotic drugs indiscriminately. ``The trend is for state courts to give more protection'' to inmates than the Supreme Court, said Brian Reed Phillips, a lawyer for a Washington state prisoner forced to take the drugs. The justices, by a 6-3 vote Tuesday, said prison officials don't need a judge's permission before forcing inmates to take the drugs. Robert D. Fleischner, representing a prisoner-rights coalition in Massachusetts, said some states guarantee a judicial hearing before prisoners can be forced to take the medication. ``Massachusetts requires judicial intervention and the system has worked to protect people's rights,'' he said. ``Requiring the appropriate care has not been overly burdensome.'' Washington State Correction Secretary Chase Riveland said Tuesday's ruling won't lead to a medication binge for disruptive prisoners. ``I'm not suggesting that we should be willy-nilly running around medicating people,'' he said. ``I think that ... if medically appropriate it's very helpful.'' Riveland said the ruling may affect 10 to 15 Washington prisoners. The Supreme Court ruled that prisoners' rights are safeguarded as long as staff psychiatrists say the drugs will help, and not merely pacify, the inmates. ``An inmate's interests are adequately protected and perhaps better served by allowing the decision to medicate to be made by medical professionals rather than a judge,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the court. But the dissenters, led by Justice John Paul Stevens, said the ruling means prison officials seeking to maintain order may force inmates to take dangerous, even life-threatening, drugs with little regard for the prisoners' well-being. In other decisions, the court: _Ruled 5-4 in a Florida case that patients involuntarily committed to state mental hospitals may sue officials in federal court for monetary damages over failure to get legally required hearings. _Ruled unanimously that the Boeing Co. did not violate a federal conflict-of-interest law when it paid $485,000 in severance to five employees who left to take government jobs. The prisoners' rights decision overturned a 1988 Washington state Supreme Court ruling that convicted robber Walter Harper, diagnosed as schizophrenic, must be given a court hearing before he is given anti-psychotic drugs. The case pitted the American Psychiatric Association, which supported the prison officials, against the American Psychological Association. Clifford Stromberg, a lawyer for the psychologists group, said the court ``unfortunately seems to have underestimated the danger of these drugs, particularly when no objective decision-maker decides when they're going to be used.'' Harper, paroled on condition he take the drugs, was returned to prison after he attacked two nurses at a Seattle hospital. Back in prison, he refused in 1982 to take the medication, saying it was poisoning his brain and causing other side effects. He sued when prison officials forced him to take the drugs. The officials said the drugs were for his own good and needed to control his violent behavior. The state Supreme Court, calling the drugs as intrusive as electro-shock therapy, ruled that an inmate who has not been found mentally incompetent has a right to determine what should be done to his body. While the drugs are beneficial to seriously ill patients, they also can have serious side effects ranging from involuntary spasms to permanent brain damage. Prisoner-rights advocates say physical restraints or isolation are preferable methods to control unruly inmates. But public health and law enforcement officials say it makes little sense to give an irrational or mentally disturbed person the right to veto sensible medical practices. Courts in several states have ruled that mental patients who are legally competent have a right to refuse anti-psychotic drugs. But, according to some studies, judges in those states almost always decide that anti-psychotic drugs may be administered against the individual's will after holding hearings in individual cases.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 34,591.99, up 694.04 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Flexibility Is Administration Watchword
DOC.TEXT: A report by the Agriculture Department says the 1990 wheat program included a great deal of flexibility, the latest farm policy watchword in the Bush administration. The Economic Research Service report also noted that winter wheat farmers accept the idea too well. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced in September that farmers participating in the 1990 wheat program could plant up to 105 percent of their wheat base. The goal was to produce more wheat this year. But for every acre planted in excess of 95 percent of the base, the acreage used to compute ``deficiency'' payments would be reduced by one acre. Despite the leeway, farmers boosted winter wheat plantings last fall by only 3 percent from a year earlier. In Kansas, the major producer, there was no increase. ``Farmers may have been reluctant to lose deficiency payments or acreage in fallow rotation, or their plantable area may have been constrained by the amount of wheat base they had idled under the Conservation Reserve Program,'' the report said. ``Much of the CRP land in Kansas is wheat base.'' The report, included in the March issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, said dry soil conditions may have held down plantings in some areas. Also, farmers may have learned about the 1990 program changes too late to alter their plans. ``In any case, the relatively small wheat response to the 105 percent offer should not be taken as an indication that farmers would not respond to more if the administration's new proposal were adopted,'' the report said. ``The 105 percent provision is just a small part of the new flexibility.'' For example, it said, corn farmers in Indiana this year could not plant wheat on corn base and still collect deficiency payments. They could under the new flexibility proposal. A farmer with 100 acres of corn base, 100 acres of wheat base and 100 acres of a new oilseed base would set aside 20 acres of wheat and corn land if there was a 10 percent ``acreage reduction program'' requirement, or ARP. ``One the remaining 280 acres, the farmer could grow any program or oilseed crop and still collect deficiency payments as if the permitted base acres had been planted to wheat and corn,'' the report said. ``And base history, which is used to calculate future eligibility for benefits, would be unaffected.'' Further, any conserving-use crop such as clover or alfalfa could be grown on program cropland without loss of deficiency payments _ so long as it was not harvested. Also, farmers could grow certain non-program alternative crops on base acres but would give up deficiency payments for those acres. ``Producers would be able to grow and harvest the program crop, conserving crops and industrial crops on the ARP acreage as well, but would forgo deficiency payments on an acre-for-acre basis,'' the report said. The article, written by economists Greg Gajewski and Ed Allen, said some farmers ``could face more challenges'' if the administration's proposals are accepted by Congress. ``For example, some soybean farmers who lacked wheat, feed grain, rice or cotton base might experience stiffer competition as more producers switched to soybeans in years when soybean prospects appeared especially bright,'' the report said. ``The competition would result because there is no target price and deficiency mechanism for soybeans, and none is being proposed.'' However, it added, some traditional soybean growers might switch to other crops in relatively tight supply ``and expect a reasonable return from them.''

A government report says widespread snow and rain over large areas of the Great Plains have brightened the outlook for wheat farmers. ``Moisture improved winter wheat growth in the central and southern Great Plains'' during the week of Feb. 19-25, the Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. ``The northern Great Plains remained dry.'' The facility is operated by the departments of Agriculture and Commerce. Weekly reports cover weather and crop conditions but do not include production forecasts. Looking at other crops, the report said rain again slowed field work in the Delta and Southeast. Corn planting began in southwest Georgia and continued in Florida and Texas. Rain fell in all of Florida's citrus areas, and new growth was reported ``abundant and trees were blooming in all areas.'' ``Cold temperatures may have damaged peaches in northern Georgia and portions of Tennessee,'' the report said. ``Peaches were blooming in Texas (and) cold temperatures may have damaged peaches in the Cross Timbers area.'' In California, early varieties of apricots, plums, nectarines and peaches were blooming, but frost damage was reported to early peaches and table grapes in Riverside County.

The value of U.S. agricultural exports is forecast at $38.5 billion this year, up $500 million from prospects last fall, according to an analysis by the Agriculture Department. But the new forecast for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 still represents a 3 percent decline from an eight-year high of $39.7 billion in 1989. The record was $43.8 billion in 1981. ``The upward revision (from November) largely reflected a 3 million ton increase in expected U.S. coarse grain exports,'' the report said Tuesday. ``Prospects for foreign coarse grain imports have increased, and U.S. corn is expected to capture a larger share.'' Overall, fiscal 1990 exports are forecast at 148.5 million metric tons, up 3 million tons from November and nearly 2 million tons more then in 1989. The decline in value was blamed on ``lower prices for grains and oilseeds,'' which more than offset the larger export volume. Estimates of agricultural imports were raised $500 million to $21.5 billion, matching last year's record. ``December's severe freeze in Florida and Texas has increased prospects for fruit, juice and vegetable imports,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A judge who wants to hold a jail house party is sure the well-heeled will pay $100 each for the chance to slumber in the slammer. ``For one night, we could be operating the largest hotel in the city,'' said Tarrant County Judge Roy English, who proposed a sleep-over party in the 1,400-bed jail at a session Monday of the county Commissioners Court. The party would show off the new jail, built to ease overcrowding, and raise money for a worthy cause _ either a memorial to slain Tarrant County police officers, or a charity such one that helps the homeless, English said. A jail party in Flint, Mich., in which lavishly dressed guests toasted with champagne and danced in the cells, was lampooned in last year's film ``Roger and Me.'' English said he hasn't seen the movie but has heard of jail parties elsewhere. Sheriff Don Carpenter said he has seen too many jail interiors to pay to get into one, but he likes the idea of showing off the building. ``Everyone wants to know what a jail looks like,'' he said.

Weird temperature shifts are cracking open the streets of this former Pony Express station, and the driving is reminiscent of rough rider days. ``It's the pits. You just literally bounce down the street,'' said Shirel Ames, deli manager at a 7-Eleven. ``We haven't had any killer potholes where we've had to roadblock anything, but it is worse than usual because of the moisture out there and the constant freezing and thawing,'' John Loete, Reno's maintenance engineer, said Tuesday. ``The 40-degree temperature swings we get each day make the situation worse.'' The worst street blemishes were revealed with the melting of 22 inches of snow that fell in a Feb. 16-17 storm, the heaviest snowfall since 1916. The asphalt has been loosened and cracked from freezing and thawing that cause expansion and contraction, said Bob Mays, county road superintendent. Loete said his crews were regularly coming across potholes a foot wide and a few inches deep. ``I'm sure we'll see some more because right now there's still a lot of ice out there covering problems up,'' Loete said.

Researchers will show the Marx Brothers, The Three Stooges, W.C. Fields and ``I Love Lucy'' to ailing nursing home residents to test the theory that tickling the funny bone can be therapeutic. Researchers will show about 150 nursing home residents comic films and TV programs to see if humor can reduce requests for non-prescription pain medicine, Fran McGuire, a Clemson University researcher, said this week. ``If this kind of thing is true, it would be a tremendous tool for activity directors'' in nursing homes and other group settings, said McGuire. A smaller study by Clemson two years ago indicated what appeared to be dramatic decreases in requests for drugs, he said. That could have been the result of chemical changes in the body or the result of reduced stress. That study found that later comedies didn't do the trick, said Rosangela Boyd, who showed the films at a nursing home as part of the earlier study. ``They did not find modern comedies, such as `Three Men and a Baby,' to be funny nor did they like any of the films with offensive language,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Denies Contacts With Iran on Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The White House is doing everything possible to win freedom for the eight American hostages in Lebanon, but a spokesman says there's no evidence to suggest their release will come soon. ``We are ... pursuing every lead, pursuing every contact, talking to everybody we can,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday.
