However, Fitzwater denied a report that the United States and Iran had held secret talks on the hostages in Geneva. ``There are no direct talks between Iran and the United States authorized by the president,'' he said in response to a report in the London-based Lebanese newspaper, Al Hayat. ``We have no information on any special missions to Geneva of the kind that's reported here. ``There are a lot of people around the world talking about release of the hostages in Lebanon,'' involving Americans and people from other countries ``at all levels,'' he said. ``I will never rule out meetings anywhere, anyplace, any time by anybody on the hostage question, because there are meetings happening. But high level U.S. officials? Direct secret talks? No. ``Do I expect a breakthrough or anything new happening? No,'' Fitzwater said. Al-Hayat reported that Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, a key Lebanese Shiite Moslem cleric, said contacts occurred between Iran and the United States through third parties. Fadlallah is the spiritual leader of the Iran-aligned Hezbollah group. Some Western hostages are believed held by factions linked to Hezbollah. Fitzwater said recent comments by Iranian President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and Fadlallah, as well as Peggy Say's meeting with Palestinian Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat ``have created a lot of new speculation and hope about the hostages.'' But, he said, ``we know of no new evidence to support that hope.'' Mrs. Say is the sister of Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press and the longest held hostage. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Arafat told Mrs. Say he was trying to win release of the Americans and 10 other foreign hostages, but that he had no direct influence on the kidnappers. Last month, a Kuwaiti newspaper said ``an American personality'' had met in Geneva with a representative of Rafsanjani to discuss the hostages. None of the parties was identified. The other American hostages are Thomas Sutherland, Frank Herbert Reed, Joseph James Cicippio, Edward Austin Tracy, Jesse Turner, Alann Steen and Robert Polhill.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Judges Bow Out of Bomb-Related Case
DOC.TEXT: The judges of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals removed themselves Tuesday from the case of a man being investigated in a series of mail bombings that killed one of their colleagues. Walter Leroy Moody Jr. filed a motion last week contending the judges could not be impartial on matters related to his case because of the mail bomb that killed 11th Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance at his Mountain Brook, Ala., home. ``The active and senior judges of this court, acting on their own initiative, hereby recuse themselves from participating in this case and in any other case relating to the investigation of the murder of the honorable Robert S. Vance, in which Walter Leroy Moody Jr. is a party,'' said Tuesday's order, signed by Chief Judge Gerald Tjoflat. The order did not address Moody's request to disqualify all federal district judges in Florida, Georgia and Alabama, some of whom serve temporarily on the appeals bench. Moody, of Rex, Ga., is one of three men whose property has been searched during the federal investigation of the spate of bombings late last year. Vance and Robert Robinson, a Savannah attorney and alderman, were killed by bombs, and bombs were intercepted at the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta and in Jacksonville, Fla. No one has been charged in the case. The 11th Circuit has before it an appeal of U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman's order last week sealing all proceedings in the investigation of Moody until further court order or an indictment. The order, requested by Moody, was appealed by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and WSB-TV. Moody also has asked the courts to order the return of items confiscated by investigators from his home, storage area and vehicles, and has filed court papers accusing the Atlanta newspapers of violating Freeman's order by publishing a story about his motion to disqualify the judges.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board: Airliner Brakes Less Safe With Wear
DOC.TEXT: Airliner brakes can't handle high-energy aborted takeoffs as they wear thin, even though they meet federal certification standards, the National Transportation Safety Board says. Blaming ``inadequate certification'' by the Federal Aviation Administration for the May 21 aborted takeoff of an American Airlines DC-10 at Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, the safety board called Tuesday for airlines to re-evaluate the capacity of their brakes when they begin to wear out. Board member Jim Burnett said the problem could be costly for the aviation industry because, without new brake designs, it might involve reducing the capacity of airliners, the distance they could fly or the length of runways. The American jetliner skidded more than 1,000 feet off the end of the runway, injuring eight of its 254 occupants. The plane was too severely damaged to repair. It was the first time the board had cited FAA certification of an airliner model as the probable cause in a crash, Burnett said. ``We have already lost an airliner and we face the real possibility of losing a planeful of people,'' he said after the four-member panel approved a series of recommendations to the FAA and airlines for testing the capacity of brakes when they are worn. The board raised doubts about FAA certification and test procedures for all airliner brakes, which it said may fail when planes abort takeoffs at high speed. The Dallas plane, scheduled to fly to Frankfurt, West Germany, reached 178 miles per hour before the pilot reversed engine thrust and applied the brakes. The brakes failed before the plane reached the end of the runway. The NTSB also blamed the brake manufacturer, Loral, in the aborted takeoff. Board members said brakes near their wear limit don't have the same margin of safety as new ones, and the FAA didn't consider that when it certified the brakes on the DC-10 two decades ago. Airlines have about 3,000 rejected takeoffs each year, but most are executed at a low enough speed that braking power, combined with reverse engine thrust, is adequate to stop the plane without damage. But an average of about four high-powered rejections result in accidents each year, board members said. Investigators testified that only the newest brakes are adequate to safely stop an airliner that has to abort a takeoff near ``V-1,'' the velocity at which the plane ordinarily must continue its take off. The American plane was near that speed when a warning light and audible signal indicated a wing-slat problem. The signal proved to be false, but the board did not fault the pilot for aborting the takeoff. In a separate action, the board recommended that the DC-10's warning system on wing slat deployment be redesigned so it won't go off so late in the takeoff. Investigators said planes are easily able to fly even when slats are in the worst position, while a high-powered aborted takeoff can be dangerous.

DOC.HEAD: Fancy Legal Footwork Accompanies Government Move To Quash Enrile
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The arrest of opposition Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile on charges of supporting the bloody December coup attempt was aimed at projecting an image of toughness in a government long criticized as weak. But fancy legal footwork raises doubt about government motives. Enrile, a former defense minister and one of President Corazon Aquino's most outspoken critics, was arrested Tuesday after he and six others were indicted for allegedly supporting the Dec. 1-9 failed coup, in which at least 113 people were killed and more than 600 wounded. The 66-year-old senator was the most prominent figure arrested in any of the six armed attempts to oust Mrs. Aquino since she took power in the February 1986 ``people power'' uprising against Ferdinand Marcos. After previous coup attempts, the government was criticized for weakness because of lenient treatment of mutineers. Although dozens of officers have been convicted in coup attempts, most enlisted participants are simply reassigned to different units. In a radio interview today, presidential Press Secretary Tomas Gomez acknowledged that the government felt under pressure to take decisive action in order to restore confidence among foreign investors. ``Our friends abroad are beginning to shy away,'' Gomez said. ``They are scared because they (mutineers) have created a perception of instability, that this government has very weak knees.'' In moving against Enrile, the government stretched existing statutes to charge him with as serious an offense as possible. Enrile was charged with ``rebellion with murder.'' Under the charge, which carries a life sentence, no bail is allowed. According to documents released so far, the government's case is based on statements by witnesses who claimed they saw Enrile with mutineers the first two days of the coup attempt. Prosecutors claim that proves Enrile supported the mutiny. Legal sources not involved in the case say Enrile should have been charged only with ``rebellion,'' a lesser offense that carries six to 12 years imprisonment and allows bail. The sources cite a 1956 Supreme Court decision that ruled offenses such as murder committed in connection with an uprising should be lumped together as rebellion. Gomez said the government would ask the court to reconsider that decision and approve charges of rebellion with murder in the Enrile case. He said the Department of Justice has begun ``a legal crusade ... to request the Supreme Court that it is now time to review the existing jurisprudence,'' he said. ``Remember that there are forces led by Mr. Enrile who would like to destroy the democracy of ours.'' During martial law, Marcos overturned the 1956 court decision and authorized lumping rebellion and murder. But Mrs. Aquino canceled Marcos' decree in June 1987 as ``repressive.'' The government's handling of the filing of charges showed the political sensitivity of the case. Justice officials leaked word of the charges on Monday, then announced they would be filed in a regional court in suburban Makati. Enrile's lawyers and reporters rushed there early Tuesday, but government prosecutors said they were waiting ``for some documents'' before filing the complaint. But the only charge filed against Enrile in Makati was harboring a fugitive, a relatively minor offense. The more serious rebellion with murder charge was filed quietly in another court in what government sources said was a calculated ruse to throw Enrile's lawyers off guard. The moves have created the impression among some Filipinos that the government is interested primarily in nailing Enrile. Gomez denied there was any vendetta but added: ``How can one be vindictive to a person who is also perceived to be a criminal.'' Enrile is among the most controversial figures here because of his long involvement with the most odious aspects of the Marcos government. As Marcos' defense minister, Enrile ordered the arrest of thousands, including Mrs. Aquino's late husband, Benigno Jr., during the eight years of martial law. Later, Enrile broke with Marcos and led the February 1986 military mutiny that triggered the ``people power'' uprising. Mrs. Aquino retained him as defense minister but fired him nine months later after a failed coup by his followers. Since then, neither Mrs. Aquino nor Enrile have made any secret of their mutual loathing. Enrile has accused Mrs. Aquino of corruption and incompetence. Last week, he publicly ``apologized'' for helping install her in power. On Sunday, during a speech marking her fourth year in office, Mrs. Aquino repeatedly accused Enrile of seeking to restore dictatorship, adding: ``Mr. Enrile, have you no shame?'' ``Blame it on the timing, but people are bound to doubt if the rebellion charges with murder filed yesterday against (Enrile) indeed show the `effective operation of our criminal justice system' or is simply political vengeance at its worst,'' the independent daily Malaya said.

DOC.HEAD: Angolans Meeting With U.S. Officials
DOC.TEXT: Two high-ranking Angolans are meeting with U.S. officials this week amid conflicting reports about the military situation in the African country. Minister of Justice Fernando Van Dunem and Gen. Roberto Monteiro-Ngongo, deputy chief of staff of the Angolan military said they had tried to explain why their government launched a military offensive earlier this year. Peace prospects have deteriorated recently because of the intense fighting between the Soviet-backed government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and the U.S.-backed UNITA rebels of Jonas Savimbi. ``Everybody is tired of war,'' Van Dunem said in an interview Tuesday. ``We have never had a single day of peace.'' The State Department and Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Bob Dole, R-Kan., have criticized the dos Santos government for its military activities. ``Little attention has been paid in recent months to what may become a large-scale slaughter,'' DeConcini said earlier this month, condemning the dos Santos government's military offensive in southern Africa. Jardo Muekalia, Savimbi's representative in Washington, accused the Angolan government of derailing the peace process with its military activity. Under a 1989 agreement, Zairian President Seko Sese Mobutu was supposed to mediate between the two sides to form a national reconciliation. The Angolan officials met with Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen and members of Congress to clarify the dos Santos government's position. Any military action is simply retaliation for Savimbi, they said. ``The government had to react ... show our ability to keep law and order,'' van Dunem said. Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Africa subcommittee, said he met with the Angolans but did not have a clear picture of what was happening in Angola. ``My sense is that there has been more military activity,'' he said. ``Our interest is to get people back to the negotiating table.'' Recent fighting has centered around Mavinga, 700 miles southeast of the capital of Luanda. An airstrip at Mavinga and a nearby rebel base block the government forces way to rebel headquarters at Jamba, more than 120 miles farther south. Van Dunem and Monteiro-Ngongo said the government controlled Mavinga where mopping up operations were under way. They also said the government had bombed Jamba on Saturday. A State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said fighting continues around Mavinga, but it's ``not clear if either controls the entire Mavinga.'' The official could not confirm that Jamba had been bombed. Muekalia denied that Jamba had been bombed, but said the government had conducted ``carpet bombings'' in the country against UNITA.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury in Stuart Shooting Reportedly Hears 10-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury has a new twist in the Stuart shooting case: A 10-year-old boy testified he heard a shot and saw a tall, black man fleeing from the Stuarts' car the night of the shooting, news reports said. The Boston Herald and WBZ-TV quoted unidentified sources as saying the boy, along with a teacher and a teacher's aide from a special-education primary school the boy attended, testified before the Suffolk County grand jury Monday. The unidentified boy lives on the street in the Mission Hill district where Charles and Carol Stuart were found wounded in their car Oct. 23. Stuart called police on his car phone and directed them to where he and his wife had been shot. Stuart said he and his pregnant wife were shot by a black man who got in their car and robbed them after they left a hospital birthing class. Mrs. Stuart died hours after she was shot. Her child, delivered prematurely, died 17 days later. A black man, William Bennett, reportedly was considered the leading suspect in the shootings until Stuart was implicated by his brother Matthew on Jan. 3. The next day, Charles Stuart apparently jumped to his death from a bridge. District Attorney Newman Flanagan then said Bennett, who had been arrested on an unrelated charge, no longer was considered a suspect. The police manhunt for a black man and the subsequent revelation that Stuart may have been the real culprit prompted outrage in Mission Hill and charges of racism from civil rights leaders. The 10-year-old apparently told his teachers what he had heard and seen shortly after the shootings, but prosecutors were not told until recently, the Herald said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Stocks Rebound in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar retreated Wednesday, as the key indicator on the Tokyo Stock Market soared. The dollar ended the day's trading at 148.52 yen, down 0.51 yen from Tuesday's close of 149.03 yen. It opened at 148.64 yen and ranged from 148.33-148.89 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, the stock market's leading indicator, gained 694.04 points, or 2.0 percent, to close the day at 34,591.99. Volume was relatively heavy as an estimated 700 million shares changed hands. The Nikkei rose 576.08 points on Tuesday, one day after Monday's plunge of 1,569.10 points, or 4.5 percent. The dollar closed morning trading at 148.55 yen, down from 148.64 at the opening and off from Tuesday's close of 149.03 yen. It ranged from 148.35-148.89 yen. Some brokers saw the stock rally as an indication that the market had found its floor after a series of dizzying falls that had knocked 14 percent off the market's value this year as of Monday. ``The market is in the process of recovery,'' said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. But not everyone was convinced. Economist Adrian Tschoegl of SBCI Securities Asia said he calculates the market should fall another 10 percent to reach a path of sustainable growth, in line with its historical trend. ``But there's no way to know if the market will drop 10 percent tomorrow or go sideways for six months,'' he said. Foreign exchange dealers said the stock market's strong performance drove up the yen against the dollar. A dealer at Fuji Bank said the stock upturn dampened some of the bullishness for the dollar. The Bank of Japan was rumored to have intervened several times in support of the yen during the morning. The central bank does not comment on its monetary actions. Some dealers said they believed the bank was taking new measures to disguise its actions. On Tuesday, the central bank is believed to have spent $2 billion in a futile attempt to raise the value of the Japanese currency against the dollar. Prices of Japanese government bonds, which the Finance Ministry has been attempting to bolster recently, weakened slightly in the morning. That boosted the yield on the benchmark 10-year bond to 6.94 percent from 6.91 percent at Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says Serious Criminal Fraud More Likely at Failed S&L
DOC.TEXT: Serious criminal fraud is three times as likely to occur at a failed savings and loan than at an insolvent commercial bank, according to a top regulator. Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman, who also serves as head of a new S&L bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., said about 60 percent of the thrifts seized by the government over the past year have been ``victimized by serious criminal activity.'' In commercial banks, criminal fraud is present in 17 percent to 20 percent of failures, he told the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee Tuesday. ``If you can think of a kind of fraud, we'll be able to show you (an example) in the S&Ls,'' he said. However, a Justice Department official warned the panel not to expect speedy recovery of taxpayers' losses on thrifts even though the administration is spending $49 million this year on 202 FBI agents and 30 trial lawyers to go after embezzlers. ``The investigation and prosecution of major financial institution fraud typically will require ... many months or years,'' said Mark M. Richard, deputy assistant attorney general. Moreover, much of the money is gone. The value of assets involved in the fraud often has plummeted and ``the defendant may have squandered his or her own assets, leaving little or nothing to recover,'' he said. To speed the process, Richard said the Justice Department intends in some cases to seek civil fraud penalties, which require less proof than a criminal conviction. Meanwhile, Seidman defended his agency from criticism that it's not moving fast enough. The panel chairman, Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, called the RTC's progress ``damnably slow and hesitant.'' Although the government over the past year has taken control of 382 insolvent thrifts with $192 billion in assets, it has been less successful in returning the institutions to new private owners. So far, it's sold only 49 thrifts and in most cases has had to keep most of the assets. But Seidman said the RTC has had little-recognized success in selling assets from thrifts before they are sold or liquidated. All told in 1989, the agency sold assets or collected bad loans totaling about $25 billion, he said. Separately, another bailout official announced a change in policy aimed at speeding the sale of bankrupt institutions. William Taylor, acting chief staff officer of the RTC Oversight Board, said Tuesday that thrift buyers in many cases now will get up to a year to return loans, real estate and other assets to the government. The previous limit of six months may have discouraged bids from some potential buyers, who maintained they needed more time to evaluate large, complex asset portfolios, he told the National Council of Savings Institutions. The oversight board is the Treasury Department-led panel controlling the policy and funding of Seidman's agency. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., introduced legislation Tuesday to abolish the oversight board, calling it ``a shackle around the neck of those trying to solve the S&L crisis.'' In another development, a senior official of the Office of Thrift Supervision resigned Tuesday. Karl T. Hoyle, the senior deputy director in charge of congressional and media relations, left to form his own lobbying company. He is the second top thrift office official to leave in less than a week and his departure leaves three of the agency's top eight spots vacant. Last Friday, Jordan Luke, chief counsel of the agency, said he was entering private law practice. Thrift office director M. Danny Wall, under fire from Congress, resigned Dec. 4 but continues to serve. The Treasury Department has been unable to find a replacement.

DOC.HEAD: Government Endorses Effort to Reduce Fat, Cholesterol
DOC.TEXT: A government-endorsed report recommends an ambitious effort by food companies, physicians and individuals to improve health by reducing fat and cholesterol in the national diet. The result, says the expert panel that produced the report, would be a 20 percent reduction in coronary heart disease. ``The American public should have a greater range of low-saturated fatty acid, low-fat and low-cholesterol food options available, and they should have the information to establish heart-healthy eating patterns,'' said James Cleeman, coordinator of the National Cholesterol Education Program. The NCEP report, endorsed by government agencies and 26 health and professional groups, includes recommendations ranging from nutrient consumption to standardized food labeling to educational programs. Heart disease is the nation's No. 1 killer disease, claiming the lives of about 500,000 Americans each year. It is associated with high levels of cholesterol in the blood, which clogs arteries. The panel recommended a two-pronged approach, the first of which seeks to identify and treat people at high risk of heart disease with dietary therapy and possibly medication. Those people generally have blood cholesterol levels of more than 240 milligrams per deciliter. But more than 60 percent of the disabilities and premature deaths associated with heart disease occur in millions of Americans whose cholesterol levels are below that level, the report said. These people, as well as all Americans over age 2, would benefit from the second part of the strategy, aimed at lowering cholesterol levels by promoting healthful food choices and making food lower in saturated fat and cholesterol more widely available. Of greatest importance in the diet, the report said, is saturated fat from animal and vegetable sources. Saturated fats are more important to overall blood cholesterol levels than the amount of cholesterol consumed. Claims that foods with no cholesterol are healthier are misleading because the food may contain high amounts of saturated fat, said Dr. Richard Carleton, head of the Population Panel of the National Cholesterol Education Program. He said no food is a ``magic bullet'' for lowering cholesterol, and that eliminating a single food, such as egg yolks, which have a high cholesterol content, is also not a solution. The report calls on the food industry to ``promote, label and distribute good-tasting, safe foods'' lower in fat and cholesterol and high in complex carbohydrates, including soluble fiber. It says the government should expand and standardize food labeling requirements so consumers can have more information. The Food and Drug Administration is drafting new food-labeling regulations and legislation is pending in Congress. Other recommendations call on health professionals to advocate healthier diets, for educational programs and continued nutrition research. If the recommendations are heeded, ``large numbers of Americans will be at lower risk of coronary heart disease,'' Carleton said. On nutrients, the panel recommends the same intake averages as recommended by the American Heart Association and the National Research Council. They include less than 10 percent of total calories from saturated fat, an average of 30 percent of total calories or less from all fat, and less than 300 milligrams of cholesterol per day. The report was endorsed by the NCEP Coordinating Committee, which includes the Department of Health and Human Services, the Department of Agriculture and other government agencies, as well as professional groups such as the American Medical Association, the American Heart Association and the American Public Health Association.

DOC.HEAD: Judge May Sentence Dead Man to Let Lawyer Collect Bail Money
DOC.TEXT: A judge may sentence a dead man to prison this week _ not out of any sense of moral outrage, but as a way of enabling the defendant's lawyer to recover the $30,000 bail he put up for his client. Before Santiago Alfred Gallegos was killed while awaiting resentencing for sexually abusing a child, Morris Collins put up the money with the promise of producing his client in court. Gallegos, of course, never showed. So the game plan now appears to be to have a judge sentence Gallegos on Friday, have defense attorneys ask for a new trial on the grounds that their client was not present for sentencing, and then have the prosecutor dismiss the charge. ``It's one of those queer deals where there is no provision in the books for this,'' said District Judge Phil Chavarria Jr. He said, however, he is not convinced the law allows him to send a dead man to prison. Gallegos was convicted in 1986 and sentenced to eight years in prison. The sentence was overturned on a technicality but the conviction was upheld on appeal. In December, Gallegos, 54, was found beaten to death in his home. Assistant District Attorney Ed Shaughnessy said the judge cannot just dismiss the charge because the appellate courts have upheld the conviction. On the other hand, said Harry Nass, Gallegos' current attorney, Collins shouldn't be out $30,000. ``I think you'll find Mr. Gallegos was hit over the head with blunt object. I think it is a logical presumption that he's not voluntarily absent,'' Nass said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Analysts Say Bush's Tax Proposals Fall Short
DOC.TEXT: A collection of tax changes that President Bush says would increase collections by $13.9 billion next year will, in fact, net only $9.4 billion, congressional analysts say. The projections by the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, if accurate, would mean that Bush would fall $4.5 billion short of his claim that his 1991 budget cuts next year's federal deficit by $37.5 billion. Elsewhere, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, the House's top tax writer, said Tuesday he believes Congress won't be able to boost next year's tax collections by the $13.9 billion Bush wants. The CBO projections obtained by The Associated Press showed that Bush's 40 tax proposals would reap $13 billion in additional receipts between 1991 and 1993. Bush's fiscal 1991 budget, released last month, estimated that his proposed levy changes would bring $29.4 billion into government coffers during that three-year period. In addition, CBO estimated that Bush's proposed changes would actually cost the government $400 million in 1993 because he has proposed creating so-called family savings accounts that would offer tax breaks, and offering a series of tax advantages to companies that conduct research. There were two chief differences between Bush's estimates and the CBO's projections for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Bush claimed he would save $2.5 billion next year by making unspecified improvements in the Internal Revenue Service's efficiency. CBO said no savings would result. Second, Bush projected new collections of $4.9 billion next year by cutting the tax rate on capital gains, a move he argues would stimulate sales real estate and other property. Capital gains are profits on the sales of those holdings. CBO estimated that the reduction would reap the government $3.2 billion next year. In addition, the congressional analysts said the rate cut would lose from $3.1 billion to $4.3 billion for each of the next four years. The Bush administration has argued that the cut would bring in money to the Treasury each year. The Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law requires the use of White House estimates of revenues and spending in determining the federal deficit. CBO's figures are respected by many lawmakers for their objectivity and accuracy, and are used as a benchmark to judge the administration's numbers. Meanwhile, Rostenkowski's pessimism about the ability of lawmakers to raise $13.9 billion in taxes makes it seem even less likely that Bush and Congress will have an easy time of agreeing to a budget for next year. The Illinois Democrat said that if his committee is told to find $14 billion in new taxes, ``we're just not that good a magician, unless we become very serious about reaching out for revenues that are certainly going to be ducks.'' The word ``ducks'' was a reference to Budget Director Richard Darman's statement last year that Bush's pledge of no new taxes applies to any levies the public would perceive as taxes. He used the expression that if something walks and talks like a duck, it's a duck. Bush has repeatedly promised to veto increases in such taxes. Congress' Democratic leaders have said they will propose no tax increases that will provoke a veto and leave their party as the sole advocate of higher taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin: Bush Must Face Consequences for Choosing Weapons Over People
DOC.TEXT: President Bush must face the likely consequences of massive military layoffs because he favored weapons over people, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee says. ``Putting weapons before people was their decision and now they're stuck with it,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said Tuesday in response to Pentagon outrage over congressional refusal to consider a shift in defense funds. The Defense Department requested the authority to move $852 million from other accounts to personnel to avoid the dismissal of tens of thousands of men and women by October. The cuts are required under the Gramm-Rudman budget cutting law. But Aspin, with the backing of House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., declined to bring the request up before his committee, informing the service chiefs and his committee colleagues in separate letters dated Monday. Such reprogrammings of funds must be approved by each of the House and Senate Armed Services Committees and the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. ``If we don't stand firm now, this administration will have us playing `chicken' with the budget every year, distorting the deficit reduction process and relying on us to save it from its more irresponsible excesses,'' Aspin said in a memorandum to his committee members. Bush had the option of exempting military personnel from the Gramm-Rudman law. Aspin said his committee is rejecting the budget ``shell game'' that Bush and White House budget chief Richard Darman are playing with the military personnel account. But Pentagon officials lashed out at the congressional inaction, charging that it will have ``an absolutely devastating effect'' on military personnel. The Pentagon estimates that without the reprogramming authority, 44,100 to 68,200 military personnel would have to be fired by Oct. 1; between 32,500 and 32,600 people would be frozen in their current jobs; 57,000 to 67,000 promotions would be delayed; and 59,900 to 115,900 fewer men and women could be brought into the armed forces. There are about 2.1 million men and women in uniform. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams argued that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was directed by Congress in the fiscal 1990 defense spending bill to request approval of the transfer. Williams quoted the bill as saying the request should be made ``to prevent a return to the 1970's phenomenon of the `hollow' Army in which many units were substantially undermanned.'' Williams said the Pentagon has been preparing ``dramatic decreases'' in force size to be executed judiciously over a period of years. ``You don't simply reach in and yank out a certain number of people in the force,'' he said. Christopher Jehn, assistant secretary of defense for force management and personnel, told the House Armed Services subcommittee on military personnel and compensation that failure of Congress to agree to shift funds would be a disaster. The director of the Congressional Budget Office, called before the subcommittee to testify about reshaping the military, said the Defense Department should be able to handle a quick reduction in forces. ``It's do-able but extremely difficult,'' said Robert D. Reischauer. The hearing focused on five alternative plans to restructure U.S. military forces in light of the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe and the possibility of a U.S.-Soviet agreement to reduce strategic arms and conventional forces. The CBO alternatives would reduce the annual defense budget by between $9 billion and $80 billion with cuts in active duty manpower ranging from about 100,000 to almost 600,000.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Wants to Revive Public Campaign Financing
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democratic Whip Alan Cranston, citing his own tarnished image from the ``Keating Five'' scandal, is encouraging his colleagues to revive public financing as a campaign reform issue. ``So long as our elected representatives must depend on private contributions to be viable candidates, our political system will be suspect,'' the California lawmaker told the Senate Rules Committee. The panel, in a damage-control effort by both parties to the growing public perception that Congress can be bought, is scheduled to begin writing a campaign reform bill next week. Cranston's colleagues were courteous Tuesday, but his proposal for using payroll tax-withholding system to collect $1-a-month voluntary contributions as an alternative to private campaign financing is expected to get scant attention. Sen. Wendell Ford, the panel chairman, said he expected few, if any, changes to a bill that would set ``voluntary'' spending ceilings using discount mail and television rates rather than public campaign dollars as an incentive for compliance. Cranston's name was linked last fall with influence-peddling on behalf of savings and loan operator Charles H. Keating Jr. Ford, a Kentucky Democrat, said then that he would run against Cranston for the whip's post after November's election. However, the race for the No. 2 party post in the Senate never came up in Tuesday's hearing. Instead, Ford and fellow Kentuckian Mitch McConnell, a leading Senate Republican on the campaign reform issue, patiently listened as Cranston critiqued the present system's reliance on wealthy contributors and political action committees. ``No matter how ethical we are, no matter how carefully we evaluate our activities on our constituents' behalf, our dependence on campaign fund-raising from private sources casts a shadow on the ethics of us all,'' Cranston said. ``So long as any wealthy contributor benefits from any action a senator takes, that senator can be accused of selling out,'' he said. ``The only way to lift that shadow is to end our ... dependence on private sources of campaign funds.'' Cranston is one of five senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee on charges they took a total of $1.3 million in campaign gifts raised by Keating and then interceded in 1987 with federal thrift regulators. The other four senators are John Glenn, D-Ohio; Donald Riegle, D-Mich.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; and Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. At the time, regulators were moving against the Phoenix millionaire's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., which was taken over by the government in April. Regulators estimate that Lincoln's losses of federally insured deposits to risky land investments and allegedly fraudulent loans will ultimately cost taxpayers up to $2 billion.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 10 a.m. EST; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Faltering as Other Countries Take Manufacturing Lead
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government is faltering as Japan and other countries work to make their manufacturers competitive, a congressional advisory agency said today. ``American manufacturing has never been in more trouble than it is now,'' the Office of Technology Assessment said in a 231-page report prepared for the Senate Banking Committee. The report rekindles a two-decade-old debate over industrial policy and the government's role in private enterprise, with the agency clearly siding with those favoring greater federal participation. ``With few exceptions, the U.S. government has been reluctant to adopt pro-active policies to build competitiveness,'' it said. ``The time is ripe for reopening the question ... before industry is so weakened that national security is threatened.'' Agency advisers suggested establishing a civilian technology agency through the National Institute of Standards and Technology. ``Unless U.S. industry and government take coordinated and timely action, there will be a long-term deterioration of our industrial strength and military security, and an erosion of our economic health,'' they said. The report acknowledged that selective government support of key technologies or industries amounts to ``picking winners'' and that government bureaucrats often are ill-equipped to make such choices. As an example, it cited the hundreds of millions of dollars the now-defunct Synfuels Corp. spent in the early 1980s subsidizing coal- and shale-based substitutes for oil and natural gas. But it said joint Japanese government-industry efforts have not always enjoyed success. Among the Japanese failures cited were attempts at jump-starting biotechnology development, building a fifth generation of computers and erecting a civilian airliner industry. The dominance of U.S. civilian aircraft manufacturers in world markets can be attributed to government-supported research on airframe and engine technologies in the early part of the century, the report said. ``A lesson is that a crisis is a poor crucible for making such decisions,'' it said. ``The failure of the Synfuels project can be traced largely to the atmosphere of crisis in which it was born.'' The advisers also cited government support of agricultural technology development through land grant universities and cooperative extension services as being a key to the rapid productivity growth of American farms. It is possible to ``take the best from the picking winners debate'' and develop institutions for government collaboration with manufacturers without becoming captive to them, the report said. ``The argument cannot and should not be resolved by counting up successes and failures. Any sustained effort ... will include some failures, and some industries might succeed more in spite of government support than because of it.''

DOC.HEAD: ABC Feature Out-Ranks `60 Minutes'
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in 12 years, an entertainment show beat ``60 Minutes'' in the ratings, and the CBS program's executive producer says Andy Rooney's suspension ``played a pretty big part.'' ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' finished eighth in the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings for the week ended Feb. 25. ``60 Minutes'' was No. 18. ``For the first time since 1978 we lost the time period for a broadcast other than a sporting event,'' Don Hewitt, executive producer of ``60 Minutes,'' said in a memo to his staff Tuesday. ``What part the Andy Rooney affair played is anybody's guess. Mine is that it played a pretty big part. ``Be that as it may, Andy will soon be coming back.'' Rooney was handed a three-month suspension without pay three weeks ago for racial remarks attributed to him by a gay magazine. He was alleged to have said blacks had ``watered down their genes.'' Rooney vehemently denied making the remarks. In 1978, the entertainment show ``ABC's Silver Anniversary Special'' won the 7-to-8 p.m. slot against ``60 Minutes.'' NBC won the ratings for the week with an average of 15.1, followed by ABC with 13.7 and CBS with 13.4. The rating represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million TV homes. Here are the Top 10 shows, their networks and ratings: ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 23.6; (tied with) ``Cheers,'' NBC, 23.6; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 21.5; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 21.0; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 20.7; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 20.4; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 19.8; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 19.4; ``The 32nd Annual Grammy Awards,'' CBS, 18.9; and ``L.A. Law,'' NBC, 18.6. Peter Jennings' ``World News Tonight'' on ABC won its seventh straight week in the news ratings, earning an 11.3. Dan Rather's slumping ``CBS Evening News'' was third at 9.9. Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News'' got a 10.1 rating. NBC's midseason prime-time replacement ``Grand'' was 11th, while CBS' ``The Bradys'' _ an updated version of ``The Brady Bunch'' _ fell to 69th. Fox's ``Married ... With Children'' was No. 24 and the highest ranked show for that network last week, with ``The Simpsons'' 26th. Fox said it beat NBC and ABC with ``The Simpsons'' and CBS and ABC with ``Married ... With Children.'' Several specials did well, with ``The 32nd Annual Grammy Awards'' capturing ninth place, and the middle and concluding chapter of ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts'' taking 13th and 19th places, respectively. The annual CBS broadcast of ``The Wizard of Oz'' on Tuesday night was 27th. NBC's movie ``Nasty Boys'' ranked 37th in the ratings, but the Friday night premiere of the ``Nasty Boys'' series was No. 52. ``A Family For Joe,'' an NBC Sunday night movie starring Robert Mitchum, was 22nd. Viewers agreed with critics and turned away from ABC's ``Challenger'' on Sunday night. The story about the shuttle tragedy was 44th, with a 12.8 rating, a sharp drop-off from ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' lead-in of 19.4. For the season to date, NBC leads the ratings averages with 14.9, followed by ABC with 13.0 and CBS with 12.3. The five bottom-ranked shows were: ``Primetime Live,'' ABC, 8.7; ``The Bradys,'' CBS, 8.5; ``Mission: Impossible,'' ABC, 7.7; (tied with) ``Tour of Duty,'' CBS, 7.7; and ``Magical World of Disney,'' a showing of ``Alice in Wonderland,'' NBC, 7.5.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Praises California Oil Cleanup
With PM-Exxon-Valdez, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A 1{-mile stretch of beach fouled by oil from a ruptured tanker was reopened, and the Coast Guard commandant praised the cleanup as a ``textbook case'' of how to handle such spills. Thirty-five percent of the crude that leaked from the American Trader on Feb. 7 was skimmed before it could go ashore, compared to international averages of 10 percent to 15 percent, Adm. Paul Yost said Tuesday. ``We had more oil skimmed percentage-wise than any other oil spill in the United States,'' he said. A sandy 1{-mile stretch between Newport Pier and Balboa Pier was deemed safe for beachgoers Tuesday after inspection of the sand and testing of 74 samples for hydrocarbons, said city fire Capt. Ray Pendleton. With 100 parts per million established as the upper limit, the tests found an average of 14 ppm in the sand, he said. An additional 10 miles of Orange County beaches affected by the Feb. 7 spill remained closed, but more openings were anticipated. The American Trader, whose cargo was owned by British Petroleum, leaked 394,000 gallons of crude while mooring at an offshore oil pipeline at Huntington Beach. The ship apparently was punctured by its own anchor.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Shuttle Atlantis Blasts Into Orbit on Secret Spy Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with lead UPDATING with shuttle in orbit.
DOC.TEXT: Riding a 700-foot geyser of fire, shuttle Atlantis set the night ablaze in a dazzling sound-and-light show as it rocketed into orbit early Wednesday on a secret mission to put a spy satellite in orbit. After five postponements, the 100-ton spaceship thundered into a clear sky at 2:51 a.m. and darted out over the Atlantic Ocean. Eight minutes and 40 seconds later, Mission Control Center in Houston reported Atlantis was in a secure orbit. ``The flight engineer reports the main engine cutoff was nominal,'' Mission Control reported as the spacecraft soared into orbit more than 100 miles high. Once Atlantis reached orbit, NASA and the Pentagon placed a news blackout on the progress of the flight. Unless there was a major problem, only two announcements were planned, one about three hours after liftoff that orbital operations had begun and another 30 hours into the flight with the date and time of landing. Atlantis and its crew of five military officers headed on a northeast course skirting the East Coast. Officials said earlier that if skies were clear, the fiery liftoff might be visible for hundreds of miles and that residents as far north as New Jersey might see the rising shuttle as a shooting star. Only three of the previous 33 shuttle missions began in darkness. The shuttle's course and launch time were determined by the need to place a photo-reconnaissance satellite into position to observe military bases and missile bases in northern regions of the Soviet Union. Because the mission is classified, NASA and the Pentagon blacked out the status of the countdown until the clock ticked down to nine minutes. Two minutes into the flight, the two solid-fuel rockets burned out and fell away, Atlantis continuing its climb into space on the thrust of its three main liquid-fuel engines. The sixth delay tied the record for launch postponements by two earlier shuttle missions. The launch had been delayed five times by bad weather, a cold that felled Atlantis commander, Navy Capt. John O. Creighton, and a faulty computer that halted the count Sunday just 31 seconds before liftoff. Despite a forecast of high winds, shuttle managers gave the go-ahead again Tuesday to proceed with the countdown and workers pumped 528,000 pounds of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen into the shuttle's external fuel tank. But the winds abated as the countdown advanced, and Atlantis safely cleared the pad on blastoff. Low clouds and gusty winds early Monday caused the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to postpone the flight for the fifth time. Shuttle managers then decided to put off for 48 hours another attempt so that the astronauts and launch team could rest. The records for launch postponements were in 1986. Columbia lifted off Jan. 12, after six delays caused by weather and mechanical problems. Challenger's doomed launch on Jan. 28, came after six delays, three as a result of the Columbia postponements and three during countdowns. Atlantis was delayed twice because of weather and Creighton's sore throat and nasal congestion. Weather alone caused two other delays and a failed computer was blamed for one more delay. The first attempt was last Thursday. The shuttle was expected to fly northeastward, a few hundred miles off the East Coast. If the weather were clear, the launch could be visible for hundreds of miles, as far north as New Jersey. Atlantis' launch path would put it in an orbit that reportedly would cover a greater area of the globe than any other shuttle so that its photo-reconnaissance satellite, once released by the crew, could gather intelligence over northern areas of the Soviet Union where there are numerous military bases and missile sites. The purpose of the four-day mission is secret, but sources close to the project have said the astronauts were to deploy a 37,300-pound, $500 million satellite capable of taking super-sharp photos and eavesdropping on military and diplomatic communications around the world. In covering most of the Soviet Union, the satellite would be important in verifying Soviet compliance with arms control agreements. Creighton, a Navy commander, is being accompanied in space by Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Atlantis' flight will be the 34th shuttle mission and the sixth classified military flight.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead in 2nd item to fix clarify
DOC.HEAD: Koop Says Officials Miss Chances for AIDS Policy
DOC.TEXT: Former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop is criticizing Congress and his former employer for failing to come up with a federal policy to deal with AIDS. ``There are ample opportunities'' for the White House and Congress to develop an AIDS policy, Koop told a House panel Tuesday. ``I think it's almost 10 years overdue.'' ``My concerns this morning have yet to be addressed at a national level,'' said Koop. He said later, ``It seems incredible that the federal government has not had a dialogue'' with state and local governments and insurers. Rep. Henry A. Waxman, D-Calif., chairman of the health and environment subcommittee, faulted President Bush for failing to act on groundwork laid when Koop was surgeon general under President Reagan. ``Having missed the opportunity to get the ounce of prevention, we now have to pay for the pounds and pounds of cure,'' said Waxman, who was hearing testimony on his proposed legislation to expand Medicaid coverage for people with AIDS or infected with the HIV virus believed to cause the disease.
DOC.HEAD: Report Criticizes Job-Training Program
DOC.TEXT: A private study says the nation's major job-training program is not working the way it was intended, with those who are least in need getting most of the help as Americans who are troubled and discouraged are weeded out. The report, published by the Economic Policy Institute, a union-backed think tank, said private contractors participating in the Job Training Partnership Act are ``cream-skimming,'' or picking promising candidates with skills over welfare recipients and high school dropouts. But a Labor Department official said Tuesday that the report, written by John Donahue of Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, ``sounds like it's getting a little too carried away.'' ``We need to keep in mind that JTPA has been extremely successful,'' said Roberts T. Jones, assistant secretary for employment and training. He said 97 percent of those served are defined by law as economically disadvantaged. Donahue's report suggested that JTPA is ``merely finding jobs for workers who already are the best-equipped and most desirable to employers'' rather than actually helping people develop long-term skills.
DOC.HEAD: PACs Raised $171 Million Last Year; Spent $132 Million
DOC.TEXT: Federal Election Commission figures show Political action committees raised $171 million last year and spent $132 million, with the Teamsters union PAC retaining its place as the top PAC in both fundraising and spending. The FEC said in its analysis that the overall levels PAC fund-raising and spending were little changed from the two years ago but that contributions from PACs to federal candidates, political parties and related election committees rose 24 percent to $69 million last year compared to $56 million in 1987. Some of that increase can be attributed to the eight special elections last year to fill congressional seats, an unusually high number. The FEC said some of the increase also likely was attributable to efforts by candidates and political committees to retire 1988 campaign debts. The $171 million raised by PACs last year compared to $166 million in 1987, when total PAC spending was $122 million. In 1985, the off-year before the 1986 congressional elections, PACs raised $152 million and spent $112 million, with $45 million of that going to federal candidates, parties or political committees. Critics of PAC influence on elections are lobbying heavily for Congress to adopt limits on the amounts congressional candidates could accept from political action committees. Congressional action on the proposals is expected to begin in earnest next month.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Gain, Dollar Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today kept up their strong recovery from Monday's severe plunge, while the dollar ended a six-day climb against the Japanese yen after reaching an eight-month high. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, the stock market's leading indicator, gained 694.04 points, or 2.04 percent, closing at 34,591.99. Volume was a relatively heavy 700 million shares on the first section. The gain followed a 576.08-point rise Tuesday, the day after the index fell 1,569.10 points in its second-biggest one-day plunge ever and its worst since the October 1987 ``Black Monday'' global crash. Dealers said investors had regained confidence in the market after a series of declines that had trimmed 14 percent off the Nikkei's value by Monday. ``The market is in the process of recovery,'' declared Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. ``Allowing for stability in the bond market, we are quite confident that the market found its lowest point yesterday at 32,443.18 points on the Nikkei average,'' said Yutaka Nakai of Daiwa Securities Co. ``Investors, especially individual investors, feel increasing confidence.'' The recovery apparently didn't come fast enough for someone in Osaka, Japan's second-biggest city. Windows at seven brokerages there were smashed overnight in what seemed to be an expression of outrage, the national newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported. Meanwhile, not everyone was convinced the market had bottomed out. Economist Adrian Tschoegl of SBCI Securities Asia said he calculates the stock market should fall another 10 percent to reach a path of sustainable growth, in line with its historical trend. ``But there's no way to know if the market will drop 10 percent tomorrow or go sideways for six months,'' he said. Nakai cautioned that the yen-dollar rate remained a threat to the stock market rally. The yen's recent weakness has been cited as one factor making stock investment unattractive. The dollar closed today at 148.52 yen, down 0.51 yen from Tuesday's close of 149.03 yen. It opened at 148.64 yen and ranged from 148.33 yen to 148.89 yen. In the preceding six trading days, it had climbed a total of 4.51 yen, reaching its highest level since June. ``Today, the dollar appeared stable at 148 yen. But if the yen weakens to 151-152 yen and Japanese authorities cannot raise the (official discount rate) due to U.S. pressure, we do not see any resistance line beyond that until 160 yen,'' Nakai said. The discount rate, the interest charged by the central bank for loans to commercial banks, affects other interest rates. Some analysts have expressed concern that higher interest rates in Japan would draw funds back from the United States. ``We expected that the stock market rally might drive the dollar below 148 yen,'' said Masafumi Koyama, chief dealer at the Bank of Tokyo, ``but at 148.30 yen, there was a massive buy order that drove the dollar back up to 148.60. It was quite a surprise.'' Koyama said Japanese institutional investors were buying and selling dollars with equal fervor. Japanese government bonds, which the Finance Ministry has struggled to bolster lately, continued to weaken. The yield on the benchmark No. 119 issue climbed to 7.03 percent, up from 6.91 percent Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Fat Tuesday Now Ash Wednesday: Mardi Gras Over
DOC.TEXT: The licentiousness of Mardi Gras gave way to the austerity of Lent today as cleanup crews took back the streets from the partyers to scoop up the litter that will tell how successful the blowout was. ``The crowd's been unusually heavy, but it's been very peaceful,'' said police Capt. George Bourgeois of the French Quarter, where officers on horseback swept revelers off the street as midnight turned Fat Tuesday into Ash Wednesday. The end of the party marked the first of 40 days of fasting and penitence with which many Christians mark Lent. Once streets are clear, street cleaning trucks scoop up the vast amounts of litter left after a day of partying and parades. The trash tonnage _ one of the measures of Mardi Gras' success _ won't be known for a couple of days. However, Capt. Paul Titus said after a helicopter flight over the city that more than 1 million people were on the streets, as in most previous years. An additional 600,000 to 700,000 enjoyed Tuesday's balmy weather in suburban Metairie, with thousands more in other suburbs and cities around southern Louisiana. Celebrations in heavily Roman Catholic Louisiana began Jan. 6 and went into high geae than a week before Tuesday's climax, which included 15 parades in New Orleans and its suburbtightly packed crowd probably was at Bourbon Street, as five women bared their breasts on different floors of one hotel. Every so often, one would disappear _ apparently at the behest of hotel security _ and reappear at another window to lift her shirt n exchange for beads thrown from the crowd below the street, bodies became so tightly jammed that it was impossible to move for 15 minutes. ``Can you believe that?!'' said a woman who squeezed into the Sho Bar Striptease club, buying a drink so she could stay. Bourgeois said Tuesday's only injury was to a French Quarter officer whose knee was hurt when his horse slipped and fell on pavement slick from spilled booze. Parades in New Orleans started with the club called Zulu, whose members _ blacks in blackface and grass skirts _ tossed painted coconuts and spears along with plastic beads and big aluminum Spanish-style doubloons. Next came the elegant procession of Rex, the king of Carnival, followed by 150 home-built floats. ``It's New Orleans' mission to see to it that everyone in the world has plastic beads, plastic cups and rubber chickens. The stuff they throw from the pa good, but everyone wants it,'' said Rita Miller of Metairie. Many in the crowds dressed up as Batman. Most of his imitators had the full cape, tights and cowl, but Eric Wright's minimalist approach _ a leather jockstrap with a plastic bat taped to it _ drew a crowd. Rick Ward, 21, of Albuquerque said someone ran into his parked car and totaled it Saturday, and on previous days his wallet and stereo were swiped from the car. But that didn't spoil his party mood. ``I love it,'' he said. ``We're going to move here. All we have to do is fly home and get reservations to fly back.''

DOC.HEAD: Park Lighting Ballot Question Turns Ugly With Racist Flier
DOC.TEXT: A nearly all-white community voted to allow lights at its soccer field despite a racist flier warning that black youngsters from inner-city Oakland would be drawn to a park for night games. Measure A had divided this wealthy city even before about 50 of the fliers were placed on cars and homes Sunday night. But on Tuesday, voters overwhelmingly defeated the referendum, which would have prohibited any new lighting at public playing fields in Piedmont. There were 2,442 votes cast against the measure and 1,421 votes in favor. No one took responsibility for the fliers, which said lighted fields could draw ``black disadvantaged inner-city Oakland youngsters, many from single head-of-household families and some from drug rehabilitation programs.'' Such youngsters, the fliers said, ``desperately need sports areas that are easily accessible and free of drugs and gang warfare.'' A nonexistent group called ``Blacks for No on A'' was named on the flier, which listed 37 apparently phony names. Mayor Susan Hill, who supported the measure, said the fliers played on residents' fears. Only 1 percent of Piedmont's 10,450 residents are black. ``I think it's very discouraging and disappointing that someone would distribute this type of material,'' she said. ``I don't think that residents of Piedmont would be swayed by this type of hate piece.'' She added: ``The truth is that Piedmont is surrounded by Oakland. Every newspaper shows the incredible crime rate and the burglaries. Most crimes are drug-related. It's not a myth.'' Robert Steinhorn, a leader of the Measure A campaign, said the fliers were ``obviously a bunch of racist garbage'' intended to make his camp look bad. The measure was placed on the ballot in response to plans by the City Council to light a playing field until 8 p.m. for about six weeks each year for night practice sessions of a community soccer club. Neighbors said the plan would cause the values of their $300,000 homes to plummet.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Storm Hits Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell across parts of the Midwest early today, while temperatures rose in the Northeast. A winter storm brought snow to central Nebraska and upper Michigan. Snow advisories were posted today for southwest Kansas and the Texas Panhandle. Rain fell in Oklahoma City, while showers dampened Miami. Temperatures in the East were generally milder than Tuesday, rising to above freezing in New York and Philadephia. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 88 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. Elsewhere Tuesday, thunderstorms developed over central New Mexico and western Texas. A tornado touched down near Valentine, Texas. Thunderstorm winds gusted to 93 mph in the afternoon at White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico. In Texas, a tornado touched down near Valentine and golf ball-size hail fell at Balmorhea. Rain dampened western and north-central Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, West Virginia and Virginia. Freezing rain extended over the northern portion of the Texas Panhandle into the Oklahoma Panhandle. Snow fell over Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Nebraska, Pennsylvania, inland New York, Vermont, Maine and southeastern New England. DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Rules Transportation Union Members Can Withhold Dues
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that transportation workers who join unions have the same right as non-members to refuse to pay dues that would be used to promote political or ideological causes they oppose. The decision Tuesday by U.S. District Judge Paul V. Niemeyer will make it easier for union members to demand rebates on their dues, said attorney Milton L. Chappell of the National Right to Work Legal Defense Fund. ``Most unions have taken the position in the past that any right to pay a reduced fee only applies to non-members,'' said Chappell, who brought the case on behalf of a Greenbelt woman who belongs to the Transportation Communications International Union. Niemeyer said that for the union to use her dues for political or ideological reasons violated her First Amendment rights and the federal Railway Labor Act. Niemeyer issued the ruling under the Railway Labor Act, which governs only the transportation industries, but it could set a precedent for courts ruling on similar demands by other workers unhappy with their unions' political activities. Other court decisions have held that non-union members working in a union shop, where all workers must join the labor organization, could reject union assessments for activities not directly related to contract negotiations, grievance procedures or other central functions. Mitchell M. Kraus, general counsel for the Transportation Communications International Union, said the ruling was disappointing, but he could not say whether the union, which represents 100,000 employees, would appeal. ``To my knowledge, this is the first ruling of its kind,'' Kraus said. The case was brought on behalf of Kathryn A. Kidwell, an Amtrak secretary. She objected to her dues being used for purposes unrelated to collective bargaining but said she did not want to quit the union. In his decision, Niemeyer said Kidwell was faced with the dilemma of staying in the union and having her money used for causes she opposes, or leaving and giving up her right to vote on the terms and conditions of her employment. ``In short ... she is given the option of protecting free speech or of protecting her vote on the continuation or conditions of work, but not both,'' the judge said. He ordered the union to give Kidwell and others similarly situated the right to receive a reduction in dues.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Sketches of Atlantis' Astronauts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item to CORRECT name to `Casper' sted `Caspar.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Navy Capt. John O. Creighton, commander of the all-military crew aboard Atlantis, was the pilot on his first trip into space nearly five years ago. Creighton, 46, became an astronaut in 1978 and flew his first shuttle mission aboard Discovery in June 1985. Born in Orange, Texas, he grew up in Seattle. After earning a bachelor's degree from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1966, Creighton began flight training and received his wings a year later. He received a master's degree in administration of science and technology from George Washington University in 1978. Creighton has logged about 5,000 hours flying time and has completed 500 carrier landings and 175 combat missions. He was the lead capsule communicator _ the astronaut who talks to the crew for Mission Control _ on the first four shuttle flights in the post-Challenger era. Creighton married Terry Stanford. He has received 10 air medals and the Navy Commendation Medal.

Air Force Col. John H. Casper is making his first trip into space aboard Atlantis as pilot of the mission. The 46-year-old pilot became an astronaut in 1984. Born in Greenville, S.C., he grew up in Gainesville, Ga. He received a bachelor's in engineering science from the Air Force Academy and a master's in astronautics from Purdue. He also is a 1986 graduate of the Air Force Air War College. In 1968, Casper received his wings. He flew 229 combat missions in Southeast Asia. Casper also served four years in England. He was a test pilot at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., and was assigned to the Pentagon in 1980. He and his wife, Christine, have two children. Casper's awards include the Legion of Merit, the Distinguished Flying Cross and six Air Force commendation medals.

Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, a mission specialist aboard Atlantis, has flown two previous shuttle flights, including the first post-Challenger mission. The former jet pilot was selected as an astronaut in 1980 and flew his first shuttle mission in October 1985. He was a crew member aboard the 1988 Discovery mission. Hilmers, 40, grew up in DeWitt, Iowa, and graduated with a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Cornell College in 1972. He earned a master's in electrical engineering in 1977 and the degree of electrical engineer from the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School in 1978. His first flight, the maiden voyage of Atlantis, also was a classified Defense Department mission. He and his wife, Lynn, have two children.

Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane, a veteran of two previous shuttle flights and a mission specialist aboard Atlantis, is retiring from the space agency and the military this summer. Mullane will return to Albuquerque, N.M., his hometown. Mullane became an astronaut in 1978 and flew his first shuttle mission in August 1984. His second shuttle mission was a classified flight in December 1988. Mullane earned a bachelor's degree in military engineering from the U.S. Military Academy and a master's in aeronautical engineering from the Air Force Institute of Technology. While stationed in Vietnam, Mullane flew 150 combat missions. He later served four years at Royal Air Force Base, Alconbury, England. Mullane also was assigned as a flight test weapon system operator at Eglin Air Force Base, Fla. He and his wife, Donna, have three children. Mullane has received six air medals, the Air Force Distinguished Flying Cross and the National Defense Service Medal.

Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre Thuout is the second space rookie aboard Atlantis. Thuout, 35, was selected as an astronaut in 1985. At NASA, he has helped design and develop shuttle payloads and crew equipment used for spacewalks and for the shuttle robot arm, which has been used to deploy and retrieve satellites. He also has been a capsule communicator for several shuttle flights. Born in Groton, Conn., he grew up in Fairfax, Va. He earned his bachelor's degree in physics from the Naval Academy and a master's degree in systems management from the University of Southern California. Thuout also is a graduate Navy Fighter Weapons School, or TOPGUN, and the Naval Test Pilot School. He married Cheryl Ann Mattingly. His honors include two meritorious unit commendations, two battle efficiency awards and the sea service deployment ribbon.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Family: Politics Stops At The Dinner Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT second Claudia to Cristiana, SUB 6th graf, `Pedro Joaquin ... anti-Sandinista.' Picks up 7th graf, `Between them ...' ^By ELOY O. AGUILAR
DOC.TEXT: Divided by ideology and united by strong family ties, the Chamorro family _ now led by President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro _ sums up the complexity of Nicaraguan political life. Mrs. Chamorro was a housewife from the conservative region of Rivas, in the traditional mold of the Nicarguan upper middle class woman. She went from housewife to newspaper publisher when her husband Pedro Joaquin Chamorro was assassinated, apparently by agents of dictator Anastasio Somoza, on Jan. 10, 1978. The assassination turned Chamorro into a martyr of the Sandinista revolution, which toppled Somoza 19 months later on July 19, 1979. Mrs. Chamorro became a symbol of the revolution, joining the junta that took over. Nine months later she quit. Pedro Joaquin and Violeta's children are evenly split _ Carlos Fernando and Claudia are militant Sandinistas and government officials; Pedro Joaquin and Cristiana are bitterly anti-Sandinista. Between them, the Chamorros run two of the three daily newspapers in town _ the opposition La Prensa and the Sandinista party paper Barricada _ which split off from La Prensa. The Chamorro children tear at each others' throats in print, but at family reunions politics end at the dinner table. ``We are brothers and sisters with political differences. We meet occasionally and we treat each other with respect,'' said Cristiana, the youngest of the children at 30 and director of La Prensa, which her late father turned into a constant political critic of the late dictator Somoza. The family story became the center of attention again this week when Mrs. Chamorro, heading an opposition coalition of 14 political parties and other groups, defeated President Daniel Ortega's bid for re-election, appearing to put an end to Sandinista rule. ``The same differences of political opinion we had in 1979 are the differences we have now, but we have affectionate family relations,'' said Carlos Fernando, who as director of Barricada published articles that often ridiculed Mrs. Chamorro during her presidential campaign. Yet the two embraced publicly as loving mother and son Monday when Ortega visited Mrs. Chamorro to congratulate her on her electoral victory. ``I have been a Sandinista for a long time,'' Carlos Fernando said. A friend of the family, speaking on condition of anonimity said of the Chamorros: ``They have one thing in common _ a conservative patrician sense of unity of the family above everything else. After that, the differences begin.'' They are all children of Pedro Joaquin, publisher, guerrilla, novelist and romantic whose constant attacks on Somoza eventually brought him death on a street cornder in a hail of bullets. Many people like to speculate whether Pedro Joaquin would be on the Sandinistas' side were he alive today. Carlos Fernando and Pedro Joaquin the younger studied in Canada, but Carlos Fernando was the only one allowed to work as a reporter at La Prensa while Pedro Joaquin was alive. ``Carlos Fernando inherited the social concerns and political traditions of his father,'' said the friend of the family. ``Pedro Joaquin inherited the business sense of the Cardenal family on his paternal grandmother's side.'' Pedro Joaquin eventually became director of La Prensa when it was the target of government attacks in the early 80s. ``Pedro Joaquin was really afraid of the revolution,'' the friend added. ``He and Cristiana really identified themselves with the people opposed to the revolution. La Prensa then became a forum for those people.'' Claudia served as an ambassador for the Sandinista government. ``Conservative or liberal, they are fighters. Maybe Pedro Joaquin and Cristiana are not the journalists that Carlos Fernando is and they can't write worth a darn, but they were never afraid to say what they thought.'' The paper was closed by the Sandinista government several times when young Pedro Joaquin was the director. The paper was closed for more than a year. Under international pressure, Ortega once visited Mrs. Chamorro and told her she could publish but the government would have to have a censor at the newspaper. ``Then I won't publish,'' said Mrs. Chamorro, a stubborn woman from a cattle region who once started a campaign speech, when newspapers referred to her by her maiden name, by saying: ``I have on me the brand of the Chamorros.''

DOC.HEAD: Contras Refuse Call to Disband Before Gov't Change
DOC.TEXT: The Contra rebels are refusing to heed a call from Nicaraguan leaders and the Honduran president to disband immediately, saying they'll wait until the newly elected government in Managua takes office. Dismantling the U.S.-backed force has emerged as a critical element in a peaceful transition in Nicaragua following the opposition's stunning electoral triumph Sunday over the leftist Sandinistas. On Tuesday, both Sandinista President Daniel Ortega and the opposition president-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, said the rebels must immediately disband. ``The causes that started the civil war in Nicaragua have disappeared,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in a radio broadcast Tuesday night. ``That's why those who took to the hills should now lay down their guns and return peacefully to Nicaragua with their families to work for the reconstruction of our motherland.'' Earlier, President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras said the Contras must leave Honduras as soon as possible. But Israel Galeano, the senior leader among the estimated 10,000 rebels in camps near Nicaragua's northern border, said they did not trust the Sandinistas, who control Nicaragua's army and police. ``Our disbanding will take effect when the Sandinistas turn over power,'' Galeano said. ``Meanwhile, we will remain in Honduras.'' Galeano said in a telephone interview that the rebels would remain in camps on the Honduran side of the border ``waiting for there to be adequate conditions in Nicaragua for our return.'' ``They (the Sandinistas) are capable of relinquishing the government but not power or weapons to the winners of last Sunday's election.'' Galeano spoke after the call by Ortega to disband but before the similar urging by Mrs. Chamorro, and it was unclear whether her statement would affect the Contras' decision. Some members of her coalition are former Contra leaders who returned to Nicaragua under a government amnesty. After a six-hour meeting of Sandinista party leaders on Tuesday, Ortega said the party would hand over power but ``defend the integrity and professionalism of the army and the police forces.'' ``The Sandinista National Liberation Front demands the immediate demobilization and disarming of the Contras so there can be a peaceful transition,'' he said, reading from a statement by party leaders. Mrs. Chamorro is to take office for a six-year term April 25. About 10,000 Contra combatants retreated in March 1988 to Yamales, 120 miles southeast of Tegucigalpa, after the United States suspended military assistance and limited non-lethal aid. Since then, they have been living in camps on the Honduran side of the border with Nicaragua, some of them with their relatives. In addition, an unknown number of Contras were in Nicaragua right up to Sunday's election. Galeano said the rebels' 43 commanders would meet this week to develop their strategy for the transition period. ``The Assembly of Commanders will decide on it (the strategy) democratically but for the moment we are not willing to demobilize,'' he said. Under a plan signed by five Central American presidents in August, the Contras were to demobilize by December and turn over their weapons to a verification commission. They did not. Galeano said he had ordered his troops to act only in self-defense and not to attack Sandinista positions ``to avoid armed confrontations that have no reason to occur at this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Independent Journalist Says He Barred from UNESCO Conference
DOC.TEXT: Independent journalist Sergei Grigoryants today said he was barred by authorities from traveling to Paris to attend a U.N. agency conference discussing assistance for non-government media in Eastern Europe. ``This shows what they really think here of the freedom of the press, of the freedom of human contacts,'' Grigoryants said in a telephone interview. Grigoryants, the publisher of the independent human rights bulletin ``Glasnost'' and a former political prisoner, said he was given a French visa to attend the conference of the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization after receiving a personal invitation from UNESCO's director-general, Federico Mayor of Spain. He was issued a passport at the Consular Service of the Foreign Ministry, he said. But when he returned Monday to have it stamped with the exit permit Soviets need to travel abroad, he said his passport was confiscated. ``They told me they hadn't received permission from the competent organs,'' Grigoryants said. ``That means the KGB.'' He said leaders from official publications, such as Ogonyok magazine editor-in-chief Vitaly Korotich and Vladislav A. Starkov, editor of the weekly newspaper Arguments and Facts, had no problem in obtaining permission to travel to Paris. As the UNESCO conference opened Tuesday, Mayor urged the West to provide practical assistance to independent media in Eastern Europe as journalists and broadcasters there help forge new societies. Media leaders from 15 Western countries including the United States and Canada were attending the two-day conference along with journalists from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland, Romania and the Soviet Union.
