DOC.HEAD: Criticized Plan to Expand Fort Worth Art Museum Postponed
DOC.TEXT: Trustees of the Kimbell Art Museum, a Louis Kahn design hailed by many as a shining example of modern architecture, voted to postpone indefinitely a roundly criticized plan to nearly double gallery space. Kimbell Art Foundation members announced in a statement Tuesday they were putting aside the proposal they adopted in July to expand the 18-year-old museum. Sue Ann Kahn, Kahn's daughter and a critic of the proposed expansion, called the trustees' decision courageous. Kahn's survivors and others had objected to the expansion, contending the Kimbell is a masterpiece that should not be tampered with. Nine internationally prominent architects, including Phillip Johnson, Richard Meier and James Sterling, wrote a letter in November to the foundation president calling the proposed addition ``mimicry of the most simple-minded character.'' The proposal mainly involved adding circular vault sections similar to the original to both ends of the building. The $8 million plan would have added 14,000 square feet of gallery space.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis' Ascent Seen Along East Coast
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: People along the East Coast glimpsed ribbons of blue, white and red light across the pre-dawn sky as space shuttle Atlantis streaked like a shooting star on a secret military mission. ``It weaved in and out of the clouds. It was beautiful, very bright. It had a long tail,'' said Theresa Yohn, a TV news producer in Jacksonville, Fla. ``It was almost like another star, a white bright pinpoint of blue light that continued upwards,'' said Mike Albertson, an editor with the Savannah Evening Press who was staked out with binoculars at Tybee Island, about 18 mile east of Savannah, Ga. Albertson described the shuttle's rocket boosters as ``twin streaks of red side by side.'' ``It was a great show. It's so incredible that something like that could be bearing humans,'' he said. The 100-ton spaceship was spotted as far north as Washington, D.C., in the minutes following the fiery liftoff at 2:51 a.m. Clouds obscured visibility in some areas, however, as Atlantis raced up the coast on the highest inclination orbit ever traveled by a shuttle. ``At first, it was pretty much a white light,'' said Coast Guard fireman Samuel Sellars, who watched from his station on Ocracoke Island, just south of Cape Hatteras, N.C. ``All of a sudden, it looked kind of like a flare. I thought there had been another explosion,'' he said. Sellars soon realized he was watching the two solid-fuel rockets burn out and fall away. ``For a moment, I was scared,'' he said. ``I feel kind of proud now.'' After lighting up the sky for miles around the Kennedy Space Center, Atlantis ducked in and out of clouds on a northeasterly course. The three main engines burned out east of Atlantic City, N.J., and the shuttle headed toward Newfoundland. Wednesday's launch was NASA's sixth attempt to send Atlantis aloft with its five-man, all-military crew and a $500 million spy satellite. The previous efforts were scrubbed because of bad weather, crew illness and a malfunctioning computer. Among those eagerly awaiting liftoff were doctors at an emergency room who asked Ms. Yohn's newsroom to call them once the shuttle took off. ``They couldn't stand outside waiting to see the launch. They wanted to be able to run outside and watch it pass over, and then run back inside to work,'' she said. ``It only lasted about 7 to 10 seconds. But it beat the hell out of a fireworks show,'' Albertson said. It was the fourth nighttime launch for NASA. The last ascent in the dark was Discovery's in November, but clouds obscured visibility for most of the Southeast outside Florida. The evening launch of Atlantis in November 1985 was seen as far north as Charleston, S.C. The other nighttime liftoff was Challenger in August 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Group Claims Responsibility for Attempted Bombing at IRS Office
DOC.TEXT: A group calling itself Up the IRS Inc. claimed responsibility for an explosives-laden truck parked outside an Internal Revenue Service office, and it threatened more acts against the tax agency. The claim was made in a letter received Tuesday by The Outlook newspaper of Santa Monica. The attempted bombing Thursday forced thousands of people to evacuate an area around the West Los Angeles IRS office. ``As long as the IRS is used to extort such high, unfair and ambiguous taxes from the populace using tactics more appropriate to the SS or KGB, you and the government agencies can expect to see more of these events and with increasing severity with successive events,'' the letter said. A bomb squad disarmed the device, made of five 55-gallon steel drums containing explosive chemicals. The explosives were in the bed of a truck that had been set on fire. FBI spokesman Fred Reagan said a group with the same name claimed responsibility for a bomb that exploded in the area in 1988. In Tuesday's letter, Up the IRS Inc. said it timed the incident to coincide with George Washington's birthday. ``George would have applauded and had a good laugh at the distress of the thieves in the IRS offices,'' it said. ``The truck was parked at that location for 48 hours and we could have detonated it at any time.'' There have been several bombings and attempted bombings of Southern California IRS offices in recent years. An explosion and fire at a Glendale IRS office in 1986 caused more than $1 million damage. Authorities defused four pipe bombs at a vacant Culver City IRS office that same week. In 1987, authorities safely detonated pipe bombs found at a Laguna Niguel IRS office.

DOC.HEAD: Operation Rescue, Officers Fined for Contempt
DOC.TEXT: A judge has heaped $450,000 more in contempt fines on Operation Rescue, but a leader of the debt-ridden anti-abortion group says he won't pay ``one dime.'' U.S. District Judge Robert Ward on Tuesday imposed a $100,000 fine against Operation Rescue founder Randall Terry and $350,000 in fines against a chapter of the group and nine other people who blocked women from entering clinics in New York City and nearby counties. The judge said Operation Rescue violated his injunction against blocking entrances to clinics where abortions are performed. He also ordered the defendants to pay attorneys' fees, which have not yet been calculated. ``This is selective and it's disgusting,'' Terry said. ``Where else have there been fines like this for protesting? Not for animal rights groups. Not for gay groups.'' ``I have no intention of paying one dime of these fines,'' said Michael McMonagle, an Operation Rescue deputy director who was fined $25,000. Other activists also were refusing to pay their fines, The New York Times reported today. Terry said the anti-abortion group, which has ignored $50,000 in fines in other states, is more than $70,000 in debt. Debts forced the group to announce Jan. 31 the closing of its national headquarters in Binghamton. In Los Angeles, 15 Operation Rescue members were convicted Monday on misdemeanor charges for a demonstration at a clinic last March. They face up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. McMonagle said of Tuesday's ruling: ``I'm afraid that it will have a chilling effect on many people, but babies are being killed and we have a moral obligation to save them.'' The fines grew out of a lawsuit against Terry and his group by the National Organization for Women and other abortion-rights groups. Mary M. Gundrum, an attorney who worked with NOW, said the contempt actions were pursued to ``give fair warning to those persons and groups that the court will proceed to fine them if they violate the constitutional rights of women.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against major foreign currencies in calm European trading today, dealers said. Gold prices were mixed. Currency dealers said the dollar was trading within a narrow range, buoyed by weakness in the West German mark and the yen but capped by concerns about the U.S. economy. A dealer at a West German bank in Frankfurt predicted the dollar's upward trend would continue mostly because of persistent yen weakness. Others said the markets were waiting for U.S. fourth quarter gross national product data due for release later today. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.51 yen to a closing 148.52 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 148.68 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6915 West German marks, up from 1.6836 _1.4875 Swiss francs, up from 1.4857 _5.7235 French francs, up from 5.7010 _1.9082 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8985 _1,250.50 Italian lire, up from 1,245.25 _1.1910 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1908 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6872, compared with $1.6915 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $408.75 a troy ounce, up from $407.25 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $409.10. In Zurich, the bid price was $409.25, down from $411.25 Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.07 to close at a bid $408.92. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.11.

DOC.HEAD: Vegas Oddsmaker Makes ``Driving Miss Daisy'' Favorite For Oscars
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy'' is an oddsmaker's slight favorite for an Academy Awards sweep: best picture, Morgan Freeman as best actor and Jessica Tandy as best actress. Bally's oddsmaker Lenny Del Genio, who has put out Oscar odds for eight years, made ``Driving Miss Daisy'' an even-money favorite to win the best picture award, followed closely by ``Born on the Fourth of July'' at 6-5. Freeman is an even-money pick to win for best actor, while Tom Cruise is also listed at even money to win for ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' Tandy is even money to win the Oscar for her role in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' while Michelle Pfeiffer is listed at 6-5 to win for ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' Del Genio's odds are for entertainment purposes only, as Nevada gaming regulators forbid betting on anything other than sports events or horse races in the state's sports books. Del Genio said the odds for best picture were the closest ever, reflecting a race that is very much up in the air going into the Academy Awards show March 26 in Los Angeles. ``This year can go any way,'' he said. ``All of the nominations for best picture are strong in their support.'' Del Genio's odds in the top categories: Best Picture _ ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' even money; ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' 6-5; ``My Left Foot,'' 3-1; ``Dead Poets Society,'' 4-1; ``Field of Dreams,'' 5-1. Best Actor _ Freeman, even money; Cruise, even money; Daniel Day-Lewis ``My Left Foot,'' 6-5; Robin Williams ``Dead Poets Society,'' 3-1; Kenneth Branagh ``Henry V,'' 5-1. Best Actress _ Tandy, even money; Pfeiffer, 6-5; Jessica Lange ``Music Box,'' 3-1; Pauline Collins ``Shirley Valentine,'' 4-1; Isabelle Adjani ``Camille Claudel,'' 5-1. Best Supporting Actor _ Martin Landau ``Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' even money; Denzel Washington ``Glory,'' 6-5; Dan Aykroyd ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' 3-1; Marlon Brando ``A Dry White Season,' 4-1; Danny Aiello ``Do the Right Thing,'' 5-1. Best Supporting Actress _ Brenda Fricker ``My Left Foot,'' 6-5; Anjelica Huston ``Enemies, A Love Story,'' 7-5; Julia Roberts ``Steel Magnolias,'' 3-1; Dianne Wiest ``Parenthood,'' 4-1; Lena Olin ``Enemies, A Love Story,'' 5-1. Best Director _ Oliver Stone ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' 6-5; Peter Weir ``Dead Poets Society,'' 7-5; Jim Sheridan ``My Left Foot,'' 3-1; Woody Allen ``Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' 4-1; Kenneth Branagh ``Henry V,'' 5-1.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises As Clashes Between Black Factions Continues
DOC.TEXT: Protesters hurling rocks clashed with police as rival black factions fought for control of black townships in Natal Province, police said today. At least six people were reported killed. Two black men were killed and a third man was wounded when police opened fire Tuesday on protesters who hurled rocks at police patrols near Durban in the southeastern province, police officials said. Rival factions set fire to houses and huts in several townships and police used guns, rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse mobs that attacked police patrols, the officials said. Four bodies of black men apparently killed in fighting between rival black factions were found around Durban, police said. All of the bodies had been set on fire, police said. The United Democratic Front is locked in a bloody struggle in Natal with the conservative Inkatha Zulu political movement. Hundreds of blacks have died in factional clashes in recent months. Black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, released Feb. 11 after 27 years in jail, appealed at a rally in Durban in Sunday for an end to the fighting. But more than 20 people have died in clashes since the weekend with no sign of any halt to the fighting. Minister of Law and Order Adriaan Vlok, who heads the South African police, said he was concerned about growing attacks on police in Natal. He said police officers would be protected and not prevented from enforcing the law. Seven police officers had been killed so far this year in Natal and there had been 108 attacks on police officers in the province, Vlok said Tuesday in Cape Town.

DOC.HEAD: College Applications Down Since Quake
DOC.TEXT: High school seniors from other states, apparently shaken by the Oct. 17 earthquake, don't appear as eager to attend area colleges, according to school officials. The earthquake reversed a steady increase in freshman applicants from outside California at Stanford University, Santa Clara University and the University of California, officials said. The UC system had a record 19 percent drop in out-of-state applicants for fall openings at its eight campuses. Including in-state applicants, UC Santa Cruz suffered the steepest decline, with applications down by 11.8 percent. By contrast, UC San Diego had the smallest decline with .05 percent. The epicenter of the 7.1-magnitude quake that killed 67 people and caused an estimated $7 billion in damage was near Santa Cruz. ``A number of students back East told our staff, `I want to come, but Mom and Dad don't want me to,''' because of the quake, said Dan Saracino, dean of undergraduate admissions at the University of Santa Clara, where the drop exceeded 6 percent. Stanford applications were off by 13 percent, officials said. Joe Allen, admissions director for UC Santa Cruz, said the drop would be hard to explain except for the quake. Californians apparently did not let the quake change their plans, however. In-state applications remained close to steady despite a predicted drop in the number of 1990 high school graduates.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Time in Borrego, Cool in Gunnison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, He said, to CORRECT last word to winter sted summer
DOC.TEXT: Folks looking for a hot time should head for Borrego Springs, Calif., while Gunnison, Colo., is the place for cool dudes. The Southern California desert community was the hottest place in the nation 50 times last year, more often than any other community, according to the annual rankings published by Weatherwise magazine. Gunnison ranked as coldest place most often _ 62 times. Officials in both towns see their weather as a boon. The piping-hot performance of 1989 moved Borrego Springs into the top spot in the warm-weather sweepstakes, ahead of Palm Springs, Calif., which led the list a year earlier. ``We're strictly a winter resort area. Our best time is October to May,'' said Len Surles, secretary of the Borrego Springs Chamber of Commerce. ``That's what brings people here, the mild temperatures in the winter time, the lack of bad weather.'' He said only about 2,700 people live all year in the town, about 90 miles from San Diego, but that can double in winter. While Borrego Springs was the national hot spot most often, last year's hottest reading outside of Death Valley, Calif., was 121 degrees. That dubious distinction was shared by Blythe and Palm Springs, Calif., on July 4 and Laughlin, Nev., the next day. Located high in the chilly Rocky Mountains, Gunnison was first in frost for the fifth straight year, according to the analysis prepared by David H. Hickcox, a professor of geography at Ohio Wesleyan College in Delaware, Ohio. Winter sports are a feature at Gunnison, located in a valley 7,700 feet above sea level. ``It's a fun place to live. If you like the outdoors it's a paradise,'' said Dale Howard, city manager of the community of 7,000 located 200 miles southwest of Denver. The low temperatures occur in the early hours of the morning when cold air settles from the Rocky Mountains into Gunnison, Howard said, adding that most days are sunny and that the temperature warms up rapidly after sunrise. Last year's single coldest reading was 54 degrees below zero Feb. 6 at Logan Canyon, Utah. Hickcox's analysis excludes Death Valley, Calif., from the heat list and Alaska from the cold list, since the extremes recorded in those places would nearly always dominate the standings. For the record, Death Valley had a maximum reading of 127 degrees July 7 and the top temperature there was over 100 every day from June 6 to Sept. 18. Alaska had a numbing 76 below zero at Tanana on Jan. 27, lowest reading for the year in North America. The average for the month of January at Fort Yukon was 33.5 below zero. Following Gunnison on the icy list was Truckee, Calif., the coldest spot on 28 days; Fraser, Colo., 23 days; Leadville, Colo., 20; and Wisdom, Mont., 19. On the sultry side of the statistics, Borrego Springs was trailed by Bullhead City, Ariz., which was the hot spot 45 times and then by dethroned champ Palm Springs, which was the sweatiest place 33 times. Rounding out the fiery five were Laughlin, Nev., with 28 highest readings and, tied for fifth at 27 days with the top torrid temperature, were Laredo and McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Fined for Prescription Violations
DOC.TEXT: A neurologist who improperly signed more than 100 prescriptions for narcotics has been fined $390,000, the largest amount in a civil lawsuit against a doctor for improper drug distribution, the government said. The fine approved Tuesday by U.S. District Judge Andrew Caffrey settled a lawsuit brought against Dr. Julian Ungar-Sargon. He was accused of leaving batches of signed prescription forms for Percodan and Percocet, which are pain relievers, with associates at the Manomet Medical Center in Plymouth, southeast of Boston. Ungar-Sargon owned and operated the center in 1985 and 1986. At that time, the government alleges, he was not authorized to write prescriptions in Massachusetts and spent only a few hours at the center every two weeks. ``There is no charge of illegal drug distribution at all,'' said Ungar-Sargon's lawyer, Nancy Gertner. ``There are a host of complicated regulations he did not follow.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Journalists Seek Meeting With Gov't
DOC.TEXT: An organization representing more than 100 foreign journalists today requested a meeting with government officials to discuss a recent increase in police surveillance. ``We strongly object to this interference in the journalistic work of accredited foreign correspondents,'' the Foreign Correspondents Club of Beijing said in a letter to Foreign Ministry. It requested a meeting with the ministry's director of information, Li Zhaoxing, and ``representatives of relevant security organizations at the earliest possible date.'' The letter was delivered to the ministry today, and there was no immediate response. More than 130 foreign correspondents from more than two dozen countries belong to the organization. Police have sharply increased surveillance of foreign journalists since martial law was lifted in Beijing last month. Correspondents from nearly a dozen news organizations, including Americans, Europeans and Soviets, said they have been tailed at least once by plainclothes police in the past few weeks. One reporter said his Chinese friends had been warned by their employers to stop seeing him. Three Chinese who visited another reporter's home last week were taken away by security agents as they left. Foreign journalists have faced reduced access to officials and tighter controls since June, when the army was called in to crush massive popular protests for democracy. Some have been tailed from time to time, but surveillance has become markedly more intense since Jan. 11, when martial law was lifted. Under martial law, foreign journalists were required to get military approval for all interviews. Police surveillance appears to be a substitute measure. Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, in Geneva to attend a disarmament conference, said the reports of stepped up surveillance were inaccurate and warned that any ``secret activities'' by foreign journaists would prompt official response. As during past upsurges of conservative ideology, longstanding official suspicion and resentment of all foreigners also has come to the fore. A Western diplomat in Shanghai said security guards recently accused his driver of being a foreign lackey and beat him up.

DOC.HEAD: Catholics Launch Petition Drive for Reform
DOC.TEXT: A group of Roman Catholics is seeking 100,000 signatures on a petition calling for major reform in the church. A full-page advertisement in today's New York Times calls for the acceptance of women and married people into the priesthood, development of Catholic Church teachings on sexuality, financial openness and an end to the silencing of theologians. Among the 4,505 people who have already signed the petition are a New York auxiliary bishop, Emerson Moore, prominent theologians and a number of lay people, priests and nuns. Dan Dailey, head of the Chicago-based group Call to Action, which placed the ad, said that the credibility of the church's teachings on justice and peace would be undermined unless the church's internal structure was changed. The group argues for more participation by Catholics at all levels of the church, more outreach to racial and ethnic minorities, academic freedom and consultation before choosing bishops or closing of parishes and their schools. Reaction to the call for reform was mixed. Helen Hull Hitchcock, the director of Women for Faith and Family, said it was ``deplorable'' for such a ``divisive'' statement to be released on Ash Wednesday, a solemn holy day. The organization stresses strict adherence to church doctrine. The Rev. Kenneth J. Doyle, a spokesman for the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, sounded a conciliatory note. ``Some of these opinions we would identify with strongly, others we would have some difficulty with,'' Doyle said. Dailey acknowledged that the Vatican would most likely frown on the call for reform. ``But a year or two ago, nobody in their right mind would have dreamed of the changes in Eastern Europe,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of thousands Demonstrate in Srinagar
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people chanting ``We want freedom!'' took to the streets of this city today demanding that Moslem-dominated Kashmir valley be granted autonomy from India, witnesses said. The witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said local Hindus and Sikhs joined Moslems in the procession through the city. The witnesses said at least 300,000 of the city's one million people joined the demonstration. ``We want liberty! We want freedom!'' marchers chanted, the witnesses said. The movement for an independent Kashmir has mostly been led by the area's Moslems, who form about 65 percent the population of Jammu-Kashmir, the only state with a Moslem majority in predominantly Hindu India. The four-decade-old agitation has flared in recent months. A government crackdown on the movement on Jan. 18 prompted confrontations between demonstrators and security forces in which at least 112 people have been killed. Witnesses said paramilitary police lined the route of the procession but did not attempt to break up the demonstration. Most shops in the city were closed in support. Kashmir, once a princely state, was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding areas of the valley became part of Indian-held Jammu-Kashmir state. Moslems make up 12 percent of the 880 million population and Hindus comprise 82 percent. Sikhs, Christians and Buddhists make up the rest. Kashmiri militants had earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, which claims Kashmir because of its predominant Moslem population, but now demand independence and the status of a neutral nation. India has fought two wars with Pakistan over Kashmir and the two nations have traded angry statements in recent weeks blaming each other for the trouble in the valley.

DOC.HEAD: Public Barred from Air Base During Shuttle Landing
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The public site for watching space shuttle landings will be closed when Atlantis touches down after its classified military mission, NASA said. The shuttle was launched from Florida early today, reportedly to put a $500 million spy satellite in orbit. The landing time won't be announced until 24 hours beforehand, but the mission is expected to last about 4{ days, so Atlantis should land at this Mojave Desert military base Sunday morning. During non-military shuttle flights, up to 500,000 people have jammed onto the unpaved public viewing site on the east shore of Rogers Dry Lake. But after secret missions ``it's been Department of Defense policy to restrict the public from watching the landings,'' said Don Haley, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The rationale for the ban isn't clear, since news reporters and photographers have been allowed to watch and photograph military shuttle landings, and they have done so from a site closer to the runway than the public viewing site. Those landings also have been televised, and the shuttle landings are visible at a distance from portions of Highway 58 north of Edwards Air Force Base. Haley said the viewing site will be open after the next shuttle flight, when Discovery lands after a five-day mission to put the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit around the Earth. Discovery is scheduled for launch April 12.

DOC.HEAD: Wrong Dog Placed on Death Row
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `She peeked...', to identify man quoted as boy's stepfather.
DOC.TEXT: The wrong dog was on death row but his master's voice saved him from destruction. The dog Bud Lite was to be destroyed by lethal injection at the Genesee County animal shelter for biting a 12-year-old boy. But authorities say Bud Lite had done no wrong and was the victim of an insidious dog switch. A 20-year-old woman, who wasn't identified, had agreed to have her dog put to sleep for biting the boy in exchange for dismissal of a misdemeanor charge against her, City Attorney Richard Hamilton said Tuesday. Officials in this community about five miles east of Flint said they are investigating this possible scenario: The woman snatched Bud Lite from his yard, switched his collar and tags with her doomed dog's tags and turned him in to the shelter. Bud Lite, owned by 14-year-old Jason Griffin, resembles the condemned dog and lives about a mile away. Court records described the offending dog as a brown pit bull; Bud Lite is a pit bull-retriever mix. ``In the 16 years since I've been doing this, this is a first,'' Assistant City Attorney Rick Austin said. The woman, if guilty of switching the dogs, could face a charge of larceny, he said. Bud Lite was missing for several days before Jason's mother, Kathy Johnston, checked the Genesee County animal shelter. ``She peeked into death row and said, `There it is. That's my dog,''' said Jeff Johnston, Jason's stepfather. ``The (animal shelter) woman said, `That can't be your dog. That's a court-ordered destruction. Some other woman brought that dog in.''' Police confirmed that Bud Lite was the wrong dog. The woman is scheduled to appear Thursday before District Judge Gerald D. Snodgrass. Her dog remains at large.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Won't Seek Charges Against Former Korean President
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said today they would not seek an indictment against former President Choi Kyu-hah. The legislature had sought criminal charges after he refused to testify about a civil uprising in 1980. Senior prosecutor Park Soon-yong cited executive privilege and national security concerns in making the decision. Choi, a former prime minister, briefly served as a figurehead president after the assassination of his predecessor Park Chung-hee in late 1979. He was succeeded by Chun Doo-hwan who seized power with military backing in 1980. The National Assembly sought criminal charges against Choi early last month after the ex-president ignored five subpoenas to testify on his alleged role in the military crackdown on a pro-democracy movement in the southern city of Kwangju in 1980. About 200 people were killed and more than 1,500 injured in the 10-day uprising, the worst in modern Korean history. A special Parliament committee investigating the tragedy summoned Choi to testify on the incident, but he refused to, citing executive privilege. When Chun was subpeoned late last year, he testified before in a raucous session that shed little light on his role in putting down the uprising.

DOC.HEAD: University Student Finds Egyptian Mummy in His Bed
DOC.TEXT: A college freshman was shocked when he returned to his dorm room and found his bed had been occupied by someone dead for a long, long time. The body was a 2,500-year-old unwrapped Egyptian mummy. The mummy had been swiped from its Wesleyan University hiding place and slipped into Tim Abel's bed as a practical joke, campus public safety officials and Abel said Tuesday. Abel said he had returned to his dorm room Saturday night to find a crowd gathering and a prankster trying to spirit a body away. Abel grabbed the body to see if it was real, and was disgusted to find flakes chipped off in his hand. The prankster, whom Abel declined to identify, fled, clutching the body. ``It was one of the most putrid things I've ever seen,'' said Abel, of Wilmington, Del. ``I looked at my bed and there were all these skin chips and little chips in it. It was pretty disgusting.'' The espisode is being investigated by Middletown police and campus security officers. Wesleyan President William M. Chace promises to make sure the mummy receives proper care and respect, a school spokesman said. A Wesleyan classics professor bought the mummy in Athens in the 1880s, at a time when pilfering Egyptian tombs was popular. The 5-foot, 2-inch body was displayed at the university's natural history museum until the 1950s, when interest in mummies waned and it was stored in a library attic. University scholars decided in 1978 to study the mummy further. An X-ray showed it was a young man with four mysterious tubes in his tummy. The mummy was unwrapped and sliced open a year later in the university's archaeology lab. The tubes showed traces of organic matter, leading the scholars to conclude that bits of organs removed from the body during mummification had been sewn back to be reunited with the body in the afterlife. Inscriptions on the bandages and other evidence led to the conclusion that the mummy had been a scholar and a member of Egypt's priestly class who died in his early 20s. Since then, the mummy had been wrapped in plastic and stored in a wooden crate. After its surprise appearance in Abel's room, it was returned to its climate-controlled resting place in a campus building.

DOC.HEAD: No Concessions Until Conditions Are Met, Says Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela today reiterated that the African National Congress will not hold talks with the South African government until South Africa's white leaders meet long-standing conditions. Those conditions include lifting the 3{-year-old state of emergency and a general amnesty for exiles selected to take part in preliminary talks with South African President F.W. de Klerk. ``The simple position is that until South Africa complies with the preconditions we have set, the ANC is not in the same position as the National Party'' of de Klerk, Mandela told reporters after meeting with seven African presidents and Commonwealth leaders in Lusaka. Whatever political or security problems the government faces in South Africa, the ANC ``cannot be expected to make any concessions,'' he said. Mandela was on the second day of a visit to Zambia, where he met with exiled ANC leaders at their external headquarters. It was his first trip out of South Africa since a clandestine border crossing in 1962. Later that year, Mandela was jailed for plotting against the South African government. He was freed Feb. 11. De Klerk legalized the ANC Feb. 2, but Mandela demanded a general amnesty for ANC exiles to prevent them from being prosecuted if they entered South Africa to take part in talks. He said the legalization of the ANC might not protect all exiles from prosecution for certain offenses. The refusal to accommodate the ANC demands showed ``it is quite clear the government is not yet prepared to meet us,'' Mandela said. Mandela compared the situation of South Africa's black majority to that of Palestinians in Israel, saying: ``We live under a unique form of colonialism in South Africa as well as in Israel.'' He defended his support of PLO leader Yasser Arafat, who arrived in Zambia on Tuesday to meet with him, and also defended the ANC's support of continued economic sanctions against the South Africa government to pressure it to lift apartheid. Britian's unilateral decision to lift an investment ban will be taken up directly by the ANC with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, he said. Thatcher has argued that sanctions hurt South Africa's blacks the most, and she said easing sanctions would encourage de Klerk to press ahead with reforms. President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, one of the ANC's staunchest suporters, said Mandela met with leaders of the six black African Frontline nations surrounding South Africa, and with members of a nine-nation committee on Southern Africa set up by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth leaders and the Frontline nations _ Angola, Botswana, Mozambique, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe _ endorsed the ANC's policy on economic sanctions and agreed there should be no immediate easing of punitive measures. Mandela is on an 18-day, four-nation tour that will also take him to Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Sweden.

DOC.HEAD: Eight-Eight Killed in Election Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with early returns. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Preliminary returns indicated that the governing National Front coalition and a Hindu fundamentalist group gained seats in elections for eight state legislatures, news reports said today. At least 88 people were reported killed in violence related to the voting. Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, which had controlled all eight legislatures suffered heavy losses in Tuesday's balloting, the early returns indicated. The Congress Party won only seven of the 33 races decided, United News of India said. A total of 1,610 seats were at stake. Widespread fraud was reported in the balloting, and the federal Election Commission said that voting was repeated in 400 election centers today because of the violence and ballot-stuffing. Tuesday's elections were seen as a test of whether Prime Minister V.P. Singh, Gandhi's successor, could consolidate the gains made by his National Front coalition in November's parliamentary elections. They were also a test for the increasingly popular Hindu fundamentalists, the Indian People's Party. United News of India said four people were killed today in Haryana state when police opened fire on a crowd protesting alleged vote fraud. On Tuesday, 84 people were killed and 250 injured in violence set off by the voting, eight in the eastern state of Bihar. At least two people were killed in western Gujarat, the Times of India said. An election official died of a heart attack during the voting in the northern state of Himachal Pradesh. Bihar, India's poorest state, is notorious for its organized criminal gangs, which appear to multiply during elections. Many candidates seek their support and privately acknowledge the gangs can achieve more successful results than traditional canvassing. The latest killings raised to 102 the number of deaths in election violence since the campaign began Jan. 24. At least 150 million voters cast their ballots Tuesday to elect legislatures in eight of India's 25 states. About 213 million voters were registered for the polls in Arunachal Pradesh, Bihar, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Orissa and Rajasthan states spanning the breadth of India's diverse geography from the western deserts to the foothills and mountains of the northern Himalayas. Elections were also held for 30 constituencies in Pondicherry, a federally administered territory in the south. They were also held in five national parliamentary constituencies and 17 other state assembly constituencies where elections were either countermanded or byelections were due. United News of India said the right-wing Indian People's Party was ``maintaining comfortable leads'' in Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan, while the National Front ``continued to consolidate its position in Orissa.'' The Hindu group supports the National Front government but is running its own candidates in some elections. In Gujarat, the National Front and Indian People's Party were leading in 128 of the state's 182 constituencies where results were available. A pre-election survey, published in the latest issue of the influential magazine ``Sunday,'' said the Congress Party was likely to be voted out of power in all eight states. Political analysts say the Congress Party will face large-scale defections after the elections.

DOC.HEAD: East German Mark Surges As Free Electiosn Draw Near
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to CORRECT exchange rate. Pickup 4th, `The dire...'
DOC.TEXT: Predictions of imminent doom for the East German economy have fallen off in recent days as March 18 elections draw nearer and the country's currency surges against the powerful West German mark. Boosted by expectations of a favorable exchange rate once the West German currency becomes legal tender in both countries, the East mark rocketed by as much as 30 percent in black market trading Tuesday to 21.50 West German marks for every 100 East marks, currency traders in West Germany and Austria said. Before West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced plans Feb. 6 to fuse the two German economies in a monetary union as a first step to political unification, the unofficial traders paid out only 14 to 18 West German marks for each 100 East marks. The dire predictions prompted Bonn to offer monetary union and accelerate political unification. Explaining the East Mark's surge, Reinhard Pohl, a monetary expert at the German Economic Research Institute in West Berlin said some West Germans have been trading their convertible Deutschmarks at the favorable black-market rate of about five to one, then giving the East German marks to relatives or friends in East Germany in hopes they can be traded back at one- or two-to-one after currency union. Bonn officials have sought to discount speculation that West Germany's central bank would buy East Germans' estimated 17 billion marks of savings at a one-to-one ratio, but no final decision is expected on the exchange rate until after the elections. A one-to-one exchange would cost West Germany billions and raise the possibility of high inflation, something that postwar West Germany has worked to avoid. Nevertheless, many West Germans consider drastic economic assistance for East Germany necessary to staunch the flow of thousands of East Germans to the West. The immigrants have strained West German housing and social services. On Tuesday, a small East German party backed by Kohl's Christian Democratic Union called for postponement of the vote because it said election rules hadn't been released in time to allow a fair fight for the 400 parliamentary seats to be decided. The rules were printed and made available to bookstores Friday but did not appear in newspapers. The German Social Union is a member of a conservative coalition that originally pushed for East Germany's first free elections to be advanced from the original date of May 6, in part out of fear that neither the Communist-led government nor the economy could hold out that long. Some larger parties, including the Communists, have political networks with offices, telephones, vehicles and other advantages not available to new groups that have sprung up since a peaceful popular revolt toppled hard-line Communist leaders last fall. Even so, the clear leader is the Social Democratic Party, founded less than five months ago and supported by a sister party that is West Germany's main opposition. Polls of East German voters predict the Social Democrats will get at least 50 percent if the elections are held on March 18. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union supports the German Social Union, East Germany's Christian Democrats and the Democratic Awakening, which are joined in conservative alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Says He Won't Give Up on Armenian Resolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name to Sungar sted Sangar in 11th graf, In Ankara
DOC.TEXT: Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole says he's not giving up his effort to gain approval of a measure to mark the deaths of hundreds of thousands of Armenians during in the reign of the Ottoman Empire. The Kansas Republican, who lost a second procedural vote in the Senate, said Tuesday that he might introduce the controversial resolution in another form. The measure, which designates April 24 as ``National Day of Remembrance of the 75th anniversary of the Armenian genocide of 1915-1923,'' has created a firestorm in Turkey, where officials strenuously object to the use of the word genocide. The Turkish government praised the setback to the resolution. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., waged a filibuster against the resolution last week, arguing the measure could seriously jeopardize U.S. relations with Turkey. The Senate refused by a 51-48 vote to cut off debate. Dole said Americans of Armenian heritage deserved to be recognized for their suffering, and called the resolution a human rights issue. The alleged genocide occurred before the birth of the Republic of Turkey. Armenians say 1.5 million were killed because of their race. Turkish officials dispute the alleged genocide. They say some 600,000 people, including Muslims and Christians were killed in the turbulent times because of civil strife and marauding bands. The Bush administration opposed the resolution, but Dole said Tuesday that White House officials would not object to softening the language in the measure and making it a concurrent resolution. Bush would not have to sign such a measure. In Ankara today, Murat Sungar, spokesman for the Turkish Foreign Ministry, praised the Senate's action, saying: ``We note with appreciation the fact that an important number of the esteemed senators acted with composure, prudence and foresight, refusing to condone the distortion of historical realities.'' Sungar said that adoption of the measure ``would have negative effects on bilateral ties as well as shaking the stability of the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares March 1-7 Quarter Horse Week
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a proclamation today designating March 1-7 as National Quarter Horse Week. ``This horse is uniquely ours, having been developed in colonial America and bred for speed,'' said Bush. ``No other horse is a greater part of Western folklore, and none has contributed more to our nation's development and cultural heritage,'' the president said in his proclamation. The American Quarter Horse Association, founded by a group of ranchers in the Southwest, is marking its 50th anniversary on March 15. Its registry of horses now numbers more than 2.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes Fell 2.2 Percent Last Month
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes fell 2.2 percent last month, pulled down by higher mortgage interest rates combined with the usual January buying lull, a real estate trade group reported today. The National Association of Realtors said January sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.48 million units, the slowest since last August's 3.44 million rate. Interest rates rose from 9.83 percent to 10.05 percent last month, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. ``The rate rise made a dent, in high-end and less-expensive markets,'' said Realtors President Norman D. Flynn, who also noted that the beginning of a year is generally a slow home sales period. NAR chief economist John A. Tuccillo said a big increase in sales is unlikely in the coming months because of the mortgage rates, but added that ``as rates taper off in the spring, we expect sales to pick up, mainly in markets offering moderately priced homes.'' The national median price for existing single-family homes last month was $96,200, up 4 percent from December and 7.1 percent from January 1989. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. The South was the only region posting an increase in sales in January, up 0.7 percent to 1.40 million units. The median price there was $86,300. The biggest decline in sales was in the West, where the 540,000-unit pace was 11.5 percent below the December rate. The median price was $144,000, up 7 percent from January 1989 but a smaller increase than recent annual price hikes in the region. ``The high priced, high-volume markets on California's West Coast cooled down,'' Tuccillo said. Sales in the Northeast were down 3.4 percent to 560,000 units. The median price there was $147,100, prompting Tuccillo to observe that ``high-cost areas in the Northeast remain sluggish and this likely will continue through the year.'' The Midwest resale rate of 960,000 units was 2 percent below the December pace. The median price there was $74,6000.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Casts Doubt on Israel Accepting U.S. Peace Proposals
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir will probably reject U.S.-backed compromises aimed at starting peace talks with Palestinians because of stiff resistance within his Likud bloc, Vice Premier Shimon Peres said today. Peres, the head of the left-leaning Labor Party, spoke in an interview amid a widening rebellion against Shamir by hard-liners in his right-wing bloc. Former Industry Minister Ariel Sharon, who quit the Cabinet two weeks ago to protest Shamir's policies, has threatened to convene Likud's decision-making Central Committee next week without the prime minister's consent. Other Likud lawmakers said they would support a vote of no confidence against Shamir if he agrees to a U.S.-backed formula that would include Palestinians from east Jerusalem or Palestinian deportees in peace talks. Asked if he thought Shamir could overcome the differences and move Middle East peace efforts ahead by accepting compromises proposed by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Peres said: ``I have my doubts.'' Baker has been attempting to bridge differences between Israel and Palestinians over the composition of a Palestinian delegation for preliminary peace talks in Cairo. The talks are to focus on Israel's plan for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip that would lead to limited self-rule for 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied lands. Hundreds of Palestinians and about 40 Israelis have been killed during the last 27 months in a Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the territories. Peres, whose party agrees to Baker's suggestions, has given Shamir a March 7 deadline to approve them. ``We are nearing the real decision now.'' Peres said. ``In a week or so we shall see what is happening.'' He described the current crisis as ``more serious than previous ones'' and added: ``From the Likud point of view, they have reached the point where they have to make up their mind.'' Peres indicated that Labor would leave its coalition with Likud and try to form a new government with smaller religious and left-wing parties if Likud continues to balk at peace efforts. Asked whether he was ready to form a new Cabinet, Peres said, ``Maybe, I don't exclude it.'' The Hadashot daily quoted Peres as telling party activists Tuesday he could put together a narrow government within 10 days if Shamir's government falls. Peres also told The Associated Press that if he forms a new government, he will continue to back the Israeli elections plan rather seek a new peace formula. ``If there was a new government it would stay with the current approach,'' Peres said. Baker's compromise on the composition of a Palestinian delegation calls for including Palestinians from east Jerusalem and some deported by Israel in preliminary Cairo peace talks, Israeli newspapers said. They also call for Egypt to announce the names of the delegates and for the agenda to be left open to allow Palestinians to bring up subjects other than the elections. Including Palestinians from east Jerusalem has been a major sticking point for Likud, which fears such a move would undercut Israel's claim to the entire mixed Jewish-Arab city as its capital. Israel annexed the Arab sector after capturing it from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. ``I'm not sure east Jerusalem is the only issue,'' Peres said. ``They (Likud) think it's the wrong way to go.'' Likud fears that some of the proposals could lead to indirect involvement by the PLO, which Israel considers a terrorist organization. It also opposes any land-for-peace settlement, which the United States and Labor would accept.

DOC.HEAD: Fires Rage in Corsica as Storm Toll in Europe Rises to 53
DOC.TEXT: Brush fires driven by high winds burned on this Mediterranean island today, but the Atlantic storm that raked Europe and killed at least 53 people began losing strength over most of France. In eastern Nancy, a motorist died when he was blown off an icy road late Tuesday into an electricity pylon. The 74 mph winds that struck northern France on Monday reached the Mediterranean Tuesday, turning small fires on the sun-parched island into major conflagrations. Firefighters evacuated 800 people late Tuesday from the villages of Folelli and Moriani-Place as flames neared their communities. Residents returned home early today as the blazes were brought under control. But new fires broke out at Valle D'Alsani de Zuani, Poleroso, Santa Maria Di Lota and Farinole. Winds estimated at 93 mph prevented aircraft in Marseille from aiding firefighters on the ground. Many islanders remained without electricity or telephone service. Conditions, meanwhile, returned to relative calm in northern France, with winds dying to 56 mph in Normandy and floodwaters rolling back from some coastal areas. In Britain, raging seas whipped up by the storm surged through a shattered sea wall and swamped homes in Towyn, Wales on Tuesday. Rescue workers wearing rubber wet suits and traveling in flat-bottom boats helped evacuate 2,000 residents stranded by water five feet deep. Twenty-five people were hospitalized for treatment of hypothermia, and some people who ventured out to retrieve belongings from their homes had to be rescued by helicopter as the tide rose along the north coast of Wales. The storm knocked a hole 2,000 feet long in the century-old sea wall. Fifty-three deaths have been reported in Europe since the storm struck Monday: 17 in Britain, 12 in West Germany and three in East Germany, 11 in France, five in Belgium, two in Switzerland and one each in Ireland, Italy and the Netherlands. In Switzerland, violent winds disrupted rail and road traffic and caused widespread tree damage and power outages Tuesday, authorities said. On Jungfraujoch, 11,340 feet up the Bernese Oberland, winds reached 140 mph. The main north-south rail link through the Gotthard tunnel was interrupted, as were many other sections of the Swiss electrified network because overhead lines were cut. Swiss radio said it was the worst blow to rail traffic in decades. It said that even in the region of Zurich, Switzerland's most populous city, winds blew at up to 92 mph. In the north of Britain, driving snow and 120 mph winds hampered efforts to reach an injured climber, later found dead in his survival bag. Throughout Britain, volunteers and rescuers faced similar perils, exacerbated by power outages affecting 40,000 homes, road and rail disruptions and fears of sewage contamination and gas leaks caused by damaged pipes. A 32-year-old West German man and his 6-year-old son were feared drowned today after their dinghy was found capsized by the storm off a southern Denmark island on Monday, police in Copenhagen said. The two had gone fishing near Nordborg on the island of Als. Police abandoned the search for the bodies of the two, who were not identified, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Up 0.9 Percent in Fourth Quarter, 3 Percent for Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf, An inflation, to CORRECT inflation increase to 4.5 percent for the year and provide quarterly revision from 3.8 percent to 3.6 percent
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy grew by 0.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989, faster than previously estimated but still the slowest pace in more than three years, the government said today. The Commerce Department said its revised estimate of October-December growth means the gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ rose 3 percent for all of 1989. That was the slowest yearly advance since a 2.7 percent gain in 1986 and followed a 4.4 percent increase in 1988. The fourth-quarter gain was stronger than the initial report last month of 0.5 percent growth, but was still the lowest since a 0.8 percent advance in the third quarter of 1986. A consensus of economists had indicated in advance of the new report that fourth-quarter growth would be lowered to 0.4 percent. The improvement should ease fears the economy had entered a downturn at year's end, although there is considerable anxiety over the months ahead. The department will make one more revision in the GNP _ the broadest measure of the nation's economic health _ after more solid information is available next month. A recession usually is defined as two consecutive quarterly declines in the GNP. The last decline was a one-quarter drop of 1.8 percent in 1986, after which the economy resumed growth. The last recession occurred in 1981-82. Since then, the economic expansion has continued for 87 months and in November broke the peacetime growth record. If it continues through October 1991, it will set a new overall record. An inflation index tied to the GNP rose 4.5 percent last year, the report said. The fourth-quarter figure was revised downward from the 3.8 percent annual rate reported initially to 3.6 percent today. Some economists, including Chairman Michael Boskin of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, had attributed the sluggishness in the fourth quarter in part to the effects of the fourth coldest December on record, Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake. Most of the upward revision was attributed to a better-than-anticipated trade performance. The December trade deficit was not available when the advance GNP estimate was made. The new report said exports climbed at an annual rate of 8.6 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with the advance estimate of 4.9 percent. Imports grew by 2 percent in the revised report instead of 7.5 percent first reported. Business inventories, meanwhile, were lowered from an initial 48.9 percent increase to a 19.6 percent gain today. Other changes included personal consumption, up 0.4 percent rather than the 0.1 percent decline first reported. But business investment declined 6.4 percent in the latest estimate, compared with a 3 percent decline in the first. Despite the improvement in fourth-quarter growth, several jolts from recent economic indicators have prompted some analysts to question whether the nation's manufacturing economy will be able to avoid further deterioration this year and whether it will spread to other areas. ``There is just not any evidence that the manufacturing sector has any strength,'' said Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``The question is whether this weakness in manufacturing will spread to other sectors of the economy.'' The latest jolt to the current quarter's growth was the Commerce Department's report on Tuesday that orders to U.S. factories for durable goods plummeted 10.5 percent last month in their steepest fall in 32 years of government recordkeeping. ``The report signifies an ongoing recession for a chunk of the U.S. manufacturing sector,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co. ``The sharp decline is another sign we'll see virtually no real economic growth in the first quarter,'' added Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. ``You've got pockets of recession in sectors such as automobiles surrounded by an absence of activity in the economy in general.'' Less than two weeks ago, the Commerce Department reported that industrial production in January fell 1.2 percent, its largest drop since falling 1.3 percent four years earlier. The economic weakness has prompted the Bush administration and many economists to urge the Federal Reserve to permit interest rates to fall further and thus stimulate the economy. The central bank has kept a tight rein on credit for a year in an attempt to drive down inflation. But the government reported last week that consumer prices rose a hefty 1.1 percent last month, the largest advance since a 1.4 percent gain 10 years ago, and Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan indicated in congressional testimony that the central bank is unlikely to loosen its grip soon. The Fed's tight-money policy is blamed for economic growth slowing from 3 percent during the third quarter of 1989. However, two recent surveys indicate optimism that, while economic activity will continue to be sluggish this year, the economy will avoid sliding into a recession. Eighty-two percent of the executives questioned in a National Association of Manufacturers' poll said 1990 will produce slow growth but no recession. And 60.6 percent of the professional forecasters surveyed by the National Association of Business Economists said they believe the economy will avoid a recession for the next three years. But, the latter survey found, ``the economy is in a danger zone'' and ``the probability of a recession is not trivial.''

DOC.HEAD: DC Mayor Pleads Innocent to Drug Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 3rd graf, The mayor's, with 4 grafs of courtroom color and comment from U.S. attorney; inserts new 11th graf, Mundy said, with wife not attending; subs pvs 11th graf to conform
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry pleaded innocent today to cocaine possession and perjury charges filed after a 14-month investigation of his ties to a convicted drug dealer. At the brief hearing, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson set June 4 for the trial on three felony charges of lying to a grand jury and five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges. Barry, dressed in a grey suit, white shirt and burgundy tie, sat frowning at the defense table as he read over the indictment. He then sat expressionless as his attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, entered the innocent pleas. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said in a statement after the hearing that his office was proceeding with a related grand jury investigation into city government corruption. Mundy said in a statement outside the courthouse that Barry was ``anticipating the trial and anticipating winning the trial.'' The lawyer said there would be no plea bargaining and Barry would not resign from public office. ``There is no reason for him to resign. In our democratic system, an accused person is guaranteed the presumption of innocence until proven guilty,'' he added. Barry, who has denied ever using cocaine or other drugs, has been undergoing treatment at substance abuse centers in Florida and South Carolina for what aides have said is alcoholism. Mundy said the mayor's treatment for alcoholism was ``going well'' and Barry was in ``good spirits.'' Barry entered the courthouse through a side door and held up two fingers in a ``victory'' sign. Extraordinary security procedures were in effect. Reporters and photographers were moved across the street to allow Barry free access to the courthouse. Mundy said he advised Barry's wife, Effi, not to attend the hearing, and she did not. Barry and his wife had difficulty entering the building for a court appearance on Jan. 19, the day after he was arrested, because of a crush of reporters and camera crews. Several members of the Guardian Angels, an anti-crime-patrol group, carried signs calling for Barry's resignation outside the courthouse today. One sign read, ``Do The Right Thing _ Resign.'' Barry arrived in the nation's capital Tuesday from the Fenwick Hall hospital outside Charleston, S.C., where he is enrolled in a substance abuse treatment program. The charges stem from an investigation into Barry's ties to a convicted drug dealer. One possession charge involved the mayor's Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation at a downtown Washington hotel. City Corporation Counsel Herbert O. Reid said Barry would return to Fenwick Hall hospital after his court appearance. Mundy refused to comment when he arrived at Barry's office for a meeting with top city officials late Tuesday. He declined to say who he was meeting with, but sources said Mundy, City Administrator Carol B. Thompson and Barry Chief of Staff Maudine Cooper met for almost an hour. None of the three would comment afterward. The mayor's arraignment date was postponed from Feb. 21 after his attorney argued that the first appearance date would interfere with the Florida substance abuse treatment program in which the mayor was enrolled. Barry moved to the South Carolina facility last week. The grand jury that indicted him met Tuesday, but handled other matters and did not review the mayor's case, sources familiar with the proe said. Last week, prosecutors subpoenaed city records relating to eight close friends of the mayor's, and sources close to the probe say investigators are trying to learn whether the mayor participated in any contracting irregularities or whether any of his friends skirted city contracting law in getting contracts. Last month, Stephens said the FBI sting operation that netted the mayor was part of a ``broad, ongoing probe'' into allegations of wrongdoing involving both Barry and various city services. If convicted of all charges filed against him, the mayor could face a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $1.25 million fine.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Approve Bill Allowing Peasants to Lease Land
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature today overwhelmingly approved a bill that would allow citizens to lease land and bequeath it to their children for the first time since peasants were stripped of their farms under Stalin. The legislature first voted on each chapter of the 52-article law separately and then approved the entire law 349-7, with 12 abstentions. It is part of a package of measures designed to give force of law to the economic and social reforms championed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The official Tass news agency called it ``a major legal document of Soviet economic reform.'' According to the current Soviet Constitution, all land in the Soviet Union is the property of the state. The government hopes that if this is changed to allow peasants on collective or state-owned farms to acquire their own plots, productivity on that land will increase. Productivity on state-owned and collective farms currently is notoriously low. The Congress of People's Deputies, the Supreme Soviet's parent body, will be asked to amend the constitution to incorporate the new law when it meets March 12. Today's four-hour session was the third time the Supreme Soviet considered the Law on Land. During debate on the bill earlier this month, about 150 proposals and criticisms were made. Alexander Nikonov, president of the Soviet Agricultural Academy, who submitted the bill said about 40 percent of the original draft had been revised. The law states that land is the property of the people living on a given territory and that every Soviet citizen has the right to a piece of land. Land would be distributed by collective farms or, in the case of city dwellers or other who wanted to hold land, by local officials. The land would not actually be purchased, but leased, and selling it would be illegal, according to the law. Plots would be subject to taxes but could be bequeathed to the holder's children. The state would set land prices. Supreme Soviet deputy Pavel Bunich, an economist, said a nationwide evaluation of the land would have to be carried out before any distribution could begin. He said he was concerned that local governments would make available only undesirable land. The law represents a major step forward in wresting control of the land from the state. The Bolsheviks socialized land in 1918 which took away holdings from many city dwellers. Peasants were allowed to keep land until the brutal policy of collectivization went into effect in the late 1920s. Millions of peasants died in labor camps or of famine as a result of Stalin's collectivization plan, which crippled Soviet agriculture. In action Tuesday, the legislature approved by a wide margin the creation of a much stronger Soviet presidency, an office Gorbachev is widely expected to hold. Subject to final approval by the Congress of People's Deputies, the president will be granted powers to veto laws, unilaterally declare states of emergency, and name the prime minister, according to a copy of the bill shown to Western reporters. Gorbachev, who chaired the legislature's proceedings, emphasized he has not yet been elected president and said he has even considered refusing the office, but few expect the 58-year-old Communist Party chief not to be chosen. According to Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov, the Supreme Soviet is to meet in closed session on Thursday to discuss the ethnic conflict between the two Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan, now in its third year.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Gets Grants for Scaled-down Nuclear Reactors
DOC.TEXT: The federal government and a utilities group are providing $93 million to Westinghouse Electric Corp. for a project to develop smaller, simpler nuclear plants by 1999. The Energy Department on Tuesday granted Pittsburgh-based Westinghouse $50 million to develop blueprints that will be submitted to the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission for approval. Electric utilities are chipping in $43 million, said Jack Berga, a lobbyist with the Electric Power Research Institute in Washington, D.C. While environmentalists and coal producers dispute that the scaled-down plants will reduce cost and safety concerns about nuclear power, Westinghouse portrays the project, which it began in 1984, as getting back to basics. ``This goes back to our first principles of plant design for the nuclear Navy. They were simple, designed to be run by sailors,'' said Richard Slember, director of the Westinghouse's energy unit in Monroeville, 15 miles east of Pittsburgh. High costs and construction delays are keeping electric utilities out of the nuclear power industry, Slember said. The new plants will cost about $2 billion, one-third less than existing facilities, he said. Westinghouse said its plants will take three years to build. Construction of existing plants has taken as long as 17 years. ``The plants are economic, reliable, long-lived and _ to use a computer term _ user-friendly,'' said Berga. Westinghouse's plans for the new reactors, called AP600s, fall in line with those of President Bush, an Energy Department official said. ``The president has indicated that nuclear power must play a critical role in meeting our energy needs. The nuclear option can restore viability by the end of this decade,'' said David McGoff, a deputy secretary in the department's nuclear division. Not so, said a spokesman for American coal producers. ``Nuclear power can't do it by itself,'' National Coal Association spokesman John Grasser said from Washington, D.C. ``And I don't see any major rush on the part of utility producers to get off of fossil fuels. ... Yeah, we believe in nuclear power, but it's only one piece among a lot of pieces.'' The Westinghouse plants would employ 200 to 300 people, Slember said. They would use 60 percent fewer valves and 60 percent less piping. Slember said they also would be safer than current plants, because ``the AP600 is less susceptible to the kind of errors human operators make.'' Judith Johnsrud, director of the Environmental Coalition on Nuclear Power, a Pennsylvania group based in State College, said, ``The new plants may be termed inherently safe, but the wastes they generate are inherently unsafe.'' Federal regulators expect Westinghouse to submit its plant design sometime this year, spokesman John Kopeck said from NRC offices in Bethesda, Md. He said licensing of subsequent plants could be sped up if a standardized design plan is approved. The commission approved the last new U.S. nuclear plant in 1978, Kopeck said. There are 112 nuclear reactors operating in the United States, he said. Westinghouse's new plants would be capable of producing 600 megawatts, or enough power for a city of about 600,000 people. Most nuclear plants supply from 900 to 1,100 megawatts.

DOC.HEAD: 5-Year-old Boy Who Drank Large Amount Of Bourbon Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old boy who drank 10 ounces of bourbon after an adult allegedly prompted him to do so ``like a man'' died this morning following his removal from life support systems, authorities said. Everman Police Sgt. Mark Bigler said Thomas Griffin died at Cook-Fort Worth Children's Medical Center at about 8:45 a.m. The respirator supporting the youngster's breathing was disconnected at about 10 p.m. Tuesday, but the child had continued to breathe on his own. The hospital was not releasing further detail on the child at the parent's request. Police in suburban Everman said the boy was given the alcohol at a party Friday night and ``told to drink it like a man.'' Anthony Jimerson, 21, of Forest Hills was being held in the Tarrant County Jail in lieu of $100,000 bail after being charged with injury to a child, officials said. There was no immediate word on whether the charges would be changed in light of the boy's death. The boy was taken to the hospital Saturday afternoon after he went into convulsions, Everman Police Sgt. Mark Bigler said. At one point, the boy's blood-alcohol level was about .55 percent, Bigler said. The minimum level to be considered legally intoxicated in most states is less than one-fifth that. Doctors said he would probably have suffered irreversible brain damage, the officer said. At the time the boy drank the liquor, Jimerson was visiting the Fort Worth-area apartment of Raymond's mother, Patricia Griffin, 31, police said. It was not clear today whether Ms. Griffin knew that the boy was being given the alcohol, or whether she found out about the drinking after the boy began having convulsions.

DOC.HEAD: Court Gives Police New Power to Conduct Searches in Private Homes
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today gave police broad new power to conduct sweeping searches after making arrests in private homes. By a 7-2 vote, the justices said the police may use evidence seized when they arrested a Maryland man, Jerome Buie, accused of armed robbery. The ruling reinstated Buie's conviction and 35-year prison sentence. Justice Byron R. White, writing for the court, said police may search throughout a house when they have a reasonable suspicion there is a hidden danger to the arresting officers _ even if the authorities lack a search warrant and probable cause to believe there is a danger. White said the Constitution ``permits a properly limited protective sweep in conjunction with an in-home arrest when the searching officer possesses a reasonable belief based on specific and articulable facts that the area to be swept harbors an individual posing a danger to those on the arrest scene.'' Prince George's County police investigating the Feb. 3, 1986, armed robbery of a restaurant obtained arrest warrants for Buie and Lloyd Allen. A half-dozen police officers went to Buie's home in Riverdale two days after the robbery to arrest him. After entering the home, they looked for him on the first and second floors. One officer went to the basement stairs and yelled for anyone who might be down there to come out. Buie eventually emerged and climbed the basement stairs to be searched, handcuffed and arrested by the officers. At that point, another officer descended the stairs to the basement where he saw a red running suit, similar to one a victim of the robbery said was worn by one of the holdup men. The suit was introduced as evidence that helped convict Buie. The Maryland Court of Appeals, the state's highest, ordered a new trial for Buie. By a 4-3 vote, the state court said Buie's rights protected by the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution were violated because police lacked a search warrant and probable cause to search the basement. Before today, police making arrests generally were allowed to conduct such protective searches only of the area within a suspect's reach. Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented today. Brennan, writing for both, said the ruling gives police too much discretion to search ``the special sanctity of a private residence.'' ``Police officers searching for potential ambushers might ... open up closets, lockers, chests, wardrobes and cars, and peer under beds and behind furniture,'' Brennan said. Even personal letters and documents could be inspected, he said. The case is Maryland vs. Buie, 88-1369.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Protesters Arrested At Clinic
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 members of an anti-abortion group held an Ash Wednesday demonstration today at a Planned Parenthood clinic and 59 were arrested, police said. Police carried away protesters who refused to leave the scene of the demonstration by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Pro Life Coalition for Non-violent Direct Action, according to police Officer Jean Wallace. She said the protesters who were arrested would be charged with disorderly conduct and could face fines up to $200. A spokeswoman for the clinic, Frances Sheehan, said the protest delayed the opening of the clinic by about one hour. She said no appointments were canceled, but patients with morning appointments were taken by staff members to other nearby clinics. ``It was a very standard Ash Wednesday protest,'' Ms. Sheehan said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Confirms 1975 Attempted Mutiny on Warship
DOC.TEXT: The government newspaper Izvestia confirmed Western news reports of an attempted mutiny aboard a Soviet naval ship in 1975 that Tom Clancy used as the basis of his bestseller, ``The Hunt for Red October.'' The book is about an officer aboard a Soviet nuclear sub on a secret mission who decides to defect to the West, taking the vessel with him. In the book, which was made into a movie to be released next month, Soviet naval forces chase the sub and U.S. forces try to give it safe passage to the United States. In Washington, Clancy said today he was contacted by an Izvestia reporter, who told him the imminent release of the ``Red October'' movie gave the Soviet government an excuse to acknowledge ``the incident really did take place.'' On Tuesday, a military prosecutor's office admitted the anti-submarine ship Storozhevoi tried to escape to Sweden in November 1975, the news agency Tass quoted Izvestia as saying. According to the office, the ship's deputy commanding officer, Capt. 3rd rank Valery Sablin, led the attempted mutiny, the newspaper said. His plan was to commandeer the Storozhevoi after isolating the commanding officer and other officers and deceiving the crew into obeying his orders, Izvestia said. The newspaper said Sablin was able to get the ship across the Soviet border in the Baltic Sea 21 miles toward Swedish territorial waters. But his plan fell through when the Storozhevoi was intercepted and returned to base, the newspaper said. It was not known whether any crew members supported the mutiny. Izvestia quoted the military prosecutor's office as saying breaking the oath of enlistment, commandeering a naval ship, removing it from subordination to the naval command and refusing to obey orders are grave military crimes and betrayals of one's homeland. Sablin was tried by the Supreme Court's military wing, found guilty and sentenced to death by firing squad, according to Isvestia. The report did not specify whether the sentence was carried out.

DOC.HEAD: Court Gives US Agents More Power to Conduct Searches in Foreign Countries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes garble
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today bolstered the fight against international drug trafficking and terrorism by giving U.S. law enforcement agents more power to conduct searches in foreign countries. In another decision, it gave police broad new power to conduct sweeping searches after making arrests in private homes. And in a third ruling, the court upheld Pennsylvania's death penalty laws, removing a threat to similar laws in 13 other states. By a 6-3 vote, the justices said U.S. agents did not need a court warrant to search the home of a suspected Mexican drug smuggler later convicted in the killing of a federal drug agent. The ruling gives U.S. law enforcement officials broad authority to conduct warrantless searches abroad of non-U.S. citizens. The Constitution's Fourth Amendment ban on illegal searches does not apply to non-citizens outside U.S. borders, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. ``Situations threatening to important American interests may arise halfway around the globe ... (that) require an American response with armed force,'' Rehnquist said. ``If there are to be restrictions on searches and seizures which occur incident to such American action, they must be imposed by the political branches through diplomatic understanding, treaty or legislation.'' The dissenters said the ruling may cause disrespect here and abroad for U.S. laws and constitutional protections. ``When we tell the world that we expect all people, wherever they may be, to abide by our laws, we cannot in the same breath tell the world that our law enforcement officers need not do the same,'' said Justice William J. Brennan in a dissent joined by Justice Thurgood Marshall. Justice Harry A. Blackmun also dissented. In the domestic search case, the justices ruled 7-2 that the police may use evidence seized when they arrested a Maryland man accused of armed robbery. The ruling reinstated Jerome Buie's conviction and 35-year prison sentence. Justice Byron R. White, writing for the court, said police may search throughout a house when they have a reasonable suspicion there is a hidden danger to the arresting officers _ even if the authorities lack a search warrant and probable cause to believe there is a danger. In the death penalty case, the justices ruled that Pennsylvania's laws do not limit improperly the discretion of sentencing juries and are not impermissibly mandatory.
