The decision removes a threat that existed for similar death penalty laws in Arizona, California, Connecticut, Idaho, Illinois, Maryland, Montana, New Jersey, Ohio, Oregon, Tennessee, Texas and Washington. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the court, said states enjoy wide latitude in drawing capital-punishment laws. ``The fact that other states have enacted different forms of death penalty statutes which also satisfy constitutional requirements casts no doubt on Pennsylvania's choice,'' Rehnquist said. The international search ruling could have a bearing on the government's prosecution of Manuel Antonio Noriega, the ousted Panamanian leader who faces drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges from a 12-count indictment handed down in February 1988. After U.S. troops invaded Panama in December to capture Noriega, he surrendered and was brought to the United States to stand trial in Florida. There has been speculation that Noriega's lawyers might argue U.S. armed forces illegally seized evidence in the invasion. The decision was hailed by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who said it ``recognizes the right and need of law enforcement officers to have lawful, practical means of dealing with international drug trafficking operations. ``This decision will clarify and assist our international cooperative law enforcement efforts, particularly in overseas drug cases. Drug traffickers and terrorists will take no cheer from the court's opinion,'' Thornburgh said. The U.S. military is seeking to become more involved in fighting drug smuggling by using spy satellites and other surveillance techniques to track suspects in foreign countries. The suspected drug smuggler in today's ruling, Rene Verdugo Urquidez, was convicted in Caifornia in 1988 of taking part in the 1985 kidnapping, torture and murder of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Verdugo, identified as a top lieutenant to reputed Mexican drug kingpin Rafael Caro Quintero, is serving a sentence of 240 years plus life. He is not eligible for parole for 59 years, when he would be 96. Verdugo's drug conviction and sentence in the killings were not at issue in the case decided today. The search warrant issue arose in a separate, although related, prosecution. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals suppressed evidence obtained by the DEA in its search of Verdugo's Mexicali, Mexico, home in 1988. Verdugo was arrested by Mexican police in 1986 and was turned over to U.S. authorities in California. While he was awaiting trial, the DEA got the cooperation of Mexican authorities to search the home. The agents seized a tally sheet they said shows the quantities of marijuana smuggled into the United States by Verdugo. A federal judge in California ruled that the evidence is not admissible because the U.S. agents failed to obtain a warrant in a U.S. court. The 9th Circuit court upheld the judge's decision, saying U.S. agents are not free to ignore the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution that protects against unreasonable government searches. The Bush administration argued that the DEA agents received assurances from Mexican government officials that the search was lawful there without a warrant. The DEA said requiring warrants in such cases could hamper its campaign against drug smugglers. It has offices in 45 nations. In 1988 alone, it said, it helped in investigations that led to 1,200 arrests of suspected drug smugglers in foreign countries. The case is U.S. vs. Verdugo-Urquidez, 88-1353.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Wednesday by the Supreme Court.
FOREIGN SEARCHES
The court bolstered the fight against international drug trafficking and terrorism by giving U.S. law enforcement agents more power to conduct searches in foreign countries. By a 6-3 vote, the justices said U.S. agents did not need a court warrant to search the home of a suspected Mexican drug smuggler later convicted in the killing of a federal drug agent. The ruling gives U.S. law enforcement officials broad authority to conduct warrantless searches abroad of non-U.S. citizens. The case is U.S. vs. Verdugo-Urquidez, 88-1353.
DOMESTIC SEARCHES
The court gave police broad new power to conduct sweeping searches after making arrests in private homes. By a 7-2 vote, the justices said the police may use evidence seized when they arrested a Maryland man, Jerome Buie, accused of armed robbery. The ruling reinstated Buie's conviction and 35-year prison sentence. Justice Byron R. White, writing for the court, said police may search throughout a house when they have a reasonable suspicion there is a hidden danger to the arresting officers _ even if the authorities lack a search warrant and probable cause to believe there is a danger. The case is Maryland vs. Buie, 88-1369.
DEATH PENALTY
The court upheld Pennsylvania's death penalty laws by a 5-4 vote. The justices ruled that the state's laws do not limit improperly the discretion of sentencing juries and are not impermissibly mandatory. The decision removes a threat to similar death penalty laws in 13 other states _ Arizona, California, Connecticut, Idaho, Illinois, Maryland, Montana, New Jersey, Ohio, Oregon, Tennessee, Texas and Washington. The case is Blystone vs. Pennsylvania, 88-6222.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. Feb. 27 Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal on the Nicaraguan election: A decade after a bloody revolution deposed an oppressive dictator and swept a band of Marxists into power, a peaceful revolution at the ballot box transferred the reins of power from their hands to the people. Nicaragua held surprises this week. Opposition candidate, now President-elect Violeta (Barrios de) Chamorro, the predicted loser, proved that the science of precision polling is not even an art in Nicaragua. More surprising is the grace with which President Daniel Ortega seems to have met his rebuff by the voters. Sunday's polling left its mark _ as an anti-fraud measure, voters' thumbs were marked with indelible green ink. May those green thumbs indicate that after a long fallow season Nicaraguans are growing a society that is as free and fair and productive as Sunday's returns.

Feb. 27 St. Louis Post-Dispatch on the Nicaraguan election: After almost 10 years of warfare and intense economic hardship, the people of Nicaragua have voted the Sandinistas out. ... The United States is indispensable to Nicaragua's economic recovery. The first step will be to stop supporting the Contras. That should mean that for the first time in years, Nicaraguans will not have to fear being killed by their countrymen. So far, 30,000 have died in the U.S.-sponsored guerrilla war. ... But there must be more. Washington can supply desperately needed economic aid and end the trade embargo. The reasons for (President Daniel) Ortega's defeat are undoubtedly numerous, but a major one surely is that the people had been worn down by the tremendous hardship imposed on them by the Reagan and Bush administrations. They knew that if Sandinista rule ended, U.S.-sponsored terrorism and economic deprivation would soon end. President Bush has proclaimed ... (Violeta Barrios de) Chamorro's election as a victory for democracy. It is rather a victory for oppression _ U.S. oppression. The United States defeated the Sandinistas at enormous cost to the people of Nicaragua. The United States, too, paid a high price: It betrayed its own human and constitutional values as it sought to maintain hegemony in Latin America. Now that the United States is about to have a government in Managua that it approves of, it has a serious moral obligation to undo the damage it has inflicted on that hapless country for so long and to try to restore its own self respect as well.

Feb. 27 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on the Nicaraguan election: What has often been forgotten should now be remembered: The principal opponents of the Sandinistas have not been one-time Somoza henchmen but Nicaraguans devoted to democratic change. ... (Violeta Barrios de) Chamorro, whose husband was killed in the battle against Somoza, is the symbol of her country's long struggle for freedom _ and, in recent years, its betrayal by the communist junta. Now, with some timely assistance from the United States _ including, we expect, the lifting of economic sanctions _ Nicaraguan democracy has air to breathe, and plenty of room to grow.

Feb. 27 The Wichita (Kan.) Eagle on the Nicaraguan election: The spirit of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro must be proud. The crusading newspaper editor's equally courageous widow, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, has won the presidency of Nicaragua in the first free and democratic elections ever held there. She did it against all the odds _ against a government that could marshal all the resources of a totalitarian state against her; against the collective wisdom of friend and enemy alike that said there was no way she could win. ``The Nicaraguan people have shown that they want to live in democracy, in peace and in freedom,'' Mrs. Chamorro said after her election. Whatever difficulties may lie ahead, now at last they'll have that chance.

Feb. 26 The Janesville (Wis.) Gazette on the airline smoking ban: Starting Sunday (Feb. 25), virtually all airline flights in the United States became smoke-free. Passengers now must wait as long as six hours for a smoke if they intend to fly the friendly skies. It's about time. Those of us who recognize the dangers of smoking (both directly and as inhalers of secondary smoke) should not have to put up with the smell of cigarettes while traveling in the much-too-close confines of an airplane. This commendable move is just the latest in a positive trend. Many workplaces are now completely off-limits to smokers. So are lots of public buildings. Most restaurants also make accommodations that allow their diners to enjoy their meals without smelling someone else's smoke. Sure, cigarette smokers should have the right to smoke. That right, however, should never infringe on the much more important right of non-smokers to breathe fresh air and avoid the medical risks posed by secondhand smoke.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Witness in Bensonhurst Case Missing
DOC.TEXT: An important prosecution witness in a racial killing has been missing since the first of the year, a district attorney confirmed today. Prosecutors will ask a judge to postpone a trial, scheduled to begin next week, unless witness John Vento is found before then, Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said at a news conference. However, if Vento is not found in a month the prosecution will go ahead without him, Hynes said. He called Vento important but not a key witness. ``We have a trial-ready case,'' Hynes said. ``I'm confident we have a substantial case.'' Vento told police he was one of the bat-wielding gang of young whites who confronted 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins and three other young blacks in the predominately white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, unidentified sources told the Daily News and New York Newsday, which initially reported Vento's absence today. Hynes said prosecutors learned early in January from Vento's family that he had ``taken off'' during the Christmas holidays. He said police and federal agents were looking for Vento in upstate New York and in Ohio, but declined to elaborate. Joseph Fama, 18, is accused of firing the shot that killed Hawkins. Vento accused Joseph Serrano, 19, of handing the murder weapon to Fama, and has connected several other youths to the slaying, the News reported. Unspecified charges against Vento were dropped last year after he signed an agreement with former Brooklyn District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman to testify. The agreement said charges could be reinstated if he failed to take the stand.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: secondhand smoke.
DOC.TEXT: Feb. 25 The Flint (Mich.) Journal on Reagan-Poindexter: ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ``I don't recall.'' ... And so on and so on. In all, former President Ronald Reagan uttered that phrase at least 124 times while under oath during eight hours of testimony regarding his involvement in the Iran-Contra affair _ a scandal that nearly destroyed his presidency. The nation's 40th president was testifying as a special defense witness in the trial of his former national security adviser, John M. Poindexter. Now, to be fair, some of the events he was asked about occurred years ago. Also, it is common for witnesses during depositions who cannot remember details precisely to claim, ``I don't recall.'' Finally, we must take into account that Reagan is now 79 years old and that as president he was involved in thousands of meetings and millions of documents. But he uttered ``I don't recall'' so many times it is certain to heighten suspicions of those who believe he is lying or trying to cover up details. And mixed in between his memory lapses are denials of wrongdoing that are in conflict with the claims of Poindexter, who says he had presidential authorization for everything he did during the incident. Reagan's testimony also did very little to alter the perception of him as a scripted actor dangerously detached from the presidency _ an executive who delegated far too much authority, paid far too little attention to detail and was blind to serious crimes being committed around him. It's a pity that this man, who stepped down from the most powerful office on Earth a little more than a year ago and who now commands millions of dollars in speaking fees for his thoughts and memoirs, is suffering such memory lapses. It would be a much greater shame if the American people never learned the entire truth about this serious constitutional crime called Iran-Contra.

Feb. 24 Post-Bulletin, Rochester, Minn., on Reagan-Poindexter: It is hard to give a charitable interpretation of former President Ronald Reagan's performance in his testimony in the case of John Poindexter. Poindexter, formerly director of the National Security Council under Reagan, is facing trial on charges of obstructing congressional inquiries into the sale of U.S. arms to Iran for providing support to the Contras in Nicaragua at a time when such support was banned by Congress. Most of the former president's answers consisted of ``I don't recall.'' He used that reply (about) 100 times in the course of (his videotaped) deposition. It would be easy to excuse the former president on the ground of his age, except that his performance was consistent with his record during eight years as president. There is no question that Reagan was relaxed and detached as a chief executive. We are now reaping the results of that sort of detachment in the savings and loan debacle, the HUD scandals, the debt crisis, and the trials of his former subordinates. When histories of the 20th century are written, Calvin Coolidge and Warren Harding may seem like astute and farsighted leaders compared to Ronald Reagan.

Feb. 21 The Hudson Dispatch, Union City, N.J., on drug-eating bugs: The Bush administration is working on a plan to develop caterpillars who love to chew on coca leaves. If this all works out, the insects could be scattered through the coca fields of Latin America, chewing up the raw materials for cocaine. Whether our good friends in Latin America would welcome the prospect of millions of caterpillars dropping from the skies is a different matter. ... Since the drug bug can't solve our problems with narcotics production, the United States might want to consider a different approach. We could ship down a couple of thousand of those signs you see posted outside ... schools, the ones that say ``Drug Free Zone.'' That might not have any effect on production, of course. But what effect has it had on consumption? And it makes as much sense as a drug-eating caterpillar.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: drug-eating caterpillar.
DOC.TEXT: Feb. 24 The Keene (N.H.) Sentinel on Wall Street greed: In the days leading to the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the managers of the New York-based investment house paid themselves more than $300 million in bonuses. ... The bonuses are big, but their actual sizes aren't as important as knowing that, unfortunately, they reflect something a bit more permanent than Drexel Burnham Lambert. That ``something'' is the principle that a successful life, to many people today, is but a succession of transactions whose sole objective is to get rich and live rich; if, in the course of this pursuit, people cause a company to fail or fall apart, too bad; that's Darwin for you. ... There's no way to regulate greed out of existence. But we can do something about it. ... We can teach our children that there's such a thing as over-consumption. We can moderate our immediate needs, and invest for the long haul. We can return to a time when accumulation of wealth was merely a vehicle for building the economy, not the absolute value it has become today.

Feb. 21 Beaumont (Texas) Enterprise on the budget deficit: The federal government is playing its hide-the-budget-deficit game with more than just the Social Security surplus money. Although Social Security provides the largest surplus by far, more billions can be found in other fund accounts. For example, an airport trust fund financed by a tax on tickets will have a surplus of $7.6 billion by the end of fiscal year 1990. The money is supposed to be used to improve frustratingly overcrowded airports and the dangerously overworked air traffic control system. But the White House and Congress allow the fund to accumulate because keeping the surplus on the books makes the budget deficit seem smaller. And to top it off, President Bush's fiscal 1991 budget calls for increasing the tax on airline tickets to 10 percent from the current 8 percent. It is outrageous to hit airline passengers with a 25 percent increase in the tax on tickets while the government refuses to spend the money it has now.

Feb. 26 The Sun Herald, Biloxi, Miss., on U.S. bases in the Philippines: In looking at military cutbacks all over the world, the United States will be looking doubly hard at its six military installations in the Philippines. The U.S. pours about $600 million into that part of the world, about $500 million of that specifically to the Philippines. ... (President Corazon) Aquino's blatant snub of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney last week, because of proposed reduction in U.S. outlay to the Philippines, has even the most liberal Americans gritting their teeth. Of course, Aquino may be posturing _ attempting a show of strength in the face of another coup attempt, attempting to get more U.S. dollars for her impoverished country, attempting to prove she is not an American puppet. Even so, the tactic could backfire. The killing of an American and his family and anti-American demonstrations in Manila only add to questions about the wisdom of continued U.S. presence there. The Philippines' strategic geographic position ... (and) the tremendous investment we already have made in that country make us reluctant to pull out our 18,000 military personnel and their dependents. And we shouldn't pull out simply because of a snub. But if we are going to make cutbacks around the world, the first place we should consider packing up is where we are not welcome.

Feb. 24 The Tribune, San Diego, on an earlier California presidential primary: With state lawmakers locked in partisan moves and countermoves, the proposal to advance the date of California's (June) presidential primary may get lost in the shuffle. That's too bad. An early primary offers California a prime opportunity to have a say in who governs the nation. ... Think back to the 1988 presidential primary. If the California primary had been held early enough to affect the process, candidate George Bush would have been forced to face a key issue: offshore oil drilling. Poll after poll shows that California voters vehemently oppose risking our pristine shores to drill for questionable amounts of offshore oil. Candidate Bush didn't have to worry. By the time his campaign rolled west, the Golden State vote was irrelevant. He could speak vaguely of a commitment to the environment, but make no solid promises about offshore drilling. He's still waffling on the issue.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Court Convicts Five of Spying for Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: A Shanghai court Wednesday convicted five men of spying for the rival Nationalist government on Taiwan and sentenced them to prison terms of five years to life. They were among more than a dozen mainland Chinese accused of acting as agents of Taiwan during last year's massive pro-democracy protests. Zhou Yan, 23, and Qiu Lin, 30, were recruited by Taiwan's secret service while abroad in 1988, the official Xinhua News Agency said. It did not say why the two men were abroad. Zhou allegedly recruited three other men when he returned, and they all gave Taiwan information about the democracy movement, Xinhua said. Zhou was sentenced to life in prison, Feng to 15 years, and the others to terms ranging from 13 years to five years. Taiwan, an island province off China's east coast, has been ruled since 1949 by the Nationalists, who fled there after being defeated by the Communists on the mainland. The Nationalists still claim to be the rightful rulers of all China.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators, Women's Group Criticize Freeing Of Double Killer
DOC.TEXT: Legislators and a women's group criticized a judge for failing to imprison a Royal Marine commando who admitted he shot and killed his wife and baby boy for no apparent reason. A jury found Graham Sherman, 21, guilty of culpable homicide in the shotgun slaying of his wife Michelle, 23, and month-old son, Josh, as they slept in their home in November. But the 74-year-old High Court judge, Lord Dunpark, released Sherman on Tuesday without giving him a prison term or even probation saying, ``You have punished yourself more than enough ... The sooner you try to forget this the better ... You have my deep sympathy.'' Legislator David Evans of Britain's ruling Conservative Party said after the ruling: ``This is a terrible decision.'' Bill Walker, the Conservative Party spokesman for defense matters in Scotland, said the judge was ``out of touch with the real world.'' There has been growing criticism in recent years of court decisions in England, where killers have escaped mandatory life sentences for murder after being convicted on the lesser charge of manslaughter. This is the rough equivalent of culpable homicide in Scotland, which has a separate legal system. The death penalty has been abandoned for murder throughout Britain. The penalty for manslaughter and culpable homicide is at the judge's discretion in both legal systems. The Scottish Women's Aid group said in a statement the message of Dunpark's ruling was that the safety of women and children was not a priority. ``It is a strange message to come from a courtroom that the crime of homicide can be purged by mental self-punishment,'' said Brian Wilson, Scottish spokesman for the opposition Labor Party. Legislator Andrew Welsh of the Scottish National Party called for Dunpark to give a detailed explanation. ``The judge may find he is out of line with public opinion on this,'' he said. Dunpark told Sherman the sentence was something ``I don't anticipate I will ever do ... again. I am going to admonish you on both charges.'' The judge said the purpose of sentencing is to punish, and to deter others. ``In my opinion you have punished yourself more than enough by what you did,'' the judge said. ``You will have to live with this for the rest of your life. You don't know why you did it. No one has been able to offer an explanation as to why you did it.'' There was no deterrent value in a prison sentence, the judge said, ``for no one in their right mind would have killed without reason these two people who were dearest to them in the world. ``But that's what you did. There's no point in deferring sentence for good behavior. You have no previous convictions. Neither is this a case in which in my opinion a probation order would help you. It would just keep reminding you of what you have done. ``And the sooner you try to forget this the better. For all these reasons I admonish you on both these charges and you have my deep sympathy.'' A letter Sherman wrote to his sister-in-law, but never mailed, was read in court, saying: ``I don't expect forgiveness, nor do I expect anyone to understand why. I have gone over it time and time again in my mind, and I still can't find an answer... ``You all know that I love Michelle and Josh with all my heart, and believe me I still do.''

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Laying Off 2,000 Workers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to update with detail on stock price, total work force, $250 million infusion, 40,000 jobs cut industry wide, picking up at the 7th graf pvs, `Shearson reported...'. ADDS byline. A longer version, slugged PM-Shearson, moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Financially troubled Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. announced today it would cut another 2,000 jobs from its payroll. The investment firm announced the layoffs in a letter to employees. Late last year, Shearson said it was eliminating 800 jobs to reduce expenses. Shearson President Howard Clark told employees the newest cuts, which were expected to be completed during the first quarter, were part of an expense reduction program that would save the company $400 million a year. Clark said the cost-cutting plan and business review is expected to reduce first-quarter earnings because of one-time costs associated with the layoffs. Shearson's stock reacted positively to the cutbacks, gaining 75 cents to $12.75 around midday on the New York Stock Exchange. The layoffs would reduce Shearson's current work force to 33,500 from a peak of 47,000. Shearson officials said the layoffs would occur in all areas at the firm, including the firm's corps of highly paid investment bankers. Today's announcement came two days after Shearson's parent, American Express Co., said it would inject $750 million into its subsidiary to shore up its finances, following a $250 million infusion in December. In return, American Express increased its ownsership stake in Shearson. Shearson has been hard hit by the slump in business on Wall Street. Profits at many Wall Street firms have been pressured by a drop in merger activity and securities underwriting and sluggish stock and bond trading since the October 1987 crash. More than 40,000 jobs have been cut from the industry during the slump. Shearson reported 1989 earnings of $110 million, up from $96 million a year earlier, but a third of the profits came from the sale of a money management unit. Investment banking revenue, which includes merger advising and securities underwriting, was down 27 percent. The company's problems forced Shearson Chairman Peter A. Cohen to resign in January. Many analysts believe Shearson expanded too far too fast during the 1980s and now is paying the price. Besides laying off workers, the company has been forced to cut broker commissions and shake up its senior management in an attempt to turn its balance sheet around. Shearson also is trying to stave off a downgrading of its credit ratings. Last fall, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it was considering downgrading Shearson's rating because of the firm's low capital level, weak profits and exposure to commercial real estate loans and investments, as well as the overall securities industry slump.

DOC.HEAD: New Protein Blocks Cold Virus Infections, May Lead to Anti-Cold Drug
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have created a substance that blocks infection by viruses that cause colds, a possible step toward drugs for preventing or treating the malady, a study says. A drug based on the manmade protein might be able to block or ease up to 45 percent of colds, said co-author Steven Marlin. But he cautioned that the study was done in the test tube, and that speculating on its meaning for a human cold is ``a huge leap.'' The research, based on a strategy that shows promise against the AIDS virus, is presented in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature. Marlin did the study with colleagues at Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Ridgefield, Conn., and with researchers at the Center for Blood Research in Boston and the Ernst Boehringer Institute in Vienna, Austria. Their research focused on rhinoviruses, which cause about half of common colds. As a first step toward infecting cells, many rhinoviruses attach themselves to a structure on the cell surface called the intercellular adhesion molecule-1, or ICAM-1. For the new study, scientists created a special form of ICAM-1. They hoped it would act as a decoy, so that free-floating viruses would bind to it rather than their normal target on cell surfaces. By this process, researchers found, the manmade ICAM-1 was largely able to block rhinovirus infection of human cells in the test tube. The result suggests that manmade ICAM-1 or a similar substance might be able to prevent colds if given before infection, Marlin said. Scientists would have to do experiments in people to discover if such a substance would help ease a cold that has already started, he said in a telephone interview. The protein used in the study would have to be given as a nasal spray, but it may give researchers leads for developing similar drugs that could be taken orally, he said. Since natural ICAM-1 plays a role in the body's disease-fighting immune system, scientists must determine how the presence of a manmade version would affect that system, researchers said. In an editorial accompanying the paper, two British scientists cited some other hurdles, such as showing in an animal that the strategy does any good. Such a drug would have to work in concentrations that can be maintained on the inner lining of the nose, wrote Charles Bangham and Andrew McMichael of John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford. Marlin acknowledged that it might be difficult to maintain effective concentrations over a long period because the nose tends to expel substances quickly. The British scientists also cautioned that the drug might cause an allergic reaction in the nose. Marlin said that might not be a serious problem because the manmade ICAM-1 closely mimics its natural counterpart. In research by other scientists, a manmade version of a cellular structure called CD4 shows promise in blocking infection by the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The experimental drug appears to be tolerated without serious side effects in people.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Leftists Clash: Three Dead
DOC.TEXT: Three people were killed in this coastal resort when clashes broke out between police and demonstrators protesting the outcome of statewide municipal elections, authorities said. The airport was closed for about three hours during Tuesday's unrest, said a federal highway police duty officer in Acapulco. The officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also reported political unrest Tuesday in Acapulco, where he said at least 30 people were injured. In Zihuatanejo, 210 miles southwest of Mexico City, about 200 supporters of the Democratic Revolutionary Party blocked the airport road. Two protesters and one security policeman were killed by gunfire when officers removed them, the police official said. The police did not say who fired the fatal shots. There was no word on injuries. At least 30 people were injured when police broke up a march by about 400 people headed for the airport of Acapulco, the officer said. Police wielding clubs stopped them from blocking the highway to the airport, he said. The protesters were demanding that victories they claim in the Dec. 3 Guerrero state municipal elections be respected. The government news agency Notimex said the protesters came from numerous towns in Guerrero, where elections either have not been resolved or the results are disputed by the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Announces End to Offensive Military Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `The pro-government...' to explain number of seats in legislature. Pickup 16th, `Former President...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX11
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega ordered a unilateral halt to all offensive military operations today and said the U.S.-supported Contra rebels should disband so Nicaragua can peacefully change governments. Late Tuesday, President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro also told the Honduras-based rebels to lay down their weapons immediately. In a statement issued by his press office, Ortega said the unilateral halt to military activity was aimed at encouraging the Contras to demobilize quickly and quietly. Ortega also urged the Honduran government to dismantle Contras base camps near the Nicaraguan border and asked the Bush administration to end all U.S. aid to them. There were indications, meanwhile, that the transfer of power from Ortega's leftist Sandinistas to Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-backed coalition would be troubled, as passions ran strong about what Nicaragua's future should hold. Despite being trounced at the polls Sunday by Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, the Sandinistas remain the country's largest and most cohesive political force. They control the military and police and have the allegiance of a large bureaucracy. As transition talks got under way, Sandinista party members vowed never to let their revolution die. The opposition coalition favors a free-market economy, but the Sandinistas insisted Tuesday that banks and industries stay in the hands of the state and that land seized by the government remain in peasant hands. ``A change of government does not mean the end of the revolution,'' Ortega told a cheering crowd of thousands after a meeting of Sandinista party leaders. Rafael Solis, a high-ranking military commander, said the Sandinistas would not cede control of the police or Central America's largest army until the Contras disband. The top Contra leader, Israel Galeano, said from Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Tuesday the rebels would not disband until after Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated April 25 for a six-year term. Officials in Honduras estimate 10,000 rebels and some 42,000 dependents are living in makeshift camps near the Nicaraguan border. President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras said that they must leave as soon as possible. Vice President-elect, Virgilio Godoy, early today accused election officials of delaying the vote count in the National Assembly races to fiddle with the results and deprive the opposition of the two-thirds majority required to make constitutional changes. The last time election results were announced _ Monday afternoon with 82 percent of the vote reported _ the United National Opposition (UNO) had 55 percent of the vote, to the Sandinistas' 41 percent. The pro-government newspaper El Nuevo Diario estimated that under the proportional system UNO would win 52 seats in the legislature, short of the necessary two-thirds. It said the Sandinistas would have 38 and the Social Christians one. The assembly has at least 90 seats, but any presidential candidate who gets more than a certain number of votes may also take a seat if they choose. Only Ortega qualified for an extra seat but has not said if he will take it. Former President Jimmy Carter, a mediator between the two groups, said UNO was concerned because the Sandinista army is written into the constitution and the coalition would be several votes short of a majority needed to amend it. Control of military and police forces is considered the most delicate issue in the negotiations. They are closely identified with the Sandinista party, and the army is known as the Sandinista People's Army, not the Nicaraguan army. UNO has promised to eliminate the draft and reduce the size of the armed forces. But the fractious amalgam of 14 parties and an Indian organization spans the political spectrum from far right to far left and will need considerable muscle to stand up to the Sandinistas. A statement Tuesday said the Sandinistas, who have ruled alone since overthrowing President Anastasio Somoza in 1979, would ``defend the integrity and professionalism of the army and the police forces.'' The Sandinistas said they still have ``the responsibility to watch over and guarantee the continuity of the revolutionary process.'' In the statement, they said their party would oppose any change in its agrarian reform and nationalization of banks and demanded jobs of all public workers be guaranteed. Solis, the military commander, said ``if UNO decides to privatize the banking system it could be an irresponsible act that starts a war.'' Privatization is a fundamental part of UNO's economic program. It hopes to reduce the public sector and return inefficient state-owned industries to the private sector to halt four-digit inflation. Carter, who held an initial meeting with both sides Tuesday night, said he was trying to help the parties define the issues and find a common ground. He said before the meeting that Humberto Ortega, and Interior Minister Tomas Borge, in charge of police forces, had agreed to give up their posts. But it was unknown to what degree the Sandinista rank and file would go along. ``We will give up the government, but not our weapons,'' said one Sandinista Youth member, Lester Rivera, among 15,000 Sandinista loyalists at a downtown rally Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Rockets into Space With a Dazzling Display of Light
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after the 3rd to update with spokesman comment on progress, picking up 4th graf pvs, `Observers as...'. SUBS 10th graf pvs, ``The first two,'' to CORRECT sequence of earlier attempts; the computer glitch was on fourth try sted fifth.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis rocketed into the nighttime sky after five postponements and carried a spy satellite into orbit today, riding a dazzling, 700-foot column of fire seen for hundreds of miles. After waiting out clouds and rain, the shuttle lifted off at 2:51 a.m., sending brilliant light and a shock wave across the darkened seaside space center. The craft, carrying a five-man, all-military crew on a secret mission expected to last four days, disappeared into clouds in just 38 seconds, leaving briefly a glow like a shrouded full moon. Two hours later, NASA shut down public commentary about the classified mission and spokesman Bruce Buckingham said at midday today that silence meant all was well. ``The fact that we haven't heard anything indicates that all is going to according to plan,'' said Buckingham. ``If something out of the ordinary takes place, we'll be informed.'' Observers as far north as Washington, D.C., reported seeing the light of Atlantis' rockets as the craft followed a route never before taken by a shuttle. NASA administrator Dick Truly congratulated the launch team, noting, ``it was a tough one to get off, but a great job.'' No comment was heard from Atlantis' astronauts, and launch director Bob Sieck said at a news conference, ``the crew was pretty quiet and very patient.'' Weather threatened a sixth delay of the mission, and the launch _ first targeted for last Thursday _ was in doubt until the final moments. NASA halted the countdown for about two hours to wait for clouds and light rain to move through. The countdown was restarted at nine minutes, paused briefly for a final weather check, then ticked smoothly on to lift off. As the rocket ignited, light burst from the launch pad and leaped from cloud to cloud as far as the eye could see. Water surrounding the pad was gilded with light from the brilliant cascade of fire powering Atlantis. The first two scheduled launches were halted by a combination of an astronaut's illness and uncertain weather. The third and fifth tries were blocked by bad weather and the fourth by a failed computer. Because of the payload's classified nature, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration kept secret the flight path, but the shuttle's orbit brought the ship up roughly parallel to the East Coast, giving residents a rare, nighttime view of a spacebound shuttle. Theresa Yohn, news producer at WTLV-TV in Jacksonville, Fla., watched the shuttle pass overhead for about 25 seconds from a window at the station, some 150 miles north of the launch site. ``It weaved in and out of the clouds,'' said Yohn. ``It was beautiful, very bright. It had a long tail. It looked like a bright falling star.'' The light show was shorter at Tybee Island, Ga., east of Savannah. ``It was almost like another star, a white bright pinpoint of blue light that continued upwards,'' said Mike Albertson, assistant city editor of the Savannah Evening Press. ``It only lasted about 7 to 10 seconds. But it beat the hell out of a fireworks show.'' Atlantis, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity, is carrying a $500 million satellite capable to taking high-resolution photographs and listening in on electronic communications from all over the world. Its high-inclination orbit is designed to carry it over far northern parts of the Soviet Union never before observed by a shuttle-launched satellite, the sources said. That trajectory could play a role in monitoring arms agreements between the two countries. The Soviets have similar satellites over the United States. Because of the secret nature of the mission, NASA blacked out public release of communications from the spacecraft, and there was not a word heard from the crew on NASA's public channels during the launch. Atlantis' all-military crew is commanded by Navy Capt. John O. Creighton. The others are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Sources said the mission is to last four days, ending with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in California.

DOC.HEAD: Third Package Bomb in Two Days Injures Workers, Fourth Bomb Defused
DOC.TEXT: A package bomb exploded today in Madrid's main post office, injuring two workers, and police said they defused a letter bomb sent to a government prosecutor at the national court. Earlier this week, two package bombs were sent to private homes, and a court official was injured in one of the attacks. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attacks, but a police spokesman said the Basque separatist group ETA was the main suspect because it has used package bombs in the past. The explosions could delay renewed talks between ETA and the government, which said Friday it would respond favorably to a six-month end to Basque terrorist attacks. Police, fearing more bombs, ordered the evacuation of the post office after the explosion, which scattered debris in a first-floor sorting room. Doctors at Gregorio Maranon hospital said sorter Maria del Pilar Fernandez was in serious condition with burns on her neck and face and injuries to both eyes. Another unidentified postal worker was taken to the hospital after the explosion deafened him in one ear, doctors said. Later, police defused a letter bomb discovered by a bodyguard of prosecutor Eduardo Fungairino, a police official said. Fungairino investigated ETA's bloodiest action, a June 1987 car bombing that killed 21 people in the parking garage of a Barcelona department store. On Tuesday, a package bomb exploded at the Madrid home of Fernando de Mateo Lage, the president of the national court, which tries all terrorist cases. Hospital officials today said the judge lost both hands and damaged his eyes in the blast. Also Tuesday, a bomb delivered to a retired army officer in Valencia exploded without causing injuries. Interior Minister Jose Luis Corcuera said ETA was the chief suspect in the attack on Mateo Lage. In September, ETA gunmen assassinated anti-terrorist prosecutor Carmen Tagle, who worked at the same court. ``It is obvious that ETA is still mounting attacks against society and while there are attacks there will be no changes in anti-terrorist policy,'' Corcuera said. The package bomb that injured Mateo Lage was mailed on Friday, the same day Corcuera said the government would respond favorably if the Basque group halted attacks for six months. ETA has claimed responsibility for killing more than 600 people since it began its 21-year violent campaign for independence for the northern, three-province Spanish Basque region. ETA, whose initials stand for Homeland and Liberty in the Basque language, claimed responsibility for attacks that killed 17 people last year. ETA-claimed actions have caused one death so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Discount Benefits of Extra Potassium and Monounsaturated Oil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Heart-conscious eaters who are fed up with low-fat diets can safely add some olive oil and other monounsaturated fats to their daily fare, but the extra dose probably won't reduce their cholesterol, a study concludes. A second report has found that getting lots of potassium, another nutrient with a wholesome image, is no substitute for taking high blood pressure medicines. Scientists have been searching for foods that prevent disease rather than cause it, and potassium and monounsaturated fats have been among the possible candidates. Two studies examining these substances were published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. Some studies have suggested that foods high in monounsaturated fat, such as olive oil, actually might lower blood cholesterol levels. However, the new work found that while monounsaturated fats don't raise cholesterol, they don't seem to lower it significantly. Dr. Henry N. Ginsberg and colleagues from Columbia University randomly assigned 36 healthy young men to eat specially prepared meals for 10 weeks. One group followed the American Heart Association's ``step 1'' diet. In this regimen, they limited their daily fat intake to 30 percent of total calories. Ten percent of the calories wer from saturated fat, 10 percent from polyunsaturated fat and 10 percent from monounsaturated fat. A second group followed the same diet except that 18 percent of the daily calories were from monounsaturated fat. The third group ate a standard American diet, in which 18 percent of calories were from saturated fat, 10 percent polyunsaturated and 10 percent monounsaturated. When the study was over, blood cholesterol levels had fallen 8 percent in those who followed the heart association diet and 10 percent in those who got extra monounsaturated fat. The study did not enroll enough people to make a direct comparison between the two diets. ``I can only conclude indirectly that both of the experimental diets were about the same,'' Ginsberg said. ``What we hoped to do here was try to straighten out some misconceptions about `monos' that have arisen, mostly from the media and food companies, that they had some independent effect on lowering cholesterol.'' He said the research suggests that people who give up saturated fat can safely replace it with monounsaturated fat. But he noted that increasing consumption of carbohydrates is less fattening. ``If you want to have more fat in your diet, you can get away with it by substituting some monounsaturates for carbohydrates, as long as you keep your saturated fat consumption low,'' commented Dr. Scott Grundy of the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas. Population studies have shown that groups with high levels of potassium in their diets also tend to have healthy blood pressures. Several small studies to check potassium's have produced conflicting results. In the latest work, Dr. Richard H. Grimm Jr. and colleagues from the University of Minnesota studied 287 middle-age men who were already taking medicine for high blood pressure. Half were put on potassium, and the rest receive placebos. Then their regular blood pressure medicines were withdrawn. During the next two years, the men continued taking the supplements _ either potassium or the dummies _ and followed low-salt diets. About half the people in both groups had to resume taking blood pressure pills because of rising blood pressure. They said their work suggests that ``potassium supplementation does not reduce the need for anti-hypertensive medication of men on a low-sodium diet.'' In an accompanying editorial, Drs. Norman M. Kaplan and C. Venkata S. Ram of Southwestern Medical Center cautioned against discounting potassium entirely. They noted that most of the men in the Minnesota study were white, and they raised the possibility that extra potassium may help black patients who are still on high-salt diets. They also said they believe people should eat food that is naturally high in potassium. ``The wisdom of nature, honed by thousands of years of physiologic adaptations to a naturally high potassium intake, should not be lightly dismissed,'' they wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Sister of U.S. Hostage More Optimistic that Release Will Occur
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to Update with Mrs. Say meeting with archbishop of Canterbury; Pickup 11th, `Five years...'
DOC.TEXT: The sister of the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon said today as she ended a pilgrimage to Europe and the Middle East that she believes the atmosphere is right for the release of all 18 captives. ``I think that this is the beginning of the end,'' said Peggy Say, the sister of Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. ``There was almost, if not 100 percent, agreement among everybody that I talked to that the timing seems to be right,'' she said in a British Broadcasting Corp. television interview today. ``It might not happen tomorrow, it might not happen next week, but when it happens, I believe it's going to be all of them, and I would rather see all the hostages come out next month than see Terry Anderson come out today alone,'' she said. Later, Mrs. Say met the Archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie, whose personal envoy, Terry Waite, is among the hostages. Waite disappeared Jan. 20, 1987 while on a mission to Beirut to try to free the captives. At a news conference after the meeting, Mrs. Say recalled that she had met Runcie and Waite for the first time before Waite went to Beirut. ``I must admit that I feel some responsibility and was just devastated when Terry Waite was kidnapped,'' she said. ``I continue to hope and to pray that when the hostages are released, they all come out.'' Mrs. Say was concluding her 2{-week trip with a private dinner with the families of British hostages and the Scottish relatives of American hostage Thomas Sutherland. She is especially hopeful because she believes that for the first time since Anderson was seized nearly five years ago, the three key nations _ the United States, Syria, and Iran _ are working together to try to free the hostages. ``There had to be the U.S., Syria and Iran. It had to be a cooperative effort and I feel that it is, given that nothing happens to interfere with it,'' she said in an interview Tuesday night. ``We've got all the components here. Given that everything stays on track, I feel it will end, as other people say to me, sooner rather than later.'' She praised the U.S. government for its efforts. ``I did not have to worry about pressuring my own government to use its influence in a positive way,'' Mrs. Say told NBC's ``Today'' show. ``Everywhere I went they assured me that that was being done and that's...quite different from what's happened in the past.'' Anderson was kidnapped in west Beirut on March 16, 1985. A pro-Iranian group called Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, claims to hold him. ``Five years seems to have triggered something in people,'' said Mrs. Say on Tuesday. ``It seems everybody is realizing that these hostages are becoming a real obstacle ... that they are preventing a move forward between the United States and other countries, and that obstacle has to be removed so they can get on to other things,'' she said. Mrs. Say said she was encouraged by a commentary last week in the Tehran Times, which usually reflects the thinking of President Hashemi Rafsanjani, that the hostages should be freed; and by a statement Sunday from Iran's chief justice, Mohammad Yazdi, that Islam opposed hostage-taking. Mrs. Say was also heartened by an appeal for a new approach to free the hostages made Friday by Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the most influential Shiite Moslem cleric in Lebanon. He is the spiritual guide to the Iranian-aligned Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is believed to be an umbrella organization for groups holding most of the hostages. A report Tuesday in al-Hayat, an Arab newspaper published in London, that contacts in Geneva among the United States, Syria and Iran were making progress on the hostage issue was one of ``many, many positive signals,'' she said. The White House and State Department on Tuesday denied reports of secret talks in Geneva. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater did not rule out that the hostage issue was under discussion, stressing there were no face-to-face negotiations. Mrs. Say said she's ``hoped and prayed for the last few years that when a hostage release comes, it's part of something larger, maybe a recementing or a reaffirming of our relationship with Syria, opening the door for dialogue with Iran, moving toward a settlement in the region. ``If that happened, if these hostages are a part of that, I don't begrudge the pain and I know Terry Anderson would not. It would have been worth every day that we've all suffered. I've prayed that it won't happen for nothing.''

DOC.HEAD: The Landslide That Slid the Other Way
DOC.TEXT: In advance, Daniel Oretega's triumph at the polls last Sunday _ the one that didn't come about _ seemed inevitable. Polls conducted by American outfits showed him a landslide winner. But that didn't take into account the distrust ordinary Nicaraguans might have had for strangers with clipboards asking questions. The Washington Post-ABC News poll had Ortega leading Violeta Barrios de Chamorro by 48 percent to 32 percent, with the rest scattered, undecided or unwilling to declare themselves. A poll conducted for the Spanish-language television network Univsion had Ortega winning by an even bigger landslide: 53 percent to 35 percent. When Nicaraguans voted Sunday, they turned those polls on their heads. Mrs. Chamorro won overwhelmingly, 55-41 percent, catching pollsters, analysts and commentators off guard, surprising her opponents and herself. The post-mortem search for an explanation has been under way ever since. In advance, Mrs. Chamorro had been portrayed as a loser _ disorganized, offering no articulate solutions to Nicragua's woeful problems, leading a splintered coalition, slowed down by a knee injury which put her on crutches. It was said that the $1.8 million in aid offered her campaign by the United States had only stirred resentment among Nicaraguans. And the Panama invasion was pictured as another impediment. Even Secretary of State James L. Baker III seemed to have caught the Ortega-can't-lose bug. Asked at a congressional hearing last Thursday about U.S. policy if Ortega won, Baker said, ``We shouldn't assume this.'' Then he went on to assume it, and laid out tough terms for Ortega to meet before normal relations could be restored. Many network newscasts left little room for doubt. Said NBC's Ed Rabel from Managua on Feb. 21 over a picture of Ortega, ``This is the man, pollsters say, who will be elected overwhelmingly this weekend. ... The election observers say the Bush administration may have itself to blame for Daniel Ortega's rise in popularity among the votes. The reason, they say, is the U.S. military invasion in Panama ... It was a close race until the U.S. invaded.'' ``Almost certainly,'' said Ted Koppel of ABC two nights later, ``the Sandinistas will still win.'' In the post-mortems, a single explanation was often offered: American polling outfits made a fatal mistake in assuming that Nicaraguans would tell strangers how they would vote. ``Many of the people we interviewed in Nicaragua were simply unwilling to allow themselves to be identified as an enemy of the Sandinista government,'' says Rob Schroth of Bendixen & Schroth, which took the Univision poll. Howard Schuman, director of the University of Michigan Survey Research Center and a member of the Commission on Nicaragua Pre-Election Polls, cautioned when the ABC News-Washington Post poll came out that difficulties in sampling in rural areas probably made for a larger-than-normal margin of error. In addition, he said this week, ``My guess is that at least one component (of the polls' failures) is that people did not answer frankly. The question is how much they trusted that their answers would be treated confidentially.'' Added Mark Penn, a pollster who has worked widely in Latin America but stayed away from Nicaragua, ``Polling is a device that is useful in a stable democracy, but in a place where there is no history of democracy it is unreliable.'' Schroth noted that all the polls weren't wrong. Those by organizations from Venezuela, Argentina and Costa Rica put Mrs. Chamorro in the lead. The Washington Post said that of 27 polls released in 1989 and this year, 14 showed the Sandinistas ahead and 13 gave the lead to Mrs. Camorro's coalition. Some analysts say, in retrospect, that those expecting an Ortega victory overlooked Nicaragua's economic pains. And one, pollster Stanley Greenberg of Greenberg-Lake Associates, says Ortega booted it. ``He conducted a glitzy American-style campaign and it backfired,'' said Greenberg, whose own polls for Hemisphere Initiative, an observer group, were just as wrong as the other American polls. Ortega put himself in a losing proposition, Greenberg said, by asking voters to choose between his own austere personality and Mrs. Chamorro's warmth. ``But once the Sandinista campaign centered on the cult of personality, once the advertising was rock music and the youth culture, I wonder if the campaign didn't trivalize the issues,'' Greenburg said. Laurence Birns, executive director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a liberal research group critical of U.S. policy toward Nicaragua, also stressed the economic issue. ``No government associated with hyper-inflation is going to win an election,'' he said. But like others, Birns miscalculated; he had predicted a narrow Sandinista win.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Orbiting Earth After Sixth Launch Try
With AM-Shuttle-Last Mission, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis, aloft at last on a secret military mission after five launch delays, orbited the globe Wednesday in a public silence that NASA officials said meant all was well. Atlantis blasted off with five military astronauts and a cargo believed to be a $500 million spy satellite at 2:51 a.m., its 700-foot column of fire visible for hundreds of miles. It was NASA's sixth attempt at launching the 100-ton spaceship for the mission, one short a record for the most shuttle postponements. ``Thank goodness we can finally stop meeting like this,'' NASA administrator Richard Truly told the launch team after Atlantis rocketed into orbit. ``It was a tough one to get off, but a great job.'' Nothing was heard from Atlantis' all-military crew, and launch director Bob Sieck said, ``the crew was pretty quiet and very patient.'' ``The fact that we haven't heard anything indicates that all is going according to plan,'' added Bruce Buckingham, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Because of the classified nature of the Defense Department mission, NASA quickly blacked out public release of communications from the shuttle for the entire trip. Liftoff, originally set for Feb. 15, almost was delayed a sixth time because of bad weather at Kennedy Space Center and at emergency abort sites. The first scheduled liftoff was halted when the crew's commander was stricken with a cold. His illness, combined with uncertain weather, prompted NASA to scrub the second launch. The others were blocked twice by bad weather and once by a malfunctioning computer. With rain and clouds threatening to postpone once more, NASA halted Wednesday's countdown for about two hours. The clock was restarted at nine minutes, paused briefly for a final weather check, then ticked to liftoff. ``The weather finally cooperated. We had a good, smooth count,'' said Forrest McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center. ``The team exercised good patience.'' As the rocket ignited, light burst from the launch pad and leaped form cloud to cloud across the nighttime horizon. People as far north as Washington, D.C., reported seeing the blue, white and red light of Atlantis' rockets as the spaceship streaked up the East Coast on the highest inclination orbit ever traveled by a shuttle. For many, it resembled a brilliant falling star. ``It only lasted about seven to 10 seconds. But it beat the hell out of a fireworks show,'' said Mike Albertson, an editor at the Savannah (Ga.) Evening Press who watched from Tybee Island, Ga. Atlantis' 62-degree inclination puts it over far northern parts of the Soviet Union never before observed by a shuttle-launched satellite. The spy satellite on board is capable of taking high-resolution photographs and listening in on electronic communications from around the world, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The mission is expected to last 4{ days and end with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in Calif., sources said. Atlantis' crew is commanded by Navy Capt. John O. Creighton. The others are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot.

DOC.HEAD: British Remember 1940 Air Battles
DOC.TEXT: Commemorations to mark the 50th anniversary of the Battle of Britain in World War II opened on Wednesday with a display of paintings, drawings and sculpture at the Royal Air Force Museum in Hendon. Most members of the Guild of Aviation Artists who produced the works at the north London museum's request were not born when the RAF Hurricanes and Spitfires met the German Luftwaffe over southern England in the summer of 1940. The exhibits depict the aircraft and people of the battle on both sides and cost from $75 for a pencil drawing of a pilot to $25,000 for a large oil of three Spitfires by Frank Wootton, a leading aviation artist during the war. The museum is the largest in Europe devoted to aviation. ``We have planned an extensive program of events for the anniversary year and in April we will open a major exhibition about the battle, with British and German aircraft which took part in it,'' said the director, Michael Fopp. Memorial ceremonies to remember those who fought and died will take place throughout Britain during the summer.

DOC.HEAD: Meat, Poultry Products Will Get More-Detailed Labels
DOC.TEXT: Labels on meat and poultry products will have to be more specific when certain flavorings are used, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Federal rules are being changed, effective March 1, to require ``proteinaceous material'' derived from livestock, poultry, eggs, milk, plants and yeast to be listed on labels by their names. In the past, such substances could be listed simply as ``flavorings'' or similar terms. For example, a popular ``flavor agent'' or enhancer used for years in hot dogs will have to be labeled ``milk protein hydrolyzate.'' Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said the new rule _ which was proposed in August 1987 _ was adopted ``to better protect the public health and serve the consumer's right to know'' what's in food products. ``For many years, the agency has required labels for meat and poultry products to list all ingredients,'' he said. ``However, an exception was made to allow `natural flavoring' and similar terms to designate substances which are often added as flavor enhancers, emulsifiers, stabilizers, binders, extenders and nutrient sources in products such as frankfurthers and bologna.'' Crawford said the exception was allowed because the additives were primarily flavorings in meat and poultry products and did not make a significant nutritional contribution. But he said the agency's ``paramount concern is public health'' and that it was found some people can have severe allergic reactions to these substances. ``The agency is also concerned about a marked increase in the use of these ingredients during the last decade,'' Crawford said. ``Some manufacturers may be using the substances inappropriately as low-cost meat replacements.'' Now, he said, consumers with allergies to certain substances can tell if the product contains those ingredients. Crawford said meat and poultry processors will be allowed to make label changes over six months, although the agency is working closely with the companies to speed it up. At least one company is adding a ``stick on'' label to its regular packaging to further define the product ingredients, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Who Founded Covenant House Resigns; Prosecutor Rules Out Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with prosecutor ruling out charges. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `The controversy...'. SUBS 10th graf pvs, `The charges..', to delete now-redundant first reference to Kite.
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor today ruled out criminal charges against the Rev. Bruce Ritter, saying an investigation into allegations of financial impropriety against the Covenant House founder had not turned up enough to warrant prosecution. Ritter, also a target of allegations of sexual improprieties, resigned Tuesday night as director of the network of shelters for runaways he founded in 1968. District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said there were some ``questionable financial transactions'' discovered in the review of expenditures in behalf of Kevin Kite, a former male prostitute who claimed he had sex with Ritter in return for material favors. He declined to be more specific but said the problems uncovered were insufficient evidence to warrant prosecution. Morgenthau also said violations of law may have occurred when Covenant House supplied Kite with false identification papers in the name of a dead child. He said he had decided not to bring charges in that matter either, after consultation with the family of the dead child. A separate investigation by the state attorney general's office is continuing. Since December, four young men who took shelter at Covenant House have accused Ritter in news reports of having affairs with them. Prosecutors were studying whether any funds raised by the charity were misused. The district attorney said Covenant House officials had cooperated in the investigation and nothing was discovered that cast doubt on the merit of its programs. ``Although Covenant House has had to endure a brief period of adversity, I am confident that it will emerge from this episode a stronger and more effective organization which continues to deserve widespread public support,'' Morgenthau said. In resigning at a board meeting Tuesday night, Ritter said the sex misconduct allegations made it ``impossible for me to lead Covenant House effectively.'' He said he didn't want to jeopardize the well-being of the thousands of young people Covenant House serves. ``The controversy that has surrounded me for the past three months has made it impossible for me to lead Covenant House effectively,'' Ritter said in a statement. ``Therefore, after a great deal of thought and prayer, I have come to the conclusion that in the best interest of Covenant House and, most especially, for the well-being of thousands of street kids, I should resign.'' Former city schools chancellor Frank Macchiarola, who served as acting president of Covenant House while the allegations were investigated, also resigned. James J. Harnett, executive vice president and chief operating officer, will replace Ritter until a permanent successor is found. ``The focus has got to be on the needs of the kids,'' Harnett said. ``Covenant House is not one man. It's not me, it's not Father Ritter. He was not all of Covenant House. But his vision, his courage and determination remain.'' Harnett said the controversy has ``been very upsetting to the kids and the kids are going to be very upset'' by Ritter's decision to leave. The charges against Ritter, 62, arose in December, when the New York Post quoted Kite as saying he had had an affair with Ritter last year. Three more men have since said they had affairs with Ritter. Ritter, who is accustomed to laudatory coverage and was once hailed by President Reagan as a hero, called the accusations ``garbage.'' The Roman Catholic priest started Covenant House by putting up runaways in his apartment. It now serves 25,000 youths annually at 17 shelters in the United States, Canada and Latin America. Nearly all of its $85 million annual budget comes from donations. Contributions to Covenant House were said to have fallen off since the allegations against Ritter surfaced. Macchiarola, named acting president Feb. 7, said in a statement he resigned after Covenant House's board rejected his proposal for the organization's future. His spokeswoman, Maureen Connelly, said Macchiarola had wanted to ``conduct reviews, investigations and audits of current practices and make changes.'' Harnett said the board ``accepted all of those recommendations'' and plans to hire consultants to revamp procedures. But he said the board disagreed with Macchiarola on who was best qualified to replace Ritter.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Discuss Nicaraguan Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 23, The president, to make quote as delivered. Editing throughout to shorten. ^By RITA BEAMISH
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said he and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev today engaged in a ``very constructive'' 40-minute telephone conversation on dramatic recent developments in Nicaragua and Eastern Europe. While declining to give details of the talk, Bush told reporters flying with him aboard Air Force One to New York that ``it was a good talk.'' ``We're going to continue to try to have consultations. We agreed these kinds of conversations are very useful. I think we need to do a little more of that kind of thing, and I think he agrees,'' Bush said. The president made the phone call, which had been arranged Tuesday, shortly before leaving the White House on a four-day politicking trip that will wind up with a meeting in California with the prime minister of Japan. ``We touched on matters relating to Nicaragua and Central America, but also matters relating to changes in Europe,'' Bush said. Bush also said he had thanked Gorbachev for the warm reception the Soviet president had given Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Baker's trip to Moscow earlier this month. The president said he assured Gorbachev that he was committed to moving ahead on arms control negotiations under a timetable set up by Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. The administration hopes to move forward on three treaties with the Soviet Union this year: on nuclear strategic weapons, on conventional arms in Europe and on limiting chemical weapons. Both sides have said they hope the strategic weapons treaty can be ready to be signed by Bush and Gorbachev's summit in June. Bush characterized the call as ``a very constructive conversation.'' He said it was ``forthright, and where we differ we can spell out the differences without rancor and that's important in the U.S.-Soviet relationship.'' The Soviet news agency Tass reported from Moscow that Bush and Gorbachev ``had a telephone conversation today within the framework of regular opinion exchange.'' An official Soviet statement said the two leaders discussed some pressing international issues, including Nicaragua, problems of European security including German reunification and preparations for the upcoming Soviet-U.S. summit. Bush, in his talk with reporters aboard Air Force One, did not identify any differences he might have had with Gorbachev in the conversation. ``It's important that there be some confidentiality if we're going to be able to speak as frankly as we did today.'' he said. ``We touched on a lot of matters,'' he added. Bush said he was pleased that the Soviet Union had recognized the results of Sunday's presidential election in Nicaragua won by U.S.-backed candidate Violeta Chamorro. The Soviet Union played an important behind-the-scenes role in encouraging Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista government to hold an honest election last Sunday, a senior administration official said Tuesday. The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, listed the Soviet role among a number of key elements that led to the free elections in which Sandinista President Daniel Ortega was ousted. Before leaving Washington for his first stop in New York, Bush also met with Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, a Zulu leader from South Africa who urged him to lift U.S. sanctions against Pretoria as soon as he legally can. On the first stop of his trip today, Bush called for lower taxes for American business. ``Lower taxes are the key to making America competitive in the global marketplace,'' Bush said at a Staten Island fundraiser for Republican congressional candidate Susan Molinari. ``We can outproduce, outmarket and outsell anybody else _ if we can keep taxes low for American business,'' Bush said. The president said his trip to California would focus on efforts to fight drugs and crime, and he would see Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu ``to discuss another important issue. It's an issue of concern to everybody in this country...American competitiveness in the Pacific Rim.'' Ms. Molinari, a city council member, is seeking to succeed her father, Guy Molinari, in a special election March 20 for the seat he resigned when he was elected borough president. Her opponent is Democrat Robert Gigante, an attorney who has twice before failed to win the Staten Island congressional seat. Bush heads to San Francisco tonight to raise money for Republican Sen. Pete Wilson's gubernatorial bid on the first of four nights in California. Bush ends the week with his talks with Kaifu in Palm Springs. The Kaifu meeting is expected to indirectly aid GOP political efforts in California by spotlighting trade issues that are of vital importance to the state, said one GOP operative who spoke on condition of anonymity. Resentment of Japan centers on trade competition in key areas such as the auto industry, electronics and agriculture.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says He's Open for New Talks With New Zealand
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday proposed a thaw in U.S. relations with New Zealand, chilled in recent years by disagreements over American nuclear policy. ``I don't think it makes sense to continue a ban on high-level contacts on matters other than military or intelligence,'' Baker told the Senate Budget Committee. He observed that the two countries share similar positions on combating drug trafficking and in opposing driftnet fishing in the Pacific. ``It is short-sighted,'' Baker said. ``I am prepared to resume contacts with my counterpart'' in New Zealand's government. The United States in 1986 suspended high-level contacts with New Zealand and froze New Zealand out of the ANZUS alliance, which also includes the United States and Australia. The move followed New Zealand's denial of docking rights for U.S. military vessels unless they carried no nuclear weapons. The United States, in line with its standard policy, refused to confirm or deny whether such weapons were aboard its ships. David Lange, of New Zealand's Labor party, came to power in July 1984 after making a campaign promise to ban nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed U.S. naval vessels from the country's waters. The Reagan administration accused the government of undermining the alliance's nuclear deterrent.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Chief Will Retire Next Month, Join New York Yankees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 7 grafs with new detail on Lawn's move to Yankees; picks up at pvs 6th graf, Shults said
DOC.TEXT: Drug Enforcement Administration chief John C. Lawn is resigning after five turbulent years as director of the lead federal anti-drug agency, and will become an executive with the New York Yankees, the DEA said today. ``There's no suggestion that he's giving up the war on drugs,'' agency spokesman Frank Shults said of Lawn. ``He's very torn. ... It was an extremely difficult decision for him to make.'' Lawn has accepted an offer from Yankees owner George Steinbrenner to become vice president and chief of operations for the baseball organization, Shults said. ``He will handle all matters pertaining to the New York Yankees except for the players,'' Shults said. Lawn and Steinbrenner met in 1987 when they were on a speaking panel together, and Lawn is a close personal friend of Phil McNiss, a retired FBI agent who is vice president of Steinbrenner's American Shipbuilding Co., the spokesman said. The DEA chief was a basketball coach when he taught English and American hisstory at Brooklyn Preparatory School, a Jesuit school, for seven years before beginning his law enforcement career, Shults said. Lawn was named high school coach of the year for New York City in 1964, he said. His move to the Yankee organization was reported first by The Washington Post, Scripps Howard News Service and Newsday. Shults said Tuesday that one reason behind the former Marine Corps officer's decision to retire March 23 after 27 years of government service is that he will turn 55 in a few months. As a presidential appointee, Lawn is exempt from the mandatory retirement age of 55 imposed on other federal law enforcement officers. However, ``he would not be able to maintain his position as a law enforcement officer, just an administrator,'' Shults said. ``It's extremely important to him ... that he is a special agent. That's his motivation.'' ``My service as administrator of DEA over the past five years has been most rewarding and most satisfying,'' Lawn said in a letter to President Bush. ``The ratification of the United Nations Convention, the National Drug Control Strategy and the Cartagena summit have established the foundations upon which we can project with confidence our ultimate success in this battle.'' Lawn also thanked Bush for his ``personal involvement in honoring those DEA special agents who have paid the ultimate price in this battle.'' In an interview in December, Lawn said the loss of personnel was the toughest part of his job.
