DOC.TEXT: Many American politicians who for years condemned Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega as an untrustworthy Marxist aggressor are reacting with surprise over his quiet acceptance of electoral defeat. Others say that a careful examination of the record will show that Ortega, in an utterly consistent fashion, always kept his word _ once he gave it. But still others point out that Nicaragua is now entering a period of political transition with Ortega's Sandinistas in firm control of a large standing army and with Ortega himself proclaiming that the nation's revolution has not been extinguished. ``The story sure isn't over,'' said former Sen. Daniel Evans, R-Wash., who briefed the Senate Republican Caucus this week on his experiences as an official observer of the Nicaraguan election process. Refering to Ortega's concession of defeat by Violeta Chamorro, Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., said, ``I was really caught off guard; I was basically surprised.'' ``I thought we were going to have another Noriega situation,'' Heflin said, referring to now-deposed Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega's nullification of his country's presidential elections last year. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, who for years denounced Ortega and the Sandinistas for allegedly exporting revolution throughout Central America, wasn't ready to to philosophize about why Ortega permitted a fair election and why he didn't quibble about the results. ``He's defeated; I haven't tried to analyze him,'' Dole said. ``I just enjoyed the results.'' Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska., said he believes Ortega and the Sandinistas simply bowed to reality. The severe impact of Reagan's economic sanctions made defeat inevitable, he said, adding, ``I'm going to call President Reagan and tell him that.'' But Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., who was denied permission by the Sandinista government to lead a team of congressional election observers to Nicaragua, said he believes Ortega has undergone ``an evolution of style.'' ``It is surprising,'' Lugar said of Ortega's concession without a struggle. ``But I suppose equally surprising was his conduct in the last few weeks as he adopted Western campaign techniques, dispensing with much of his security apparatus'' and campaigning voter to voter, rally to rally, Lugar said. Now, Lugar said, Ortega has transformed himself into ``an important opposition figure.'' Evans said he believes the Sandinistas have not chosen to change the election results by military force because ``there was a recognition that if they were to use the power of his army Ortega would initiate a bloody, bloody conflict in every city and on every street.'' ``I think there was also a feeling that, well, we didn't win this one, but there will be another time, another day and at some point we could well be back in power,'' he said, noting that the next presidential election is scheduled in six years. Looking at the troubles that lie ahead for Nicaragua, Evans noted that Mrs. Chamorro's UNO coalition spans the political spectrum from the far right to the Nicaraguan Communist Party and is therefore fragile. Moreover, compared to the Sandinistas, who have a decade of government experience behind them, the UNO coalition is ``terribly weak in terms of expertise,'' Evans said. He noted that the Sandinistas will still be in control of many municipalities and will retain strong representation in the national assembly and on every important elected body. ``The Sandinistas still have the army, a party army,'' Evans said. ``UNO's task is to change that, take command and reduce the size of the armed forces.'' Mrs. Chamorro and her coalition will inherit an economy in ruins and despite the fact that much of the blame can be attributed to Sandinista mismanagement, Ortega will be looking to exploit his successor's mistakes, Evans said. ``As events unfold in Nicaragua, I fear that the tendency in the United States will be to give a deep sigh of relief and move on and pay little further attention,'' Evans said. ``And that would be a tragedy.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Says ATVs Still Causing Deaths Despite Court Agreement
DOC.TEXT: A court-backed agreement on safety measures for all-terrain vehicles has failed to result in the expected sharp decline in injuries and deaths, the chairman of a House panel said Wednesday. Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga., whose subcommittee helped prompt a 1988 agreement banning new sales of three-wheeled off-the-road vehicles, questioned the agressiveness of the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission in enforcing safety provisions for ATVs. ``Your advocacy, to me, comes short,'' Barnard told commission chairman Jacqueline Jones-Smith. In a hearing before Barnard's House Government Operations subcommittee, safety experts said that off-road vehicles remain inherently unstable and deceptively dangerous for their riders. They said that there are some 2.5 million of the existing three-wheeled models and the newer four-wheel versions, many of them ridden primarily by children. They said an agreement by manufacturers not to sell adult-sized vehicles for use by children under 16 is being ignored. ``ATVs are kid-killers, plain and simple,'' said Charles Chvala, a Wisconsin state senator who is pushing state legislation to restrict the vehicles. The industry defended its action and safety record. ``Riding an ATV is far less risky than a number of other popular activities,'' said Howard P. Willens, lobbyist for distributers of Honda, Kawasaki, Suzuki and Yamaha brand vehicles. Distributors of the three- and four-wheeled vehicles agreed to a consent decree with the federal government in 1988 on safety steps for ATVs. The order, signed by federal Judge Gerhard Gesell, was in response to a suit by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, after congressional hearings. As part of the agreement, the industry agreed to sell only four-wheeled versions in the future, but there was no recall of existing three-wheel models. It also required safety warnings and public awareness campaigns, and sale of adult-size vehicles only for use by people 16 or over. Jones-Smith defended that agreement and the commission's enforcement. She said deaths and injuries due to the vehicles have declined from 350 in 1986 to approximately 300 annually. About 40 percent of the deaths are children under 16, she said. She said an undercover investigation by the CPSC staff found a majority of dealers recommended vehicles not appropriate for a purchaser seeking a vehicle for a 13-year-old child. She said distributers should take steps to make their dealers comply with age requirements. Janine Jagger, assistant professor of neurosurgery at the University of Virginia, said the consent decree ``is a safety sham'' that has not lessened risk or changed ``the practices of this irresponsible and arrogant industry.'' Willens, the industry lobbyist, said the injury rate has dropped 52 percent since 1985, and the fatality rate 27 percent. Willens said most fatalities were due to ``extreme forms of vehicle misuse.'' Barnard said he was concerned deaths have not declined further and called on the commission to face whether continuing levels of death and injury with ATVs are ``reasonable.'' ``I do not think it is reasonable to accept 300 deaths per year, mostly children, and tens of thousands of injuries,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Exchange Fire; Religious Leaders Demand Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces dueled with mortars and machine guns in east Beirut Wednesday and their religious leaders demanded an immediate cease-fire in the one-month showdown. No casualties were reported in the intermittent exchanges in Ashrafiyeh, held by the Lebanese Forces under Samir Geagea, and on the city's southeastern edge, controlled by Gen. Michel Aoun's troops. By police count, the showdown for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has killed 694 people and wounded 1,934 since it broke out Jan. 30. A shaky cease-fire has been in effect since Feb. 17. After a three-hour meeting, spiritual leaders of Christian sects demanded Aoun and Geagea respect the cease-fire, withdraw their forces, reopen all roads and end the vitriolic propaganda campaigns. The leaders, who met at the seat of Maronite Catholic patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir in Bkirki, north of Beirut, also asked that Aoun and Geagea begin a political dialogue after implementing the security arrangements. Geagea said in a statement he would comply with the clerics' peace plan and said he hoped Aoun would follow suit. ``We hope that a similar decision will be taken by the other side and that the spiritual leaders will directly supervise the conduct of the plan,'' Geagea said. There was no immediate reaction from Aoun. But the plan differed sharply from Aoun's earlier demand that a political agreement be reached with Geagea before Aoun withdraws his 19,000 soldiers from the embattled districts of east Beirut and other sectors. Geagea has demanded a ``normalization of the situation'' between his 6,000-strong militia and Aoun's troops prior to any political talks. Sfeir, addressing the churchmen, said peace was ``God's gift to man. Nevertheless, peace is made by man. We call on the leaders to make peace.'' Both Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the Catholic community that has dominated Lebanon since its independence from France in 1943. A three-man mediation committee said it would resume deadlocked efforts to work out a settlement to the worst fighting among Christians in the nearly 15-year-old civil war. ``We are going through a very delicate and difficult era,'' said Shaker Abu Suleiman, a member of the mediation committee who attended part of the meeting at Bkirki. Aoun wants the Lebanese Forces to disband and become a political organization. Geagea refuses to break up his military force. In September 1988 Aoun was appointed head of an interim military Cabinet by outgoing President Amin Gemayel after parliament failed to elect a successor. But on Nov. 24 the Lebanese Parliament elected Elias Hrawi president, backed by Syria, which has 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate. Aoun considers the Syrians an occuption army. Hrawi fired Aoun as army chief and caretaker premier, but the general refused to step down, alleging Hrawi's election was unconstitutional. Aoun considers himself the sole legitimate authority in Lebanon. In another development, the daily An-Nahar said a Panamanian freighter, the Atlantic 3, unloaded its shipment of Iraqi weapons at the Lebanese Forces port of jounieh a week ago, bolstering the militia's position. The paper said Iraq sent Aoun the shipment more than four months ago, but tried to recall it when the Arab League announced a peace plan. Instead, the captain dropped anchor off Malta and said he would deliver to whoever paid. The Lebanese Forces paid, the paper said, without elaborating on the price or contents.

DOC.HEAD: Taxpayers Filing Faster, Getting More Back, IRS Says
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service is processing tax returns at a near record pace and promising refunds in about four weeks. During the first half of the filing season, 31.9 million returns were received by the IRS, about 30 percent of the total expected this year. Receipts through Feb. 23 were 3.6 percent higher than a year ago. The agency said Wednesday that it has processed 19.4 percent more returns than at this time last year, 18.1 million compared with 15.1 million. More than half the processed returns, 9.9 million, have produced refunds, up 20.3 percent from last year. This year's refunds are averaging $868, compared with $825 during the same period last year. Refunds have totaled $8.6 billion, up 26.5 percent. ``Those who file returns before the last-minute rush can expect refunds in about four weeks,'' the IRS said. More than 2.5 million taxpayers have opted for refunds within about two weeks by filing their returns electronically through companies authorized by the IRS. By comparison, about 645,000 electronic returns were received during the same period last year. Electronic filing is available in every state this year, although only to taxpayers who are due refunds.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Ask Who Will Pay the Price of Resettlers
DOC.TEXT: The welcome mat for East German immigrants is wearing thin as overcrowded resettlement centers and fears of higher taxes remind West Germans of the cost of hospitality. Throughout the country, West German politicians are toning down the euphoria over East Germany's open borders and encouraging resettlers to return home to help rebuild their country. At least one major conservative politician, Gov. Lothar Spaeth of Baden-Wuerttemburg state, has even suggested East Germans be paid to go home, a strategy used to encourage Turkish guest workers to leave several years ago. ``We helped the Turks return. So why shouldn't we do the same for these people?'' asked Spaeth, of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. When the mostly young, skilled East Germans began their exodus last fall, West Germans credited them with forcing democratic change in their homeland. But the more than 100,000 who have arrived already this year are increasingly seen as taking advantage of West Germany's liberal policies. Under West Germany's Constitution, they are granted automatic citizenship and are eligible for the same social benefits as West German taxpayers. Impatience with them appears to be on the rise. The Hamburg-based weekly magazine Stern said in this week's edition that more than two-thirds of 1,012 West Germans questioned in a recent poll wanted to halt East German resettlement. In recent weeks, police had to be called to quell fights between drunken East Germans at resettlement centers in Saarland and North Rhine-Westphalia state, Stern said. North Rhine-Westphalia already has stopped 64 towns from accepting more resettlers because of overcrowding, the magazine said. Welt am Sonntag newspaper reported Sunday that in the northern port city of Bremen, the local government is refusing to accept more East German resettlers but is continuing to allow asylum seekers from the Third World. In one Bremen resettlement center, 87 East German men share one toilet, two washing machines, a small table and two chairs, the newspaper said. They sleep in double-deck army cots in a school gymnasium, said the report. ``The gymnasium is not an isolated case,'' the newspaper said. ``About 350 (East) Germans are living in Bremen gymnasiums.'' West Germans complain that East German resettlers are given preferential treatment in social and unemployment pay and are overcrowding the already strapped housing market. Resettlers who quit work to come to the West are eligible for immediate unemployment pay, which averages about $588 a month. West Germans who switch jobs must wait 12 weeks to be eligible for unemployment, Stern said. Each East German also receives a one-time payment of $117 in ``welcome money,'' and East Germans are eligible for low-interest loans of $1,765 to $5,880 to set up households. The left-leaning Social Democratic Party has said Kohl's conservative government should try harder to persuade East Germans to remain in their homeland. ``With the reforms there now, there is no reason they should leave,'' said Gov. Oskar Lafontaine of Saarland state, a Social Democrat who is expected to be Kohl's top challenger for chancellor in December elections. Estimates of the costs of rebuilding East Germany and putting the two states under a single currency have been as high as $58.8 billion, and there are increased fears that West Germans will pay much of this in higher taxes. ``You know whose going to pay for all this,'' said Frankfurt restaurant owner Peter Blisch. ``We the taxpayers, and it won't be cheap.'' Alexander Schwerein of the Christian Democrats said a tax increase ``cannot be discounted'' if elections March 18 in East Germany do not result in a stable government. But Kohl's chief of staff, Rudolf Seiters, has said that uniting the two Germanys ``can be realized without a tax increase.''

DOC.HEAD: It's a Dog of a Story as Capitol Newshounds Meet the Schnauzers
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf, bgng, ``I think ... to CORRECT Elizabeth Dole's title
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't the kind of event Capitol Hill's newshounds usually cover, but when Leader, R-Kan., and Chelsea Marie, R-S.C., appeared with their eight puppies Wednesday, journalists flocked to the canine briefing. ``Event of the decade! Dole-Thurmond Pups Coming to Washington,'' trumpeted a press release handed out in advance by Leader's owner, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole. As reporters oohed and aahed, Chelsea Marie's owner, Sen. Strom Thurmond carried a basketfull of 5-week-old schnauzer puppies into the ornate room, carefully placing them on a table draped with green felt. A plastic cover was hidden underneath in case of an accident. Thurmond's wife, Nancy, clutched Chelsea Marie, while Dole tried to control Leader. ``I think Leader has something else in mind,'' Dole quipped as he handed the energetic schnauzer to his wife, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. The Doles were joined by Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., and his wife, Penny, who are planning to take one of the puppies as a replacement for Heidi, their schnauzer who died two weeks ago. Dole assured the group that schnuzers were ``bipartisan dogs.'' Leader, he said, ``barks at everybody.'' The cuddly balls of fur with blue or pink ribbons around their necks _ five puppies are boys and three are girls _ were the result of a trip Leader took to Aiken, S.C., Thurmond said. ``He enjoyed his venture down there,'' said the 87-year-old Thurmond, the father of four children ages 13 to 18. In South Carolina, the puppies have been big news. ``When Strom announced, the dogs were on the front page and Strom was inside,'' Dole said, referring to Thurmond's recent decision to run for a seventh term. Most of the puppies already are taken. Two will go to Mrs. Dole's relatives in Raleigh, N.C., while two more will be auctioned off at charity events. The Thurmonds are charged with finding homes for the remaining three. Leader has been a frequent visitor to Capitol Hill since Mrs. Dole adopted him from the pound and gave him to her husband when he was named majority leader in 1984. The Doles have no children, although Dole has a daughter by his first marriage. Dole said he invited President Bush's dog, Millie, to the press conference. ``She was tied up in meetings,'' Dole said.

DOC.HEAD: South African Zulu Leader Urges Bush to Lift Sanctions Against Pretoria
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, a Zulu leader, conferred Wednesday on how to end apartheid in South Africa, and both agreed that black-on-black violence in Natal Province must stop. Buthelezi said afterwards he urged Bush to lift economic sanctions as soon as he legally can. The chief, a longtime foe of sanctions, said isolating South Africa just ``minimizes economic growth and maximizes black misery.'' Bush has expressed his own reservations about sanctions, but aides said later his main interest in the Oval Office meeting was in discussing ways to negotiate an end to apartheid, the system of racial discrimination that Pretoria has used to enforce white minority rule. Buthelezi is chief minister of the tribal homeland of KwaZulu and president of the 1.5-million member Inkatha movement, which has opposed the African National Congress' guerrilla tactics and advocacy of sanctions. Buthelezi told reporters that black disunity is the biggest obstacle to negotiations with the de Klerk government to end apartheid. Black-against-black fighting in Natal Province has claimed more than 2,500 lives in the past three years. Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader released from prison Feb. 11 after 27 years, appealed in Durban last Sunday for an end to that strife. To negotiate an end to apartheid, ``we as blacks must get our act together. I really feel that the biggest obstacle to negotiations taking off are these cleavages in the black community itself,'' said Buthelezi. Buthelezi deplored the violence in Natal. Like Mandela, he said, ``I, too, demand that blacks throw their guns, knives, spears, pangas and other instruments of death into the sea.'' Buthelezi said his ``gut feeling'' is that Bush will lift sanctions as soon as possible. But the Zulu leader said, ``He didn't express it in so many words.'' Buthelezi said he believes South African President F.W. de Klerk is honest and sincere. ``He has burned the bridges behind him. We can only go forward,'' the chief said. Buthelezi said last week in Johannesburg that he was the target of a ``sordid'' smear campaign by some ANC activists depicting him as the main cause of the Natal conflict. Bush has invited Mandela and de Klerk for White House visits, but no dates have been set.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Says Disarray in Likud Could Prevent Peace Progress
DOC.TEXT: Vice Premier Shimon Peres said Wednesday he believes disarray in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc could block progress in the U.S.-backed peace process. Peres, head of the left-leaning Labor Party, said in an interview with The Associated Press that Shamir's ``basic problem right now is to keep his party together'' as Likud hard-liners put increasing pressure on him to reject U.S.-proposed compromises. Asked if Shamir was likely to accept the compromises urged by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III to get preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks under way, Peres said: ``I have my doubts.'' He also repeated his warning that if Shamir's party does not move ahead with the peace process, his Labor Party may bolt from the coalition government. ``If there won't be a prospect for peace, there is no reason for us to remain in the government,'' Peres said. Shamir faces a rebellion from hard-liners in his party. Former Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, who quit the Cabinet two weeks ago, has threatened to convene Likud's decision-making Central Committee next week to challenge Shamir's policies. Sharon heads the committee, while Shamir is the chairman of the party. Sharon appeared Wednesday to be trying to lower the public debate, telling army radio: ``I think that as the situation becomes worse, we have to be quieter.'' Several other Likud legislators, however, said they would support a vote of no confidence against Shamir in Parliament if he agrees to a U.S.-backed formula that would involve Palestinians from east Jerusalem or Palestinian deportees in peace talks. Likud hard-liners fear such an approach could lead to a role for the PLO, which Israel considers a terrorist organization, or a threat to Israel's control of Arab east Jerusalem, annexed by Israel after its capture in the 1967 Middle East War. But Shamir said he believed the opposition within Likud was much broader that just the issues of east Jerusalem and deportees. ``The issue today in the Likud Party is they oppose the nature of the whole move. ... They think it's the wrong way to go,'' Peres said. Baker has been attempting to bridge differences between Israel and the Palestinians over how to start talks on Israel's plan for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The vote is designed to lead to limited self-rule for 1.7 million Palestinians and eventual talks on the final status of the occupied lands. Peres, whose party agrees to Baker's suggestions, has given Shamir a March 7 deadline to approve them. ``We are nearing the real decision now.'' Peres said. ``In a week or so we shall see what is happening.'' The Likud-Labor coaltion has been torn at least four times in the past year over how to proceed with Shamir's election plan, but Peres said the current crisis was ``more serious than previous ones.'' ``They (Likud) have reached the point where they have to make up their mind,'' he said. Peres also said that if he forms a new government, he will continue to back the election plan rather seek a new peace formula. ``If there was a new government it would stay with the current approach,'' Peres said. Asked how the changes sweeping East Europe might affect the Middle East, Peres said, ``it will affect us greatly and deeply.'' He said that as the Soviet Union reduces its support for leftist regimes, Arab nations will be forced to shift toward democratic reforms. ``A few years ago, nobody would think that Jordan would have elections ... that Russia would take resolves in their relations with Syria,'' Peres said, referring to a Soviet diplomat's call for Syria to stop seeking military parity with Israel. Asked about possible German unification, Peres said the Germans should first tell Poland that they respect current borders and should reassure the Jews by ``confronting very strongly ... nationalistic or anti-Semitic forces.''

DOC.HEAD: Hearings Focus on Math and Science Education
DOC.TEXT: To excel again in math and science, schools must change teaching methods and Americans must change their attitude that such subjects are ``too hard and too weird,'' Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said Wednesday. Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., said more federal money is needed to update equipment for science education. Cavazos told a subcommittee of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, ``Perhaps it is ambitious, courageous, maybe even a little rash'' to set a national education goal that American students will be first in the world in mathematics and science achievement in 10 years _ a goal approved by President Bush and the nation's governors Sunday. ``We can do it, but only if we make fundamental changes in math and science education,'' said Cavazos, who added that ``on every recent international test of math and science achievement, U.S. students have scored at or near the bottom.'' The Education Department has requested $24.6 billion for fiscal 1991. Cavazos said Bush's budget includes $230 million for the Eisenhower Mathematics and Science program, which supports efforts to improve math and science teaching and increase opportunities for women and minorities in these fields. There should be ``better teacher preparation,'' said Cavazos. ``We need to introduce science earlier and in an innovative way, and we need to make our math curriculum more intense. ``Studies of mathematics curricula have shown that, in contrast to other countries, U.S. students are exposed to a repetitious, slow-moving curriculum that, until eighth grade or even later, consists almost completely of low-level arithmetic skills.'' Cavazos also said, ``We must change the way we as a nation think about math and science. For too long, our national attitude has been that science and math are too hard and too weird for most people to learn, and that in any case they are irrelevant and unimportant to the everyday life of `normal' people.'' At a nearby hearing of the House Committee on Education and Labor, Williams questioned the administration's commitment to education. He said educators have told him of the struggles schools have ``trying to prepare tomorrow's scientists'' with 20-year-old equipment. ``Let's just take as a fact that equipment has to be improved,'' Williams said in questioning Charles Kolb, who oversees the Education Department's budget. ``What would you think we should use to buy new equipment? Peanuts, chocolates, Hershey bars, or would you suggest that maybe the transfer of money would be needed to buy the new equipment.'' ``The transfer of money,'' answered Kolb. ``That's the point,'' Williams said. Kolb said increased funding will not necessarily improve student achievement in math and science, or any other subjects. He noted that ``as aggregate elementary and secondary education spending in the United States rose by 27 percent from 1980 to 1988, scores on national reading and writing tests remained virtually unchanged.'' M. Edith Rasell and Lawrence Mishel of the Economic Policy Institute said that the United States does not spend huge amounts on education and pointed to their study that showed the United States spends relatively less on elementary and secondary education than 13 other industrial countries.

DOC.HEAD: After Remarks Cause Stir, MLK III Says He Opposes Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Martin Luther King III, whose remarks to a school group about homosexuality angered gay-rights groups, said Wednesday he opposes discrimination against anyone. King, a Fulton County commissioner and son of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., said in a speech Tuesday that he thinks homosexuals have a problem. ``Now something may be wrong in the makeup of that individual if they happen to be that way,'' he told middle-school students in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. ``Any man that has a desire to be with another man has a problem, in my opinion. And that applies to any woman who has a desire to be with another woman.'' The New York-based Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation called King's remarks ``strange and upsetting,'' and on Wednesday the Atlanta Gay Center requested a meeting with King to discuss the remarks. In a statement issued by his office Wednesday, King said he understands the obstacles that discrimination poses for all minorities. ``I can state without any reservation that I am totally committed to protecting the rights of members of the gay community,'' King said. ``Further, I must emphasize strongly and emphatically that I oppose any form of discrimination against gays and that I will continue to seek non-violent ways of protecting all men, women and children from any and all forms of discrimination.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Kneels To Receive Ashes From Cardinal
DOC.TEXT: As a French cardinal dabbed ashes on his forehead, Pope John Paul II on Wednesday marked the start of Lent, the Roman Catholic church's solemn period of reflection and penance before Easter. Wearing a purple velvet chasuble and a gold miter, the pope knelt down before Cardinal Gabriel-Marie Garrone to receive the symbol of Lent during an Ash Wednesday service in a 5th-century church on Rome's Aventine Hill. The pope led a procession from a Benedictine monastery to St. Sabina's church for the ceremony. In remarks to the service, the pope lamented that modern man ``seems to have barricaded himself against the Lenten call of the church'' because ``our civilization _ technical, audio-visual and self-centered'' blocks access to the truth. The Lenten's period most solemn day occurs on Good Friday, to commemorate Jesus' crucifixion. This year it occurs on April 13, followed two days later by Easter, the church's most joyous celebration.

DOC.HEAD: Rate Commission Members Want Final Say on Stamp Prices
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Postal Rate Commission urged on Wednesday that they be given the final say on how much it costs to mail a letter. Commissioner W.H. Trey LeBlanc told the House Post Office Committee that it is ``more important now than ever before'' that the commission have ``final responsibility for rates.'' The U.S. Postal Service is expected to announce next week that it wants to increase rates in 1991, probably to 30 cents for a first class stamp. Under current procedures, the independent rate commission will then have 10 months to review the proposed rates and to make a recommendation back to the Postal Service. Usually, the commission's recommendation becomes final. But the board of governors of the Postal Service can overrule it, if the governors vote unanimously to do so. That has only happened once. ``Someone has got to be accountable for what is happening,'' commented LeBlanc in urging the transfer of final rate-making power. ``I'm definitely incined toward having the final rate power in the Postal Rate Commission. I would strongly support that,'' added the newly installed commission chairman, George W. Haley. Commissioner John W. Crutcher told reporters after the hearing that he agreed with LeBlanc. Commissioner Patti Birge Tyson commented that she would like to see a system in which, if the postal board of governors disagreed with the commission, it resubmitted the proposal, rather than voting to overrule. The fifth commission member, Vice Chairman Henry W. Folsom, said that he is ``not too hung up'' on where final authority rests, noting that the commission nearly has that now, since it takes a unanimous vote of the nine postal governors to overrule them. With a new rate case expected shortly, LeBlanc also urged Congress to expand the powers of the commission to subpoena information, if necessary, for its deliberations. The members of the rate commission appeared at one of a series of congressional hearings on postal ooperations. Other hearings will include officials of the Postal Service.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Asked to Strengthen Warning on Birth Control Pills
DOC.TEXT: A private health group asked the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday to strengthen the wording of warning labels on oral contraceptives. The Public Citizen Health Research Group said its review of 13 studies published since 1977 shows that women under 45 who use birth control pills for many years may be at increased risk of developing breast cancer. An FDA advisory committee, in January 1989, recommended no changes in use of the pill, saying research on a possible link to breast cancer was inconclusive and more study was needed. More than 13 million women in the United States between the ages of 15 and 44 use oral contraceptives. Fourteen studies published in the past decade found no link between the pill and breast cancer, but few of these examined women who began using the pill at a young age and continued for many years, the group said. Of the 13 studies reviewed, three show that the risk of early breast cancer appears to increase for these women, said Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of the Health Research Group, founded by consumer advocate Ralph Nader. Wolfe said the current labeling system for oral contraceptives is ``inadequate, years out of date and misleading.'' The group, however, cautions women against stopping the pill or switching to a less effective method of birth control. Rather, the group urges women who are concerned to discuss the research with their doctor.

DOC.HEAD: Advocacy Group Disagrees With Rail Industry, Government Over Safety
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group said Wednesday that train accidents involving hazardous materials jumped 32 percent in a year, but government regulators and the rail industry said safety has improved. Testifying before a congressional subcommittee, Citizen Action released a report saying that one in seven rail accidents now involves toxic materials and toxic accidents on major rail lines jumped 75 percent in 1988, the most recent year for which complete data is available. Both Federal Railroad Administration and American Association of Railroads officials said the non-profit group used selective data to support its conclusions. They told the Government Operations transportation subcommittee that train accidents in which hazardous materials were actually released have fallen sharply since the mid-1970s and fell from 50 in 1987 to 44 in 1988 and rose to 53 in 1989. Citizen Action, which claims 1.8 million members and has taken stands against insurance industry overcharging and in favor of a national health care program, said Federal Railroad Administration figures show 361 accidents involving hazardous materials in 1987 and an increase to 475 in 1988. The group gave no number for 1989. All of the figures come Transportation Department reports. The difference is that the advocacy group includes all accidents involving a train carrying toxic materials and the FRA and AAR point only to accidents where hazardous materials were released. ``The study makes clear that toxic rail shipments are a growing danger to the public,'' said John Cameron of Citizen Action. The study was conducted for Citizen Action by Illinois Public Action, which found that Illinois led the nation in the number of toxic rail accidents in 1988. ``We have achieved considerable improvement in railroad safety during the past 12 years,'' said Gregory B. McBride, FRA chief counsel for safety, adding that he thought it has been ``dramatic'' improvement. McBride accused Citizen Action of ``a significantly misleading use of the statistics.'' He said the group was trying to reach a predetermined result with ``vague and not constructive'' findings. William H. Dempsey, president of AAR, which represents the rail industry, said there have been ``dramatic improvements in the safe transportation of hazardous materials.'' But Dempsey acknowledged that railroads ``run the risk of having fairly catastrophic accidents, and that is the incentive we have to improve safety.'' Between 1979 and 1988, Dempsey said, fatalities in train accidents went down 16 percent, lost work time due to accidents declined 66 percent and train accidents dropped 69 percent.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Finds Lax Regulation of Free-Standing Health Centers
DOC.TEXT: Growing numbers of Americans are getting their medical care at walk-in clinics and other free-standing centers that are inadequately regulated to ensure quality care, a congressional report said Wednesday. The General Accounting Office said states don't license or regulate most types of free-standing medical facilities, and they impose few penalties when problems are uncovered at licensed centers. The report was released by Rep. Edward Roybal, D-Calif., who said the lack of oversight ``permits abuses in patient care to occur with increasing frequency.'' ``When Americans walk into unlicensed facilities, they walk in with blindfolds _ unaware of the competence of the provider or of the quality of care they will receive,'' said Roybal, who chairs the House Select Committee on Aging and its subcommittee on health and long-term care. The GAO report had been requested by Roybal's predecessor as subcommittee chairman, the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. It covers free-standing facilities such as walk-in health clinics, 24-hour emergency centers, mental health centers, cancer treatment facilities, cardiac catheterization laboratories, surgical centers, and alcohol and drug abuse treatment facilities. ``States have been slow to license free-standing providers; further, they have limited plans to expand licensing requirements,'' the GAO said. ``No one else currently fills the gaps. Consumers, therefore, do not have adequate assurance that unlicensed free-standing providers are giving quality care.'' Free-standing medical clinics and health maintenance organizations have expanded rapidly in recent years as a result of efforts to control health care costs, developing technology and increased competition, the GAO said. Roybal noted that before cost-control rules were imposed on hospitals in the early 1980s, 95 percent of cataract surgeries were performed in hospitals. He said 95 percent of the operations now are performed outside of hopsitals to avoid those cost controls. A study prepared for the National Conference of State Legislatures estimated that up to 40 percent of diagnostic procedures and surgeries are being done outside hospitals. Among the findings in the GAO report: _Only Montana and New York require licenses for all the types of health-care centers operating in their states. _No state licenses or otherwise regulates cancer treatment centers or pain control centers, although such centers are operating in 14-18 states. _Only Virginia and California license cardiac catheterization laboratories, although the procedure sometimes can involve complications that result in death, stroke, heart attack or uncontrolled hemorrhaging. _Less than half the states require licenses for independent clinical laboratories, walk-in clinics or out-patient psychiatric centers. _States frequently did not know what types and numbers of free-standing clinics were operating within their borders. The GAO found that even those centers that are licensed by the states are subject to few sanctions. In fiscal 1987, for example, 23,000 free-standing health facilities were licensed by the states, of which 165 were cited for deficiences and 28 had their licenses suspended or revoked. Officials in 36 states expressed concerns about the adequacy of their oversight of free-standing centers, but most had no plans to regulate more facilities, the GAO said.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Viewing Site Closed, But Secrecy Policy Under Review
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle fans must wait until April to watch an orbiter land, but officials are reviewing the policy that will keep Atlantis' arrival closed to public viewing, NASA said Wednesday. Discussions on ending the secrecy policy are being held between officials of the Air Force and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said space agency spokeswoman Nancy Lovato. Atlantis blasted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla., early Wednesday on a much-delayed mission, reportedly to put a $500 million spy satellite in orbit. The flight is expected to last about four days and 10 hours, so the shuttle should land at this Mojave Desert military base Sunday morning. The unpaved public viewing site on the east shore of Rogers Dry Lake at this high-desert base has been jammed with up to 500,000 spectators during non-military shuttle landings. But, as is the case on all classified shuttle missions, it will be closed when Atlantis returns to Earth. ``We're sorry it's closed, but of course we're due to have another (non-classified) landing coming up in April, so people are invited and welcome to attend the April landing,'' Lovato said. The shuttle Discovery is scheduled for launch April 12 on a five-day mission to put the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit, NASA spokesman Don Haley said. The no-spectator policy for military shuttle landings has been under review for some time, Lovato said, adding that she believes a decision is likely before the next Defense Department flight, scheduled for July. The rationale for the spectator ban isn't clear, since news reporters and photographers have been allowed to watch and photograph military shuttle landings, and they have done so from a site closer to the runway than the public viewing site. Those landings also have been televised, and the shuttle landings are visible from sections of state Highway 58 north of Edwards Air Force Base.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Prices at Farm Drop Slightly in February, Says USDA
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers got for raw products declined 0.6 percent from January to February, but overall commodity index still averaged 2.7 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Lower prices for milk, eggs, lettuce and wheat were mostly responsible for the decline from January, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. However, the report said higher prices for cattle, broiler and tomatoes partly offset the decline for the other commodities during the month. ``Tomato prices for February were at the highest level of records,'' the report said. ``During the past two months prices have been about twice the previous record established in March of 1985.'' The price climb was due to short supplies caused by the December freeze in Florida in December, the report said. On the other hand, the report said the drop in milk prices paid to farmers _ which had been at record levels _ was largest month-to-month decline ever recorded. And the egg price drop was said to be the third-largest on record. The report did not include new figures on farm expenses. Those are computed every three months. In January, however, new quarterly figures showed that prices paid by farmers were up 1.1 percent from October, the previous reading, and averaged 2.9 percent more than a year earlier. Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with $48 billion last year. Consumer food prices are forecast by USDA economists to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told Congress on Wednesday that farm commodity prices are expected to be ``relatively favorable'' in 1990 because of strong demand and declining inventories of most crops. He said feed grains and soybeans may be exceptions, however. ``Production may rise as acreage reduction requirements for wheat, cotton and rice are lessened, bringing more acreage into production,'' he told a Senate Appropriation subcommittee. Based on the preliminary figures, the February price index for livestock and poultry was down 0.6 percent from January but was up 8.2 percent from February 1989. Milk prices dropped 80 cents from January to $14.90 per 100 pounds but were still $1.80 more than a year ago. Crop prices, overall, dropped 0.7 percent from December and were 2.9 percent below the year-earlier average. The report said: _Cattle averaged $74.60 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $73.70 in January and $71.60 in February 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $48.20 per 100 pounds, compared with $47.30 in February and $40.40 a year earlier. _Corn, at $2.27 a bushel, edged down from $2.31 in January and was down from $2.59 a year earlier. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $3.57 per bushel, compared with $3.71 in January and $4.03 a year earlier. _Rice averaged $7.29 per 100 pounds, compared with $7.40 in January and $6.67 in February 1989. _Soybeans were $5.51 per bushel, down from $5.65 in January and $7.41 a year earlier. _Upland cotton was reported at 61.7 cents per pound, up from 59.8 in January and 52.8 a year earlier. _Eggs were 70.4 cents per dozen, compared with 83.8 in January and 62.1 in February 1989. _Milk was $14.90 per 100 pounds, down from $15.70 in January but above the average of $13.10 a year ago. _Broilers were 33.5 cents per pound, live weight, up from 30.7 cents in January but down from 38.3 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Controversial Prosecutor as U.S. Attorney in Florida
DOC.TEXT: The White House announced Wednesday that President Bush will nominate Dexter W. Lehtinen as U.S. attorney for South Florida, a job he has held on an acting basis for nearly two years. The nomination of the prosecutor, whose tenure has been marked by controversy, had been in limbo for months, in part because of an FBI background check. Lehtinen, 43, is a battle-scarred Vietnam veteran who graduated at the top of his class from Stanford Law School in 1975. In January, he indicated at first he would be the lead prosecutor in the drug prosecution of Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed ruler of Panama. He then stepped aside and appointed members of his office to lead the prosecution team. The tough-talking Lehtinen once created a stir by waving what he later said was a replica AK-47 assault rifle at a meeting with prosecutors to dramatize the seriousness of the fight against drugs. He is a former Florida state representative and senator whose wife, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, was elected to Congress last year as a Republican to fill the Miami seat left vacant by the death of Rep. Claude Pepper. Lehtinen worked as a Justice Department assistant attorney in California in 1975-77 and in Miami on the Miami Organized Crime Strike Force in 1978-81. He began his career in Florida state politics in 1980, then returned to the U.S. attorney's office in Miami in 1988 after Leon B. Kellner stepped down. The Miami Herald printed excerpts from his FBI background report in January, including allegations that he had pushed his first wife down and abused an ex-girlfriend. The Herald reported that the White House had decided to hold up the nomination to see if any further charges surfaced, but that the president still intended to support Lehtinen barring any new revelations. The post requires Senate confirmation. The White House said Bush ``announced his intention to nominate'' Lehtinen to the job for a four-year term. Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla., said Wednesday he expects to support Lehtinen's nomination when it reaches the Senate floor. Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., had expressed reservations, but said Wednesday he is also inclined to support the nomination. Lehtinen and his wife have four children and live in Miami. She is the first Cuban-American to serve in Congress.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Official Unsure If Andy Rooney Suspension Hurt ``60 Minutes''
DOC.TEXT: Although an ABC show beat CBS' ``60 Minutes'' in ratings Sunday, a senior ABC official said Wednesday it's simplistic to think the Andy Rooney controversy has caused the CBS show's recent ratings decline. ABC's Alan Wurtzel said he didn't have any research to show ``60 Minutes'' was hurt by CBS' suspension of Rooney from the show after a gay magazine attributed a racial slur to him. The humorist denies saying it. ``It's very simplistic and one-dimensional to think that any one event triggers things like that'' ratings decline, said Wurtzel, ABC's senior vice president for research. ``I think it's a much more complicated thing.'' ``60 Minutes'' was 18th in national ratings last week, beaten in its time period by a rerun of the premiere of ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' It was the first time in 12 years an entertainment show has beaten a first-run ``60 Minutes'' broadcast. In a memo to his staff, Don Hewitt, ``60 Minutes'' executive producer, said he guessed the Rooney flap had ``played a pretty big part'' in the ratings results. ``60 Minutes'' was in 11th place the previous week, and in 10th place the week before that. Rooney was suspended without pay for three months on Feb. 8. CBS says the suspension still is in effect, despite reports it may end soon. Michael Eisenberg, a CBS research vice president, said ABC's Sunday show drew viewers because ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' is ``a pretty hot show and would do well wherever you put it.'' He noted that ``60 Minutes'' still is sixth in ratings averages for the season to date, averaging a 33 per cent share of audience. It averaged a 20 rating on a scale in which each ratings point represents 921,000 homes watching a show. Wurtzel met with reporters to discuss the February ratings ``sweeps'' period that ended Wednesday. His NBC and CBS counterparts will hold similar sessions Thursday. His figures, lacking just the last two days of ratings for the period, didn't produce any surprises. NBC continued to lead in prime time ratings, with a 15.1 average rating for the period, followed by ABC with a 13.0 and CBS with a 12.6. He ducked a question on whether he thought ``60 Minutes'' would continue to decline in the ratings. Noting that the show has been on the air since 1968, he said it's ``still a strong show. But I don't think I'm surprised to see that there's been a certain amount of slippage.'' He cited as factors the cyclical nature of television and competition against CBS' newsmagazine series from ``an enormous proliferation of similar types of programs'' in recent months. Wurtzel, speaking of the ratings slide of the once-dominant ``CBS Evening News'' and the rise of ABC's ``World News Tonight,'' predicted that the latter's string of ratings victories will continue. ABC's broadcast has won seven consecutive weeks in evening news ratings. CBS' program has been in third place for five of the last eight weeks, and tied once with the ``NBC Evening News'' for second place, CBS estimates show. ``In essence, what we see is that CBS and NBC will be fighting it out for second place position for some time to come,'' Wurtzel said.

DOC.HEAD: News on the Health Front
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contains AM-Heart-Diet, a0615; AM-Colds Blocker, a0607; AM-Food Flavorings, a0623; AM-Fetal Monitoring, a0640; AM-Epilepsy Drug, a0646; AM-CDC-AIDS Report. The first, second, third and fifth items are embargoed until 6 p.m. EST.
For release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Heart-conscious eaters can safely add monounsaturated fats to their low-fat diets, but it probably won't reduce their cholesterol, a study concludes. Researchers who compared blood cholesterol levels in groups of men after they followed diets with different levels of saturated, monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats found that while monounsaturated fats don't raise cholesterol, they don't lower it significantly either. ``What we hoped to do here was try to straighten out some misconceptions about `monos' that have arisen ... that they had some independent effect on lowering cholesterol,'' said Dr. Henry N. Ginsberg who worked on the study, published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine.
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Getting lots of potassium is no substitute for taking high blood pressure medicines, according to a report being published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. Researchers studied 287 middle-age men already on medication for high blood pressure and put half on potassium and half on placebos. Then their regular blood pressure medicines were withdrawn. During the next two years, the men took the potassium or dummy supplements and followed low-salt diets. About half the people in both groups had to resume taking blood pressure pills because of rising blood pressure. The researchers said their work suggests that ``potassium supplementation does not reduce the need for anti-hypertensive medication of men on a low-sodium diet.'' The study was suggested by population research that found groups with high levels of potassium in their diets also tend to have healthy blood pressures.
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have created a substance that blocks infection by viruses that cause colds, a possible step toward drugs that could prevent or ease up to 45 percent of all colds. But one of the study's authors, Steven Marlin, cautioned that it was done in the test tube, and speculating on its meaning for a human cold is ``a huge leap.'' In the study, scientists decoyed cold-causing rhinoviruses into attaching themselves to a free-floating man-made version of a molecule that the viruses normally bind to on the surfaces of healthy cells, thus diverting the viruses from their normal target. By this process, researchers found the man-made molecule was largely able to block rhinovirus infection of human cells in the test tube. The research is presented in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature.

Labels on meat and poultry products will have to be more specific when certain flavorings are used, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Federal rules are being changed, effective March 1, to require ``proteinaceous material'' derived from livestock, poultry, eggs, milk, plants and yeast to be listed on labels by their names. In the past, such substances could be listed simply as ``flavorings'' or similar terms. For example, a popular ``flavor agent'' or enhancer used for years in hot dogs will have to be labeled ``milk protein hydrolyzate.'' Lester M. Crawford of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service said the new rule was adopted ``to better protect the public health and serve the consumer's right to know'' what is in food products.
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Electronic fetal monitors routinely used in hospital delivery rooms aren't any better _ and perhaps riskier _ than ordinary stethoscopes for monitoring the progress of babies during birth, a study concludes. Researchers found signs that cerebral palsy may be more common among infants whose births are electronically monitored, although they cautioned that this finding could be a statistical fluke. But even if electronic monitoring isn't any worse than the traditional stethoscope, the study failed to find evidence that it improves the chances of a healthy birth. One researcher noted that, in part, the wide use of electronic monitors has taught doctors what warning signs they need to listen for with their stethoscopes. The results were published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine.

A drug used to prevent epileptic seizures can lose a third of its effectiveness if stored in humid conditions, according to study results released Wednesday by the Food and Drug Administration. The FDA is asking manufacturers of the epilepsy drug, carbamazepine, to change their packaging of the drug to keep out moisture. Users of the drug should keep their supplies tightly closed in a cool, dry place, away from bathrooms, showers and humidifiers, the agency said. The research found that when carbamazepine tablets were exposed to humidity, they hardened and dissolved poorly in test liquids. Blood samples confirmed that carbamazepine tablets that dissolved poorly also were absorbed poorly by the body and were less effective.

Growth in federal financing for AIDS prevention will slow down because AIDS has to compete for funds with other health problems and national priorities, the Centers for Disease Control warns in a new draft report on AIDS in the 1990s. ``Program needs can be expected to continue to grow at a pace that will probably exceed available resources,'' the CDC cautioned. ``We must approach our planning with an awareness of these changes and a willingness to change.'' The CDC, in a preliminary draft of its ``Strategic Plan for Prevention of HIV Infection, 1990 _ and Beyond,'' outlines the agency's goals and objectives for AIDS. Recommendations in the plan, such as proposals for increased testing, counseling and partner notifications aren't specific suggestions to state and local health agencies, but rather are ``a plan, communicating generally to the public,'' said Dr. Gary Noble, deputy director for AIDS programs. After public comment and possible revisions, the CDC report is scheduled for release in June.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll from Europe Storm Rises to 65
DOC.TEXT: Europe's second deadly storm of the year took three more lives Wednesday, bringing the death toll to 65 in three days of severe winds that caused destruction from Sweden to Sicily. Firefighters controlled brush fires that had been fanned by 70 mph winds on Corsica, the French Mediterranean island southeast of Nice, but forecasters said winds up to 100 mph could hit again on Thursday. About 800 people were evacuated Tuesday night as fires approached their villages but most were returning home Wednesday, Corsican officials said. A 50-year-old woman was killed Wednesday in Catania, Sicily, when wind buffeted her car and sent it crashing into a tree, and a 57-year-old man died in Salonica, Greece, when his car was blown off the road. Altogether, 18 people were reported killed in Britain, 12 each in West Germany and France, six in Switzerland and Italy, five in Belgium, three in East Germany, and one each in Ireland, Greece and the Netherlands. In Denmark, a West German father and son were feared dead after disappearing on a fishing trip. The European Community announced about $2 million in emergency aid for Red Cross associations in seven stricken countries, with Britain getting the largest share, $600,000. Prince Charles cut short his Swiss skiing holiday so that he and Princess Diana could visit flood-stricken northwestern Wales on Thursday. In the seaside resort of Towyn, 800 villagers fled their homes when the sea wall broke and were being housed in four temporary shelters including a factory cafeteria and Bodelwyddan Castle. Tractors and large trucks dumped 5-ton boulders during low tide periods to fill the 2,000-foot gap knocked into the sea wall by storm waters. ``We will be consolidating it and progressively strengthening it in the future, but for now the main thing is to get something very solid in place,'' said Colwyn Borough Council chief executive Bill Breeze. The 50,000 residents of Cockermouth and Workington in northwestern England were warned Wednesday to boil their water because the storm had knocked out power at a treatment plant. High winds knocked out power to thousands in Sweden's second-largest city, Goteborg. In Denmark, an empty ferry sank in her berth, several towns along the west coast were flooded and fallen trees blocked roads. Finnish army recruits and firefighters left the presidential palace in downtown Helsinki after spending the night piling sand bags along the sea front only 110 yards away. ``The president is in, but there's no danger,'' Deputy Fire Chief Ake Gronmark said. Swiss trains and buses rolled back to a normal schedule after transportation was halted Tuesday by 167 mph winds, the strongest on record in that nation, the Swiss weather office said. Many alpine villagers were stranded without electricity by rain and winds that Swiss newspapers headlined ``the storm of the century.'' The Swiss government has set up a crisis unit for the forestry industry. Authorities say the storm knocked down $67 million in timber, one-quarter of the nation's yearly consumption. French fishermen who have been kept in port much of the month by storms will be eligible for unemployment and other benefits, the government said. In Greece, the Merchant Marine Ministry banned all passenger and ferry ships from sailing to islands in the Aegean and Ionian seas because of gale-force winds. High-spirited ferry passengers stranded 24 hours in the North Sea when the dock gate at Teesport was damaged, streamed off the Norstar Wednesday at the British port after having ``a whale of a time'' assisted by a full stock of alcohol. ``A lot of people enjoyed it,'' passenger John Asher said. ``With a great crowd of 600 on board, 150 of them Liverpudlians, and plenty of duty-free drink, what else could you expect?''

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor Pleads Innocent to Cocaine, Perjury Charges
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 10-11, bgng, Subpoenas were ... with additional subpoenas, picks up 10th graf pvs., All but ...
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, back in the capital for the first time in more than a month, pleaded innocent Wednesday to cocaine possession and perjury charges filed after an investigation into his ties to a convicted drug dealer. ``We will not plea bargain, and the mayor is not considering resigning,'' Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, said after the nine-minute court proceeding. ``The mayor is confident he will be vindicated at trial.'' U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson scheduled a June 4 trial on three counts of perjury and five counts of misdemeanor possession of cocaine. Barry is enrolled in a substance abuse treatment program at the Fenwick Hall hospital outside Charleston, S.C.. A senior Barry aide speaking on condition of anonymity said Barry, who returned to Washington Tuesday, would go back to the center later Wednesday. Mundy said the mayor's treatment for alcoholism was ``going well'' and Barry was in ``good spirits.'' Barry, 53, did not speak to reporters upon entering or exiting the courthouse. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens would not comment on the possibility of a plea bargain, but said that the probe was continuing ``with respect to a variety of allegations'' involving Barry and various city services. Meanwhile, a top city government source said prosecutors have delivered subpoenas to ``at least a dozen'' city agencies that have had dealings with eight of Barry's close friends. The city records of those Barry associates were subpoenaed last week. The new subpoenas have been issued to determine whether there were any irregularities in any contracts the mayor's friends have received, sources said. Subpoenas were also issued Wednesday for a number of Barry's telephone records, including the period surrounding Barry's arrest at a downtown Washington hotel in January, a city government source said. The subpoenas for the mayor's office and car telephone records include the periods from Jan. 1, 1988, through March, 31, 1988 and Jan. 1, 1989, through Jan. 23, 1990, the source said. Barry was arrested and charged with cocaine possession in an FBI sting operation at a downtown Washington hotel Jan. 18 and left for a Florida substance abuse treatment center on Jan. 22. All but one of the charges against the mayor stem from an investigation into Barry's ties to convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, who has testified that he supplied the mayor with crack cocaine in December 1988. One possession charge involved the mayor's sting operation arrest. Barry sat at the defense table reading the indictment prior to the start of his arraignment and did not speak as Mundy entered the innocent pleas. Mundy said Barry's wife, Effi, did not attend the court session on his advice. Prior to the mayor's arrival at the courthouse, 18 Guardian Angels paraded outside, chanting that the mayor should leave office. Many carried signs reading ``Mr. Mayor, do the right thing _ resign.'' All were chanting, ``Barry, it's the time, it's time for you to resign.'' Reporters and cameramen were ordered by police off the plaza outside the main entrance to the courthouse amid fears of a repeat of the melee that resulted from Barry's court appearance on Jan. 19, the day following his arrest. If convicted of all charges filed against him, the mayor could face a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $1.25 million fine.

DOC.HEAD: Important Prosecution Witness in Bensonhurst Case Missing
DOC.TEXT: A witness in the alleged killing of a black teen-ager by a gang of white youths has been missing for two months and prosecutors will try to delay next week's trial if he is not located soon, a district attorney said Wednesday. The witness, John Vento, 21, an alleged participant in the Aug. 23 attack in the predominantly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, had agreed to testify before a grand jury and at the trial, said Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes. Under an agreement with the former Brooklyn district attorney, in exchange for his testimony Vento would not be charged in the attack, Hynes said. He described Vento as ``a very important witness'' but said his absence was ``not devastating.'' ``It's important to have Vento in this case,'' Hynes said. ``But if we don't find him, we're going to proceed.'' On Monday, when defendants in the case are scheduled to go on trial, prosecutors will ask state Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens to postpone the trial for a month, Hynes said. The judge signed a material witness order on Feb. 14 directing Vento to appear at the trial. If Vento surrenders within the next several weeks, Hynes said he would abide by the agreement. But if Vento refuses to voluntarily come forward he could face second-degree murder charges for his role in the shooting death of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, Hynes said. ``I do not choose to do that right now because I'm not looking to make this witness an antagonistic witness. I'm looking to have him do the right thing and give some justice to this kid,'' Hynes said at a news conference. There was no indication Vento has met with foul play, Hynes said. ``I suspect the reason he took off was a fairly uncomplicated one,'' Hynes said. ``As the trial drew closer, he chickened out.'' Hawkins was fatally shot when he and three friends, all black, were surrounded by a gang of young whites shortly after they arrived in Bensonhurst to look at a used car. Six defendants face trial on second-degree murder charges and a seventh was charged with first-degree assault. All of them except the alleged trigger man, Joseph Fama, 18, have been released on bail. An attorney for Fama, Stanley Meyer, said he would oppose an adjournment because the judge earlier denied defense requests for more time to prepare their cases. He said he believed Vento was ``a major component in the case. Apparently, he's going to say someone put the gun in Fama's hands.'' Prosecutors learned early in January from Vento's parents that their son ``had taken off during the Christmas holidays,'' Hynes said. Police and the FBI traced Vento to undisclosed locations upstate and in Ohio, but prosecutors believe he is now in the New York City area. Vento's lawyer, Gerald Dichiara, said ``I haven't seen him in months.'' He said Vento may have fled after it became apparent he would have to testify against his friends.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates U.S. Marshal, Others
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate Leo A. Giacometto, a Montana state representative, to be the U.S. Marshal for Montana, the White House said Wednesday. Giacometto, 27, is also an executive assistant to Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont. He owns and manages a ranch in Alzada, Mont. He would succeed Ronald J. Alles as marshal. The White House said Bush will nominate two new regents for the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences. They are Drs. Clarence S. Avery, a surgeon at Holderman Hospital in Yountville, Calif., and George Tryon Harding IV, a psychiatry professor at Ohio State University's College of Medicine. It said Bush also will appoint Harry R. King of the Cypress Creek Co. of Louisville, Ky., as the new chairman of the board of the Student Loan Marketing Assocation. In addition, he will name Stan Huckaby of Huckaby and Associates in Alexandria, Va., to the board.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Court Denies Tax Deduction to Anthony Accardo
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Tax Court on Wednesday denied reputed Chicago mob boss Anthony J. Accardo a tax deduction for $224,500 of legal fees incurred in winning acquittal on racketeering charges. Accardo contended that the fees were deductible on grounds that he had spent the money to prevent government confiscation of his income-producing bank accounts. The court noted that Accardo ``does not explain why he believes that none of his legal fees were incurred to conserve and maintain his other, non-income-producing property ... (condominiums in Illinois and California) or to keep him out of jail.'' ``No part of the legal fees is deductible,'' the court held. ``Petitioner's (Accardo's) situation is no different from that of any defendant in a criminal or civil trial who faces a potential fine or monetary judgment that must be paid out of income-producing assets such as savings accounts, certificates of deposit or stocks.'' Accardo was acquitted in Miami in 1982 of racketeering charges alleging a kickback conspiracy in affairs of the Laborers Union.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Leader To Become Yankees' Operations Chief
DOC.TEXT: After years in the trenches of America's drug war, Drug Enforcement Administration chief John C. Lawn is heading to a new turf: overseeing operations for the New York Yankees baseball organization. ``He will be involved with all operational areas other than player personnel,'' Yankees spokesman Arthur Richman said Wednesday. Lawn, who announced Tuesday that he will retire as DEA chief on March 23 after 27 years in government service, will become vice president and chief of operations for the Yankees, he said. Yankees owner George Steinbrenner met Lawn in 1987 when the two were on a speaking panel before the World Business Council, said DEA spokesman Frank Shults. In addition, Lawn is a close personal friend of Phil McNiss, a retired FBI agent who is vice president of Steinbrenner's American Shipbuilding Co., the spokesman said. McNiss recommended Lawn ``very highly'' for the job, and was instrumental in his hiring, said Richman, senior vice president for the Yankees. Lawn's starting date with the Yankees remains uncertain, Richman said. ``Mr. Steinbrenner said he can take all the time necessary to assist President Bush in seeking and counseling a replacement,'' he said. Richman said Lawn would not be involved in any anti-drug activities with the Yankees. Shults described Lawn as ``very athletic,'' but said there was no indication he had any particular background in baseball. The DEA chief was a basketball coach when he taught English and American history at the Jesuit-run Brooklyn Preparatory School for seven years after leaving the Marine Corps and before beginning his law enforcement career, Shults said. In 1964, Lawn was named New York City's high school coach of the year, he said. Lawn joined the FBI in 1967 and was named DEA acting deputy administrator in 1982. President Reagan nominated him to the top DEA job in 1985 to replace Francis M. Mullen, who had retired.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Halts Attacks on Contras; Chamorro Vows to Run Things
LaserPhotos MGA5,6
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega declared a halt to attacks on the Contras Wednesday and called again on the United States to help dismantle the rebel force. President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who joined Ortega on Tuesday in asking the U.S.-backed Contras to put down their arms, praised his move as a step forward. ``The causes of civil war in Nicaragua have disappeared,'' Mrs. Chamorro told a news conference. ``There is no reason for war.'' She said the Contras, most of them based in neighboring Honduras, ``must lay down their weapons and come home to work for the reconstruction of Nicaragua.'' Ortega said in a statement that he ordered all offensive military operations against the Contras to halt. He said the United States should help pay for demobilizing and relocating the rebels. Mrs. Chamorro upset Ortega in an election on Sunday that he agreed to as part of a Central American plan for ending the war and which he clearly expected to win. Demobilizing the Contras is the trickiest issue in transition talks that began Tuesday between Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition, the United National Opposition, and the stunned Sandinistas, who have been in power for 10{ years. Sandinista officials say they cannot give up control of the armed forces and police, both party organs, as long as the 10,000-man Contra army is intact. Mrs. Chamorro made it clear she expects Ortega to keep his promise to turn over power and that her government plans to run the army and security forces. ``I'm the one who is going to give orders,'' said the silver-haired widow, who was chosen to run against Ortega because of her powerful symbolic value. The 1978 death of her husband, opposition publisher Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, touched off the revolution that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza and put the Sandinistas in power. She said the Sandinistas ``have to turn over everything,'' including the armed forces _ the traditional source of real power in Latin America. ``The minister of defense will be a civilian,'' she declared. The current minister, Gen. Humberto Ortega, the president's brother, leads the Sandinista transition team. Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and campaign manager, Antonio Lacayo, heads the United National Opposition team. The transition talks are expected to be complex and delicate. Ortega laid out tough Sandinista positions on Tuesday before thousands of cheering party members. He demanded demobilization of the Contras and said the party would ``defend the integrity and the professionalism of the army and the police forces.'' Mrs. Chamorro campaigned on a platform that promised an end to the draft and drastic cuts in the armed forces, which Soviet aid has built into the most powerul military machine in the region. The statement from the Sandinista leadership also challenged privatization, a major plank in the UNO platform. Francisco Mayorga, an economic adviser to Mrs. Chamorro, said the new government would not return banks to private ownership. ``The banks will stay nationalized,'' he said in a brief interview while waiting for Mrs. Chamorro's news conference to begin. Mayorga said he was going to New York and Washington this week at the head of an UNO delegation seeking funds to help Nicaragua rebuild. The economy has been savaged by the civil war, a U.S. economic embargo and poor management. The Bush administration, which backed UNO, has said Mrs. Chamorro's victory means it will lift the embargo. Mrs. Chamorro's running mate, Virgilio Godoy, told reporters he suspects the Sandinistas of trying to alter election returns to affect the outcome of the National Assembly races. But former U.S. Attorney General Elliot Richardson, leader of the United Nations election monitoring team, said nothing was amiss with the vote count. ``Everything is normal,'' he said by telephone. Richardson said final results should be released within days. Preliminary results based on returns from 82 percent of the precincts indicate Mrs. Chamorro took 55.2 percent of the vote to Ortega's 40.8 percent, with the remainder going to minor party nominees. UNO won 52 seats in the National Assembly while the Sandinistas got 39, including one awarded to Ortega as a presidential candidate who got at least 1 percent of the vote, according to preliminary figures. Depending on final returns, Moises Hassan of the Revolutionary Unity Movement may also qualify for a seat as a losing presidential candidate, which would mean a 92-member assembly. The 240-member U.N. team was one of hundreds of organizations monitoring Sunday's general elections.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Says Foreigners With AIDS Should be Allowed to Visit U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The Centers for Disease Control is recommending that AIDS and virtualy all other contagious diseases be dropped as reasons for preventing foreigners from entering the United States, a federal health official said Wednesday. The CDC's action on AIDS is largely symbolic, however, because the list still would include infection with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. That restriction was imposed by Congress. The recommendation by the CDC to remove AIDS is seen as ``signaling Congress that they should take HIV off'' the list as well, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Along with AIDS, the CDC is recommending removing from the list all other contagious diseases except infectious tuberculosis, the source said. After a review of the diseases on the list, including syphilis, gonorrhea and leprosy, the CDC decided that only tuberculosis posed an important threat because it is highly contagious in its active stage. While AIDS is also contagious, certain behavior _ such as sexual contact or needle-sharing _ is required to transmit the virus. Efforts are underway in Congress to give the administration complete discretion as to what diseases to put on the list. However, an aide on the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee said ``it's still an open question'' whether an act of Congress is required. The immigration regulations concerning AIDS have been protested by AIDS activist groups, including the National Commission on AIDS and the World Health Organization. Several groups, including the National Association of People with AIDS, have said they will boycott two major AIDS conferences in the United States this year unless the restrictions are changed. Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health at the Department of Health and Human Services, asked the CDC to review the diseases on the immigration-restriction list and recommend changes. The list had not been reviewed since 1977. After consulting with outside medical experts, the CDC recommended that all but tuberculosis be dropped from the list. If Mason approves the recommendation, the change would be published in the Federal Register before taking effect.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Moving Toward Eastern European Trade Agreements
