DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Wednesday the administration was moving quickly to negotiate preferential trade agreements to support the new reform governments in Eastern Europe. But she cautioned that the success of the new governments would depend on the extent of internal reforms rather than outside assistance from other Western nations. In congressional testimony, Hills said that it was crucial for the new leaders in Eastern Europe to realize that ``minimal measures to reform a command economy simply will not work. Real substantive change is the best hope.'' She said each formerly communist government needed to institute market-oriented reforms emphasizing private ownership and decentralized economic decision-making along with providing adequate protections for foreign investors. ``The degree and the speed of economic reform in these centrally planned economies will be the determining factor in whether their economies develop and their products are able to become competitive in world markets,'' she told members of the House Ways and Means Committee. The administration has already begun funneling economic assistance to Poland and Hungary while making plans to provide help for other Eastern European nations as well. Hills said the administration was in various stages of the negotiating process to enact new trade treaties granting the countries most favored nation status, which qualifies them for the lowest tariffs granted to any nation with which America trades. Poland and Hungary have already been granted the most favored nation designation and the administration two weeks ago launched negotiations with the Soviet Union aimed at awarding the Soviets similar status. Hills said the second round of the Soviet trade talks would be held in London on Thursday and Friday. A third session is scheduled for later in March and Hills repeated the administration's goal of having a treaty ready for signing at the next summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev in June. Granting the Soviets the lower tariffs hinges on final approval by the Soviet parliament of a liberalized emigration law. Several members of the committee questioned Hills about the refusal of the Soviets to allow direct commercial airline flights from the Soviet Union to Israel, saying American trade negotiators should push for these flights in order to facilitate Jewish emigration from the country. Hills said that Secretary of State James A. Baker III had raised this issue with the Soviets but that the administration did not want the trade normalization effort to hinge on the airline issue.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Win in 1st Senate Tiff Over `Peace Dividend'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs with ``no'' votes and those not voting.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats prevailed Wednesday in the year's first congressional battle over the so-called peace dividend, pushing language through the Senate recommending that defense budget savings be used to slash the federal deficit. In the second of a pair of votes, a Republican alternative urging the use of the moneys to cut taxes was defeated by majority Democrats. The fight was over a competing pair of non-binding resolutions and was therefore largely symbolic. Nonetheless, it provided a preview of a partisan dispute likely to reverberate through Congress for years: What to do with billions of dollars in planned military spending that have been made unnecessary by easing East-West tensions. The Senate voted 79-19 for language by liberal Democrats, led by Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and James Sasser, D-Tenn., urging the Senate to use defense savings mainly to help balance the federal budget. As lesser priorities, they said the savings should also be used to address ``urgent national priorities'' such as anti-drug and education efforts, and to cut taxes ``for working men and women.'' Minutes later, senators voted 50-48 against a rival proposal from 12 GOP conservatives, led by Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas, recommending that money siphoned from the Pentagon's budget ``be returned to America's taxpayers.'' The Republicans said that would include tax deductions for child care, a capital gains tax rate cut, a lowering of other tax rates and additional ideas. Democrats argued that the large tax cuts of 1981 did not improve the nation's economy and that the country has too many unaddressed problems. ``It's high time we quit squandering the treasury of this nation for overly sophisticated weapons systems,'' Sasser said. ``We need to take this peace dividend, and we need to apply these funds wisely.'' Republicans countered that in the years following the Vietnam War, moneys taken from the Pentagon budget were spent fruitlessly by Congress, a scenario that should be avoided. The term ``peace dividend,'' while widely used, can be misleading. Technically, with the government running large deficits each year, reductions in the Pentagon's budget will not leave the government with surplus dollars to spend. The Congressional Budget Office expects the deficit in fiscal 1991 _ which begins Oct. 1 _ to be $138 billion. Nonetheless, since the Warsaw Pact began deteriorating late last year, lawmakers have been arguing over what to do with the money that everyone had assumed would be used for defense spending. In his budget for the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1, President Bush proposed Pentagon spending of $292.1 billion. That is $5.3 billion more than is being spent this year but $3.9 billion below the amount that would have been needed to keep pace with inflation. Most Democrats and some Republicans have said Bush's request is too high, and most lawmakers expect Congress to approve a figure that is several billion dollars lower. The resolutions were offered as amendments to a bill that would allow the government to spend $125 million to set up programs for volunteers. In the 79-19 vote by which the Senate adopted the Democratic peace dividend resolution, those voting no were: Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo.; John Chafee, R-R.I.; John Danforth, R-Mo.; Bob Dole, R-Kan.; Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M.; Jake Garn, R-Utah; Charles Grassley, R-Iowa; Jesse Helms, R-N.C.; Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H.; James Jeffords, R-Vt.; Nancy Landon Kassebaum; R-Kan.; Richard Lugar, R-Ind.; Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska; William Roth, D-Del.; Warren Rudman, R-N.H.; Alan Simpson, R-Wyo.; Ted Stevens, R-Alaska; Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., and John Warner, R-Va. Not voting were Pete Wilson, R-Calif., and Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Brings Heavy Rain And Snow To South Central US
DOC.TEXT: A storm moving out of the southern Rockies spread heavy rain and snow over parts of the south-central section of the nation Wednesday. The heaviest overnight accumulation was in southeastern Colorado, where 12 inches fell at Lamar, 8 inches fell in Walsh and 7 inches fell at Holly. Light snow fell across all of eastern Colorado and much of Kansas, and spread into western Nebraska and western Oklahoma. By afternoon, mostly showers extended over much of Oklahoma, the eastern half of Texas and western Arkansas. Light rain and snow fell over southeastern Kansas and southwestern Missouri. Earlier precipitation was heavier. During the 24-hour period up to 6 a.m. CST, 2.76 inches fell at Dyess Air Force Base at Abilene, Texas, with 2.39 inches at Fort Sill, Okla., and 2.2 inches at Wichita Falls, Texas. Oklahoma City received 1.21 inches of rain overnight, pushing their total for the month to a record 4.49 inches as of noon. The previous February record was 4.05 inches, set in 1987. The total for the month at Wichita Falls was 4.55 inches, the highest February total since 1903. Cloud cover and blustery northerly wind kept temperatures in Oklahoma and western Texas only in the 30s and 40s during the afternoon. On the northern Plains, that same temperature range was considered a warming trend, thanks to sunshine and southwesterly wind. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 9 below zero at Houghton Lake, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Injure Postal Workers as Terror Campaign Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead, ADDS 4 grafs to UPDATE with powder magazine explosion in Melilla. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A bombing campaign blamed on Basque separatists terrorized Madrid on Wednesday as a parcel blew up at the main post office and an explosive sent to a government prosecutor was discovered. Police said two postal workers were injured, one seriously, in the post office explosion. The second bomb was defused before it went off, police said. On Tuesday, the president of the national court, which tries all terrorism cases, was seriously injured when a package delivered to his Madrid home blew up as he opened it. Another package bomb delivered Tuesday to a retired army officer in Valencia was discovered and detonated by bomb experts without causing injuries. The explosions destroyed hopes of renewed talks between the government and the Basque separatist group ETA, which police suspect is behind the attacks. ETA, which in Basque language stands for Homeland and Liberty, seeks autonomy for the three-province Basque region of northern Spain. The post office blast occurred in the first-floor sorting room where Maria del Pilar was working. Doctors at Gregorio Maranon hospital said she was in serious condition and had lost a finger, suffered burns on her neck and face, and sustained injuries to both eyes. Another postal worker was deafened in one ear, doctors said. Later, a letter bomb was defused in a Madrid police laboratory after it was discovered by a bodyguard of prosecutor Eduardo Fungairino, a police official said. Fungairino investigated ETA's bloodiest action, a June 1987 car bombing that killed 21 people in the parking garage of a Barcelona department store. Judge Fernando de Mateo Lage of the national court, or Audiencia Nacional, underwent surgery following Tuesday's blast. Mateo Lage, 60, lost both his hands, had severe lung complications and was in danger of losing his sight, doctors said. Although no group claimed responsibility for the attacks, police have blamed ETA, which has used package bombs in the past. In September, ETA gunmen ambushed and killed anti-terrorist prosecutor Carmen Tagle, who worked at the national court. ``It is obvious that ETA is still mounting attacks against society and while there are attacks, there will be no changes in anti-terrorist policy,'' Interior Minister Jose Luis Corcuera said Tuesday. The package bomb that injured Mateo Lage was mailed Friday, the same day Corcuera said the government would respond favorably if the Basque group halted attacks for six months. ETA has claimed responsibility for killing more than 600 people since it began its independence campaign 21 years ago. Also on Wednesday, nine soldiers were slightly injured in an explosion of gun powder in a storage area in the Spanish enclave of Melilla on the north coast of Morocco, most of them cut by glass, sources for the Military Hospital there said. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known but a fire was believed the reason. Other military sources said the blast damaged a television relay and telephone lines. The sources demanded anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Services Republican Says Bush Must Fight for Defense Budget
DOC.TEXT: The ranking Republican on the House Armed Services Committee is warning President Bush that without a concerted effort for his fiscal 1991 defense budget, administration priorities will be undermined. ``Your supporters on Capitol Hill will obviously do everything possible to defend your priorities, but our chances of success are dismal without your aggressive, hands-on participation,'' Rep. William Dickinson, R-Ala., said in a three-page letter to Bush dated Monday. Dickinson said that for the past two years, Congress and the White House have reached an agreement on a total for defense spending, but the chances for such an agreement this year ``are not promising at this point in time.'' In addition, several Democratic lawmakers are suggesting cuts of $10 billion to $12 billion in the Bush administration's proposed defense budget of $292 billion for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Dickinson noted that even if Congress cancels the major strategic modernization programs such as the B-2 stealth bomber, the two land-based nuclear missiles and the Trident submarine as well as the Advanced Tactical Fighter and the C-17 transport plane, the savings won't add up to the amount many members are seeking. The cuts, instead, would have to come from personnel and readiness, ``the very essence of the U.S. military,'' Dickinson said. Dickinson predicted that Congress, facing a diminishing Soviet threat to the West and an increasing budget deficit, will provide funds for only one of the two land-based, nuclear missiles the administration wants. The congressman said that without the president's leadership, ``I fear the national security policies and priorities that you and I both support will be compromised by an unfocused Congress hoping to reduce defense spending and demanding to micro-manage whatever is left.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Foreign Minister Visits Auschwitz
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Israel visited on Wednesday the site of the Auschwitz death camp, where millions of Jews died at the hands of their Nazi captors. ``You cannot travel to any country of Eastern Europe _ and certainly not to Poland _ without pondering the tragic fate of the Jewish nation during the last war,'' Arens said in an interview with the government daily Rzeczpospolita Wednesday. He was visiting Poland to renew full diplomatic ties. ``While being here, our delegation wants to go to all those places where Jews have been killed.'' Arens credited Poland with giving Jews ``great assistance'' during World War II, when an estimated 3 million of 3.5 million Polish Jews were murdered by the Nazis. Millions of other Jews were brought from across Europe to their deaths at camps in Poland. The Auschwitz complex and the adjacent Birkenau camp, an integral part of German dictator Adolf Hitler's ``Final Solution,'' were built to exterminate Jews, and then Poles and other Slavs. Estimates of the death toll at the camp in southern Poland range from 2.5 million to 4 million, the vast majority Jews. A Roman Catholic convent at the edge of the camp has strained Jewish-Polish relations and stirred international controversy. Arens discussed the convent with Polish officials Tuesday. The government underlined its support for building an alternate home for the nuns. Ground was broken last week for an interfaith prayer center, which will include a new convent. Arens visited the Majdanek concentration camp near Lublin in southestern Poland on Monday at the start of his four-day visit. On Tuesday, Arens and Polish Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski signed an accord establishing full diplomatic relations after a 23-year break. Poland became the third Warsaw Pact country after Hungary and Czechoslovakia to renew relations with Israel in the past six months. Poland, like the entire Soviet bloc except Romania, cut off relations in 1967 to support the Arab side in a Middle East war that year.

DOC.HEAD: Muskie Criticizes U.S. Policy on Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie on Wednesday criticized the Bush administration's policy on Cambodia, saying it could lead to ``a return of tragedy'' in the nation. Muskie also said the United States should grant diplomatic recognition to Vietnam, which he said is more interested these days in economic development that military expansion. The former Democratic senator from Maine told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he is perplexed by U.S. policy on Cambodia, where efforts are under way to find a new government. Muskie recently toured Cambodia under the auspices of the Center for National Policy, a non-partisan research group. ``From the conversations I had and from my own observations, I have concluded that a fundamental redirection of U.S. policy must take place, if we are not to contribute to a return of tragedy in this nation,'' he said. Specifically, Muskie objected to allowing the Khmer Rouge any kind of political role in the country prior to national elections there. The Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge, a well-armed guerrilla force, were responsible hundreds of thousands of deaths between 1975 and 1978 when they were ousted by Vietnamese occupation forces. ``My view is that I would rather have the Khmer Rouge outside,'' Muskie said. The Khmer Rouge and two non-communist guerrilla groups backed by the United States are battling the Vietnam-installed government of Premier Hun Sen. Vietnam said it withdrew the last of its troops from Cambodia last fall, but there have been allegations that some soldiers and advisers have returned to help support government troops. The United States and Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union have advocated a plan _ proposed by Australia _ to have the United Nations run Cambodia until elections, and to deploy an international peacekeeping force to ensure security. The Khmer Rouge hold Cambodia's seat at the U.N. General Assembly. Muskie said that it ``became clear that the central question for U.S. policy had to be, simply, this: why should we insist on dismantling the existing government prior to elections and thereby risk the return of chaos?'' But David Lambertson, the deputy assistant secretary of State, defended the U.S. policy. While the United States is ``unalterably opposed'' to the ``abhorrent'' Khmer Rouge, he said they were a ``unpleasant reality'' who had to be addressed. He said the State Department's is convinced that ``only a negotiated political settlement with a substantial U.N. peacekeeping force can provide the assurances which the Cambodian people and the international community demand.''

DOC.HEAD: Squirrel Heists Flags at Cemetery
DOC.TEXT: It's no mystery who's been stealing U.S. flags from graves at Wellsboro Cemetery, but it's doubtful the thief will be arrested. The culprit is a gray squirrel, said Robert Gee, who lives near the cemetery in this north central Pennsylvania city. The problem began last fall when the furry flag-razer swooped down from its perch in one of the cemetery's many evergreens, stripped one of the miniature flags from its standard and returned aloft, the flag trailing behind him. So far, the rampaging rodent has taken more than 20 flags and scattered them randomly among the pine tree's branches, giving the tree an almost festive appearance. Gee can't figure out how to end the squirrely crime wave, but he's certain the flags will be replaced before Memorial Day.

DOC.HEAD: Studds Grills Deland on Bush Boston Harbor Budget
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's top environmental adviser blamed Massachusetts on Wednesday for getting no Boston Harbor cleanup money. Michael Deland, head of the President's Council on Environmental Quality, appeared before the House Subcommittee on Fisheries and Wildlife Conservation to discuss the budget for the fiscal year beginning in October but was immediately put on the defensive. Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., the subcommittee chairman, chided Deland on the harbor issue. Deland's previous job was head of the regional office of the Environmental Protection Agency in Boston and a major responsibility was pushing the state to clean up the harbor. ``Explain to me why, if the president truly cares about Boston Harbor, which I know he does because I saw his presidential campaign commercials, does he not have a single dime in his budget to clean it up?'' Studds asked. Deland said Massachusetts missed its opportunity to get federal funds for the cleanup by waiting so long to start the process. ``It is not appropriate to give more money to Boston Harbor now when it had an opportunity years ago to apply for funds,'' Deland said.

DOC.HEAD: Network Apologizes Locally To Wallace For Chancellor's Mistake
DOC.TEXT: NBC Nightly News commentator John Chancellor erroneously referred to former Gov. George C. Wallace as ``the late governor,'' but that didn't bother Wallace, his spokesman said Wednesday. ``Newsmen have been making mistakes about George Wallace all of his life,'' said spokesman Elvin Stanton. ``It's something he brushes off.'' During Chancellor's commentary Tuesday night, he quoted Wallace as once saying governors were nothing more than ``ornaments.'' Chancellor then said, ``Well, it's too bad the late governor wasn't here in Washington this week'' for a national governor's conference. NBC spokeswoman Katherine McQuay said the mistake was corrected during the 6 p.m. CST feed of the national news. The NBC affiliate in Montgomery, WSFA-TV, carried a verbal apology from the network during its local broadcast. Stanton said he did not call NBC because he knew enough people were aware Wallace was still alive. Wallace, who lives in Montgomery, has kept a low profile since leaving office in January 1987 after four four-year terms, partly because of health problems stemming from a 1972 assassination attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Debate Opens on Military Role in Social Improvement
DOC.TEXT: A study showing that a Vietnam-era program failed to help low-aptitude soldiers in later civilian life was disputed in congressional testimony Wednesday, opening a debate on whether the military can promote social improvement. The House Veterans Affairs subcommittee hearing concerned ``Project 100,000,'' under which Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara tried to fight the Vietnam War and the war on poverty in one action. Rep. Lane Evans, D-Ill., chairman of the subcommittee on oversight and investigations, said he wanted to determine whether Project 100,000 was a legitimate ``Great Society'' social program. ``Or was Project 100,000 a calculated, even cynical, means to satisfy the manpower needs of the armed forces and at the same time lessen domestic opposition to the war in Vietnam?'' he asked. Under the program, the Pentagon lowered the physical and mental standards for entry into the armed services. In exchange, the new members of the service were promised remedial education and training. About 300,000 enlisted under that program from 1966 to 1971, two-thirds in the Army. Fifty-four percent were volunteers. Half came from the South. More than 40 percent were members of minority groups. The average reading ability was at the sixth grade level. Most went to combat or to ``soft skill'' jobs such as food service, supply, wire communications, motor transport and automotive repair. Flaws in the enlistment test allowed another group of about 300,000, also lacking the traditional qualifications, to enter the military from 1976 to 1980. According to the study, the Project 100,000 veterans wound up earning $5,000 to $7,000 less per year than their non-veteran counterparts. Veterans were more likely to be unemployed, less likely to be married and more likely to have been divorced. The low-aptitude veterans who served from 1976 to 1980 were not found to be better off economically, educationally or socially than their non-veteran counterparts. There were no significant differences in unemployment, kinds of jobs held or average income, the report said. But the veterans had less formal education, higher divorce rates and were more likely to be unhappy with their jobs. ``Project 100,000's social promises were not kept,'' social scientist Janice H. Laurence testified. Laurence is a senior scientist with Human Resources Research Organization, the Alexandria, Va.-based group that conducted the study for the Defense Department. She suggested that two years in the military was not enough time to counter characteristics acquired over 18 years of growing up. She noted that 4 percent of the Project 100,000 continued with military careers, while Evans noted that many were denied re-enlistment because of subsequent low test scores. ``To compensate for the deficits which the underprivileged bring with them would require more than a little extra training, and maybe even a complete restructuring of current pedagogical practices or content,'' she said. The results were disputed by researcher William E. Beusse, who studied Project 100,000 Army veterans in the early 1970s and reached opposite conclusions. Beusse said he used a far stricter sampling methods, producing more accurate results. He acknowledged that veterans would have lost seniority and the opportunity to enter a tight job market. ``In an age of dramatically reduced threat, the cost of even a scaled-down peacetime force may be too expensive for `defense' to be its only product,'' Beusse argued. ``Society may come to demand that the military assist in addressing other national needs such as providing large-scale manpower training for low aptitude men and women. In this area the military has more than proven its capability to perform.'' Wayne S. Sellman, head of recruiting policy for the Pentagon, said he believed the long-term decline in performance by low-aptitude veterans may have been due to the gradual distancing from the discipline and highly organized life that the military provided, point also made by Laurence. He said Sellman's study caught veterans fresh from the service while Laurence caught them later.

DOC.HEAD: Grateful Dead Sponsors Summer Camp for Social Justice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Santokh Khalsa is cq in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Instead of weaving baskets and making pottery, teen-agers at a summer camp sponsored in part by rockers of The Grateful Dead will organize to save the planet. For the third year, campers from around the country will gather under the redwoods in July for a 15-day intensive program designed to teach leadership and organizing skills to the next generation of social activists. ``Not many people know about it, but there is the beginning of a worldwide youth movement,'' camp organizer Santokh Khalsa said Wednesday. After early-morning yoga, the youths gather in a circle outside for seminars led by the likes of Ben Cohen, co-founder of Ben and Jerry's Ice Cream, who has been a champion of socially responsible business. Another speaker at the camp in Mendocino County north of San Francisco will be Ram Dass, the former Harvard professor who has blended Eastern philosophy and spiritualism into a unique prescription for social action. The regimen of vegetarian meals, small support groups and daily feedback sessions sounds like something out of an earlier era. It is. The camp is coordinated by a Mill Valley-based group called Creating Our Future. Established in 1987, the group helps high school students organize to tackle issues like homelessness, offshore oil drilling and the preservation of rain forests. Khalsa, the organization's co-founder, has been involved in the peace and environmental movements for three decades. Khalsa said the goal of Creating Our Future is to provide support and direction to aspiring social activists and to offer the wisdom of experience. In keeping with the group's youth-oriented philosophy, Creating Our Future's board of directors is composed of eight adults and 16 people under age 25. Grateful Dead members Bobby Weir and Jerry Garcia are on the board of directors and advisory board, respectively. The 1960s band, which still attracts a die-harde cadre of fans known as Dead Heads for concerts including such hits as ``Truckin','' plans a concert to benefit the summer camp. Campers learn to coordinate public education campaigns, fund-raising and letter-writing drives, media contacts and nonviolent public demonstrations. But camp isn't about ``just being active and doing sit-ins,'' according to Yvonne Litaker, a camp veteran and speaking tour coordinator for Creating Our Future. ``What is underneath all this is there's a big youth movement happening here,'' said Litaker, 20. ``We get letters from all over, from Kenya and Tokyo, from kids who are yearning to do something.'' For Litaker, who has worked with the organization for a year and plans to attend camp again this summer, social activism includes a vegetarian diet, boycotting products made by companies whose policies she shuns, and being a conscientious recycler. ``I've made my life a statement of how I want the world to be,'' she said, describing her efforts to use only cloth napkins and buy gasoline only from small, independent stations. Camp is an opportunity for young people to meet each other, learn from veteran social activists of the '60s era and expand the network of youths who care about changing the world, Litaker said. Last year, campers helped produce a manual titled, ``How to Organize a Rainforest Awareness Week at Your School.'' The camp has become so popular that organizers have increased the number of spaces from 30 last year to about 100 this summer. Tuition and room and board runs $480, and applications are accepted on a first-come, first-served basis, Litaker said.

DOC.HEAD: Colleagues of Prospective Duelists Meet
LaserPhoto MVD2
DOC.TEXT: Colleagues of a newspaper director and a police official met Wednesday to discuss the terms of a duel over a news article that the official claims falsely accuses him of smuggling. Last Friday, police inspector Saul Claveria from San Jose province challenged the director of the La Republica newspaper to a duel over the story, which appeared Jan. 24 in the splashy leftist tabloid. The director, Frederico Fasano, derided the challenge as ``anachronistic and medieval,'' but on Tuesday he agreed. However, he said would only show up at the duel, not defend himself. The article in dispute alleged that two cars involved in distributing contraband consumer items were registered under Claveria's name. Claveria insisted the cars had belonged to the police department but that they were sold months ago. He acknowledged he had signed papers connecting him to the cars, but said they were connected to the sale. The vehicles apparently belong to a car rental agency. Fasano, who lived in exile in Mexico during much of Uruguay's 1973-85 military dictatorship, said the story technically was not incorrect and refused to retract it. Last Saturday, the Interior Ministry approved Claveria's request for a duel. The developments have received prominent coverage by the national media. Wednesday's meeting of the colleagues, or ``seconds'' of each man, was required by a 1939 law that regulates dueling in this South American nation. If it takes place, the duel would be the first in Uruguay in 18 years. If the seconds agree to proceed, they must designate a tribunal that would arrange a site, witnesses, doctors and other details. The outcome of the meeting was not disclosed. By tradition, neither participant nor his seconds may comment publicly on developments after the challenge has been issued and accepted. Duels have a long history in Uruguay. In one of the most famous, two-time president Jose Batlle y Ordonez challenged the director of the newspaper El Pais, Washington Baltran, 70 years ago, also over a published article. He shot and killed him. In 1970, Julio M. Sanguinetti, now Uruguay's president, fought a saber duel with another member of the fractious Colorado Party, Sen. Manuel Flores Mora. The latter was grazed on the arm, and the duel was halted. The most recent duel occurred in 1972 when two retired generals faced off over a political dispute. Witnesses said Liber Seregni, leader of the Broad Front coalition of leftist parties, intentionally aimed high and missed Juan Ribas, a presidential candidate in 1958 and 1971 from a splinter group of the Colorado Party. Ribas, however, took careful aim and fired, and his bullet just missed the head of his rival.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Department Issues New `Training Wage' Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: As many as 3.7 million young Americans could be eligible for the new below-minimum ``training wage'' that takes effect April 1 along with the first increase in the minimum wage since 1981, the Labor Department said Wednesday. But few employers will develop training programs that will permit them to pay the lower wage beyond the 90-day limit, the department predicted. Only firms that develop on-the-job training programs may pay workers 16 to 19 the lower wage for a second 90-day period. Starting April 1, employers can pay teen-agers new to the job market $3.35 an hour. That's the same amount as the current minimum wage, which will increase to $3.80 an hour. On April 1, 1991, the regular minimum wage will go to $4.25 an hour while the training wage will rise to $3.61. Guidelines announced by the department Wednesday require employers who want to pay the lower wage for the second 90-day period to develop training programs that provide ``knowledge and skills beyond those customarily learned by observation and incidental work exposure.'' The programs must include training for both ``job-specific skills,'' such as cleaning equipment or running a cash register, and personal skills such as courtesy and punctuality, the guidelines said. When Congress debated the measure last year, Democrats opposed a training wage but were forced to concede the point to President Bush to avoid a veto. Democrats also had to scale back their final minimum-wage target, since Bush had vetoed a measure earlier that called for an increase to $4.55 an hour. In return, Bush agreed to have the minimum wage reach $4.25 nine months earlier than he had proposed and also accepted a far more restricted training wage than he sought earlier. Originally, Bush had wanted to allow the lower wage to be paid to all workers, regardless of age, for their first six months on any new job, regardless of past work experience.

DOC.HEAD: Anderson's Sister Optimistic About Chances for Freedom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with U.S. comment, latest news report out of London, INSERT 3 grafs after 7th pvs, `I think...' and pickup 8th pvs, `Mrs. Say...' and ADD 6 at end. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON9
DOC.TEXT: Nearly five years after Terry Anderson was taken hostage in Lebanon, his sister said Wednesday she believes the United States, Iran and Syria are moving on a common track toward freedom for all 18 Western captives. ``I'm just going to pray and hold my breath that nothing disastrous occurs before this can reach fruition,'' said Peggy Say, winding up a 2{-week trip to Europe and the Middle East that she called a ``humanitarian pilgrimage.'' ``My personal sense is, not tomorrow, not next week, maybe not next month, but certainly soon,'' she said. Anderson, 42, s the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Mrs. Say's journey with an Associated Press delegation included meetings with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Pope John Paul II, Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and two Syrian ministers. She said she felt optimistic that the hostages will be freed. ``I think that with my reassurances that the American administration is doing everything it can do, that the Syrians are certainly pledged 100 percent with their commitment to resolve it, and with the statements coming out of Tehran, to say nothing of the mood in the world today, it just gives me a feeling of hope,'' she said. But in Washington, John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, said he was not optimistic the hostages would be released soon. ``I think the chances are very slim,'' he told members of the House subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East. While he said he hopes reports of possible movement are accurate, the relatives of the hostages have been disappointed in the past. ``They get their hopes up and then get them dashed,'' he said. Mrs. Say spoke at a news conference after meeting Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, whose personal envoy Terry Waite was kidnapped in Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987, while trying to negotiate the release of Western hostages. Mrs. Say recalled that at her first meeting with Runcie and Waite, there was a mood of optimism that Waite's mission would be successful. ``I must admit that I feel some responsibility and was just devastated when Terry Waite was kidnapped,'' she said. ``I hope when all the hostages come out, certainly I hope Terry Waite is with them.'' Eve Keatley, a spokeswoman for the archbishop, said Runcie ``was very pleased to hear of Peggy's growing optimism after her trip.'' Mrs. Say concluded her trip at a private dinner with the families of Waite and other British hostages, and Scottish relatives of American hostage Thomas Sutherland. The hostages missing in Lebanon include eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. She said this trip, her fourth to the Middle East, was the first that didn't leave her feeling ``extremely depressed and thinking this situation only gets more and more complicated.'' After meetings in Syria with Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa and Information Minister Mohammed Salman, she said, ``I have no doubts about Syria's commitment. Certainly, if anyone wants it over with more than the United States, it's certainly Syria.'' She said she found it ``very, very encouraging'' that Syrian television carried a lengthy interview with her, in which she said relations with the United States would not improve until the hostages are freed. She was heartened by a commentary last week in the Tehran Times, which usually reflects the thinking of President Hashemi Rafsanjani, that the hostages should be freed. On Sunday, Iran's Chief Justice Mohammad Yazdi said that Islam opposes hostage-taking. Another positive sign, she said, was an appeal Friday by Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the most influential Shiite Moslem leader in Lebanon, for a new approach to freeing the hostages. Fadlallah is the spiritual guide to the Iranian-aligned Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is believed to be an umbrella organization for most of the hostage-takers. ``Everywhere I went I was assured that the Americans are doing the very best they can,'' she added. ``I back my administration for the first time in a long, long time in their stance which is, number one, that the hostages be released before there is any move towards reconciliation or any economic contact with Iran and, secondly, that they are not going to pay ransom,'' Mrs. Say said. ``I feel certain that there is going to be nothing shameful about the deal that is going to be made ... to release these hostages. Nobody's going to be caught at anything. We suffered our Iran-Contra, thank you very much. It devastated us,'' she said. ``I did my part, and now if everybody does their part we can all wrap our arms around the hostages and go home,'' she said. Mrs. Say has been accompanied on her trip by Larry Heinzerling, deputy director of World Services for the AP, which supports her efforts financially and logistically while pressing its own efforts for Anderson's freedom. The leading Arab newspaper Al-Hayat, published in London, reported Tuesday there had been progress in discussions between the United States, Iran and Syria aimed at freeing the hostages. The Lebanese newspaper said the high-level contacts were taking place in Geneva between U.S. and Iranian officials. The newspaper quoted Algerian sources as saying that contacts were in place through non-diplomatic organizations and that Algeria was helping in the process. The Algerian government refused Wednesday to disclose what steps it might be taking. Kelly denied reports that the United States was involved in negotiations, although he said the issue has come up once or twice when Abraham Sofaer, the State Department's legal adviser, met with Iranians in The Hague, where a international tribunal is tryin to resolve financial disputes. But Kelly said Sofaer simply reiterates the U.S. position on the hostages. He is ``not, repeat not, negotiating in The Hague with the Iranians,'' Kelly said. As for the Syrians, Sofaer said, ``I believe they could be more helpful.'' ``I don't believe the Syrians are being an obstacle in any way.''

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Agrarians Unite, Forming Strong Opposition Party
DOC.TEXT: Agrarian party officials said Wednesday their group will merge with a rival party, in a move expected to make them the favorites over the Communists in Bulgaria's first free elections in more than 42 years. Alexander Petriny, chairman of a joint contact group of the two rivals, told reporters the Bulgarian Agrarian People's Union and the Bulgarian Agrarian People's Union-Nikola Petkov agreed to join forces. With 150,000 registered members and a strong rural voice, the united Bulgarian Agrarian People's Union was expected to displace the Communist Party from its role as favorite in elections planned for July. The two parties began discussing fusion shortly after hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov was toppled in November, but differences at times appeared unbridgeable. The Agrarian party became a loyal junior partner of the Communists following the Communist takeover in December 1947, but began reasserting its independence after democratic reforms started late last year. The Nikola Petkov group _ named after an executed party founder _ is one of more than a dozen opposition parties newly formed or reactivated in the new climate of relative permissiveness. It had criticized its rival's support of the Communists and had made fusion conditional on a change in Agrarian party leadership, some of whom continue to hold high office to which they were appointed under Zhivkov. Agrarian party leader Angel Dimitrov, for instance, remains vice president of the State Council, the supreme body of state power. Petriny said the party had formally dissociated itself from the Communists, but he could not specify what the Agrarian-Communist relations were to the umbrella Union of Democratic Forces, of which the Nikola Petkov organization is a member. Other officials said the two rivals agreed to formation of a provisional leadership of a united party, pending a special Unification Congress, tenatively scheduled for March 24. Delegates at an Agrarian party congress Wednesday overwhelmingly approved a resolution to end participation in the Patriotic Front, to further distance themselves from the Communists. The Front is a mass organization set up by the Communists and made up of groups supporting them.

DOC.HEAD: Food Delivery to South Sudan Resumes in April
DOC.TEXT: The government agreed on Wednesday to let Operation Lifeline Sudan resume food deliveries to south Sudan in April, Relief Minister Peter Orat said. He said he and U.N. Undersecretary-General Farah Abdul-Rahim reached agreement at a meeting in this capital city. Preparations for holding a donors conference in Khartoum were also discussed, Orat said, without elaboration. Abdul-Rahim was in Khartoum to convey U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar's concern over interruption of relief supplies to southern Sudan. He plans to meet military ruler Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir Thursday before leaving for Ethiopia, presumably to discuss obstacles blocking relief shipments there. Renewed fighting between government forces and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army led to suspension of food flights to southern Sudan. The government is preventing departure of a relief train along a route where food shortages are severe, and the rebels have been blocking relief efforts. Estimates of the number of Sudanese potentially affected by famine range from 1 million to 3 million. Last year, Operation Lifeline Sudan, a U.N.-led campaign to get food stockpiles in place, averted a repeat of the 1988 famine that killed 250,000 Sudanese.

DOC.HEAD: Official Reiterates U.S. Opposition to Israeli Resettlement Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 2-3 and ADDs 10 grafs on Baker-Peretz meeting
DOC.TEXT: A top State Department official on Wednesday reiterated the Bush administration's opposition to allowing new Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union to settle in Israel's occupied territories. The policy statement to Congress came as an Israeli cabinet official was assuring Secretary of State James A. Baker III that Israel does not plan to settle Soviet Jewish immigrants in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, sources said. The statements to Baker were relayed by sources familiar with the meeting of the secretary and Yitzhak Peretz, the minister in charge of resettling immigrants. ``We have said repeatedly we don't want to see the expansion of settlements'' in the West Bank, Asistant Secretary of State John Kelly told the House subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East. Kelly's comments came as Israeli media quoted Yasha Kazakov, an Israeli official, as saying 230,000 Jews from the Soviet Union could settle in Israel this year. So far, about 9,400 have arrived over the last two months as a result of more liberalized emigration policies in the Soviet Union and growing fears of anti-Semitism. Arab nations have urged the Kremlin to restrict Jewish emigration because they fear the new arrivals will be resettled in the territories occupied by Israel after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. In talks with Arab leaders, Kelly said he was convinced that their major concern is resettlement of Soviet Jews in the territories, not simply the fact that the Jews were arriving. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., challenged Kelly about the administration's position on resettlement of Soviet Jews in the West Bank or Gaza. He said it was a ``preposterous notion that a democratic society should exclude its citizens from living where they want.'' But Kelly said expansion of the settlements could undermine efforts for peace. He also said the administration has not taken a position on proposed legislation that would guarantee $400 million in loans for new housing for the immigrants in Israel. Baker told Peretz that he hoped Israel would respond favorably soon to proposals for holding talks on elections among the Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza, according to the sources reporting on the talks on condition that they not be identified. Peretz, an ultra-Orthodox rabbi, also told Baker at their brief meeting that the future status of Jerusalem as Israel's capital was inviolate and was off limits in any negotiations with Palestinians. The United States refuses to recognize Jerusalem as the capital, saying the status of the city must be resolved in international negotiations. Israel captured the eastern part of Jerusalem in 1967 from Jordan and has since annexed it. Baker has expressed impatience with Israel's failure to respond to his proposals for talks to set up elections among the 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza. The Likud Party, which is the senior partner in Israel's ruling coalition, is in disarray over the proposal. Hardliners fear talks with a Palestinian delegation could result in Israel being forced to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel shuns as a terrorist organization committed to the destruction of Israel. Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met this week with State Department officials and offered his assessment that Israel should insist on assurances from the United States that it would not be forced to speak with the PLO. Netanyahu told reporters he would recommend to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that Israel refuse to conduct preliminary talks with Egypt and the United States on Palestinian elections until that point is clear. U.S. officials say they cannot give Israel such assurances because if Palestinians want the PLO to represent them, the United States would not interfere. In a two-hour meeting with Dennis Ross, one of Baker's top aides, Peretz said that the Israeli government does not channel immigrants to the West Bank and Gaza. But he urged Baker to keep up the pressure on Moscow to allow direct flights between Moscow and Tel Aviv so that Jews wishing to emigrate could do so faster, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Major Coalition To Boycott Haitian Vote
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A major political coalition said Wednesday it will boycott elections under military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril and joined most other parties in demanding that Avril resign. In another blow to government election plans, three Electoral Council members said they were suspending their work, Protestant-run Radio Lumiere said. They said they were reacting to the refusal of nearly all parties to run candidates as long as Avril remains in power. Many critics of the government doubt that Avril really intends to usher in true democracy. ``The road along which Gen. Avril persists in leading the country is a dead end,'' said a statement by the centrist National Alliance for Progress and Democracy. Marc Bazin, president of the three-party coalition, signed the statement. He said elections under Avril would be a ``farce.'' The opposition is angry about a government crackdown in January. Officials forced seven prominent critics into exile and arrested 50 others who were allegedly beaten before their release. The three Electoral Council members urged the six other members also to abandon election preparations. ``In the face of all the dissensions within and disputes outside the Council, we are asking it to call a brief halt'' to election preparation activities, said Council treasurer Jacques Jovin and members Pauris Jean-Baptiste and Archange Leon in an open letter to the Electoral Council. Jovin told The Associated Press he would ultimately resign if political parties persist in their boycott. The Electoral Council was appointed by the Roman Catholic Church, unions, human rights groups and other organizations. It was empowered by the government to organize and supervise elections. Haiti, with a long history of military rule, tried to hold independently organized elections in November 1987. These were canceled, however, after thugs, protected by soldiers, massacred at least 34 voters at voting stations. Then-ruler Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who assumed power after dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in 1986, organized army-run elections in January 1988. However, charges of election fraud abounded and most voters and parties boycotted the vote. The brief period of civilian rule ended in June 1988 when Namphy ousted the winner of the elections, Leslie Manigat. A soldiers' revolt overthrew Namphy and brought Avril to power in September 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Former FDA Official Says Drug Company Sent Him TV Set
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: A former Food and Drug Administration official says he was sent a $300 color television set by a generic drug company that was trying to get products approved by the agency, but he returned it, according to transcripts of testimony released Wednesday. Martin Seife, former director of the Food and Drug Administration's generic drug division, told a House investigations subcommittee the incident occurred in 1974 when he was a reviewer in the division. Seife said he received a package in the mail at his home from Bolar Pharmaceutical Co. Inc. of Copiague, N.Y., and when he unwrapped it, he was ``shocked and chagrined'' to find a color TV set. He said he sent it back immediately and ``nobody ever approached me in this manner again.'' Included in the transcripts was a letter to Seife from Robert Shulman, then president of Bolar, apologizing ``for an unfortunate incident that I'm sure embarrassed both of us.'' Shulman recently resigned. The letter explained: ``I just meant to say thank you to someone I felt had shown us some understanding and compassion that he didn't have to.'' Eugene Pfeifer, a Washington, D.C., attorney representing Bolar, said he was aware of the incident but added, ``We have no reason to believe it was a practice ... We're not aware of anything else like that.'' Such a gift would be considered an illegal gratuity. Though the statute of limitations on prosecution has expired, the transcripts have been turned over to the U.S. attorney in Baltimore for determination as to whether it represents part of a pattern of conduct, said a subcommittee source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Seife testified in secret before the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee on May 3 last year. Seife, who recently retired from the FDA, has been a principal source for the subcommittee, which uncovered allegations of fraud, bribery and mismanagement in the FDA's generic drug division. The scandal became public last spring and led to bribery convictions of three generic drug company executives and bribe-taking convictions of three FDA employees. The investigation also uncovered evidence that some drug companies had cheated on FDA potency tests, which prompted recalls of dozens of generic drugs, including both generic versions of the widely prescribed high-blood-pressure drug Dyazide. Bolar recalled its version of Dyazide in January after the company's lawyers said documents supporting claims about the drug appeared to be false.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Observer: Human Rights Improved in Romania, But Work Remains
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. observer said Wednesday that respect for human rights has improved markedly since Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted, but more remains to be done. The observer, Swiss jurist Joseph Voyame, told a news conference that despite the improvement since the December revolution, human rights ``have not yet been fully put into practice.'' He suggested that the U.N. Human Rights Commission maintain its watch in Romania for at least another year. He said he believed free elections are possible under present conditions ``despite the fears that still exist.'' Elections are set for May. A provisional government is now running the country. Hungary, which is concerned about treatment of the 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians in Romania, has already proposed that the commission renew Voyame's mandate. Ceausescu was ousted in December following a popular revolt and was executed along with his wife, Elena, on Christmas Day. The revolution ended more than four decades of Communist rule. Voyame, acting under a mandate from the 43-nation commission, visited Romania early this month. He submitted his findings in a report released last week.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Mercenary to Remain in South Africa Until Elections
DOC.TEXT: A mercenary who ruled the Comoros Islands until French troops forced him into exile will stay in South Africa until after elections in the Indian Ocean archipelago, the government said Wednesday. French Mercenary Bob Denard has been in South Africa since Dec. 15, the day after French troops landed in the Comoros Republic and ended the hold on power by Denard's Presidential Guard. Denard and about 30 other European mercenaries had controlled the three-island nation since the Nov. 26 shooting death of President Ahmed Abdallah. South Africa, which had helped fund the Presidential Guard, ended its support and agreed to give Denard temporary residence until he found a place to settle. Foreign Minister Pik Botha said Wednesday that after consulting with French and Comoros authorities, the decision was made to let Denard remain in South Africa. He said officials feared his return to France or movement to another country might disturb the election process in the Comoros, where a new government is being formed. The circumstances of Abdallah's death remain unclear, and many Comorans blame Denard. He has denied involvement. Denard helped engineer a 1975 coup that ousted Abdallah. Then he led a 1978 coup that restored Abdallah to power in the former French colony. The mercenary remained a leading power in the islands before taking over when Abdallah died.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Ask Freedom for Arrested Opposition Leader
LaserPhotos MLA1,3
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for Juan Ponce Enrile asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to free the opposition senator, who was arrested on charges of backing December's failed coup. Vice President Salvador Laurel described the arrest of the former defense minister as an attempt to silence the opposition. Laurel broke with President Corazon Aquino in 1987 and later joined Enrile in forming the opposition Nacionalista Party. ``It could only be the beginning,'' Laurel told reporters. ``It is not the end. We are bracing for that. We are prepared for the worst. ... I think Mrs. Aquino is exacerbating the fragmentation and disunity of the nation.'' Enrile, who played a key role in bringing Mrs. Aquino to power in a 1986 uprising, was arrested Tuesday, held overnight at the National Bureau of Investigation, and transferred early Wednesday to police headquarters in suburban Quezon City. He faces charges of ``rebellion with murder.'' Military dissidents claimed the arrest of one of the administration's sharpest critics was a prelude to martial law. In a petition filed Wednesday, Enrile's law partner, Renato Cayetano, claimed the arrest was illegal and violated the senator's rights. The petition asked that Enrile be freed. Court officials said no hearing had been scheduled. Also Wednesday, three senators filed a proposal asking judicial authorities to place Enrile under the custody of the Senate's sergeant-at-arms to allow the lone opposition senator to attend sessions. Enrile, who was among seven people indicted Tuesday, denied any role in the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt that left at least 113 people dead and wounded more than 600. Indicted with 66-year-old Enrile, were dismissed Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan; Rodolfo Aguinaldo, suspended governor of Cagayan province; ret. Brig. Gen. Felix Brawner; retired Lt. Col. Billy Bibit; and businessman Rebecco Panlilio and his wife, Erlinda. In the northern province of Cagayan, a local government official said Aguinaldo, a former army lieutenant colonel, was reported to have gone in hiding after learning late Tuesday that an arrest warrant would be served on him the next day. Enrile is the most prominent figure charged in any of the six coup attempts since Mrs. Aquino was swept to power in February 1986 by the military-popular uprising that drove the late President Ferdinand E. Marcos into exile. Troops went on alert in the Manila area Tuesday to prevent possible reprisals after the arrest, according to presidential spokesman Tomas Gomez. On Wednesday, police defused a homemade bomb outside a shopping center in Manila's financial district of Makati. Police said they did not know who placed the bomb. Enrile was defense minister under Marcos but turned against him and led the military mutiny that prompted the uprising. He kept the post under Mrs. Aquino, but he was fired in November 1986 after a coup attempt by his followers. A spokesman for soldiers involved in the December coup said the nation ``should brace itself for the imminent declaration of martial law.'' However, in a radio interview Wednesday, Gomez said the charges were justified because Enrile led ``the numerous attempts at a coup d'etat to destroy this government of ours.'' Enrile was arrested after three witnesses claimed they saw Honasan and about 100 rebels at Enrile's home on the first day of the failed coup. The senator claims not to have seen Honasan, his former protege, since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl: Germanys Should Make Formal Declarations Supporting Polish Border
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl favors the two German parliaments making formal statements that recognize Poland's western border, a government spokesman said on Wednesday. Speaking in an East German television interview Wednesday night, Kohl seemed annoyed over worries, even among his allies, about his stance on the border issue. ``In many speeches I have said that no one wants to connect the unity of the Germans with moving the borders. I don't know what more I can say,'' Kohl said on East Germany's ``Aktuella Kamera'' news program. Kohl has come under sharp criticism abroad and at home for what is seen as an unclear position on lands east of the Oder and Neisse rivers once held by Germany and now part of Poland. The land _ about one-third of present-day Poland _ was given to that country after the defeat in 1945 of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. Kohl has never formally stated that a united Germany would not lay claim to that land and this is viewed as a major difficulty in the unification process. Poland, the United States and Britain, among others, have expressed concern over what they consider Kohl's lack of action. Kohl, apparently seeking to soothe his critics, told his Cabinet Wednesday he ``understands the Polish wish for a legally binding recognition'' of Poland's western borders, said government spokesman Dieter Vogel. The chancellor also said he sees the possibility that after East Germany's elections on March 18, the parliaments of both German nations could issue declarations on the matter, said Vogel. Vogel said such a declaration could confirm a resolution already passed by the West German parliament on Nov. 8 stating that Germans ``neither now nor in the future'' will attempt to change the border. Nonetheless, in the Wednesday night interview, Kohl reiterated his view that only a united German government could have final say about a possible treaty giving a united Germany's formal recognition of the current border. Kohl said only the ``highest sovereign German power in the case of reunification'' could conclude such a treaty. He also dismissed any fears of the rise of a ``Fourth Reich'' as ``rubbish.'' ``The Germans are completely immersed in international responsibility,'' Kohl said. Kohl, under pressure from archconservative voters, has sought to allay Polish worries but at the same time has insisted only a united Germany could take an official stand on the border issue. The opposition Social Democrats have charged that with such pronouncements, Kohl is endangering international support for German unification. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the Social Democrats, said Wednesday Kohl's statements about the border issue have been ``irresponsible and detrimental ... to German interests.'' Kohl also has come under sharp criticism from the junior partners in his coalition government, the liberal Free Democrats of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Genscher himself has said the matter should be cleared up, and has expressed interest in a Polish proposal that Poland and the two German nations work up a border treaty to be signed and ratified after formal German unification. Juergen Chrobog, Genscher's spokesman, said the foreign minister ``referred to the importance'' of this proposal during Wednesday's Cabinet session. But West Germany's 2 million-strong Association of Exiles said it would take legal action if a united Germany formally recognized Poland's western border.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Draft Report: Federal AIDS Dollars Will Slow
DOC.TEXT: Federal financing for AIDS prevention is unlikely to continue to grow as fast in the 1990s as it did during the epidemic's first decade, the Centers for Disease Control warns in a draft of a new report. ``Program needs can be expected to continue to grow at a pace that will probably exceed available resources,'' the Atlanta-based agency said in the draft of its ``Strategic Plan for Prevention of HIV Infection, 1990 _ and Beyond.'' ``We must approach our planning with an awareness of these changes and a willingness to change,'' it said. The agency's congressional appropriation for AIDS programs in the current fiscal year is $443 million, up 17 percent from 1988-9. President Bush's request for the next fiscal year is $509 million, an increase of less than 15 percent. ``The rapid increase in funding in the mid-'80s is leveling off,'' said Dr. Gary Noble, deputy director for AIDS programs. ``There's a growing recognition that AIDS has to compete with all the other health problems, and all the other national priorities. ``The funding can't continue to increase at the rate that it did, without curtailing other high priority programs.'' The 50-page report, which is being circulated to public health professionals, AIDS experts and educators, outlines the agency's goals and objectives for AIDS, based on 16 ``planning assumptions.'' Among those assumptions: _ The AIDS epidemic is actually composed of ``multiple sub-epidemics,'' chiefly among homosexual men, ``selected racial and ethnic minority populations'' and intravenous drug abusers. ``Our efforts to intervene must be tailored to the specific needs of those sub-populations,'' Noble said. ``The rate of change in the epidemic is not the same for each of those sub-epidemics,'' he added, noting a slowing of AIDS in some gay white male big-city populations, while AIDS continues to soar among intravenous drug abusers. _ Human immunodeficiency virus, the AIDS virus, ``causes a lifelong, persistent infection usually leading to progressive illness and death,'' although 10 years or more can pass between initial infection and illness. _ ``Behaviors are major determinants of HIV infection,'' including gay male sex, multiple sex partners and having sex or sharing drug needles with infected people. The report says that to prevent sexaul transmission of AIDS, the CDC needs to support and promote counseling, testing, referral and notification of sexual partners. Opportunities for medical interventions to prolong the life of AIDS-infected people will be lost unless major barriers to testing programs, such as fear of public exposure and discrimination, are removed, it says. But some AIDS activists have said testing and counseling aren't nearly enough. ``Once we test all these people, what are we going to do with them?'' Mike Merdian, executive director of the National Association of People With AIDS, said in comments published in Wednesday's Atlanta Constitution. ``You can't talk about testing without talking about treatment.'' Merdian did not return calls for further comment Wednesday. The draft report said the CDC should develop and evaluate better tests for AIDS-related viruses to better prevent transmission through the blood supply. The agency noted that the risk of AIDS transmission through blood transfusion is small, but still exists, with current testing procedures. Recommendations in the plan are not specific suggestions to each and every state and local health agency, but rather are a plan, communicating generally to the public, Noble said. After public comment and possible revisions, the CDC report is scheduled for release in June. The CDC estimates that 1 million Americans are infected with HIV, while another 52,000-57,000 AIDS cases will be diagnosed this year. More than 117,000 AIDS cases have been reported since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Hail Decision to Reimburse Abortion Pill
DOC.TEXT: The head of a major abortion clinic on Wednesday hailed the government's decision to subsidize abortions performed with the controversial RU 486 pill and said it would not increase the number of pregnancies terminated in France. The government announced this week that the cost of the procedure would be reimbursed under the national health care program, which covers most medical and dental care costs in France. ``We're very pleased with the decision, which we've been expecting for some time,'' said Dr. Elisabeth Aubeny, chief of the abortion clinic at the Broussais Hospital in Paris. ``But it won't increase the number of abortions performed in France because the decision to terminate a pregnancy is not a question of money _ it's because the patient has no other choice,'' she said in a telephone interview. Under a decree signed Monday by Health Minister Claude Evin, women undergoing drug-induced abortions will be reimbursed 80 percent of the actual cost of $246. The pill procedure costs only slightly more than other types of abortion, which have been legal in France since 1975 and have been partially covered by the national health care program since 1983. The RU 486 pill, or mifepristone, invented by French researcher Etienne-Emile Beaulieu for the Roussel-Uclaf pharmaceutical company, was first authorized for use in September 1988. However, Roussel, pressured by anti-abortion activists in Europe and the United States, withdrew it from the market. The government then ordered the company to resume distribution. The pill, known under the brand name Mifegyne, has been distributed widely in France free of charge, but the company said Wednesday it will now be marketed commercially. It is not for sale elsewhere. Dr. Aubeny predicted more women would turn to the RU 486, a safer and simpler alternative to traditional methods of abortion. ``There are both physical and psychological advantages to using the abortion pill. It avoids the many complications that go with surgery and anesthesia and makes patients feel more involved in the procedure,'' she said. The pill, a synthetic hormone compound, works by blocking the action of progesterone, a hormone essential in all stages of pregnancy. Researchers say RU 486 is especially effective in the early stages of pregnancy. There are 793 centers throughout France that distribute the pill. About 20,000 women have had drug-induced abortions. The RU 486 is not a do-it-yourself, morning-after pill that can be purchased over the counter and taken at home. It is dispensed only in government-approved hospitals and clinics where patients are screened for potential physical and psychological problems. Three appointments are needed, spread over a seven-day period as required by French law. First, patients take three tablets of mifepristone simultaneously. Two days later, they receive an injection of the hormone prostaglandin, which produces contractions to dislodge the fertilized egg. Dr. Aubeny said the egg is usually expelled within 12 hours. At Broussais Hospital, patients receive their injections in the morning and spend the rest of the day under observation. The procedure is followed by a check-up, including an ultrasound test to make sure the pregnancy has been terminated. There were 162,960 abortions performed in france in 1988. Figures for 1989 have not been released.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysian Traffic Pileup Kills 11 Policemen, Five Others
DOC.TEXT: A 12-vehicle highway pileup killed 16 people Wednesday, including 11 policemen, and seriously injured 22, the national news agency Bernama reported. It quoted witnesses as saying a bus apparently went out of control coming down a slope and collided with several cars. Bernama said the body of a police truck ended up wedged in the wrecked bus. It said that the bus, the police truck, five cars, two taxis, a small truck, a tanker and a trailer truck were involved in the crash near a half-mile-long tunnel 15 miles east of Kuala Lumpur, the capital. The 11 dead officers were from the paramilitary Federal Reserve Unit, normally deployed to fight communist guerrillas in the jungles, Bernama said.

DOC.HEAD: Little Recycling for Plastic Waste, EPA Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT name of spokeswoman.
DOC.TEXT: Disposable packaging accounts for about one-third of the more than 60 billion pounds of plastics produced annually and very little is recycled, the Environmental Protection Agency said Wednesday. The EPA in a report to Congress noted that the plastics industry in recent years has stepped up its recycling efforts, but the agency said less than 1 percent of all plastic is recycled. ``We expect that amount to increase'' because of recent efforts by the plastics industry to push recycling, said Robin Woods, a spokeswoman for the EPA. The EPA said that plastics account for about 7 percent of municipal solid waste by weight and, depending on various studies, between 14 percent and 21 percent of waste by volume. ``The plastic waste stream has quadrupled since 1970. It will increase by 50 percent by the year 2000,'' said the EPA.

DOC.HEAD: Barring of Gays from Volunteer Role Urged By Senator
DOC.TEXT: The Senate abruptly halted debate on $125 million in aid for volunteer groups Tuesday after squabbling broke out over whether homosexuals should be allowed to serve as coaches, teachers and in similar jobs. ``The District of Columbia is trying to force Big Brothers and other service organizations to accept homosexual persons into their organizations as counselors and role models and I think that's intolerable,'' said Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo. The Senate had been expected to finish work Tuesday night on a $125 million authorization bill for programs to reward volunteers to aiding senior citizens, the homeless and others in need. But lawmakers halted work for the night after getting bogged down over an Armstrong plan to nullify a District government policy that requires service groups to consider homosexual applicants for membership. Armstrong would change local law to say that none of its provisions would ``bar any organization or entity from denying, restricting, abridging or conditioning the participation'' of homosexuals from any activity that ``educates, coaches or trains any minor or ... holds out the adult as a role model mentor or companion to any minor.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., called on the Senate to table, or kill, Armstrong's proposal, saying that no one had asked for it and that lawmakers should not impose something on the nation's capital that would not apply to the rest of the country. ``What's sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander,'' Kennedy said. But Kennedy, manager of the volunteer bill, did not press for a vote on his move. Instead, he said that enough work remained on the legislation that the Senate should cease work for the night and start fresh in the morning. Armstrong's measure brought a sharp rebuke from the Human Rights Campaign Fund, a gay and lesbian political group. ``We consider it a legislative hate crime against lesbians and gays,'' said fund spokesman Gregory King. The organization was a strong supporter of legislation recently passed by the Senate that calls on the Justice Department to compile statistics on ``hate crimes'' aimed at minority groups.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Opposition Leader Said Post-Election Violence Increasing
DOC.TEXT: A major opposition party leader, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, blamed the government on Wednesday for increased postelection violence that blocked roads to airports in the resort cities of Acapulco and Ixtapa. ``The government is unleashing violence,'' Cardenas, coordinator of the center-left Democratic Revolutionary Party, told a news conference. ``This is not just another incident. There has been an increase in the seriousness and degree of disrespect by authorities in several states of the republic.'' He said his party plans to file a complaint with U.N. human rights authorities. Federal highway police said two party members and one officer died Tuesday in clashes on airport roads in the southwestern coastal state of Guerrero. Cardenas said one person, a party member, was killed, and not three people. ``The hand of the government is behind reports that my colleagues planned to take over the terminals and that they provoked a confrontation,'' he said. Attorney General Rafael Robles Catalan of Guerrero state said he ordered police to disperse party members ``because the governor doesn't want vandalism and is trying to protect the community,'' Excelsior news service reported. The Democratic Revolutionary Party was formed last year by members of a coalition that supported Cardenas in his unsuccessful July 1988 presidential bid. It challenged Dec. 3 local election results in 20 Guerrero municipalities. Cardenas said 63 of his supporters now have been killed in election-related violence nationwide since the week of presidential voting in 1988. On Jan. 28, his party demanded a government investigation into the deaths of 56 supporters in violence related to local elections around Mexico. Since then seven more have died, two of them in Guerrero state, Cardenas said. Dozens of demonstrators were injured and some disappeared in Guerrero Tuesday when officers tried to stop the protests, Cardenas said. He said party leaders had police permission to hold the protests. Party leaders told officers in Acapulco and Ixtapa that about 2,500 people in each place planned to distribute leaflets in traffic on airport access routes, he said. Police estimated the number of demonstrators on each airport road at 300. Cardenas said more protests were planned. He said the party is pressing in congress for impeachment of Gov. Francisco Ruiz Massieu of Guerrero's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. However, he added, ``the climate of violence doesn't come from local politics, but is part of a national political climate generated by central policies from Mexico City.'' Interior Secretary Fernando Gutierrez Barrios said Saturday the government sought in talks with opposition parties to avoid ``violent and passionate outlooks'' to reach accords on electoral conflicts. But Cardenas insisted, ``There hasn't been a policy on the government's part of respect for finding political resolutions.'' ``If the authorities respected the law, there wouldn't have been electoral fraud on Dec. 3 and the continuing incidence of violence,'' he said. The party has also reported recent election-related armed conflicts in Michoacan, Puebla, Morelos and Oaxaca states.

DOC.HEAD: New Estimate of Soviet Jewish Arrivals Causes Turmoil for Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir comments on Arab objections to Soviet Jewish immigration. Pick up 6th pvs, `Kazakov gave...' Minor editing thereafter.
DOC.TEXT: A senior government official's prediction that 230,000 Soviet Jews could immigrate to Israel this year heightened fears Wednesday that Israel was unprepared to handle the influx. ``Panic: a quarter-million new immigrants on their way,'' read a banner headline in the Hebrew daily Hadashot. The daily Maariv and state-run Israel Radio noted the new figure heightened confusion over immigration estimates since most officials are predicting that about 100,000 Soviet Jews will arrive this year. Even that number could be a problem. Israel has geared up to receive only about 50,000. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, meanwhile, sharply criticized Arab states that object to the immigration of Soviet Jews here and called them the ``enemy of Israel.'' Shamir told U.S. Jewish leaders that the Arab campaign to halt immigration to Israel was ``hysterical.'' ``We say to all Arab countries _ including Egypt _ that anyone who fights against this immigration reveals himself as an enemy of Israel,'' he told members of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. Arab states fear that the Soviet Jews will be settled in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where the Palestine Liberation Organization has declared its independent state. Israeli officials have repeatedly denied there is a government policy of settling Soviet Jews in the occupied lands. Available figures indicate that only about 200 of 12,000 Soviet Jews who arrived last year decided on settling in the territories. About 100 are believed to have settled in the territories in the last few months. ``If anyone expects me to say that we shall forbid any Jew from going to Judea, Samaria or elsewhere _ I shall never do that,'' Shamir told the American Jewish leaders, using the biblical names for the West Bank. The higher prediction of Soviet Jewish immigration came from Yasha Kazakov, deputy head of the Liaison Bureau, a once-secret government department that deals with Soviet Jewry, Israeli media said. Kazakov gave the figure Tuesday to a group of directors of government ministries that handle immigration matters, Hadashot reported. ``When he pulled out the numbers we were in a state of shock,'' Ephraim Cohen, deputy director of the Absorption Ministry, told Maariv. ``There was silence in the hall.''
