Kazakov said he thought 50,000 Soviet Jews would arrive by June, an additional 120,000 in the summer and 60,000 more in the last four months, Maariv said. His projections were based on the possibility of increased emigration via the existing routes through Romania and Hungary and new exit routes through Czechoslovakia, Finland and Poland, Maariv said. Soviet authorities have so far refused Israeli requests to allow emigrants to fly directly from the Soviet Union to Israel. Arab nations have urged the Kremlin to restrict Jewish emigration. So far this year, 9,441 Soviet Jews have arrived, joining more than 12,000 who immigrated to Israel in 1989. The upsurge in Soviet Jewish arrivals comes as a result of more liberal Soviet emigration policies, fears of rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union, and U.S. visa restrictions. Gennady Zhuravlev, the Soviet amabassador to Egypt, charged Monday that Israel was deliberately overestimating the number of Soviet Jews it expects in order to obtain more aid from the United States and other Western nations. Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz, speaking Wednesday on Israel army radio in a telephone interview from New York, said he was visiting the United States to try to get more help from American Jews for the immigrants. ``Without a massive help from the Jewish people, we will not be able to fulfill this historic mission,'' Peretz said. Peretz said it was hard to predict immigration accurately. ``Undoubtedly, at least 120,000 to 150,000 will come with God's help, but there may be surprises and many more may come,'' he said. Peretz did not say whether his figures referred only to Soviet Jews or included immigrants from other countries as well. Meanwhile, Uri Gordon, head of the Immigration Department at the Jewish Agency, a quasi-governmental body that deals with immigrants, demanded that Israel declare a state of emergency to deal with the Soviet immigrants. ``It does not matter whether we expect 100,000 or 200,000,'' Gordon said. ``Masses of Jews could come. ... This obliges us to declare an emergency situation and set different priorities.'' He mentioned the possibility of converting youth hostels to housing for the newcomers.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Navy Fires Grenades at Suspected Foreign Submarine
DOC.TEXT: The Swedish navy fired underwater grenades Wednesday at a suspected alien submarine, the target of a weeklong search in a sensitive coastal zone south of Stockholm, the defense command said. Spokesman H.G. Wessberg said anti-submarine sonar may have picked up an echo from a rock on the seabed, instead of an intruding vessel. But the search for an intruder was continuing. The grenades were launched about 21 miles from Stockholm. No trace of a damaged sub was found, said a communique. ``There's a lot to indicate that it was a protrusion on the bottom of the sea,'' said Wessberg. Sonar is easily distorted in the shallow and brackish sea, defense experts say. Coastal units first detected indications last Thursday that Swedish waters may have been violated. It was the third time since the weekend that the Swedes fired at what they believed to be a foreign sub or group of minisubs. Rand Corp., a U.S. research institute, said two weeks ago that Soviet subs stepped up illegal incursions in Swedish waters after Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. Swedish researcher Wilhelm Agrell said in January that the Soviet military intelligence agency GRU was carrying out the intrusions, using minisubmarines launched from a mobile trailer system in the Baltic republics. The Swedish military upgraded its antisubmarine capability after a Soviet submarined was grounded outside Karlskrona naval base in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Mr. President, Don't Quit Your Day Job
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, visiting New York for a political fund raiser, couldn't resist making a joke Wednesday about the headline-grabbing divorce fight between Donald and Ivana Trump. Bush told the crowd his arrival one month before a Staten Island congressional election had put him in the midst of ``one of the greatest contests of 1990,'' a battle with ``a lot at stake, a lot of money spent on both sides, a lot of press attention.'' Pause. ``But I'm not here to talk about the Trumps.'' Ba-dum-dum. Turns out this was just the start of the president's shtick. Bush, after referring to his wife Barbara as ``the silver fox,'' attributed her absence Wednesday to the presence of Staten Island borough president Guy V. Molinari and his full head of gray hair. ``The only reason she's not here is she didn't want to put her hairdo up against Guy's,'' said Bush. The president, who received a good deal of positive press when the first dog, Millie, had a White House litter, also offered this advice to congressional candidate Susan Molinari: ``Puppies: worth 10 points easy.''

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Says Failure To Disclose $485,000 Loan Was Misunderstanding
DOC.TEXT: The failure of Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., to disclose an unsecured $485,000 loan resulted from a misunderstanding of Senate rules, aides said Thursday. Three other loans that the Minnesota Republican took out from Commercial State Bank of St. Paul, Minn., were not listed separately on his financial disclosure form, according to his staff. That also may be a violation of Senate rules. It was the first attempt by Durenberger's office to explain apparent errors in reporting favorable borrowings from the Minnesota bank. The reporting discrepancies were made public three weeks ago in a newspaper article that disclosed the favorable terms Durenberger received on a series of loans from the bank. Durenberger already is under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for failing to disclose on time reimbursement he received from lobbyists for numerous speaking engagements in 1985 and 1986. ``There's absolutely no intention to leave (information) out,'' said Durenberger spokeswoman Carrie Collins. ``There's no intention to hide anything.'' Although the Senate Ethics Committee has not looked into the loans, the committee last week found ``substantial credible evidence'' of six violations of federal law and Senate rules in the senator's financial conduct. Trial-like hearings on those allegations, which focus on a book contract he used to raise $100,000 in speaking fees, could begin later this month. The borrowings that Durenberger apparently did not disclose properly were among 20 unsecured loans totaling $1.27 million he obtained from the Commercial State Bank of St. Paul from 1979 to 1988. Durenberger's 1988 financial disclosure report listed three loans from Commercial State Bank, but missing from the form was the short-term $484,332 loan the senator got in June 1988 to obtain financing on a McLean, Va., townhouse. The attorney who prepared the report thought the ``swing'' loan did not have to be reported because senators are not required to disclose loans on their personal residences that are secured by the property, according to a statement issued by Bert McKasy, the senator's chief of staff. The senator's 1983 report listed only one liability with Commercial State Bank, although he borrowed from the bank three times at varying interest rates less than the rate he reported. An $85,000 loan taken out in 1982 at 13 percent interest was renewed and increased to $90,000 in January 1983, according to the statement. A $15,000 loan was taken out at 11.5 percent in April of that year. A third loan of $10,000 was obtained in December at 12 percent interest. The financial disclosure report listed only: a ``personal promissory note'' in the category of value of $100,001 to $250,000 at an interest rate of 13 percent. ``It was the understanding of the preparer that the forms could be filled out in that way,'' Collins said. ``The intent was to represent the total amount of liability that was due Commercial State Bank within that time frame (1983) and that was done.'' However, instructions provided with the financial disclosure forms specify that senators must disclose the amount, maturity date, repayment terms and interest rate for ``each liability'' exceeding $10,000. The instructions ``would require that you report each loan individually,'' said Wilson Abney, the Ethics Committee's chief of staff.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Given Alcohol Dies After Respirator Removed
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old boy who the authorities said was given 10 ounces of bourbon by an adult and told to ``drink it like a man'' died Wednesday almost 11 hours after being removed from life-support systems. Doctors said Raymond Thomas Griffin II fell into a coma and suffered irreversible brain damage after a 21-year-old party guest at his home allegedly told him to drink the alcohol Friday night, police said. He died at Cook-Fort Worth Children's Medical Center at 8:45 a.m. Wednesday, the hospital said. Griffin's family agreed to disconnect the life support system that had kept him alive at about 10 p.m. Tuesday, but the child had continued to breathe on his own. Anthony Jimerson, 21, of Forest Hills was being held in the Tarrant County Jail in lieu of $100,000 bail after being charged with injury to a child, officials said. The charge carries a maximum 99-year prison term. Police and prosecutors were discussing upgrading the charges against Jimerson, who told the boy to drink the alcohol, said Everman police Detective J.D. Brown. He said he did not anticipate new charges immediately. It was unclear whether the boy's mother, Patricia Griffin, 31, knew that the boy was being given liquor, or whether she found out later when Raymond became ill. ``We're getting some conflicting stories on whether she knew, whether she was told that night or in the morning,'' Brown said. Brown said it appeared that the boy began having convulsions at about 3 a.m. Saturday, but an ambulance was not called until 2:45 p.m. Brown said Ms. Griffin probably would be interviewed after the boy's funeral. The amount the boy drank was the equivalent of an adult chug-a-luging a fifth of liquor, officials said. Doctors said the boy's blood alcohol level was .55 percent, more than five times the legal limit of intoxication in Texas. Brown said doctors indicated they might have been able to help the boy if he had been brought in sooner. ``That's a question I've placed and directed straight to the doctor and the neurologist that treated Raymond,'' he said. ``If it had been recognized immediately, it is a very, very good possibility that they could have helped or saved him or maybe even stopped the damage.'' Brown said he had seen the boy before at the suburban apartment complex where Raymond lived with his mother and 2-year-old brother. ``He was just a bright, inquisitive child, very polite,'' he said. ``He was intelligent for a 5-year-old,'' the father, Raymond Griffin of Myrtle Beach, S.C., told the Fort Worth Star-Telegram. ``I used to read to him a lot and I didn't read him comic books. I read him Time, books about leadership, books about my work in the Army. ``He was going to be brilliant.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 new grafs, one graf transition to RECAST, reflecting comment that auto accord clears way for likely agreement overall; picks up 4th graf: ``The talks,''
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders and the Bush administration reached an accord Wednesday on pollution controls for automobiles, removing a major obstacle to agreement on a compromise clean air bill, Senate sources said. Closed-door negotiations continued into the evening over details about new acid rain controls, but sources close to the talks said those issues were unlikely to scuttle the rest of the pollution control package which has been worked out in three weeks of bargaining. Disagreements over acid rain might be set aside and be thrashed out on the Senate floor if the differences, involving largely disagreements among senators, are not resolved, said an aide to one senator who has been close to the private talks. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he planned to bring the clean air bill to the Senate floor on Thursday and had no desire to extend the private bargaining with the administration for another day. The talks, which had gone past midnight twice this week, continued into the evening as negotiators focused on remaining disagreements over provisions on controlling acid rain. It was the only remaining area of disagreement, the sources said. While Senate leaders and the Bush administration have agreed on most of the acid rain provision, individual senators have not. A group of Midwest senators have threatened to filibuster against the clean air bill if they do not receive help in paying for the expensive pollution controls that would be required at many of that region's coal-fired electric plants have to meet the deep cuts required for acid rain pollution. Other senators have balked at such cot-sharing because, they argued, their states already have paid to clean up their electric plants. These same senators, however, have expressed concern that the new pollution controls might inhibit growth of electric capacity in their states. The negotiations turned to the acid rain issue after the two sides agreed on how to curb emissions from automobiles and reduce the smog problem that has plagued many urban areas. The issue had been among the most contentious under discussion. The Senate bill called for two rounds of tough emission controls on automobiles to reduce urban smog. The Bush administration, however, had strongly objected to the second round of controls, saying they were too expensive and provided only marginal benefits. Senate authors of the legislation, however, argued the additional controls were needed for some of the most polluted urban centers to achieve clean air. According to sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, the compromise agreement calls for the so-called Tier 2 controls to go into effect nationwide only if 11 of 27 cities, now considered to have ``serious'' air pollution problems, fail to make adequate progress in meeting federal air quality standards by late in this decade. Environmentalists criticized the compromise as being almost as bad as not have a second round of emission controls at all. They argued that it is unlikely that 11 the 27 cities would not be able to achieve the federal standards since the group of 27 does not include the eight of the country's most polluted cities which are in categories of ``severe'' or ``extreme'' pollution. ``You could have cities with a total of 80 million people not in (federal air quality) attainment and still not have a Tier 2,'' said Gene Karpinski, executive director of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, an environmental group. The Senate-adminstration talks earlier this week produced tentative agreements on how to control toxic chemicals from industrial plants and on curbing smog-causing pollutants from an array of stationery sources from chemical plants to dry cleaners. While most of the focus has been on the Senate bill in recent weeks, a different version remains in a House committee. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Wednesday he hoped that bill could come up for floor consideration by April, several months earlier than he previously had indicated.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia to Investigate Killings of Leftist Party Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 10 grafs with drug suspects arrested, other developments.
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco said Wednesday his government will look into accusations by the leftist Patriotic Union party that senior military officials were responsible for assassinating its members. Barco said the government was not to blame for the violence against Patriotic Union members. Late Tuesday, unidentified gunmen killed six local Patriotic Union leaders on a street in Ungia, 310 miles northwest of the capital. The gunmen then fled, reported Jose Antonio Lopez in an interview Wednesday for RCN network. Lopez is the party's candidate for mayor in Apartado, 35 miles east of Ungia in the violence-plagued Uraba region bordering Panama. An armed group on Monday kidnapped and killed Apartado Mayor Diana Cardona, also a Patriotic Union member. Party leaders blamed the killing on a right-wing death squad they said was supported by members of the military. The party also blamed death squads for killing a city councilman belonging to the party, a freelance journalist and three leaders of an agricultural cooperative this week. Patriotic Union leaders on Tuesday demanded that Defense Minister Oscar Botero and three army brigade commanders be fired, accusing them of responsibility for an extermination campaign aimed against the party. Party leaders said 827 members have been killed since the party's founding in 1985. Party President Diego Montana told a Tuesday news conference that Patriotic Union members were being assassinated by ``paramilitary groups that ... are composed of members of the military.'' Barco said the allegations will be investigated, but added ``all parties make accusations before elections.'' Colombia is to hold congressional and municipal elections March 11. Barco spoke to reporters at Bogota airport shortly before leaving for Montevideo to attend the inauguration of Uruguay's new president, Luis Alberto Lacalle. Interior Minister Carlos Lemos, who will act as president while Barco is away, told reporters balloting will proceed in all regions despite pre-election violence. He said later Wednesday that leftist guerillas of the National Liberation Army, or ELN, may have staged the attacks on Patriotic Union leaders as part of a campaign to disrupt the elections. Lemos did not explain why the guerillas would attack the leftist party, whose members include many ELN sympathizers and former guerillas. Death squads have killed more than 1,000 people over the last four years, according to the attorney general's office. Human rights officials say the death squads have been supported by drug traffickers as well as by some members of the military. Meanwhile, two more drug trafficking suspects wanted for extradition to the United States were captured, a police communique said. Jorge Alirio Ortiz, an alleged member of the cocaine cartel based in the southern city of Cali, was arrested in Ibague, the communique said. Ortiz was convicted by a Washington, D.C. court on drug trafficking charges, it said. It did not give the date of conviction. Another suspect, Manuel Antonio Garces, was captured in Medellin. Garces is wanted by a U.S. court on charges of money laundering and cocaine distribution, the communique said. Since the government began its current crackdown last August, it has extradited 14 drug suspects to the United States. Authorities announced Wednesday that more of the treasure amassed by a Medellin cartel leader before he was killed had been found by police. In a raid Tuesday on a Bogota house, police discovered gold ingots and coins, platinum plates, diamond-encrusted jewelry, Australian currency and $250,000 in U.S. currency. A police spokeswoman told The Associated Press that the treasure, found in a leather suitcase and worth over $2 million, was part of the fortune of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a former leader of the Medellin cartel. Rodriguez Gacha was killed in a Dec. 15 gunfight with police. In previous raids authorities seized $36 million of gold, cash and jewelry. The police spokeswoman said two members of Rodriguez Gacha organization were captured in the raid. She did not identify the suspects.

DOC.HEAD: WWII General Buried At Historic Military Cemetery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0785 to remove LaserPhoto tag.
DOC.TEXT: James M. Gavin, a World War II general who helped lead the D-Day invasion and was later an outspoken critic of U.S. military policy, was buried Wednesday with full military honors. An honor guard from Gavin's famed 82nd Airborne Division fired a three-volley salute at the funeral at the U.S. Military Academy attended by about 200 people. Gavin was buried at the Army post's cemetery alongside such legendary military figures as George Armstrong Custer. Gavin, who died Friday in Baltimore at age 82, was one of the last great generals from World War II. Old comrades in arms recalled Gavin's courage in battle and his eagerness to embrace innovations in battlefield tactics and weapons. ``His physical courage was unchallenged,'' said retired Gen. William T. Ryder. ``His intellectual bent for battle was proven. The thing that endeared him to me the most was his integrity. ``Jim was one of those perceptive people, and they come few and far between, who knew the next war would not be fought with the last war's tools,'' Ryder said. Ryder parachuted into Sicily during World War II with Gavin. He said that when the paratroops were first organized, Gavin immediately wanted to get involved. ``As soon as he heard about airborne, he wanted to get out with the paratroops,'' Ryder said. ``He was always an avant-garde innovator.'' Frederick Spataro of New Brunswick, N.J., a paratrooper who fought with Gavin in Normandy, Holland and the Battle of the Bulge, said the general was ``always the first one out of the plane.'' Another foot soldier under Gavin, H. Joseph Hirlemann of West Orange, N.J., said he remembered fighting at a remote outpost and calling for more ammunition. Gavin delivered it personally. Gavin worked his way to the upper echelon of Army command during a 34-year career that began in 1925 when he enlisted as a private at age 17. He had dropped out of school after the eighth grade, but completed his high school education as an Army private, gained admission to West Point and was commissioned a second lieutenant in 1929. By the time he resigned at 51 in a dispute over the Army's role in missile development, he was the youngest three-star general. A captain when World War II began, Gavin was promoted to brigadier general by D-Day and later was given command of the 82nd Airborne Division. At the end of the war he was a highly decorated major general. After World War II, Gavin was instrumental in developing the Army's use of the helicopter, which was used extensively in Vietnam. An outspoken critic of President Eisenhower, his former commander, Gavin resigned in 1958 out of principle over his disagreement with Pentagon policies. At the time, he was about to take command of the Seventh Army in Europe. Gavin became an executive with the industrial and consulting form of Arthur D. Little Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. He was appointed ambassador to France by President Kennedy. As a civilian, Gavin continued to criticize the American military, and was was one of the first to criticize U.S. involvement in Vietnam. Gavin's wartime medals include the Purple Heart, Silver Star, and the Distinguished Service Cross with oak leaf cluster. France gave him its Croix de Guerre with palm and Britain named him to the Distinguished Service Order.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Die from Negligence in Hospitals, Harvard Study Shows
DOC.TEXT: More than 6,600 hospital patients died and thousands more were injured through medical negligence in New York state in 1984, but few malpractice suits were filed, said a Harvard University study released Wednesday. Although the survey involved only New York state, researchers said they expect a nationwide survey would find similar results. Dr. David Axelrod, the state health commissioner, said the results pointed to ``major inequities'' in the medical malpractice system, involving both compensating victims and deterring professional misconduct. Axelrod, who backs a proposal for no-fault malpractice insurance, said he believed such a reform would improve the system because doctors would be less fearful that reporting negligence by colleagues would bring lawsuits upon themselves or their hospital. But consumer rights groups and advocates for victims of medical negligence, who oppose the no-fault plan, called for more government policing of doctors and stiffer penalties for those found guilty of negligence. Despite the thousands of instances of malpractice documented in the study, only 26 doctors were disciplined in the state in 1984 for negligence. ``How can this be no one's fault?'' asked Elaine O'Rourke, pointing to her son, who went into a Brooklyn hospital for a bed-wetting problem and came out brain damaged and confined to a wheelchair. O'Rourke and other members of her group, Stop Hospital and Medical Errors, frequently interrupted a news conference on the study with demands that criminal penalties be adopted for health-care workers found guilty of negligent acts. Overall, the study estimated that 3.7 percent of those hospitalized sustained an injury in the hospital ``that resulted in measurable disability.'' The researchers said that would translate into 99,000 injuries out of 2.7 million people hospitalized statewide in 1984. Most of the injuries were relatively minor _ 70 percent of patients recovered completely within six months. But 14 percent were fatal, a rate which translated into more than 13,000 deaths in 1984. Fifty-one percent of the fatal injuries resulted from negligence, the study found. But it noted that ``many of the deaths occurred in patients who had greatly shortened life expectancies from their underlying diseases.'' Doctors and hospitals are required by state law to report all cases of possible medical misconduct. However, Peter Slocum, a Health Department spokesman, said the state received only 1,525 reports of possible misconduct in 1984, and only 161 came from physicians or hospitals. Axelrod denied that there was a ``code of silence'' among health care providers over reporting negligence cases. He blamed the current tort system, which he said ``deters compliance'' with the law. ``A large number of `adverse events' that occur in institutions are not currently being reported to us,'' he said. The number of malpractice claims filed against doctors and hospitals was only about 10 percent of the total number of negligent injuries, the study found. Of the patients who were found in the study to have been injured because of negligence, only 2 percent filed malpractice claims. The Medical Society of the State of New York, which supports Axelrod's calls for malpractice reform, applauded the report and said the current tort system was a ``grotesque failure.'' ``It overcompensates some, but tragically it fails to compensate many, many people who are the victims of inadequate medical care,'' spokesman Gerard L. Conway told the news conference. The New York State Trial Lawyers Association issued a statement saying the state's malpractice crisis was not the fault of the legal system, but rather ``is caused by negligent and substandard care'' by doctors. The four-year, $3.1-million study, one of the most comprehensive ever undertaken, involved a review of the records of more than 30,000 patients from 51 randomly selected hospitals in New York state. The researchers stressed that the findings could not be applied to hospitals today, since most hospitals have taken a variety of steps since 1984 to improve patient care. The study looked at cases of ``unintended injury,'' which was defined as one ``caused by medical management rather than by the disease process.'' They included errors in performing medical procedures, as well as diagnostic errors and improper or omitted care.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Ambassador Summoned on Journalist's Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's ambassador was summoned to the Foreign Office Wednesday in connection with the detention of a journalist in Khartoum. Julian Ozanne, a reporter for the Financial Times and Sunday Correspondent newspapers, was detained a week ago. According to the Foreign Office, Sudanese authorities said he was collecting information on the activities of dissidents in the Sudan. The Sudanese ambassador, Sayed El Rashid Abushama, was seen by David Gore-Booth, senior official responsible for Middle East affairs. The British Embassy in Khartoum has been allowed to make consular visits to Ozanne, the Foreign Office said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rules Officers Violated Woman's Civil Rights in Domestic Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury awarded a woman $1.1 million after deciding that four sheriff's officers, including her estranged husband's father and uncle, violated her civil rights when they intervened in a domestic dispute. Lori Bowden of Palatka said that in 1987 the four St. Johns County officers used their positions to find and detain her so her husband, Tommy Wayne Bowden Jr., could take their infant son from her. Jurors deliberated for about 70 minutes Tuesday before ruling against the defendants: Lt. Byron Kirkland, Deputy Melvin Tennyson and auxiliary officers Tommy Wayne Bowden Sr. and Fleming Bowden. The Bowdens are Tommy Bowden's father and uncle. Gayle Smith Swedmark, who represented the defendants, said she will appeal ``on the basis that it was an outrageous award.'' William L. Townsend, Mrs. Bowden's attorney, said he was satisfied with the jury's award. ``I thought something very outrageous had been done to her,'' he said. Mrs. Bowden testified that she and her husband separated in May 1987, but he returned on Oct. 5, saying he wanted to rekindle their marriage. She testified that when she tried to flee, he shot the truck she was driving, disabling it. She returned home with him but fled the next day with her 2-year-old son, Tommy Wayne Bowden III, and filed aggravated assault charges against her husband. On Oct. 9, Tennyson and the auxiliary deputies tracked her to a friend's apartment in St. Augustine. They told her they wanted to check on the boy's condition and refused to let her leave until her husband also saw him. When he arrived at the apartment, he took the boy, she said. She then returned home to be with her son. Five days later, Bowden was arrested for aggravated assault. Townsend argued that Kirkland, the watch commander that night, approved the officers' action despite a policy forbidding uniformed officers from interfering in incidents involving relatives of officers. Ms. Swedmark said the men were merely checking on the baby's welfare and that it was unclear whether Bowden took the child or Mrs. Bowden voluntarily gave him the boy. The Bowdens are now divorced and Mrs. Bowden has custody of their son.

DOC.HEAD: Samuel R. Mozes, Former City Planner, Dead at Age 66
DOC.TEXT: Samuel R. Mozes, a former city planner and prominent figure in international Jewish affairs, has died of a heart attack. He was 66. Mozes died Feb. 21 at his home in East Hampton on Long Island. He was director of the Bureau of Urban Affairs in the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal from 1959 to 1975. For seven years before that he worked in the city's Department of Planning. He was instrumental in developing the state's 1960 housing code, which became a prototype for other cities, and oversaw comprehensive rezoning of Staten Island. Born in Warsaw, Poland, Mozes fled with his family from the Nazis in 1939 and arrived in America in 1941 after stops in Lithuania and Japan. From 1941 to 1951, he was associate editor of the Overseas Jewish News Agency. He was executive director of the World Gathering of Holocaust Survivors in Israel in 1981 and in Washington in 1984. Mozes received a bachelor's degree in architecture and a master's in urban planning and housing from Columbia University. He held a doctorate in environmental science from Columbia Pacific University. Mozes taught in recent years at Long Island University and Columbia. He is survived by his wife, Janine, two sons and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: William Earl Buckler, Literature Professor, Dead at Age 65
DOC.TEXT: William Earl Buckler, a specialist in Victorian literature and a former dean at New York University, has died of cancer. He was 65. Buckler died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York, where he lived. He joined the university's English faculty in 1953 and became a full professor in 1961. He was dean of the College of Arts and Sciences from 1960 to 1969. He authored many works on Victorian writers, including ``The Victorian Imagination'' and ``Walter Pater.'' Buckler is survived by five sisters.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Says Bush Failed to Exclude Military Personnel from Budget Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 to CORRECT that members of JCS, not ``chairmen,'' appeared before committee in 2nd graf; CORRECTS title of Adm. Trost in 3rd graf to chief of naval operations sted ``chairman.''
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee accused President Bush on Wednesday of failing to exclude military personnel from required budget cuts and then calling on Congress to avert the expected layoffs. ``The administration is the one who clearly laid the bed of thorns and is now pointing the finger at Congress, saying, `Help us to get out of this situation,''' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., told reporters shortly after a hearing at which members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff painted a dire picture of the effect of the budget reductions. The Armed Services chairman also lashed out at the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost for an absence of major restructuring in the Navy force in response to the lessening Soviet threat to the West. ``I want them to think _ T-H-I-N-K,'' said Nunn, who questioned why one of the armed services could say that it had felt no effects from the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe. Nunn and Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the panel's ranking Republican, said they favor granting the Defense Department the authority to move $852 million from other accounts to personnel to avoid the discharge of tens of thousands of men and women by October. The cuts are required under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-cutting law. But Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, told the service chiefs Monday that his committee will not take up the issue of shifting the funds, thus dooming the Pentagon's request. Such ``reprogramming'' of funds must be approved by the House and Senate Armed Services Committees and the House and Senate Appropriations Commitees. Nunn questioned the service chiefs as to why Bush did not exempt military personnel from the cuts, an option that the president could have exercised last August under the law. ``The Defense Department evidently did not come down strong on exempting personnel. If they did, they failed within the administration,'' Nunn said during the committee hearing. ``Now ... everybody in the administration is pointing at Congress, saying, `Save us from what we've done, and it's your fault if you don't save us from what we didn't do.' ``That's a curious position to be in.'' Trost said all the service chiefs argued for exempting military personnel but were assured by administration officials that any cuts from Gramm-Rudman would be softened by a request to shift funds. ``We four all supported the need to protect our people last fall,'' Trost said. Nunn said the administration shouldn't have given those assurances based on the belief that officials could later convince four congressional committees to accept the transfer of funds. ``Somebody should have checked with the four committees because, obviously, the House wasn't plugged into that,'' Nunn said. He said he hoped the fund transfer could occur, but Aspin, in an interview later in the day, said the chances of his changing his mind are ``zero.'' ``You'll see a lot of wheeling and dealing, but it's not going to work,'' the House Armed Services chairman said in an interview with several reporters. The Pentagon on Tuesday released estimates showing that without the authority to transfer funds, 44,100 to 68,200 military personnel would have to be discharged by Oct. 1; 32,500 to 32,600 people would be frozen in their current jobs; 57,000 to 67,000 promotions would be delayed; and 59,900 to 115,900 fewer people could be brought into the armed forces. Questioned whether his action was irresponsible, Aspin said: ``I want to do the responsible thing. In the long run, make them (the administration) understand the consequences in the short run.''

DOC.HEAD: Actress Fabia Drake Dead at 86
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf that there were no survivors.
DOC.TEXT: Fabia Drake, whose acting career spanned 77 years with credits from the Shakespearean stage to television miniseries, died Wednesday. She was 86. Miss Drake died at her home in London, said fellow actress Rachel Kempson. ``The lovely thing about being an ancient actress is that you don't have to retire, it's just there are older parts to play,'' Miss Drake said in 1987. Her many film and television appearances included the television miniseries ``The Jewel In The Crown'' and films including ``The Good Companions'' in 1957, ``Fast and Loose'' in 1954, ``Young Wives Tales'' in 1951. In her later work, she was often cast in ``battle axe'' roles, according to Halliwell's ``Filmgoer's and Video Viewer's Companion.'' Her last role was in Milos Forman's film, ``Valmont.'' At age 9, she made her stage debut in ``The Fairy Doll.'' She was 13 when she appeared in a production of Shakespeare's ``Twelfth Night'' along with a 10-year-old actor who also made good _ Laurence Olivier. Her first major theatrical role was as Sarah Undershaft in George Bernard Shaw's ``Major Barbara'' in 1921. After leading the Royal Shakespeare Company on two tours of North America, she married Maxwell Turner, a lawyer, in 1938 and retired for a time. She returned in 1946 to produce Shakespeare's ``Much Ado about Nothing.'' Turner died in 1960. A funeral service was set for Tuesday at the Golders Green crematorium. There were no survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Maurice A. Garbell, Aviation Pioneer, Dead at Age 75
DOC.TEXT: Maurice A. Garbell, an aviation consultant who was an early advocate of a successful airport noise control plan, has died after a short illness. He was 75. Garbell died last Saturday at Pacific Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco, where he lived. He was an early proponent of a plan that called for noisy jetliners to climb steeply to avoid residential neighborhoods near airports. During World War II, he was a top aerodynamicist for Consolidated Vultee Aircraft, now General Dynamics in San Diego. There, he designed aircraft wings and wrote a book on tropical and equatorial meteorology. After the war, Garbell moved to San Francisco and worked as an aviation consultant. Survivors include his wife, Esther, and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Orion Executive Named Tri-Star Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Mike Medavoy, who recently resigned from a top spot at Orion Pictures Corp. after overseeing a string of box-office bombs, was appointed chairman of Tri-Star Pictures on Wednesday. Medavoy, 49, also will become a member of the board of Columbia Pictures Entertainment, under which Tri-Star operates. He will be responsible for overall operations of Tri-Star, including the development, production and marketing of movies. A week ago, Medavoy announced his resignation from Orion, where he was executive vice president. The Tri-Star position was formerly held by Jeff Sagansky, who left to became president of CBS Entertainment. Orion's failures include ``Valmont,'' ``Everybody Wins,'' ``She-Devil,'' ``Farewell to the King,'' ``Great Balls of Fire,'' ``Lost Angels,'' ``Eric the Viking,'' ``Heart of Dixie'' and ``The Package.''

DOC.HEAD: Ice Traps Ships in Gulf of St. Lawrence
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen ships were stuck Wednesday in the Gulf of St. Lawrence in what the Canadian Coast said were the worst ice conditions on the waterway in 10 years. Andy Maillet, assistant coast guard ice operations officer, said the combination of an early winter, extremely low temperatures and easterly winds had created a near impenetrable layer of ice. ``Some of these ships have been out there quite a long time,'' Maillet said. ``Some of them have been stuck for four or five days.'' The ice, driven by easterly winds, runs in a line from the Strait of Belle Isle to the Gaspe Peninsula and Anticosti Island. ``It has been drifting generally in a southwest direction enabling it to press up against the Newfoundland and Cape Breton coasts,'' Maillet said. The ice has disrupted shipping for the past two weeks and left coast guard officials hoping for an early spring. Six icebreakers, four from Nova Scotia and one each from Newfoundland and Quebec, were trying to break the ships free and escort them to passable ice. At one point last week, 26 ships were stuck. The numbers keep changing as some vessels break free. ``Once the ice pressure changes a little bit, they are able to back away from the particular ice pan they're in and then carry on their voyage,'' said Maillet. ``But you lose one, you gain another. '' He said he expected poor shipping conditions would continue for a couple more weeks. Maillet said none of the 18 ships _ including tankers, freighters and container vessels _ was in immediate danger, although some were low on water and fuel. ``None of them has run out of fuel yet. We won't let them,'' Maillet said. He warned the situation could change quickly, however. ``Depending on where they get stuck, they could fall into danger of drifting ashore,'' he said. Eight of the icebound ships were trying to reach gulf ports while the other 10 were trying to get through the Cabot Strait to the open Atlantic. The coast guard had to take medication by helicopter to one ship last week while a search and rescue crew carried out a medical evacuation of a crewmember with a badly cut finger.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilians Struggle Back to Work After Four Days of Carnival
DOC.TEXT: After four days of all-night dancing, drinking, parades and carvinal frivality, Brazilians straggled back to work Wednesday and stores, banks and supermarkets reopened. The country's wild pre-Lenten bash came to a close in Rio, the unofficial carnival capital, after four balls and huge street parties that attracted thousands of city residents despite periodic thunderstorms. The biggest carnival balls were televised live nationwide and, despite an impassioned appeal from the country's justice minister to exercise restraint on the filming of any public nudity, several networks showed lusty scenes. TV Manchete, Brazil's third-largest network, had extended coverage of the Monte Libano nightclub's ``Night in Baghdad'' ball, filming close-up the moves of the scantily-clad and topless female dancers. Also periodically shown were male party-goers, some appearing to be near comatose from drinking, pawing at the women. Late Wednesday, the Mocidade Independente ``samba school'' was crowned the winner of the city's world-famous samba parade. The school, which included more than 500 percussionists who played a number of exotic instruments, won a small cash prize and national acclaim. The parade, considered the highlight of Brazilian carnival, featured 16 samba schools _ neighborhood groups from poor, mostly black districts, each with as many as 5,000 exotically costumed dancers and musicians who march alongside huge floats to a pulsing samba beat. Each school created its own samba for the parade and won points awarded for music, floats, rythmn, team work and several other categories. Most samba schools devote almost the entire year to preparing for the parade, and the winners are treated like heroes. Rio was not plagued by exceptional levels of violence during carnival compared to other years, officials said. Fifty-one people were killed in Rio during the four-day carnival, police said. They said 57 people were murdered during the weekend preceding the holiday. In some parts of this country of 150 million, celebrants refused to bring the carnival party to a close. In northeastern Salvador, 1,050 miles from Rio, thousands of people Wednesday were still dancing to music blared from speakers mounted on huge trucks in a downtown square. That party began Tuesday evening. In Olinda, several hundred miles further up the coast, revelers who were not satisfied with four days of madness scheduled unofficial samba parades that were to stretch late into the night. Post-carnival times will be harsh for some. Inflation is more than 70 pecent per month and President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello, who takes office March 15, will be confronted with the country's worst economic crisis in more than a century.

DOC.HEAD: Former BFGoodrich Director Dies
DOC.TEXT: Arthur Kelly, a retired executive vice president and former director of the BFGoodrich Co., has died. He was 87. Kelly joined the company in 1925 after graduating from Purdue University. He was named president of BFGoodrich Tire Co. in 1953, executive vice president in 1956, and a director in 1961. Kelly retired in 1967, but continued as a director until 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Embassy Guard Killed
DOC.TEXT: A Swedish Embassy security guard was found beaten and shot to death Wednesday in an embassy bathroom in what appeared to be a politically motivated attack, officials said. Defense Minister Gen. Alejandro Gramajo linked the killing of Agustin Alvarado Hernandez to extremist violence in Guatemala and to U.N. discussions in Geneva of human rights in this Central American country. He said Swedish news media reported recently that Sweden had asked the United Nations to name a human rights liaison for Guatemala. ``We believe that this act of violence has to do with a policy in which the extremes are favored, whether of the leftist remnant of Marxist-Leninism that remains in the Caribbean and particularly in Guatemala, or of the `super right' that I have always called terrorist also,'' Gramajo said. Authorities said Hernandez worked for a private security company contracted by the embassy. They did not say when he was killed. Swedish Ambassador Ulf Lewin received bomb threats on Jan. 23, according to news reports at the time, and authorities offered to increase security for the embassy. Some human rights organizations estimate more than 100,000 people have been killed in political violence in Guatemala since 1954. Right-wing death squads, which once claimed responsibility for many assassinations, resurfaced in 1989 with an increase in killings, kidnappings and disappearances. The squads have claimed responsibility for only a few of the cases. Students, professionals, peasant leaders and others who work with peasants have been traditional targets of the violence, particularly during army campaigns against leftist guerrillas who have been fighting 28 years to overthrow the succession of military and military-dominated Guatemalan governments.

DOC.HEAD: Students Said to Burn Car, Beat Leader of State Student Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS to RECAST, 4 grafs SUB for grafs 10-11, They said ... UPDATING with quote from student leader, Cabinet reshuffle. Picks up 12th graf, Students said ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-West Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Militant students Wednesday set fire to a car belonging to a state-controlled student union and beat some group leaders who came to announce a concession to the protesters, students and witnesses said. On Tuesday night, soldiers marched onto the campus of the National University of Ivory Coast, beat students with truncheons and arrested about 30 who are being held at a military camp in the capital, students said. The students began protesting Feb. 19. They have demanded improved living conditions and better facilities, but also have politial demands: freedom of expression and a multiparty state in this West African nation. The militants also want officials to authorize a new group to replace the Movement of Pupils and Students, the youth league of the country's sole legal political party. Late Tuesday, leaders of the party-controlled union went to the main university campus and residences scattered around the capital to tell students the government had agreed to halve their costs of boarding and lodging. State radio broadcast the news Wednesday. But the students at dormitories in Yopougon, a working class suburb, said they attacked the student leaders and, when they fled, set their car ablaze. Foreign journalists who watched the scene said the car had government license tags, a target of students who have burned and stoned several cars and state-owned buses in the past 10 days. The students have been particularly enraged by the sleek Mercedes Benz cars that the government provides for Cabinet ministers despite a 10-year recession that has brought salary cuts, unemployment and lowered living standards. The state student movement leader, Keita Aboubacar, was beaten by about 50 students at the main suburban campus when he carried news of the government price cuts, students involved in the attack said Wednesday. They said the student leader had to be treated at the hospital Tuesday night, but he later denied to reporters there was any attack on himself or members of his movement. He said two foreign reporters who reported seeing a burning car belonging to a movement official had lied. However, a militant protester, said, ``This is our response to their efforts to pacify us. We're going to carry on demonstrating.'' The government said Wednesday it was transferring the responsibilities for secondary and higher education from Bella Keita to Alhassane N'Diaye, the minister of culture and scientific research. Militant students have demanded Keita's removal. Communications Minister Auguste Miremont told reporters no reason was given for the Cabinet reshuffle. Students said they also were angered by government proposals this week to introduce more of the austerity measures that have brought hardship to this once-prosperous nation. The Ivory Coast is suffering from slumping prices of cocoa and coffee, its main exports. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny told a meeting of worker and employer organizations Monday that he proposes to cut the salaries of government employees, including Cabinet ministers, by 15 percent to 40 percent and tax all wage earners an additional 10 percent. He also proposed a 20 percent reduction in electricity charges and up to 15 percent cuts in water bills. The president, whose civilian government has ruled since the nation became independent from France in 1960, has met unexpected opposition from the state-run General Union of Workers, a usually docile body. Union leader Adiko Gniamke said at Monday's meeting that workers could not support further salary cuts. Instead, he demanded the return of millions of dollars he said had been deposited abroad by high-ranking dignitaries. The same demand has been made by the student protesters and the Union of University Lecturers, the only body that has publicly expressed support for the rebellious students.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Put Out Canadian Tire Fire After Two Weeks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with fire now out, quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters on Wednesday finally extinguished a blaze at a dump where 14 million old tires had burned for 17 days, forcing hundreds of residents to flee from the smoky fumes, the fire chief announced. ``It's out, man, it's history,'' said Buck Slote, chief of the volunteer Hagersville fire department. ``We're going to spend about a week out there cleaning up and then we're going to have one hell of a party right here in the fire hall.'' The fire, believed set by an arsonist, began on Feb. 12 at the Tyre King Recycling dump, forcing people to leave their homes in the area 22 miles southwest of Hamilton and about 150 miles east of Detroit. Most have since returned home. Slote, 51, fought the blaze alongside his son Cary and other members of the 30-man volunteer force, plus firefighters from 24 other departments. He said he rushed to the 11-acre dump in the twilight after hearing a radio report the fire was out. What did he see? ``I saw nothing. It was beautiful.'' In frigid temperatures, pelted by snow and ice storms, the firefighters had fought the blaze into a third week before claiming victory. They used breathing apparatus to stand up to choking smoke, broke a huge mountain of tires into smaller piles and bombed the flames from the air with water mixed with a chemical fire retardant. Most days, the water bombers were grounded by bad weather and the firefighters on the ground had to go it alone. The tire dump, Ontario's largest, was declared an illegal waste site in December 1985. Groundwater and soil contamination were major concerns, but spokesman Gerry Merchant of the Ontario Environment Ministry said 107 of 125 tested wells in the area showed no contamination. He also said an air-quality monitoring system near the dump had registered only slight chemical contamination. However, officials still cautioned farmers to keep livestock away from drinking water in a nearby creek. Douglas Kittle, regional health officer, said initial test results were reassuring. But residents were still worried about long-term environmental damage. ``How ... can all that stuff go into the ground and not cause problems?'' asked Don Davidson, a 32-year-old farmer.

DOC.HEAD: Hilary's Dad Arrives for Custody Battle
DOC.TEXT: The father of a 7-year-old girl he has not seen in more than two years arrived here Thursday to renew a court battle for custody of the child, whose mother went to jail for hiding her. Dr. Erich Foretich flew into Christchurch from Auckland and said he will abide by the New Zealand Family Court ruling not to see his daughter, Hilary. Hilary's mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, has accused her former husband of sexually abusing the child, a charge Foretich has denied. Foretich, a dentist from Falls Church, Va., would not respond to the allegations Thursday, but said he would strive to keep Hilary's privacy and dignity. ``I'm not going to get involved in scintillation and retaliation,'' he told reporters at Christchurch airport before being whisked into a waiting car and driven through the city with media vehicles in pursuit. Hilary reportedly has not seen either parent for two years. No date has been set for the custody hearing, and Morgan still is awaiting a Superior Court ruling in Washington, D.C., to regain her passport, confiscated when she went to jail in August 1987 for refusing to disclose Hilary's whereabouts. Morgan sent the child off with her parents after a Washington judge ruled that Foretich could have unsupervised visits with Hilary. Morgan spent 25 months in jail and was released only after Congress passed a law tailored for her that limited imprisonment for civil contempt to one year. Foretich, aided by private investigators, tracked his daughter to Christchuch, a South Island city of 300,000 people 190 miles south of Wellington. Foreign journalists have descended on the city since he arrived in Australia on Monday, and Hilary's grandmother, Antonia Morgan, said the child was feeling ``haunted'' by the battery of photographers and journalists. The Family Court, which is to rule on the case, has warned journalists they could be fined or jailed if they publish details of the custody saga. New Zealand's contempt of court laws are much tougher than U.S. laws and bar any discussion of a case before its conclusion.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Declines to Dismiss Charges Against Imelda Marcos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with co-defendant pleading guilty and agreeing to cooperate with prosecutors; picks up 4th graf, `Keenan noted ...'
DOC.TEXT: A banker who was indicted on racketeering charges with Imelda Marcos, the widow of deposed Philippine leader Ferdinand Marcos, pleaded guilty Wednesday to a lesser charge and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. The plea by Rodolfo T. Arambulo came just hours after the judge declined to dismiss the indictment against Mrs. Marcos on a claim she and her husband were abducted from their homeland by U.S. officials during his overthrow in February 1986. Arambulo, 57, was the former president of the California Overseas Bank, a Los Angeles-based bank indicted with Arambulo and the Marcoses in October 1988. Arambulo, who had been a fugitive until his surrender Monday to FBI agents in New York, pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit mail fraud. He was accused of taking part in a scheme to fraudulently obtain insurance from the Federal Deposit and Insurance Corp. for the California Overseas Bank, which prosecutors say was secretly owned by Marcos. U.S. District Judge John Keenan revealed at the hearing that Arambulo had signed a cooperation agreement with prosecutors. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella declined to say whether Arambulo would be called as a witness at Mrs. Marcos' trial, which is scheduled to start March 20. But the plea agreement said he would be required to testify at proceedings related to the case. The conspiracy charge against Arambulo has a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. He originally was charged with racketeering and racketeering conspiracy, which both carry maximum sentences of 20 years in prison. In his ruling on Mrs. Marcos' case, Keenan also refused to hold an evidentiary hearing on the abduction allegation. Keenan noted that an entourage of 122 people accompanied the couple when they left the Philippines for their home of exile in Hawaii in February 1986, when Marcos was toppled in a revolution. ``This was more akin to a troop movement than a kidnapping,'' the judge said in a written opinion of their departure. The October 1988 indictment accused the Marcoses of siphoning more than $100 million from the Philippine treasury to buy Manhattan real estate and art. They also were charged with embezzling $165 million from several banks. Marcos died in Hawaii on Sept. 28 at age 72. In his decision, Keenan outlined Mrs. Marcos' account of events that led to the couple's arrival in Hawaii on Feb. 26, 1986, after weeks of escalating anti-Marcos sentiment in the Philippines, including attacks by rebels on the presidential palace. The judge said Mrs. Marcos claimed that at no time did she agree to leave the country. She said she refused an offer of ``safe haven'' in the United States made to her by then-first lady Nancy Reagan in a telephone conversation shortly before the Marcoses left the Philippines. Mrs. Marcos said she believed U.S. officials were going to escort them to her husband's native province in the Philippines and that she had no idea they were being taken to Hawaii. In rejecting the kidnapping claim, Keenan quoted a press statement by Marcos two days after their arrival in Hawaii in which Marcos said he was there ``under the hospitality'' of the U.S. government and that he and his wife were ``treated with the utmost respect and generosity.''

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds CIA Agreement With Author Frank Snepp
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Wednesday upheld an agreement that forces a former CIA agent to get permission from the agency before publishing a manuscript about his experiences in Vietnam. A three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a lower court judge who refused to modify a permanent injunction against Frank W. Snepp III. Snepp, a CIA agent in Vietnam for eight years, resigned from the agency and in 1977 published ``Decent Interval,'' a book about his experiences. The federal government sued Snepp for violating an employment agreement to submit all writings in advance to the CIA. In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in favor of the agency. Since then, Snepp and the CIA have agreed on publication of 18 manuscripts of books and other works by Snepp. The latest lawsuit arose out of a disagreement over Snepp's plans to write a script for a television miniseries on his experiences in Vietnam. After prolonged negotiations, the CIA approved the script but the television deal had already fallen through. Snepp sued to modify the injunction to place the burden on the CIA to initiate judicial proceedings if he and the agency could not agree on a manuscript. The appeals panel agreed with U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris of Alexandria that Snepp was trying to alter the 1980 Supreme Court ruling. ``He is essentially arguing that the original decision in his case should have placed the burden on the CIA to see judicial review. Reasserting the merits of his case does not, however, justify altering an injunction,'' the appeals court said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Former President to Campaign for East German Centrists
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan will visit East Berlin to campaign for a coalition of centrist political parties two days before East Germany's March 18 elections, the official ADN news agency reported Wednesday. ADN said Reagan offered to make a campaign appearance for the German Forum Party, the Liberal Democrats and the Free Democrats, and that the coalition had ``replied positively.'' But a Reagan spokeswoman, Cathy Goldberg, said Wednesday of the ADN report: ``As of today, he has nothing on his schedule'' showing a visit to Germany. Reagan attended a GOP event Wednesday for U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson in San Diego. ADN said Reagan would address a final election rally on March 16 for the Alliance of Free Democrats, as the centrist coalition is known. It provided no other details. The Alliance of Free Democrats currently is trailing the Social Democratic Party and the conservative coalition supported by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Top West German politicians have been appearing at campaign rallies for the parties they support in East Germany's first free elections, which will choose a 400-member parliament. But the announcement of Reagan's planned visit was the first indication that prominent U.S. politicians would become involved. Reagan visited West Berlin as president on June 12, 1987, and made a dramatic appeal before the Berlin Wall for East German and Soviet authorities to tear it down. The Berlin Wall was opened up in November during the peaceful revolution that overthrew communist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Officials Relieved that Spill Plea Bargain Fell Through
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTs 1 graf after 10th graf, `While the...,' to UPDATE with New York Times report; picks up 11th graf pvs, `The tanker...'
DOC.TEXT: Alaska officials expressed relief Wednesday that a proposed federal plea bargain fell through and Exxon Corp. was indicted on criminal charges in the nation's worst oil spill. ``I was tremendously relieved because I was worried that we were going to see some settlement that wasn't in the interests of Alaska,'' said state Rep. David Finkelstein of Anchorage. The state lobbied the U.S. Justice Department to reject the plea bargain with Exxon, saying it would hurt Alaska's efforts to win civil damages from the multibillion-dollar oil company. ``We felt the proposed plea bargain did affect our civil litigation, and we squawked about it,'' Gov. Steve Cowper said. Cowper said it appeared from the five-count indictment issued Tuesday that the federal government was ``throwing the book at Exxon, and I think that is probably appropriate.'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Tuesday that the plea bargain fell through because of state officials' objections and because of Exxon's unwillingness to meet the government's terms. Several state officials alleged the plea negotiations were part of an attempt by the Bush administration and Exxon to limit the oil company's exposure to large criminal fines. ``Exxon has a very powerful influence. They're very powerful in the economic clout they carry in Washington, D.C., as well as in Juneau. It doesn't surprise me that they attempted to do an end run,'' Sen. Jay Kerttula, whose district includes part of oil-fouled Prince William Sound, said Wednesday. Sen. Mike Szymanski of Anchorage said it appeared the administration was ``trying to cut a deal and let Exxon at least evade the criminal prosecution, which would then save them on the civil side.'' While the federal government has handled the criminal case, the state has focused on civil claims stemming from the spill. The state also is prosecuting former tanker skipper Joseph Hazelwood on felony criminal mischief and other charges stemming from the spill. The New York Times, in its Thursday editions, quoted unidentified Justice Department officials as saying the department's attempt to reach a plea bargain was motivated largely by the desire to avoid a long trial it might lose. The officials said they face a difficult court battle to convict Exxon, and said the government remains open to the possibility of a negotiated settlement, the newspaper reported. The tanker Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude in the sound March 24, killing countless birds and marine mammals and disrupting Alaska's lucrative fisheries. Under the proposed plea bargain, the federal government would have abandoned its commitment to help the state in its civil litigation, state Attorney General Douglas Baily said. State officials also criticized the Justice Department for the secrecy surrounding the plea negotiations. Rep. Gene Kubina of Valdez said the indictment ensures the criminal case will be heard in public. Finkelstein said it was in Exxon's best interest to reach a plea bargain privately before the indictment was filed. ``Now I think it's much less likely that a settlement will occur in a form that would hurt Alaska,'' he said. Exxon faces more than $700 million in possible penalties if convicted. The money would go into the federal treasury, but federal law gives the judge discretion to order restoration of the environment. State officials said any money from the case should go to restore the environment of the sound and the Gulf of Alaska to the condition it was in before the spill. ``The money shouldn't just go into the federal treasury,'' said Sen. Fred Zharoff of Kodiak. ``I think we ought to be looking at ways and means of protecting the resources.'' Szymanski maintained the federal government has an obligation to help restore the environment and improve the Coast Guard's monitoring of tanker traffic out of Valdez. State officials said large penalties are needed to ensure Exxon and other oil shippers take the precautions necessary to prevent oil spills. ``When you get up there close to a billion dollars, it's bound to get their attention,'' House Speaker Sam Cotten said.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Near-Ban on Abortion Rallies Pro-Choice Forces in Minnesota
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT that debate lasted nearly six hours, sted seven.
DOC.TEXT: A bill that would ban most abortions in Minnesota failed to get past a state Senate committee Wednesday, but the author refused to concede defeat. The bill, which would prohibit abortions for ``birth-control reasons,'' was drafted as model legislation by the National Right-To-Life Committee in the wake of last summer's U.S. Supreme Court decision that gave states more leeway to restrict abortions. ``A bill is always alive as long as the session is on,'' said Democratic Sen. Gene Waldorf after his bill failed on a tie vote in the 16-member Senate Health and Human Services Committee. ``A bill has been resurrected before,'' Waldorf said. ``Committee defeat is not the end of action on a bill.'' The vote followed nearly six hours of testimony from state and national leaders on both sides of the abortion debate. Although Minnesota was long associated in national politics with the liberalism espoused by former Vice President Walter Mondale, an abortion rights supporter, it has been a stronghold of anti-abortion sentiment. As the lawmakers debated, nearly 2,000 pro-choice activists chanting ``Choice'' exchanged taunts outside the Capitol with a small group of abortion foes shouting ``Life.'' No arrests were made. Proponents say the legislation would be the toughest enforceable anti-abortion measure in the nation, prohibiting an estimated 93 percent of the abortions performed in the state. ``Those who want this bill to become law impugn the moral dignity of Minnesota's women,'' Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, told a rally Wednesday morning before the bill was taken up by the Senate committee. ``They are implying that you cannot be trusted to make these decisions.'' Also Wednesday, lawmakers in Annapolis, Md., conducted a hearing on four abortion restriction bills and one pro-choice bill. The hearing attracted an overflow crowd that left about 150 people, mostly abortion opponents, standing with protest signs outside a legislative building. In Minnesota, Waldorf tried unsuccessfully to have the measure taken up in the House first. He had predicted the bill would lose on a tie vote in the Senate committee because the committee had been ``stacked'' against the bill by Majority Leader Roger Moe, who supports abortion rights. The House Health and Human Services Committee held hearings on the anti-abortion measure Tuesday and Wednesday and is to debate it Friday. As the Senate hearing opened, Waldorf told the committee: ``We are deciding who shall live and who shall die; who does and who does not belong to the community of legal protection.'' Jackie Schwietz, co-executive director of Minnesota Citizens Concerned for Life, said the abortion debate should not center on a woman's right to choose. ``The question is not who decides but who gets killed,'' she said. But opponents said the bill clearly violated U.S. Supreme Court decisions, including the landmark 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision which legalized abortion and last summer's so-called Webster decision which allowed states to impose some restrictions on abortions. The bill's provisions ``blatantly and unquestionably are unconstitutional in their entirety,'' said Suzanna Sherry, professor of constitutional law at the University of Minnesota. The author of the House bill, Democratic Rep. Steve Wenzel, said he's almost certain the measure will be approved by the House committee. House Democratic leaders, however, had indicated it was possible no vote would occur in the House committee if the bill were defeated by the Senate committee or if the senators did not vote. Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich, considered an ally by abortion opponents, has said he would sign whatever abortion legislation reached his desk if it were approved of by both House and Senate Democratic leaders. But Democratic leaders are split on the issue. The measure would allow abortions only in these cases: _ rape reported to police within 48 hours of the attack; _ incest reported to authorities before the abortion; _ pregnancy that threatens the woman's life or endangers her health; _ pregnancy that would result in a child born with ``profound and iremediable physical or mental disabilities incompatible with sustained survival.'' It also would establish a system of civil penalties for those performing abortions and would set out requirements for informing pregnant women about the consequences of abortion.

The Soviet Union, with strong backing from the United States, played an effective behind-the-scenes role in encouraging Nicaragua's leftist government to hold an honest election last Sunday, a senior official says. The official listed the Soviet role among a number of key elements which persuaded the Sandinista authorities that free elections were their best hope for obtaining legitimacy and international economic support. The source spoke to reporters Tuesday after President Bush conferred with congressional leaders about his plans for a ``significant and meaningful'' assistance program for Nicaragua in the approaching post-Sandinista era. President-elect Violeta Chamorro takes office April 25. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said aid for Nicaragua probably would run into hundreds of millions of dollars over five years, and he suggested the creation of an ``emerging democracy account'' to help Nicaragua, Panama and the East European countries.

The Contra rebels are refusing to heed a call from Nicaraguan leaders and the Honduran president to disband immediately, saying they'll wait until the newly elected government in Managua takes office. Dismantling the U.S.-backed force has emerged as a critical element in a peaceful transition in Nicaragua following the opposition's stunning electoral triumph Sunday over the leftist Sandinistas. On Tuesday, both Sandinista President Daniel Ortega and the opposition president-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, said the rebels must immediately disband. ``The causes that started the civil war in Nicaragua have disappeared,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in a radio broadcast Tuesday night. ``That's why those who took to the hills should now lay down their guns and return peacefully to Nicaragua with their families to work for the reconstruction of our motherland.''

The Exxon Corp. faces criminal charges and $700 million or more in possible penalties from last year's tanker spill that left hundreds of miles of Alaska shoreline polluted with oil. A federal grand jury in Alaska brought a five-count indictment against the giant oil company and its shipping subsidiary on Tuesday, charging it violated a number of federal laws in connection with the Exxon Valdez oil spill. ``The indictment ... represents our best shot at prosecuting this incident,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in announcing the indictment. The massive spill occurred when the huge tanker veered off course in Prince William Sound and struck a reef on March 24, 1989, spilling 11 million gallons of crude. It was the worst oil catastrophe in U.S. history and caused widespread damage to wildlife and Alaska's ecology.

Atlantis rocketed into the nighttime sky after five postponements and carried a spy satellite into orbit today, riding a dazzling, 700-foot tail of fire seen for hundreds of miles. After waiting out clouds and rain, the craft thundered from the pad at 2:51 a.m. EST, sending light and a shock wave of sound across the darkened seaside space center. It disappeared into clouds in just 38 seconds, leaving briefly a glow like a shrouded full moon. Observers as far north as Washington, D.C., reported seeing the brilliant light of Atlantis' rockets as the craft followed a route never before taken by a shuttle.

Northrop Corp., under investigation for fraud in its stealth bomber program, admitted falsifying test data on parts for two other projects _ the cruise missile and Harrier jet _ and agreed to a $17 million fine. The defense contractor Tuesday pleaded guilty to 34 counts of making false statements to the government. In exchange, the government agreed to drop 139 other counts of making false statements and two counts of conspiracy. ``This is a very significant victory in our efforts to combat defense contracting fraud and misconduct,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney William F. Fahey said. The fine will be ``a tremendous deterrent to corporations who choose to cut corners on certifications of tests on significant military programs,'' he said. In its defense, Northrop said the military services using the AV-8B Harrier attack jet and the cruise missile had reported that ``both systems have performed satisfactorily in flight operations.''

No man is a hero to his parking valet, especially if he's a congressman. ``Politicians are the worst tippers,'' says Adam Greenberg, an American University student who earns living expenses as a parking valet for black-tie galas and Georgetown dinner parties several nights every week. ``They drive up and say, `I'm a congressman _ park it close.' They go to five parties a night, stay for 15 minutes and leave. I guess they only have so much money to go around for tips,'' he says. Greenberg is one of about 170 part-time employees _ most of them college students _ who hustle cars for Atlantic Valet Parking, which handles more than 1,000 Washington social events to the tune of $1 million each year.

Nearly five years after Terry Anderson was taken hostage in Lebanon, his sister said Wednesday she believes the United States, Iran and Syria are moving on a common track toward freedom for all 18 Western captives. ``I'm just going to pray and hold my breath that nothing disastrous occurs before this can reach fruition,'' said Peggy Say, winding up a 2{-week trip to Europe and the Middle East that she called a ``humanitarian pilgrimage.'' ``My personal sense is, not tomorrow, not next week, maybe not next month, but certainly soon,'' she said. Anderson, 42, is the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985.

A terminally ill student who needs a bone marrow donor gets support from Dustin Hoffman. No, it's not a Hollywood tear-jerker, it's a real-life drama. The Oscar-winning actor has made a six-figure donation and has taken a lead role in a plea for Allison Atlas, who was told in August she had three to six months to live unless a marrow transplant checked her leukemia. ``If we find a donor, we'd literally be taking someone off death row,'' Hoffman said. ``There's a clock ticking which she's aware of. It's a hideous clock.'' Miss Atlas is one of more than 9,000 people awaiting a donor. About 25 people die each day from blood diseases that could be cured through marrow transplants, according to the Life-Savers Foundation of America, a non-profit group that recruits donors and raises money for blood tests.

Jewelry store manager Bob Husman says he had no idea he was in the path of a killer tornado ``right until the time the roof fell on my head.'' He wonders if better radar would have saved an employee. In fact, this north Alabama city was so shaken by the 20 deaths caused by the Nov. 15 storm that officials want to pay $120,000 to upgrade the radar at the local office of the National Weather Service. The Weather Service says no thanks. Federal officials plan to close the Huntsville office and more than 100 others while installing the $450 million Next Generation Weather Radar, dubbed Nexrad.

DOC.HEAD: PM-Walter Mears, ADV 01,840
DOC.NOTE: $Adv 01
For Release PMs Thurs March 1 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Governors Underestimate Bush `At Our Own Peril'
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: To the frustration of the Democratic governors' campaign chairman, President Bush seems beyond the reach of ordinary politicians, ``out there in his own medium at a distance from all the rest of us.'' If that's so, Democratic governors helped him get there. There are 29 of them, outnumbering the 21 Republicans, but that opposition majority didn't show at the National Governors' Association this week. In the antiseptic political atmosphere of those conferences, the very idea that a Democratic governor _ Roy Romer of Colorado _ was suggesting a budget challenge to the Republican administration led Romer to raise a point of order. Gov. Richard F. Celeste's bemused complaint about the apparently untouchable Republican president and his soaring approval ratings came near the end of a four-day meeting dominated by bipartisan embrace of an education reform program. The education goals were put together by the governors and the White House. But politically, the issue bears the Bush trademark. There was an undertone of Democratic dissatisfaction with the president's education budget, complaints that the federal investment he proposes doesn't come close to matching the rhetoric. Gov. Bill Clinton, D-Ark., a leader in the education reform drive, said Bush should be alerting the voters that they are going to have to pay more in local and state taxes to get results. ``I think that if he's not going to give us the money to do what plainly costs more money, then he has to be very clear and supportive of the governors in doing that at the state level,'' Clinton said. But at campaign time, governors who raise taxes, even for the worthiest causes, are governors with a potential problem. As a candidate, Bush said he wanted to be known as the education president.
