With few federal budget dollars to spare for new or expanded programs, Bush went to the governors to propose that they chart common goals for educational progress to be attained by the year 2000. That led to the education summit Bush convened in Charlottesville, Va., at the end of September. A task force of governors worked with the administration to shape the reform goals, which Bush announced to the nation in his State of the Union address. With minor changes, no dissent and little debate, those goals were approved by the governors on Sunday. Then they went to the White House for dinner and a Bush toast: ``We come together not as Republicans and Democrats, not as partisan competitors, but as fellow chief executives with our hearts and minds focused on a single goal: the future of our kids, the future of our country.'' They went back the next day to meet with the president, then to stand behind him as he praised their part in the first-ever national education goals and objectives to ``pave the way for a decade-long commitment to excellence in education for all Americans.'' But the questions of cost and of raising the money remain unanswered. The goals are bipartisan, but the taxes it will take to attain them will be guaranteed campaign issues. Gov. Cecil Andrus, D-Idaho, said none of it will work ``if he provides the rhetoric and we have to provide the resources.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley told the governors he doubted Bush could be an education president ``by proposing a meager 2 percent increase in federal spending on education.'' The governors politely requested that part of any peace dividend flowing from defense spending cuts be devoted to education. Romer of Colorado wanted them to tell the president he should shift ``substantial federal resources'' from defense to education and other needs, but they wouldn't go that far. And when a Republican governor suggested the vague language they did adopt drew a line against Bush, Romer raised a point of order, saying he was being misquoted. ``I didn't in any way say that I think we need to stand against the president,'' he said. But the Democrats are, after all, the opposition party. And consensus isn't likely to survive the election season. Thirty-six states are electing governors this year. Education and taxes will be among the issues in almost every state campaign, and Bush will be involved in some. Ohio Gov. Celeste, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association, said the Bush White House is adept at boosting Republican candidates by helping them raise funds and mobilize party workers. ``This is one very politically smart White House,'' said Celeste. ``...I can understand why George Bush dominates an arena in which we are all sort of bit players.'' He said Democratic campaigners will find effective ways to counter Bush. ``We would underestimate the president at our own peril,'' Celeste said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.NOTE: $adv01
For release Thursday, March 1
DOC.HEAD: Why You Get Those `Pre-Approved' Credit Card Applications
DOC.TEXT: If you already have a half-dozen credit cards and hardly use them, you're probably wondering why more banks are beseeching you to apply for theirs. Many use sales pitches that include waived annual fees, 24-hour card- replacement protection, instant $5,000 cash-advance limits, ``pre-approved'' applications and bonuses that range from free travel to car rental discounts. This aggressive marketing to peddle credit cards may seem even more curious in view of rising default rates for many types of loans, a growing number of debt-troubled banks, a record number of bankruptcies and a slowly emerging backlash against the 1980s era of spending borrowed money. Credit cards, nonetheless, remain one of the most profitable segments of the banking industry. The percentage of late payments remains relatively low and actually has declined compared with some years ago, industry experts say. Moreover, interest charges on many credit cards exceed 18 percent, much higher than most other types of consumer loans, making them even more attractive to an industry struggling to find new ways of making money. ``People who said the credit card market was saturated 3 or 4 or 5 years ago probably had to swallow a good bit of that crow,'' said Bruce Brittain, head of Britain Associates Inc., an Atlanta-based marketing strategy consultant that researches credit card use. Even a few new credit cards _ Discover from Sears and and Optima from American Express _ have muscled into millions of wallets. There also are indications that Japan is headed this way with the JCB (Japan Credit Bureau) card, the most widely accepted plastic in the East. There is no indication that credit card growth is leveling off. Daniel Marx, program associate at Bankcard Holders of America, a Washington-based consumer group, said outstanding debt on all types of credit cards in 1989 totaled $182 billion, vs. $82 billion at the beginning of the decade. Last year, 224 million Americans held the two most common types of bank credit cards, Mastercard and Visa, vs. 120 million in 1980, he said. Banking experts say a catalyst for this explosion is the ease with which banks can obtain screening information about potential customers, drastically lowering their cost of signing up creditworthy users. Banks once went on what amounted to fishing expeditions, mailing applications en masse. When the credit card business was in its infancy, some banks simply sent the cards and hoped users would pay their bills. Now, many banks first go to credit bureaus, which routinely sell them computerized lists of names screened by age group, income and debts. ``Banks can say, `I need the names of all males over 48 years old who make more than $75,000 a year and have $15,000 of available credit,''' Marx said. ``The computer will spit out this information for a price. There's a lot of this that goes on. This is where you get your pre-approved credit card. You fit into a niche that the banks have drawn up.'' This explains, for example, why a New Yorker who has several cards may get a solicitation from a small bank in St. Louis to sign up for its Visa or Mastercharge, or a Californian will get one from an obscure bank in Delaware. What also has happened, many experts say, is that consumers have acquired so many cards they are becoming more selective about which ones they use. This has intensified the competition. ``A bank can't sit back anymore and wait for a customer to use its card,'' said Virginia Stafford, a spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association, a Washington trade group of commercial banks. ``What the issuer has to do is make sure when you open your wallet, you pull out its card, not someone else's.'' Many credit card experts caution that users who are wondering whether to sign up for new cards should carefully read the fine print of their applications, especially regarding interest rates and grace periods, which can vary widely. They also say the ``pre-approved'' enticement, in many cases, simply means your name was culled from a pre-approved list. ``They're still going to check your credit,'' Brittain said. ``If they discover anything about you, you're still going to get bounced.'' Others say the net effect of the marketing assault on credit card users is good, mostly because it reflects competition that is providing more choices. ``We feel that frankly, it's an opportunity for the consumer to shop,'' said Jay Muzychenko, vice president of the National Foundation for Consumer Credit, a credit-counseling organization in Silver Spring, Md. ``Our position is that, bottom line, you don't have to take the cards just because they're offered.''

DOC.HEAD: Crazy Actors for Crazy Stories
DOC.TEXT: When Bertrand Blier develops a screenplay, he writes with specific people in mind. Since the French filmmaker's stories are usually a little crazy, he wants his actors the same way. ``I need an interesting starting point,'' said the director of the certifiably insane ``Too Beautiful for You'' (``Trop Belle Pour Toi''), which won the Jury's Special Prize last summer at Cannes, and ``Get Out Your Handkerchiefs'' (``Preparez Vos Mouchoirs''), winner in 1978 of the Academy Award for best foreign film. ``To have the movie start with something crazy, you need the sort of actors that are crazy enough themselves to make it credible,'' he said. Good actors, the director insists, are a little deranged, like his friend Gerard Depardieu, the star of ``Too Beautiful for You'' and ``Get Out Your Handkerchiefs'' as well as Blier's ``Menage'' and ``Cold Cuts'' (``Buffet Froid''). They met in 1973, when Blier was casting for ``Going Places'' (``Les Valseuses'') and Depardieu was an unknown actor. ``I was a little hesitant to hire him because that was a very important charatcer in the film,'' Blier recalled. ``For six months, every day, Depardieu would come to the office with a different costume on to convince me he could play different characters. One day, he was very funny. The next day he was sad and distraught. It's extraordinary.'' Depardieu got the part and Blier gave him the chance to make good on the promise of his extended audition _ to do anything. In ``Get Out Your Handkerchiefs,'' Depardieu decides his unhappy wife needs a lover and recruits a total stranger for the job _ in the middle of a restaurant. In ``Cold Cuts,'' he plays an unemployed man who accosts a stranger in a subway station and rants about his dreams of murder. In ``Menage,'' he is a thief who again inflicts himself on total strangers and takes over their lives. The films are in the spirit of those screwball comedies of the 1930s, such as ``My Man Godfrey'' and ``The Thin Man.'' Timing is essential, quick enough to make audiences laugh, but not so fast that the story loses believability. And no matter how warped the humor gets, the actors have to play it straight. ``Each film is like a game,'' Blier explained. ``With each new movie you have to set your rules and you have to explain your rules to the public if you want them to be able to play with you.'' He admires American director Billy Wilder, who depended on actors such as Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau to hustle along the story. Blier says Depardieu is ideal for that kind of comedy because he's quicker than other actors. ``The entire movie just goes a lot faster,'' Blier said. ``Even in a love scene, everything goes very fast. The other actors, even the very good ones, they tend to listen to what they're saying, contemplate themselves. He doesn't do that.'' With ``Too Beautiful for You,'' imagine ``She-Devil'' with the husband abandoning Meryl Streep and running off with Roseanne Barr. Depardieu is a respectable upper-class family man who falls in love with his homely secretary (Josiane Balasko) while spurning his beautiful wife (Carole Bouquet). Blier noted that ``Too Beautiful for You'' was harder to shoot than his earlier films because there was less action and more emphasis on affairs of the heart. Deparidieu, reluctantly, had to slow down. ``Depardieu was feeling rather uneasy when they were shooting the movie because he was under the impression that he had nothing to do. He likes to act, he prefers to act. He's always looking at the women and doing nothing. When he wanted to do something, I said, `No, don't move, only look.''' Blier, the son of actor Bernard Blier, was born in 1939 in Paris. Through his father, Blier met French directors Henri-Georges Clouzot and Jacques Becker and soon decided he wanted to make films, too. ``I was 15, 16, and it came to my mind that that was the only profession for me,'' Blier said. ``It's the only profession where you take yourself for God, pretend you're God for a while.'' His first commandment remains ``Thou Shalt Be Insane,'' and no exceptions are allowed. One poor actor was even banished for signs of excessive normal behavior. ``The first scene of `Buffet Froid' was very difficult for me because I shot the scene with another actor, who was not Michel Serrault, and it was a disaster,'' Blier said. ``I called Michel Serrault and he came for two nights to shoot his scene. Only Michel Serrault was crazy enough for the beginning of this film. I can't work with actors who are not like that.''

DOC.HEAD: As 25th Anniversary of March Nears, Selma Faces New Racial Challenges
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five years after the march to Montgomery, Selma's blacks and whites, still separated socially, are nearing political equality _ and are at the barricades of protest again. The goal of the black demonstrators a quarter-century ago was clearcut and fundamental: gaining the right to vote. The March 7, 1965, assault on the protesters by Alabama state troopers and other lawmen _ a clash known in civil rights annals as Bloody Sunday _ generated widespread support for the march and for the passage of the Voting Rights Act, which ensured blacks no longer would be denied voting rights through chicanery or intimidation. Today's protesters use the same '60s-style tactics of marches and sit-ins, but their targets are narrower: political control of Selma's school system and stopping the impending ouster of the city's first black school superintendent. Organizers planned a re-enactment Sunday of the 54-mile march to the Capitol in Montgomery, with participants including the Rev. Jesse Jackson; the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference; and Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., a former leader of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. Lowery heads the Atlanta-based organization founded by the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., who led the second march that reached Montgomery guarded by federal troops two weeks later. Lewis led the hundreds of demonstrators to Selma's Edmund Pettus Bridge on Bloody Sunday, suffering a bloodied head for his efforts. Lewis isn't the only familiar face returning from 1965. City Council President Carl Morgan and Mayor Joe Smitherman held those same posts 25 years ago, when Selma, now about 53 percent black, had no black public officials. Blacks now hold four of the nine City Council seats and three of five Dallas County Commission seats. Smitherman and Morgan are quick to list other milestones of racial progress: A district judge is black, as is an assistant police chief and the president of Wallace Community College. A black also has served as president of the embattled city school board, an 11-member appointive body with five black members. ``A lot of things have changed,'' Morgan said. ``There's no question about that. ... You've got a black state senator and two black state representatives that represent the district Selma is in.'' A new congressional district with a black majority could be carved out of central Alabama after the census is completed, giving the state its first black congressman this century. But Selma's black and white residents still live largely in separate neighborhoods, and tend not to socialize. A white former city councilman, George ``Cap'' Swift, noted, for example, that the city has two Elks Clubs, two American Legion Posts and two First Baptist churches _ one for each race. Morgan sees an ulterior motive in the current controversy engulfing Selma, which involves the white-majority school board's refusal to renew the three-year contract of Superintendent Norward Roussell at the end of this school year. ``If that situation had not come up, something else probably would have to focus on the 25th anniversary of the 1965 Voting Rights Act,'' said Morgan, a colonel in the Alabama National Guard when it was federalized to help protect the marchers. The view of a manufactured controversy to coincide with the anniversary is strongly disputed by Rose Sanders, a leader of the protests, which have included sit-ins at City Hall and at the only public high school. Mrs. Sanders said today's protests are designed to make sure black children aren't segregated through an unfair student placement system. Such a system had been used before Roussell began trying to dismantle it, she said. ``Blacks and whites go in the same school door, but once inside they go to separate and unequal classes,'' said Mrs. Sanders, like her husband, state Sen. Hank Sanders, a Harvard-educated lawyer. Smitherman contends Mrs. Sanders and the protesters are trying to segregate the schools. The 5,800-student system was 70 percent black before the protests began; with more than 250 whites withdrawing in recent weeks, it now is 75 percent black. Feelings against the protesters of 25 years ago remain strong, too, at least in some quarters. Sol Tepper Sr., a member of then-Dallas County Sheriff Jim Clark's posse, which tangled with the demonstrators, voiced a perspective on the Bloody Sunday clash that he says isn't unique. ``The media made criminals out of law-enforcement officials who were only trying to enforce the laws of the land,'' said Tepper, 81, a wealthy landowner. They ``made heroes out of a bunch of vermin, lawbreakers who descended on us like plagues out of Egypt,'' he said. Feelings also run high about the failure of an all-black and a bi-racial committee to work together to prepare for the march re-enactment, scheduled to end Saturday in Montgomery, and the commemoration of the Voting Rights Act's passage. A white banker, Rex Morthland, was co-chairman of the bi-racial committee commemorating the march. His co-chairman was Selma High School Principal F.D. Reese, the black who invited King to lead demonstrations in the city. But the panel disbanded after Morthland said he could not get cooperation from the all-black committee, which has celebrated the voting rights march in past years. Mrs. Sanders, a leader of the all-black group, dismissed the bi-racial committee as a ``tool of the mayor.'' Last week, the white-majority City Council refused to repave Martin Luther King Jr. Street for the 25th anniversary of the march, with the 5-4 vote falling along racial lines. Still, Morthland said, the years have brought improvement. ``They were tense in 1965 and they're tense now, too, but in the intervening period I think a great deal of progress has been made in racial relations in the city,'' he said. That might partly be due to a more assertive attitude on the part of blacks. ``We're a different breed than we were in the '60s,'' Dr. Samuel Lett, an obstetrician with a high profile in recent Selma protests, told blacks attending a mass meeting. ``We took things then that we won't take now.''

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Gain Electoral Office Through Massive Districting Court Case
With BC-Selma-25 Years Later, b0648
DOC.TEXT: A look at the South's political corridors before and after passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act reveals dramatic gains by blacks, but it was only a first step toward black electoral victories. In Alabama, it took a massive but mostly unheralded court case, launched in Mobile in the late 1970s, to restructure scores of local governments that had used at-large election systems to effectively bar blacks from office. The Voting Rights Act eliminated the voter registration roadblocks, candidate qualification rules and other discriminatory practices that kept elected offices tantalizingly out of reach for blacks. But it wasn't until the U.S. Senate extended the act in 1982 that language was included protecting minorities from election laws with discriminatory effects, even if their initial intent was not. Without having to prove intentional discrimination, civil rights lawyers were able to attack the at-large election systems that diluted black voting strength in cities and counties where blacks were the minority of the population. The litigation was based largely on the Mobile case, styled Bolden vs. City of Mobile, which led to a ruling mandating the dismantling of the city's commission form of government, the members of which were elected at-large. It was replaced with a seven-member council elected by districts, including at least three black-majority districts. By 1988, the use of at-large elections had all but disappeared in Alabama, with court action ``the most crucial mechanism for change,'' said historian Peyton McCrary, who studied the Voting Right Act's impact on Alabama and other Southern states. Another historian, Chandler Davidson of Rice University, has called it a ``Second Reconstruction.'' As late as 1979, Alabama's 400 municipalities had only 94 black city council members, according to the Alabama Democratic Conference, the party's black political caucus. But with the advent of the change-of-government litigation, the number had climbed by 1989 to 410 black council members, nearly one-fifth of all council seats, the group said. The state is slightly more than one-fourth black. Only a handful of Alabama's 67 counties still use at-large elections to pick commission members, most in locales with small percentages of blacks. ``Once blacks and whites get on these governing boards and have to work together, over time, they begin to become friends,'' said Jerome Gray, field director for the black caucus. But voters still split along racial lines when they go to the polls, said historian Robert J. Norrell of the University of Alabama. ``People can still win elections by appealing only to one race,'' said Norrell, author of a book on the civil rights movement in Tuskegee. David Ruffin, editor of Focus magazine, the monthly public policy magazine of the Joint Center for Political Studies in Washington, D.C., puts the Voting Rights Act in the context of the 200-year-old civil rights struggle. ``It's the 200-year process of extending the franchise to every American,'' he said. ``This is one more step.'' Ruffin said Sunday's planned re-enactment of the Selma-to-Montgomery march is part of the continuing process of political change. ``The whole reason we were out in the streets in the '60s was to be part of the establishment,'' he said. ``Martin Luther King wanted to join this great American enterprise. He wanted to be a part of the establishment, so that black people could participate.''

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Eating Caterpillars Old Hat for USDA Researchers
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department can get secretive over the darndest things sometimes. Costs of remodeling offices, who's on the appointments calendars, where the secretary goes on vacation, things like that. When it chooses, the deparment can ballyhoo with the the best of 'em. Annual yearbooks, new programs that don't cost much and White House projects that require a rural ``spin'' by appropriate agencies, for example. But there are some goings-on that often are kept under cover for years, sometimes forever. So it wasn't really surprising that the USDA clammed up tighter than a hound's jaws on a ham bone after The Washington Post reported Feb. 20 that President Bush has asked for $6.5 million in fiscal 1991 for the study of voracious caterpillars to kill coca plants in South America. Coca leaves are the raw material from which cocaine is refined, and the Bush administration says they are prime targets in the war on drugs. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said no ``biological war'' was in the works. And Bolivia and Peru said that while they wanted help in getting farmers to switch crops, coca-eating worms are not wanted. It didn't take long for information lids to clang shut at USDA. Nobody was talking about the department's coca-hungry caterpillars and the experiments. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter declined to provide further details but told reporters the experiments ``may send a message to the drug lords'' about U.S. determination on the issue. The department issued a statement attributed to Assistant Secretary Charles E. Hess, who oversees USDA's science and education programs. Hess said the department, ``in full cooperation with other agencies,'' has been involved in projects to eradicate ``plants from which illicit drugs are derived.'' Further, he said, ``These projects have not been publicized due to the obvious need for security of personnel and facilities. Accordingly, the department is not at liberty to comment on the specifics of these programs.'' The USDA has had considerable experience in clandestine operations, such as the decades of involement with the military in biological warfare projects during and after World War II. Such U.S. weapons were banned in 1969. One two-volume report, which was removed from the secret list in the late 1970s, showed that USDA's research in biological warfare was concentrated ``on the anti-personnel aspects'' of war. ``There are also smaller programs in anti-animal and anti-crop BW (biological warfare) as outgrowths of the World War II effort,'' the report said. ``The anti-animal program was closely linked to the anti-personnel program since certain diseases produced effects in humans and animals, and the scientific disciplines involved are identical or very similar.'' According to the old reports, ``The first limited BW retaliatory capability was achieved in 1951 when an anti-crop bomb was developed, tested and placed in production for the Air Force.'' The first anti-animal test was conducted in July 1951 but was discontinued three years later because it was concluded the program ``lacked military worth.'' After sputtering a few times, the anti-crop program by 1969 included three biological agents: stem rust of wheat and rye and rice blast. ``Between 1951 and 1957, wheat stem rust spores and rye stem rust spores were produced from innoculated crops at planting sites located on government installations,'' the report said. ``The harvested spores were shipped to Edgwwood Arsenal, Md., for classification, drying and storage. This operation was terminated in 1959 by the Air Force.'' However, that wasn't the end of the program to develop a wheat rust weapon. Between 1962 and 1969, rust spores were grown again at government sites, with the material shipped to the Rocky Mountain Arsenal for processing and storage. All wheat rust spores were destroyed by February 1973, the report said. Rice blast inventories, including final deliveries to Fort Detrick, Md., were destroyed the previous year. The roots of biological weaponry such as coca-eating caterpillars go back many years, at least to World War I. ``There is incontrovertible evidence, for example, that in 1915 German agents inoculated horses and cattle leaving United States ports for shipment to the Allies with disease-producing bacteria,'' the report said. In World War II, a formal stamp was put onto U.S. efforts in the summer of 1942 when the War Research Service was approved by President Franklin Roosevelt. ``Appropriate liaison was maintained with the Armed Services, the U.S. Public Health Service, the Department of Agriculture, and the Department of Interior,'' the report said.

DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department announced a five-count criminal indictment against Exxon Corp. and its shipping subsidiary over the Exxon Valdez oil spill that fouled Alaska's coast nearly a year ago. ``The indictment returned today represents our best shot at prosecuting this incident,'' Atorney General Dick Thornburgh said. If the giant oil company is convicted on all counts brought by a federal grand jury in Anchorage, it could face criminal fines of as much as $1.6 million, officials said. In addition, the government could seek as much as $700 million more in penalties. In New York, Exxon chairman Lawrence G. Rawl said in a statement, ``We will defend ourselves in court against these charges. We believe there is no statutory basis for the amount of the fines mentioned by the U.S. attorney general.''

Orders to U.S. factories for durable goods plunged 10.5 percent in January, the biggest drop in 32 years of recordkeeping, the government said. While most private analysts maintained the country will avoid a recession, some expressed fears Tuesday that further weakness in manufacturing could lead to more job layoffs, sagging consumer confidence and cutbacks in consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity.

The U.S. trade deficit narrowed to $113.2 billion last year, the smallest since 1984, despite the highest level of foreign oil imports in 10 years, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Tuesday the deficit shrank by 11 percent from an imbalance of $127.2 billion in 1988, reflecting continued growth in American exports, especially manufactured goods and agricultural products.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. lawyers asked a bankruptcy judge to allow three top Drexel executives, rather than a court-appointed examiner, to manage the liquidation of the securities firm. The move came as U.S. Trustee's office appointed a 17-member committee Tuesday to represent creditors in the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings for the parent of Drexel, which collapsed this month in a cash crisis after unrivaled success in the 1980s.

Serious criminal fraud has been found in 60 percent of the savings and loans seized by the government over the past year, more than triple the rate in commercial bank failures, a top S&L bailout official said. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the new bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., said Tuesday that regulators have referred more than 1,200 cases to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution.

The former chairman of Haas Securities Corp., which collapsed in the wake of the October 1987 market crash, was sentenced to five years in prison for manipulating the prices of three over-the-counter stocks. U.S. District Judge Thomas P. Griesa said he imposed the harsh prison term Tuesday on Eugene Laff in part because of the large losses suffered by investors as a result of the scheme.

Eddie Antar, the founder of Crazy Eddie Inc., faces criminal contempt charges after he failed to appear before a federal judge to answer demands he return $52 million to the United States. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan, meanwhile, ordered a civil lawsuit to proceed against Antar while U.S. marshals hunt him down. Antar has repeatedly ignored warnings by Politan to appear in court or be jailed, but Tuesday's action marked the first criminal finding against him. The U.S. Attorney has been seeking a criminal indictment.

The Delaware Supreme Court, in a written decision resulting from last year's Time-Warner-Paramount takeover battle, affirmed the right of a board of directors to determine the future course of a company. The ruling released Tuesday came seven months after the state's highest court upheld a Chancery Court decision allowing Time Inc. to proceed with its $14 billion takeover of Warner Communications Inc. and barring Paramount Communications Inc. and Time stockholders from interfering with the deal.

Placing further limits on tobacco and alcohol advertising could push more sports programming from broadcast television to pay-TV outlets, drive some magazines out of business and eliminate thousands of jobs in the media industry, according to a group of advertisers and media companies. But critics said the report released Tuesday failed to reflect the possibility that other advertisers likely would fill any void left by a decline in tobacco and alcohol products advertising.

Stock prices posted gains Tuesday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials added 14.64 points to close at 2,617.12. The dollar rose to another eight-month high against the Japanese yen, but closed mixed against other currencies. Bond prices rose. Gasoline futures prices led a broad decline in energy futures; silver futures led the precious metals lower; pork bellies were down the daily limit while cattle futures advanced; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Creditors Oppose Plan for Company Control
With PM-Drexel-Joseph
DOC.TEXT: Creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. say they will oppose the company's plan to have its own directors supervise the liquidation of the Wall Street powerhouse that collapsed like a house of cards. Drexel asked a bankruptcy judge Tuesday to allow three of its top executives, rather than a court-appointed examiner, manage the liquidation of the company's securities subsidiary and other units. The move came as U.S. Trustee's office appointed a 17-member committee to represent creditors in the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings for Drexel, which sought bankruptcy protection Feb. 13. after a cash crisis. But creditors said they would oppose the move, maintaining that the executives who ran the company as it deteriorated in the last year _ including Chairman John S.R. Shad _ should not oversee its dismantling. ``I think it's the job of the creditors to have input into this dissolution,'' said Sylvan Schefler, a former Drexel managing director who quit six months ago after 30 years at the firm and who was named to the creditors committee. Schefler and dozens of other ex-Drexel workers are owed payment for stock holdings they were to receive after leaving the firm. More than 300 creditors, Drexel shareholders and lawyers attended the organizational meeting, at which Drexel chief executive Frederick H. Joseph said the company was trying to maximize the value of the assets. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the brokerage unit, and other subsidiaries have liquidated more than 86 percent of their multibillion-dollar securities portfolios and other assets since the parent sought bankruptcy protection. ``We know we tried as hard as we could. We're terribly sorry to be in this position,'' Joseph told the gathering. ``At this time our job is to salvage as much value as possible.'' Drexel chief financial officer Richard Wright said the firm's total assets had been reduced to $6.9 billion from $28.6 billion at the end of 1989, while liabilities had fallen to $6.2 billion from $27.8 billion. Stockholders equity now is $700 million, down from $844 million, he said. Drexel officials said the firm lost $65 million from Jan. 1 until the bankruptcy filing. Creditors said they would demand more information about Drexel's past and present financial activities, especially the liquidation. They also said they would seek to examine why Drexel's subsidiaries were not placed into Chapter 7 liquidation proceedings, where a court would monitor the dissolution. Many people involved in the case believe creditors will seek to force Drexel into Chapter 7, where company management would have a reduced role in the firm's break-up. ``What they've done is take the court out of play,'' said attorney Stuart Hirshfield, who represents a major creditor on the committee. ``They're created an environment in which everything's going to have to be reviewed instead of checked out in advance.'' Drexel attorneys asked U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold Buschman III to give responsibility for selling assets of Drexel's subsidiaries to the company's three-member oversight committee, created last year as part of the firm's federal securities fraud settlement. The subsidiaries are not in Chapter 11 and therefore do not have to report asset sales and other activity to the judge. But Drexel's top unsecured creditors have questioned the rapid disbursement of assets and other payments, including $260 million in cash and stock bonuses paid to employees late last year. Drexel lawyers maintained that having the three-member committee monitor the liquidation was not a conflict because company executives, as stockholders in the parent, also are owed money and want to maximize asset values. The committee would report directly to the judge and allow creditors access to the process. The attorneys said placing an outsider in charge would slow the process and endanger gaining maximum value for the assets. First City Bancorp. has filed a motion asking the judge to appoint an outside examiner to look into the company and its dissolution. A hearing is scheduled for Thursday. The oversight committee consists of Shad, who is a former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission; Roderick Hills, a Washington lawyer and former SEC chairman; and Ralph Saul, chairman of Peers & Co. and a former American Stock Exchange president. All three are Drexel board members. The panel was formed as part of a settlement with the SEC last April in which Drexel overhauled its management and agreed to plead guilty to six felonies and pay $650 million in penalties to settle charges in the government's insider trading investigation. Drexel has fired almost 3,700 of its 5,380 employees. Drexel officials said at the creditors meeting they expected to reduce the staff to about 200 within one month.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Chief Executive: `We Failed'
With PM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said the firm tried to rebound from its guilty plea to securities crimes and a series of financial setbacks, but in the end: ``We failed.'' In his first public comment since Drexel's parent filed for bankruptcy protection, chief executive Frederick H. Joseph told a meeting of creditors Tuesday that the firm's demise began with its December 1988 decision to admit to six felonies and pay $650 million in penalties rather than face racketeering charges. ``We fought for a year,'' he said. ``We lost the battle.'' Joseph blamed a declining investment environment, particularly in the junk-bond field Drexel once commanded, for spurring the financial crisis. He also appeared to blame federal regulators for not forcing commercial banks to extend credit to the firm in its dying days. Drexel's parent filed for Chapter 11 protection on Feb. 13 after it defaulted on $100 million in short-term debt. The investment bank already has fired about 3,700 of 5,400 employees and liquidated most of its securities holdings as it closes down operations. Joseph said the firm needed a bridge loan of $250 million to $300 million to get through ``what appeared to us to be a 60-day difficult period.'' As collateral, Drexel would have put up its highly illiquid $1.1 billion portfolio of junk bonds. After discussions on the night of Feb. 12, Joseph said he believed that Gerald Corrigan, head of the New York Federal Reserve Board, was encouraging commercial banks to provide the loans. But in a 1 a.m. conference call hours later with Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard Breeden and Treasury Department officials, the government closed the window on Drexel, saying it wouldn't bail out the firm or encourage anyone else to do so. ``They saw no daylight here and felt the best thing for the market and for Drexel creditors and shareholders would be to file a Chapter (11) proceeding,'' Joseph said. The decision was approved at a 6 a.m. Drexel board meeting on Feb. 13. Joseph said Drexel had managed to make $50 million in the first half of 1989, largely from its underwriting of a record junk-bond offering to finance the RJR Nabisco takeover. But then it was hit with $160 million in write-offs from sour junk bond financings for Integrated Resources Inc., which also has filed for bankruptcy protection, and Paramount Petroleum Co. Drexel paid $500 million of its $650 million in government penalties last September, when the junk bond market and Drexel's large portfolio of the securities plummeted. Drexel lost $86 million in October alone, when the stock market plunged, including $25 million in arbitrage trading in UAL Corp. In November the firm began experiencing problems meeting its obligations on commercial paper, a form of short-term credit that Drexel's parent relied upon. By January, the parent was taking capital from the brokerage subsidiary to help repay its commercial paper debt. Federal regulators stopped the drain because the brokerage's net capital was approaching minumum requirements, and when bank financing became unavailable, the Drexel party ended. Drexel lost $40 million last year and about $65 million in January and February. Fees from investment banking had dried up. The firm forced employees to take some of their compensation in stock, but that failed to raise enough cash to stem the tide. ``We went throuygh the year, the difficulties piled up on us,'' Joseph said. ``It's clear that the end of the story is we didn't make it. We failed.''

DOC.HEAD: Ford Need to Solve Product Problems Earlier, Petersen Says
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. has trouble bringing new cars to market faster because it doesn't do a good enough job solving problems early in the development process, the company's outgoing chairman says. Donald Petersen, who retires Thursday after nearly 41 years with the nation's No. 2 automaker, said Tuesday that Japanese companies do a better job of solving problems early and, consequently, can bring a new car to market faster. But, he added, there's a danger in that _ a blurring of the distinctions between old and new models. ``We don't do a good enough job up front, early in the game,'' Petersen said. ``We make far too many changes.'' On the other hand, he said, Japanese automakers make a decision on a product and march forward, ruling out late-in-the-cycle changes that could help sell the vehicle but also contribute to delays. That speed creates its own problems, he said. ``The Japanese are changing their rate that isn't necessarily doing them a lot of good,'' Petersen said. ``I don't think I'm abnormal in my inability to identify one car from another.'' One of the companies with an exceptionally quick product cycle time is Honda Motor Co. Ltd. Yet its 1990 Accord, which Honda advertises as an entirely new vehicle, has been criticized for not being distinctive enough in look from earlier models. Although Ford has ties to Mazda Motor Co. and Nissan Motor Co., Petersen said he admired Toyota Motor Corp. more. ``They have a very complex product line,'' he said. ``They are a very big company and sell in very high volume. There are others but they are more limited in their product line.'' Petersen became Ford's president in 1980, a year in which the company lost $1.5 billion. He took over as chairman and chief executive officer on Feb. 1, 1985. That year, the company reported $2.5 billion in profits and Ford was on its way to setting an industry record of $5.3 billion in earnings in 1988. Last year, the company made $3.84 billion. For several of those years, Ford's earnings eclipsed those of General Motors Corp., the nation's biggest automaker, for the first time ever. Petersen's departure comes as the U.S. industry struggles to hold down costs in a sluggish market, and that tries to hold on to market share in the face of growing numbers of cars made by Japanese companies overseas and in the United States. His successor, Vice Chairman Harold ``Red'' Poling, will be faced with the same problems, but only for three years. He will retire in 1993, and his likely successor will be Executive Vice President Allan Gilmour. During the next 18 months, GM Chairman Roger B. Smith and Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca, a former Ford president, also will step aside.

DOC.HEAD: New Rule Will Bar Violators from Exchange Boards
DOC.TEXT: After months of debate and comment, federal regulators have voted to bar people who violate major commodity futures exchange rules from serving on policy- and rule-making panels. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission voted unanimously Tuesday to approve a new regulation prohibiting rule violators from serving on disciplinary committees, arbitration panels or governing boards of exchanges or futures associations. The rule would bar violators for three years or for the length of any sanction imposed against them by an exchange, whichever was longer. It was first proposed by the CFTC staff in September. In other action, the CFTC approved an application by the New York Mercantile Exchange to trade futures contracts in natural gas. The contract is designed to allow gas producers, pipeline companies, distributors and consumers to better determine prices and hedge against price fluctuations. The new disciplinary rule is an outgrowth of congressional hearings into the fraud scandals at the nation's two largest commodity futures exchanges last summer in Chicago. Forty-eight people were indicted on charges linked to allegations of fradulent trading that surfaced in a two-year, undercover federal investigation. A bill passed by the House and awaiting approval in the Senate would require the CFTC, which oversees the futures industry, to implement regulations barring major rule violators from sitting on the disciplinary committees of futures contract markets and futures associations. The new rule will go into effect 30 days after it is published in the Federal Register. Spokesmen for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade said they now have stiffer rules governing their members. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Andrew Yemma said the CFTC ``has already approved the rule change we proposed in mid-1989 that bars anyone from serving on our board of governors or disciplinary committees for a period of five years if they have a major disciplinary history.'' At the Board of Trade, Michael O'Connell said the board of directors adopted a resolution in May ``reaffirming that it is and has been the policy of the BOT that individual members with a history of significant trade practice sanctions will not be permitted to serve on the board of directors or exchange disciplinary committees.'' According to the CFTC rule, people subject to the three-year ban include those who violate major rules of self-regulated organizations, such as futures exchanges, or federal futures regulations. People fined a total of more than $5,000 in a single year for lesser violations also would be barred as well as those convicted of certain felonies, including securities law violations, embezzlement and fraud. The new rule also requires self-regulating organizations to notify the CFTC whenever it takes a disciplinary action that would disqualify an individual from serving on a committee or board. The organizations also will be required to submit an annual list of people removed from committees under the rule.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons to Seek Anti-Greenmail Proposal at Lockheed Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons will ask Lockheed Corp. shareholders to bar the company from paying ``greenmail'' to buy back its own stock, but the defense contractor says he needn't bother. ``We have no intention of paying greenmail to anyone,'' Ron Meder, a spokesman for California-based Lockheed, said Tuesday. ``We have not done so in the past and we don't intend to start now.'' Simmons, a Dallas investor with an 18.9 percent stake in Lockheed, has launched a proxy fight to unseat the company's board of directors. He has said he wants to eliminate Lockheed's shareholders rights plan, also known as a poison-pill defense, that would make it prohibitively expensive for anyone to buy more than 20 percent of the company's common stock. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission through his company NL Industries Inc., Simmons said he plans to introduce a proposal at the shareholders annual meeting March 29 to ``prohibit the expenditure of Lockheed's funds to repurchase its own equity securities at a premium price in transactions in which all holders of such equity securities are not allowed to participate on equal terms.'' Such a proposal, if passed, would prevent Lockheed management from trying to buy him off by offering above-market prices for the stock he holds. That practice is also known as ``greenmail,'' a play on the word blackmail. Simmons has said in the past that he is not a greenmailer because all stockholders _ not just him _ would benefit from his increased stake.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,825,000 net tons during the week ending Feb. 24, 1990, up 0.7 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 81.5 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Tuesday. American steelmakers produced 1,977,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 14,463,000 net tons, 6.4 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses). North East Coast 234,000 tons (236,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 279,000 tons (277,000 tons); Lake Erie 138,000 tons (143,000 tons); Detroit 148,000 tons (150,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 479,000 tons (454,000 tons); Southern 252,000 tons (252,000 tons); Western 97,000 tons (95,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Ad Bans Would Impede Access to Information, Cost Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Pay-television outlets would grab more sports programming from broadcast TV, some magazines would have to close and thousands of media jobs would be lost if tobacco and alcohol advertising were outlawed, a new report by an advertiser and media group says. But critics said the report failed to reflect the chance that other advertisers would fill the void left by the tobacco and alcohol advertisers. The report was released Tuesday by a group of advertisers, media companies and ad agencies called The Leadership Council on Advertising Issues, whose stated goal is to ``preserve and enhance the freedom to advertise.'' ``Our study shows that reduced advertising exacts social and economic penalties from the public,'' said Reginald Brack, the Time Warner Inc. executive who is co-chairman of the group. An author of the report said he hoped the findings would encourage discussion of social and economic costs whenever proposals to limit or tax advertising of tobacco, beer, wine and liquor are debated. Co-author William Lilley III, president of Policy Communications Inc., said policymakers often weigh only the social benefits at stake when discussing ad bans. But critics called the findings unrealistic. ``It's just more scare tactics primarily,'' said George Hacker, director for alcohol programs at The Advocacy Institute, a Washington, D.C.-based group that often has aligned itself with anti-smoking efforts and campaigns to promote reduced use of alcohol. ``It fails to take into account the fact that every day new products with advertising needs come on the market ready to spend tons of money to attract a consumer base. The estimates of lost jobs and decimation of the industry are quite exaggerated,'' he said. Hacker said the television industry recovered fairly quickly from the loss of ad revenue resulting from the 1971 ban on TV tobacco ads. But Lilley said media alternatives have grown since then, and a ban on advertising legal products could markedly affect whether a wide range of television programming would be available without charge to viewers. The report said beer and wine advertising, for instance, account for about 15 percent of the advertising on sports programs carried on the broadcast networks, local TV stations and basic cable networks such as ESPN. But if beer and wine advertising were banned, the report said, the decline in ad revenue would force those outlets to cut spending on sports programs. The report estimated pay cable TV outlets that charge premiums over the basic rates or fees for each program would be the big winners, boosting their sports programming by about 39 percent over current projections and paying for it by charging higher fees. The lack of sports programs would reduce the audience for broadcast TV, and the smaller audiences would mean less ad revenue and fewer resources for broadcasters to bid with for other programs, the report said. Coverage of some sports such as boat racing might be dropped altogether, it said. The losers would be lower-income consumers who could not afford pay-cable and those without access to cable TV who would be deprived of the full range of programs and information currently provided by broadcast TV, the report said. The report said a ban on beer and wine advertising would cost the broadcast television industry 4,232 jobs, or 2.9 percent of its work force, by 1993. A ban on tobacco advertising would put 165 magazines out of business, trimming circulation by about 5 percent and eliminating 4,130 jobs, the report said. Such general interest magazines as TV Guide, McCall's, Redbook and Sports Illustrated _ which the report said each get more than 10 percent of their ad revenue from tobacco ads _ would feel the impact. Magazines with large circulation and low prices generally are least able to respond to losses of ad revenue, the report said, because cover price increases trigger sharp drops in circulation. The report said lower-income readers would be affected the most because they would be the most sensitive to higher magazine prices. A tobacco advertising ban also would cost 7,904 jobs in the newspaper business, or 1.5 percent of the work force, the report said. The report said a ban on hard liquor advertising would force 84 magazines out of business and cut magazine employment by 2,100. Most severely affected would be men's magazines such as Esquire and Playboy, which get about 10 percent of their ad revenue from liquor ads, and minority-oriented magazines such as Ebony and Black Enterprise, which get 6.5 percent of their ad revenue from liquor ads, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: London shares were higher at midday Wednesday, cheered by bullish moves in other major stock markets. London prices also managed to recover immediately after falling at late morning on disappointing British trade figures. At about noon London time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was 7.3 points, or 0.3 percent, higher at 2,262.1. The index was up from a morning low of 2,254.5 reached minutes after the 11:30 a.m. release of the trade figures and below a high of 2,265.6. The government reported that Britain's merchandise trade deficit more than doubled in January to a worse-than-expected 1.98 billion pounds, or $3.3 billion at current exchange rates. It blamed a drop in Britain's oil surplus and an unusually high level of erratic items. Traders said London equities were boosted by Tuesday's rise in New York and a rally earlier Wednesday in Tokyo. Volume came to a light 197.3 million shares by midday, compared with 210.7 million shares at the same time Tuesday. Traders said institutional investors still were sidelined. Investors still were worried about possible hikes in world interest rates, they said.

Three Nordstrom Inc. stockholders have sued the upscale clothing retailer claiming they suffered financial losses because the company failed to disclose its labor problems. The suit filed in U.S. District Court Tuesday contended that management knew, or should have known, that claims filed recently by employees for unpaid work and overtime would adversely affect the price of Nordstrom stock. Nordstrom stock continued to slump Tuesday, closing at $28 in over-the-counter trading, down from a Sept. 1 high of $41.75. The suit asks that it be made a class action to include all 76,000 Nordstrom stockholders. It was filed by Elie de Comminges, Alphonse Kaufman and Jessica Longston and did not ask for specific damages. Named as defendants were Nordstrom co-chairmen Bruce Nordstrom, James Nordstrom and John Nordstrom; John McMillan, president; and John Goesling, chief financial officer. A Nordstrom spokeswoman said the company had not seen the suit late Tuesday and would not comment. The company on Monday reported a fourth-quarter drop in earnings of 34 percent, due in part to a $15 million charge to pay workers back wages. The Washington state Department of Labor and Industries ruled recently that Nordstrom was liable for back pay due workers who were required to work ``off the clock,'' or on their own time. Workers have said they stocked shelves, wrote thank you notes to customers and attended company meetings on their own time. Nordstrom's 60 stores in the six states employ 30,000 people, including 5,000 in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Faces Criminal Charges, Possible Fines in Valdez Oil Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 new graf after 6th graf pvs, ``Nobody willfully... to UPDATE with stock dropping in early trading. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Exxon has...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX10
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon Corp. faces criminal charges and $700 million or more in possible penalties from last year's tanker spill that left hundreds of miles of Alaska shoreline polluted with oil. A federal grand jury in Alaska brought a five-count indictment against the giant oil company and its shipping subsidiary on Tuesday, charging it violated a number of federal laws in connection with the Exxon Valdez oil spill. ``The indictment ... represents our best shot at prosecuting this incident,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in announcing the indictment. The massive spill occurred when the huge tanker veered off course in Prince William Sound and struck a reef on March 24, 1989, spilling 11 million gallons of crude. It was the worst oil catastrophe in U.S. history and caused widespread damage to wildlife and Alaska's ecology. In New York, Exxon chairman Lawrence G. Rawl in a statement called the grounding ``a tragic accident'' for which Exxon and its shipping subsidiary ``have apologized to the American people, especially the people of Alaska.'' ``Nobody willfully grounded the ship or caused the spill,'' said Rawl. Exxon stock tumbled $2 to $46.37{ a share in early trading today on the New York Stock Exchange. The indictment was announced long after the market closed on Tuesday. Exxon has spent more than $2 billion in cleanup efforts, but environmentalists argue that the job is far from completed and the total damages to natural resources may not be known for years. The indictment included two felony and three misdemeanor charges that could lead to a total $1.6 million in criminal fines. In addition, the government said it would seek at least $700 million _ perhaps substantially more _ in penalties under a separate law that allows recovery of twice the amount of proven losses. Thornburgh said the eventual penalties against Exxon could be substantially higher, depending on the amount of losses determined at the time of a court verdict. Rawl's statement said: ``We will defend ourselves in court against these charges. We believe there is no statutory basis for the amount of the fines mentioned by the U.S. attorney general.'' Thornburgh told a news conference the indictment was presented to the grand jury after a proposed plea deal fell through. He said the plea talks fell apart because of the unwillingness of Exxon to meet the government's terms; in addition, state officials objected to part of the proposed agreement. The indictment charged that Exxon employees aboard the tanker acted inappropriately and that the corporation ``willfully and knowingly'' allowed individuals who either lacked the required license or were ``known to be physically or mentally incapable'' to operate the vessel. The charges stemmed from reports that Exxon officials were aware that Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood had a history of drunken driving convictions in New York state, but was allowed to remain in command of the huge tanker. Hazelwood is on trial in a state court in Alaska on charges including reckless endangerment, criminal mischief and operating a vessel while intoxicated. He has denied being drunk at the time of the accident. The plea bargain discussions resulted in sharp exchanges between Alaska state officials and the Justice Department in recent weeks. In a letter to Justice last weekend, Alaska Attorney General Doug Baily accused the department of trying to force the state into signing off on an agreement by threatening to withhold continued federal involvement in joint federal-state efforts to assess damages from the spill. Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper said Tuesday night that Alaska played no role in bringing about the federal charges. ``The bottom line for the people of Alaska is that our fisheries, our shorelines and our other natural resources harmed by this oil spill are returned as much as possible to their original state. We want to recover whatever is necessary to restore Alaska to what it was before the spill.'' The charges against Exxon under the indictment were: _Violation of the Port and Waterways Safety Act, a felony. _Violation of the Dangerous Cargo Act, also a felony. _Violation of the Clean Water Act by illegally discharging pollutants into Prince William Sound, a misdemeanor. _Unlawfully discharging refuse, the oil, also a misdemeanor. _Violating the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, stemming from the deaths of more than 36,000 birds as a result of oil pollution, also a misdemeanor. Each of the felony charges carries a maximum fine of $500,000, while each misdemeanor counts carries a maximum penalty of $200,000, the Justice officials said. Thornburgh said the indictment would not affect the civil lawsuits brought by the state of Alaska and various environmental and other groups against Exxon. He also said the federal government could take separate civil action against the oil company.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Restrains Reuters From Canceling UPI Photo Contract
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has barred Reuters from unilaterally ending its photo exchange agreement with United Press International. Tuesday's temporary restraining order stemmed from a counterclaim by UPI in a lawsuit Reuters brought seeking unspecified damages for money allegedly lost on the agreement. ``This does not come as a surprise,'' said Andrew Nibley, editor of Reuters' North and Latin American operations. ``The judge has merely decided to preserve the status quo until he has had a chance to hear the merits of the case at a hearing.'' ``We did seek such court action and we're encouraged to have gotten it,'' Milt Capps, UPI's senior vice president for corporate affairs, said of the restraining order issued by U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure. Leisure issued the restraining order effective until a hearing March 12 on UPI's request for a preliminary injunction. The two news services entered into an agreement in 1984 that UPI would provide news pictures from the United States to Reuters, while Reuters would provide UPI with pictures from other countries. The agreement was to run for 10 years. On Feb. 16, the day the lawsuit was filed, Reuters said it was canceling the agreement and interrupted the exchange for four hours. UPI's counterclaim was brought Monday. The news service denied Reuters' allegations that UPI's service had declined since the exchange started in 1985. Reuters has said it would establish its own network of photographers in the United States while UPI has been exploring other avenues for pictures from abroad.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose 52.93 points over the past two sessions, was up another 5.85 at 2,622.97 by 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outpaced losers among New York Stock Exchange listed issues by 11 to 8, with 527 up, 383 down and 496 unchanged. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.36 to 182.52. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 21.88 million shares after the first 30 minutes of trading. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index edged 0.19 higher to 351.59. Market watchers said stocks could run into resistence today due to worries about how corporate profits will fare in the face of a prolonged period of sluggish economic growth. The government's latest reading on the economy came out this morning before the market opened and it showed the gross national product grew at a 0.9 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of 1989, faster than previously estimated but still the slowest pace in more than three years. The Commerce Department said its revised estimate of October-December growth means the GNP _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ rose 3 percent for all of 1989. That was the slowest yearly advance since a 2.7 percent gain in 1986 and followed a 4.4 percent increase in 1988. A continuing recovery in Tokyo from Monday's steep plunge soothed lingering anxieties on Wall Street over a possible repeat of October 1987's worldwide slump in stocks, analysts said. Actively trading blue chips in the early going included: International Business Machines, down [ to 103| and McDonalds, up [ at 31}. Exxon, which faces criminal charges and $700 million or more in possible penalties from last year's tanker spill, was off } to 47|. A federal grand jury in Alaska brought a five-count indictment against the giant oil company and its shipping subsidiary on late Tuesday. On Tuesday, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which jumped 38.29 points on Monday, added another 14.64 to close at 2,617.12. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks, with 927 up, 558 down and 496 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 152.59 million shares, up slightly from 148.91 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index ended 0.90 higher at 182.16. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 351.40, up 1.04.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Brokerage House Chairman Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A former brokerage house chairman has been sentenced to five years in prison for a stock manipulation conspiracy discovered after the October 1987 market crash that cost clients more than $5 million. ``A fraudulent scheme was carried out and resulted in great losses to people and firms in the investment community,'' U.S. District Judge Thomas P. Griesa said at Tuesday's sentencing of Eugene Laff. Laff, 52, of Greenwich, Conn., is the former chairman of Haas Securities Corp., which collapsed nine days after the crash. He was convicted in December of five counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. The prosecution maintained that the firm schemed to artificially raise the prices of so-called ``penny stocks,'' inexpensive securities traded over the counter, by creating false demand for the shares, a scheme that couldn't be maintained after the market dropped. Laff asked the judge for probation so he could earn money to pay back the victims of the fraud, many of whom have filed civil lawsuits seeking restitution. ``There is no question that crimes were committed when I was chairman at Haas,'' Laff said. ``If only I had the power to turn back the clock and undo the past, but I cannot.'' Griesa, however, said that he would not depart from federal sentencing guidelines, which mandated a prison term. The judge said he took into consideration the loss to Haas Securities clients of more than $5 million and his finding that Laff falsely testified there was no scheme to manipulate stock prices. Griesa allowed Laff to remain free pending appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Merchandise Trade Deficit More Than Doubles
DOC.TEXT: Britain's merchandise trade deficit more than doubled in January to an unexpected 1.98 billion pounds, or about $3.3 billion at current exchange rates, the government said Wednesday. The government blamed a drop in Britain's oil surplus and an unusually high level of imports of such items as diamonds for the widening gap between imports and exports. The seasonally adjusted deficit compared with a deficit of 917 million pounds in December, the Central Statistical Office said. It said the current account deficit soared to 1.88 billion pounds from 817 million pounds. The January current account deficit was the highest since September 1989, when it totaled 1.9 billion pounds. Excluding the unusual items would reduce the January current account figure by about 500 million pounds, the office said. The current account deficit equals the merchandise trade deficit plus ``invisibles'' trade. Invisibles cover services, overseas investment earnings and official transfer payments, and was estimated to be in surplus by 100 million pound. The January figures compare with market expectations of a merchandise trade deficit of 1.22 billion pounds and a current account deficit of 1.3 billion pounds. Exports totaled 8.6 billion pounds in January, down from 8.7 billion pounds in December. Imports totaled 10.6 billion pounds in January, up from 9.6 billion pounds in December.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Pledges Effort on U.S.-Japan Relations, Political Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with magazine report that Kaifu undereported money he received from Recruit. Edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today that Japan will ``do more'' to ease trade friction with the United States and pledged further efforts to reform Japanese politics. Kaifu presented his new Cabinet to Emperor Akihito after a long wrangle in his conservative party over his insistence on keeping scandal-tainted politicians out of the administration. As he was doing so, a weekly magazine said it would publish an article Thursday charging that Kaifu received larger donations than he has acknowledged from a company at the heart of a 1988 influence-peddling scandal. Kaifu's difficulty in forming a Cabinet came shortly before he was to leave for California, where President Bush is expected to urge Japan to be more conciliatory in sluggish trade talks. ``There is no magic word that will erase the $49 billion trade surplus,'' Kaifu told a nationally televised news conference. Japan will reform import taxes and expand domestic demand, he said, but ``that is not enough, so we will do more. If you look closely at what we're doing in Japan-U.S. relations, you'll see how hard we are working.'' Kaifu revealed no details of new initiatives Japan might offer in his talks Friday and Saturday with Bush in Palm Springs. Officials in both countries spoke of the need to develop their ``global partnership'' despite deep problems between the two biggest economies in the capitalist world. But a question mark hangs over the government's political strength to take domestic and international initiatives, even though the scandal-plagued governing party won a strong majority in the Feb. 18 parliamentary election. ``I think you should see it as a kind of purification,'' Kaifu said of the election victory. ``In any case, the party has been reborn with the people's trust, and our mission is to carry out political reform.'' Formation of the 21-member Cabinet was announced early today as the prime minister prevailed in his insistence on a ``clean'' government _ a requirement that eliminates the top echelon of his Liberal Democratic Party. Kaifu did not speak directly about problems forming the Cabinet, saying he had wanted the best government possible to deal with pressing foreign issues as well as domestic problems such as taxes, welfare and the aging society. He indicated, however, that he also would insist on keeping scandal-tainted politicians out of sub-Cabinet level offices such as vice minister posts. In its March 8 issue, which goes on sale Thursday, Shukan Bunshun magazine said Kaifu received a total of 26.3 million yen ($177,100) in donations from Recruit Co. between 1983 and 1987. When he took office in August, Kaifu said he received only 14.4 million yen ($96,970), all in legal donations. In a news conference today, Kaifu denied he received more. ``I have checked thoroughly and reported everything,'' he said. ``It is hard to prove the fact that I did not receive (additional donations) when I did not receive them.'' Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, a holdover from the Cabinet Kaifu formed last summer after two prime ministers resigned in quick succession amid money and sex scandals, indicated he would accompany Kaifu to the summit with Bush. Trade will be the key issue in the U.S. talks, he said, and he also expected to discuss ``global issues, such as the environment, population and drugs, as well as technology transfers.'' Bush sent his invitation to Kaifu last weekend after U.S. and Japanese negotiators expressed frustration at lack of progress in trade talks. U.S. officials said they had hoped for more political direction from the Japanese side, since the Japanese elections were over. Kaifu, 59, comes from a small faction in the Liberal Democratic Party but exerted political muscle against more powerful faction leaders in keeping out scandal-tainted figures. The struggle showed, however, that the prime minister may have difficulty keeping support of the contenders for power. Referring indirectly to the factional struggles, Kaifu said Japan has to clean up money politics and move toward more policy-oriented elections. ``This harks back to the faction question _ little by little, we should get rid of them,'' he said. The liberal-leaning newspaper Asahi Shimbun denounced as a ``disgrace'' the attempt by former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe to nominate Koko Sato to the Cabinet. Sato was convicted on a criminal charge in a 1970s Lockheed scandal. Kaifu also rebuffed an attempt by former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe to name a politician tainted by the Recruit scandal, in which many profited from sales of pre-listed shares in a Recruit subsidiary in return for political favors.
