DOC.HEAD: Marathon Talks Continue on Auto Emissions, Acid Rain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 4th graf, Mitchell said, with new Mitchell comment
DOC.TEXT: Senate and White House negotiators are pressing towards agreement by Thursday's deadline on key parts of a compromise clean air package including curbs on automobile emissions and acid rain pollution. But Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who had vowed earlier in the week to bring the legislation up for floor action no later than Thursday, backed away from that goal slightly after a second straight day of marathon talks that lasted past midnight. ``It's obviously getting more difficult, but we're still hoping,'' Mitchell said of the deadline he imposed for floor action. Mitchell said this morning that he expected to conclude the private discussions with the administration by the end of the day, but he could not say if an agreement would emerge. Senate leaders and the Bush administration representatives have been working for three weeks to craft a compromise bill that will gain White House backing and blunt regional opposition from some lawmakers. The discussions Tuesday centered on the automobile emission control section of the bill, which is aimed at dramatically reducing urban smog by the end of the decade. The White House earlier in the week abandoned its staunch opposition to a second round of auto tailpipe emission controls, but details of how such controls might go into effect have thwarted agreement among the negotiators, participants said. ``In all negotiations that last inch is darkness. And we are in the last inch, literally,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., the clean air bill's floor leader. Key differences also remained on acid rain controls, but that largely involves disagreement over whether to accommodate a group of Midwest senators who want help in paying for costly emission controls at the dirtiest coal-fired electric plants. The Bush administration and Senate leaders who support the Senate clean air legislation have opposed cost-sharing assistance to the Midwest. Sources close to the discussions said the remaining differences on acid rain, including the cost-sharing question, were not large enough to threaten compromise on an overall agreement. The closed-door iscussions are aimed at fashioning a legislative package that will have the support of the Bush administration and enough senators to avoid a lengthy floor fight and potential filibuster. Lobbyists from the auto industry and those representing various environmental groups were staked out near the meeting room Tuesday night, awaiting word of an agreement. Some environmentalists have sharply criticized the closed-door talks, maintaining that the tactic was significantly weakening a strong Senate ill approved by the Environment and Public Works Committee last November. ``It's disintegrating before our eyes,'' said Richard Ayres, executive director of the Clean Air Coalition and a member of the Natural Resources Defense Council.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Higher In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices opened lower, then turned mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting strength in the soybean oil market. The early gains in soybean oil extend a pattern of higher oil prices and lower soybean meal prices stemming from generally slack demand for soybean meal in Europe. The contract for March delivery of soybean oil was up .47 cent at 21.13 cents a pound in early trading. Tuesday's National Weather Service 90-day outlook was considered generally negative for the grain markets, with a forecast for above-normal precipitation from March through May in the mid-Mississippi River Valley and the western Great Lakes region. The Agriculture Department announced approval today of China's bid for 160,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices, a positive development for wheat prices. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to { cent higher with March at $3.94 a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to } cent higher with March at $2.45\ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2\ cents higher with March at $1.37 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3 cents higher with March at $5.62{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures were lower. Live cattle futures were .02 cent lower to .08 cent higher with April at 75.40 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent to .15 cent higher with March at 80.20 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent to .17 cent lower with April at 49.80 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent to .57 cent lower with March at 50.70 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mostly higher Tuesday while pork futures declined, led by losses of up to 2 cents, the permitted daily limit, in the pork belly market.

DOC.HEAD: USX Plans to Ask U.S. Supreme Court To Review Discrimination Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last two grafs to CORRECT spelling of Freemann. Mansmann and Rosenn are cq in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. plans to ask the U.S. Supreme Court to review an appeals court's ruling that the company discriminated against 8,000 black job applicants at a steel mill, a spokesman said today. The appeals court last week upheld a 1983 U.S. District Court decision for the second time. The Supreme Court last year ordered the appeals court to restudy the case under more stringent standards for proving bias that the high court imposed on June 5. USX spokesman Ernie Glenn said the company would seek a review of the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruling on the ground that the appeals court misapplied the Supreme Court's new interpretation of civil rights law. The June 5 decision said minorities could not rely solely on statistics to prove discrimination but must link the data to a specific corporate employment policy. The decision also let companies justify practices that statistically appear discriminatory by showing they followed a reasonable employment policy. The appeals court ruled Friday that even under the more restrictive guidelines, the black job applicants in the class-action lawsuit had proved discrimination. The court found that because the positions at the Fairless Hills, Pa., steel mill were for unskilled workers, ``any able-bodied person should be competent to perform the job.'' But the company's job interviews had a ``significantly disparate impact on blacks, as the percentage of successful black interviewees was significantly less than the overall percentage of successful interviewees,'' Chief Judge A. Leon Higginbotham Jr. wrote in the appeals court decision. Other judges taking part in the decision were Carol Los Mansmann and Max Rosenn. Attorney Richard Z. Freemann Jr., who represented the job applicants, estimated the ruling could cost the steel manufacturer nearly $30 million. ``I'm not surprised to learn that,'' Freemann said of the USX decision to seek review. ``I'm disappointed that the distribution of funds will have to wait awhile. But I'm confident that we'll prevail.''

DOC.HEAD: Good Risks and Bad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation
DOC.TEXT: You can't pay much attention to the financial news these days without seeing vivid images of the dangers of taking risks. Many ``junk'' bonds, apparently, are turning out to be true to their name. The bank and savings and loan industries are littered with the casualties of ill-considered ventures. Supposedly sacrosanct real estate markets in places like the Northeast have turned poisonous. Even the sky-high Japanese stock market seems not to be immune. Those who have suffered from these reversals aren't attracting much sympathy. The feeling among their fellows seems to be, ``that's what comes of taking chances.'' Perhaps so. But in the current climate of upheaval, some students of the subject say, the idea of risk-taking itself may be getting a bad rap. They argue that just about all business ventures, like many other things in life, are based on running risks. In this view, risk is pretty much a constant, part of the natural order, and even when it cannot be prevented or reduced it can be managed to minimize its harmful effects. When mischief occurs, it most often happens because people underestimated or just plain ignored the risks they were taking. As John T. Reed, a specialist in real estate investing, put it: ``Gamblers take risks for the thrill of it. Investors take CALCULATED risks because their calculations show they will be better off financially if they do.'' The difference, Reed says in his newsletter Real Estate Investor's Monthly, can be illustrated through the simple device of a flip of a coin. A gambler probablya would take an even-money bet that a given coin flip would turn up heads. Devotees of lotteries and other long-shot propositions might even stake small amounts on the chance that the coin would land on its edge. But wise investors would look for some edge in their favor before they put their money up. On a 50-50 proposition like a coin flip, for example, they might demand a payoff of $11 for each $10 chance they took. In addition to knowing their statistical chances of success, investors like to know as precisely as possible the expected value of winning and the penalty paid for losing. On top of that, they inquire into the worst possible outcomes that could befall them, in order to gauge their exposure even to freakish damage. For people who don't patronize casinos, what use is all this? Well, it turns out there is much more to risk-management in the world than eschewing gambling. Customers of insurance companies, for example, merely buy the right to transfer a risk they face to an institution that is willing to assume it for a price that is usually profitable. Likewise, investing of all kinds involves at least an estimate of risk. The ``aggressive'' individual may opt for some vehicle with a speculative reputation; the ``conservative'' investor sticks with supposed safety. But when the information used to make the calculation is suspect or not fully understood, Reed observes, ``to discuss the issue in terms of optimism vs. conservatism is to descend to mere name-calling. ``The question is not who is optimistic or who is conservative. The question is, who is right? ``Either you have the data to calculate your risks or you don't. Inadequate data combined with optimism is still inadequate data. Indeed, that combination is more dangerous than inadequate data alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Market Upheavals May End Cheap Capital, But Growth Seen Continuing
DOC.TEXT: Recent upheavals in Japan's capital markets may put a financial squeeze on Japanese industry and slow economic growth, analysts say, but few believe a recession will result. ``Economic conditions are still strong,'' said Hiroshi Kadota of the Japan Federation of Economic Organizations' Financial Affairs Bureau. ``Investment is expanding. The capital markets are returning to a normal trend.'' Japanese industry for years has been able to raise capital for growth at relatively little cost, but its fabled markets have shown signs of sputtering lately. The Tokyo Stock Exchange, where Sony Corp., for example, raised $2.7 billion earlier this month to help finance its overseas investments, has gyrated wildly this year. After reaching record highs at the close of 1989, the exchange's key index declined by some 14 percent before rebounding Tuesday and Wednesday. Interest rates have been rising since last summer, when the Bank of Japan began battling inflation by raising its discount rate _ the interest it charges for loans to commercial banks _ to 4.25 percent from 2.5 percent. Anticipation of a further increase has send bond prices plummeting in tandem with stock prices, increasing corporate borrowing costs. Many analysts regard these developments as corrections in an overheated capital market, rather than a vote of no confidence in the underlying economy. Adrian Tschoegl, an economist with SBCI Securities Asia, said, ``The fall in the Tokyo market is a bit like the New York crash of '87. Everyone cried `recession' then, but nothing much happened. The Tokyo market is coming down from an overheated level. The effect is going to be very slight.'' Nevertheless, with interest rates up and the stock market down, some Japanese companies apparently are shelving plans to raise equity capital in the near future and are turning to their own reserves to fuel growth. ``Several issues we're involved in have been pulled back,'' Tschoegl said. As much as $6.8 billion worth of convertible bonds, warrants and shares were scheduled to come on to the market by the end of March, several brokers said. Many of these issues will be deferred, they said. ``Equity financing is one of the most important vehicles to raise funds for Japanese corporations. Obviously, they do not want to go ahead now if they believe they're going to hurt their long-term financing,'' said Yutaka Nakai, an analyst with Daiwa Securities Co. ``They can be flexible about when to raise funds.'' Large Japanese corporations are able to weather rough sailing in the capital markets, said Kadota, ``because they have vast reserves of liquidity.'' He said a poll of business leaders conducted this month by his organization found confidence in continued growth was high. Toshiaki Kakimoto, chief economist at Sumitomo Bank, predicted Japan's gross national product growth would decline moderately to 4.5 percent in the fiscal year ending March 31 and to 4.3 percent in fiscal 1990 from 5.3 percent in fiscal 1988. If the financial environment worsens, large companies may have to liquidate some of their fixed assets, mainly real estate, says Yoshiaki Takanashi, head of economic research at Yasuda Trust Bank. ``Real estate will suffer to some extent. Investment overseas may be reviewed,'' he said. At that point, he said, ``if the market deteriorates further, then a crisis could occur.'' But under present conditions, he said, only small and medium-size companies that rely on bank financing to survive face any real hardship.

DOC.HEAD: 27,000 Gallons of Heating Oil Spills Into N.J. Waterway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf to UPDATE with Exxon statement saying it was not responsible. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Lt. Jeff...'. SUBS 7th graf, `The Coast...', with 2 grafs to add detail. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Fulton said...'.
DOC.TEXT: About 27,000 gallons of heating oil poured into a busy waterway near an Exxon Corp. terminal this morning as it was being loaded onto a barge with a hole in it, the Coast Guard said. The No. 6 heating oil leaked into the Kill Van Kull, a major route for barge and tanker traffic that separates Bayonne from New York's Staten Island, the Coast Guard said. The spill was discovered at about 4:20 a.m. and had begun about an hour earlier, authorities said. Exxon, indicted just this week on charges stemming from last year's Alaska tanker spill, issued a statement saying the company was helping out with the cleanup but was not responsible for today's spill. Lt. Jeff Crawley, a Coast Guard spokesman, said the oil poured through a 12-inch-by-6-inch hole, and forced the closing of the busy waterway. Crawley said he didn't know what caused the hole in the barge. ``The barge has numerous tanks, six or seven, and the oil is pumped from the facility to the barge,'' said Crawley. The barge owner, Ekolof Marine of Staten Island, N.Y., initially estimated the leak at 420 gallons, said Rick Fulton, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection. The Coast Guard revised the figure, initially to 24,000 gallons and later to 27,000 gallons, after studying the site, he said. Two environmental cleanup companies hired by Ekolof were at the scene this morning, laying containment booms, Fulton said. The spill spans the 3{-mile length of the Kill Van Kull, and sheens were spotted as far away as Liberty Island, about five miles northeast of the spill site. Exxon issued a statement saying the Eklof barge was loading heating oil at Exxon's Bayonne terminal, but the oil company was not involved in the spill. Exxon said Eklof had purchased the oil and was loading it for an international customer. ``Eklof has acknowledged responsibility for the spill and the cleanup effort,'' said Exxon spokesman Jack Hollern. ``Exxon has offered its full cooperation to the Coast Guard and the barge owner in assistance with the spill response.'' A person answering the phone at Eklof's offices said the company had no immediate comment. Fulton said it was too early to gauge how much damage wildlife may have suffered, adding that the area where it occured is ``one heck of a developed strip.'' The spill is located within miles of the confluence of the Kull and Arthur Kill, the scene of the Jan. 1-2 spill that leaked 567,000 gallons of heating oil from a pipe that connects Exxon Co. USA's terminal here with the Bayway refinery. Exxon is under investigation by the state Department of Environmental Protection and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for the January spill. DEP and EPA officials said they had no comment immediately on today's spill. Exxon faces lawsuits from the DEP, Elizabeth and New York for the January spill. Today's spill comes one day after a federal grand jury in Alaska brought a five-count indictment against Exxon and its shipping subsidiary on charges they violated federal laws in connection with the Exxon Valdez oil spill off Alaska last March. Exxon faces $700 million or more in possible penalties the spill of nearly 11 million gallons of crude in Prince William Sound that left hundreds of miles of Alaska shoreline polluted with oil.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas City Star to Merge With Morning Partner, Kansas City Times
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 11th graf, `By 1892...', to recast and add background; and Subs the last 3 grafs with 7 to add background on Times, interaction of two papers. Morss is cq in 7th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The name of The Kansas City Star will live on when the storied, 110-year-old afternoon paper where young Ernest Hemingway worked as a reporter merges Thursday with its morning partner, The Kansas City Times. Many other things will go _ the Star's afternoon publishing time, its layout and typeface. Some call it the end of an era. But Editor Joe McGuff sees just another stage in the newspaper's colorful history, which began in 1880 in a rough but booming river town and includes years when political boss Tom Pendergast ruled the city's voting booths and the paper's president Roy Roberts helped persuade Dwight Eisenhower he'd be a good president. The Star's course has included Pulitzers, corporate buyouts and growing competition with TV. The Star and Times have won seven Pulitzers, including a joint award for their investigation into the 1981 Hyatt Regency skywalk collapse that killed 114 people. Like hundreds of afternoon papers, the Star has faced declining readership. Its circulation dropped by 100,000 in the '80s and stood at 165,000 in September. The Times' circulation is 270,000; the Star's Sunday readership is 416,000. ``It's inevitable, and that takes away some of the sting,'' said George R. Burg, who started on the desk in 1948, moved up to managing editor and now directs philanthropic activities as assistant to the publisher. ``People just don't read afternoon papers anymore.'' William Rockhill Nelson and Samuel E. Morss started the Kansas City Evening Star on Sept. 18, 1880, a debut with a circulation of 3,000. The four-page paper cost 2 cents. Nelson bought out his partner the next year. By 1892, circulation was 50,000. In 1901, Nelson purchased the 33-year-old Times, which even at the turn of the century was still a diehard sympathizer of the Confederate cause. The words ``The Morning Kansas City Star'' appeared as a subhead on its masthead until 1977. Hemingway joined the Star in 1917, covering the train station, a hospital and police precinct before leaving seven months later to join an ambulance unit in Italy. When Nelson died in 1915, his will stipulated the paper should go to his wife and daughter and then be sold after their deaths. Employees led by Nelson's son-in-law, Irwin Kirkwood, submitted the winning bid in 1926 and established the employee ownership that would stand for five decades. The newspaper earned a reputation as a crusader when it turned against Pendergast in the mid-1930s, and the political boss fell from power all the way to a prison cell for tax evasion. In the mid-20th century, the newspaper's president was Roberts, who sat at his desk in the newsroom talking to the Republican rich and powerful on the phone. He persuaded one friend, Eisenhower, to run for president. In 1977, Capital Cities Communications, based in New York, bought the paper for $125 million, making millionaires of a few stockholders. ``They made a lot of changes that resulted in firings and forced retirements,'' said Joe Henderson, the paper's longtime federal court reporter, who is retiring. ``It was a bitter time. But those who survived are certainly a lot better off, in salary and fringe benefits, I think, than under the old Star.'' The merger won't result in any layoffs for the 300 newsroom employees. The Times remained in the Star's shadow for years. Times reporters, for example, identified themselves as Star reporters when doing interviews. ``Otherwise, no one would have known who they were,'' said Burg. But as the Star's circulation dropped over the years, the Times got more important. Its circulation bypassed the Star's in 1965. After the 1977 sale, editors placed the two news staffs in direct competition for the first time in an effort to improve reporting. Advertising and production staffs worked for both papers. Despite the attempt at direct competition, the Star in the last decade became known for its features, while the Times concentrated on national, international and regional news. Now employees and readers await Thursday morning's newspapers _ and morning newspapers thereafter. ``One lady told me she'll have to read half the paper in the morning,'' Burg said, ``and save the other half for afternoon.''

DOC.HEAD: Bank Fraud Trial Starts For Tennessee Congressman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 2nd graf to UPDATE with defense opening statement. SUBS 8-9th grafs pvs, bgng `The $350,000...', with 4 grafs to add detail. PIcks up 10th graf pvs, `After SIBC...'.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of dollars in bank loans to Rep. Harold Ford were nothing more than ``a shell game'' to hide political payoffs, a prosecutor said today at the opening of Ford's bank fraud trial. But Ford's attorney said the loans from Butcher brother banks were legitimate loans that Ford fully intended to repay, and he has repaid. Assistant U.S. Attorney Gary Humble said the bogus loans, eventually totaling some $1.5 million, were to pay Ford for political and personal influence on behalf of former Tennessee bankers Jake Butcher and C.H. Butcher Jr. ``The Butchers wanted him to use that power for their own interests ... so they lent him money,'' Humble said in his opening argument. ``There was no way Harold Ford could repay this money. He knew it. The Butchers knew it. ``The only thing he could give was his political influence and he did.'' He said that what appeared to be loans were actually payoffs. ``It was not intended that Harold Ford pay this money back,'' Humble said, Humble said Ford began receiving money from the Butcher brothers in 1972 when he was a state representative with little money or personal property. As Ford's political power grew, the Butcher payoffs also increased in size and in the 1980s he received one loan for $350,000, the prosecutor said. Defense attorney William McDaniels responded to the government's charges by proclaiming his client's innocence, calling the case ``an attack on Harold Ford personally. It is an attack on his political life.'' ``They were not phony loans,'' McDaniels said. ``They were intended to be repaid.'' The $350,000 loan, at issue in 11 of the 19 criminal counts against Ford, was issued by C.H. Butcher's now-defunct Southern Industrial Banking Corp. to a company called Tenn-Ford Inc. The government contends Tenn-Ford was a sham company, but Ford says the loan went through Tenn-Ford to the family funeral home, N.J. Ford & Son's Funeral Parlor. In his opening statement, McDaniels said Ford was not responsible for the loan. After SIBC went bust in 1983, Ford acted as majority stockholder in the funeral home while dealing with a bankruptcy trustee to settle the SIBC loan for $25,000. Ford is charged with conspiracy, bank fraud and mail fraud. He is on trial with three co-defendants, former Butcher accountant David Crabtree and lawyers Douglas Beaty and Karl Schledwitz. The four were indicted in Knoxville in April 1987, and the trial was moved to Memphis at Ford's request. Ford, the only black member of Tennessee's congressional delegation, contends he was indicted in Knoxville because East Tennessee is heavily Republican and primarily white. Ford's congressional district, which includes most of Memphis, is two-thirds black. He was first elected to Congress in 1974. The jury has eight black members and four whites. One of the jury's two alternates is white, the other black.

DOC.HEAD: Doskocil Defaults On $133 Million Loan
DOC.TEXT: Doskocil Cos., which took over Wilson Foods Corp. in 1988, defaulted on a $133 million loan and is negotiating with its lenders for additional working capital, spokesmen said Wednesday. Company Chairman Larry Doskocil said the current financial situation results from many factors, including delays in the sale of a Wilson division and a high level of interest expense. ``Operating profits have been lower than expected in recent quarters,'' Doskocil said, but added, ``Despite the current difficulties, the company believes its operations are fundamentally sound.'' Doskocil, a leading supplier of pre-cooked pizza toppings and other specialty meats, acquired the much larger Wilson Foods, an Oklahoma based meatpacker, in a deal valued at about $133 million. Part of the default involves $1.7 million in loan payments required because of reductions in Doskocil inventory and accounts receivable that helped secure the debt, the company said. Also unpaid is a $165,000 payment due Feb. 15 on another loan backed by company stock. Spokesmen said Doskocil is negotiating with its raw material suppliers the terms under which purchases can be made. The company is exploring options including debt restructuring, the spokesmen said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Delays Naming New Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp., which was expected to name a new chairman Wednesday, delayed an announcement but said it should be made by the end of the week. Sources close to the bank have said the new chairman would be Lawrence K. Fish, a former Bank of Boston Corp. executive. Fish's appointment was expected to be announced Wednesday, but Tom Lavelle, a Bank of New England spokesman, said ``an announcement should be made by the end of the week.'' Lavelle said there were no problems and added that previous news reports were premature. The naming of a new chairman has been widely anticipated since the bank dismissed several top executives this year, including former chairman Walter Connolly. Bank of New England shook up its senior level management after reporting its 1989 losses would surpass $1 billion, largely due to problem real estate loans. The bank also was expected to announce details of a consent order from the federal government that would outline steps to restore the company to financial health.

The stock market remained broadly higher in late trading today and blue chips managed to extend this week's winning streak. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 11.71 to 2,628.83 with five minutes left to go in the session.

DOC.HEAD: Comptroller Denies Attempt To Halt New England Real Estate Lending
DOC.TEXT: The chief regulator of national banks denied Wednesday that his agency is trying to bring real estate lending to a halt in New England. ``That's simply not true,'' Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke told the National Council of Savings Institutions. ``We have sounded warnings. But the warnings are warnings to take care, not to abandon the business entirely,'' he said. Clarke's office, which supervises 4,600 nationally chartered banks, has urged banks to exercise more caution in real estate lending, provoking complaints from some in New England who have accused regulators of discouraging loans to reliable borrowers. However, Clarke said not every real estate loan in New England is a bad bet. ``If the specific ... loan is justified, do it,'' he said. ``There is nothing inherently wrong with real estate or construction lending. There is nothing inherently wrong with dynamite, either. The problem comes in how you handle them. ... If you handle them negligently or with reckless disregard, they can, and will, blow you away,'' he said. Many of the real estate loan problems in New England and elsewhere ``are the result of poor management practices: specific people acting at specific institutions,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Year Later, Eastern is Taking On a New Character
LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: A year ago, the Eastern Airlines terminal at sprawling Atlanta airport resembled a ghost town, shut down by angry pickets in what has become one of the longest strikes in commercial aviation history. Today the strikers have dwindled to bitter holdouts of the Machinists union and the terminal pulsates with passengers, digested and disgorged by Eastern jetliners. But beyond the unmarked doors, down corridors to offices and employee lounges, a revolution is under way: Eastern is transforming with youthful blood. About the only things unchanged are the name and the blue-silver logo. Once heavily dependent on Florida tourism and Latin travel, Eastern is redirecting its reach toward business passengers. The airline's headquarters may be in Miami, but the most important operation is now in Atlanta's Hartsfield International, one of the world's busiest airports. Many employees are cherub-faced new hires. Some flight attendants look barely out of their teens and a number of pilots are in their 30s. They work for less money than their pre-strike counterparts and harbor none of the labor bitterness that helped drag Eastern down for years. To passengers, the ``new Eastern'' not only looks rejuvenated but it's almost evangelical. New employees bubble with conviction that they're on the ground floor of something big. Strike-scarred veterans say there's less bureaucratic bickering within the airline now. Many say they're pulling together like a team, helped partly by company-paid counseling aimed at overcoming the bitterness caused by the strike. Nonetheless, it remains unclear whether the ``New Eastern,'' which lost $852.3 million last year, can survive. The unions have been humbled but the airline has reasserted itself just as the economy seems to be weakening, leaving even the strongest airlines vulnerable. ``We face a much more sinister challenge now,'' said James Ashlock, an Eastern spokesman in Atlanta who is an unofficial historian of the airline. ``We've got to make it.'' Like an aging jet, Eastern has been stripped and overhauled by owner Frank Lorenzo with the sanction of a federal bankruptcy judge. The airline filed for protection from creditors soon after the strike began and has since sold $859.8 million in assets. The workforce has been cut to about 20,000, vs. 28,000 before the walkout. To Eastern's management however, the airline hasn't been gutted as union leaders claim, but rejiggered, reshaped and rebuilt. ``Nobody's ever built an airline like this, this fast,'' said Eastern vice president Harold Holt, highest-ranking manager in Atlanta. He said expanding the Atlanta operation during the strike was one of the more stressful tasks of his 40 years with the company. ``You either remain calm or go nuts,'' he said. ``It's been probably the worst period in my career and also the best.'' For Holt, a soft-spoken Atlanta native, that period began March 4, 1989, when Eastern pilots and flight attendants walked out in solidarity with the Machinists and grounded all flights. Holt and his colleagues scrambled to train replacement workers to gradually rebuild the flight schedule, which went from 295 a day to zero overnight in Atlanta alone and created havoc. In the early days of the strike the managers hauled bags and cleaned planes, while management pilots took over the cockpits. As the strike progressed, the Atlanta schedule was increased to 80 flights a day in July, 160 in August and 262 in September. Eastern now has about 270 daily departures from Atlanta, and its target is 315 by mid- to late 1990. Nearly a third of Eastern's workforce is based in Atlanta _ including about 1,000 pilots, 1,400 flight attendants, 750 mechanics and maintenance workers, 1,000 baggage handlers and 1,000 ticket agents, cleaners and other workers. ``Atlanta's going to be between 40 and 50 percent of Eastern Airlines,'' Holt said. Systemwide, the ``new Eastern'' operates about 800 flights a day to 86 cities. That will be cut sharply if the federal government approves Eastern's agreement to sell its Latin American routes and other assets to American Airlines for $471 million. The sale of those routes is a required condition for final approval of a new reorganization agreement between Eastern and its major creditors. Lorenzo recently pulled Eastern's healthier sister carrier Continental Airlines into the bankruptcy fray in order to gain acceptance from the big creditors for its reorganization plan. Continental, like Eastern a subsidiary of Lorenzo's Texas Air Corp., would be required to make some payments to Eastern's creditors under the new plan. If the sale to American proceeds, the importance to Eastern of Miami _ its Latin American hub _ will diminish still further. Atlanta, the business center of the South, will become Eastern's key market. It is in this city that uppity Eastern is going nose-to-nose against staid Delta Air Lines _ the nation's fourth-largest carrier and a dominant economic force in Atlanta, its home base. Eastern employees jokingly call an outdoor area of Hartsfield separating the two airlines' facilities the ``demilitarized zone.'' They refer to Delta as ``the big bear across the terminal.'' As Miami's role in Eastern's game plan shrinks, there is even speculation that Eastern could sell its maintenance base there and move more operations to Atlanta. This city's civic and business leaders have been pressing Eastern to transfer everything here, Holt said. Regardless of where Eastern concentrates its business, there is little doubt that the rancorous worker-management relationship of the pre-strike years has eased. At a recent daily briefing for about 30 Eastern pilots in Atlanta, half the group was new and half were veterans of the strike who had spent months walking picket lines. ``Let's face it, there's been a lot of divisions, there's been a lot of trauma with these people,'' said Todd Jennings, Eastern's director of flight operations in Atlanta. But he said the veterans wanted to put the past behind them. ``The name Eastern's the same, but everything else is different.''

DOC.HEAD: Flying Down to Atlanta on the `New Eastern'
With BC-Eastern
DOC.TEXT: ABOARD EASTERN FLIGHT 103 (AP) _ It's breakfast time on a weekday morning New York-to Atlanta flight, and the youthful cabin crew is serving up some corporate boosterism along with the rewarmed scrambled eggs. ``Eastern's name is built on their reputation,'' said a 21-year-old flight attendant who identified herself as Melody. She said that reputation drew her to take her first job as a flight attendant three months ago after working in the restaurant business. Flight 103 out of New York's LaGuardia Airport is nearly full, the passengers a mix of business travelers and leisure fliers. But even the new enthusiasm doesn't help the Boeing 727 buck the lineup of planes waiting to take off: the 9:05 departure isn't airborne until 9:35. Melody's colleagues on the flight, Carlos Cardenas and Cody Fulmer, also are young, enthusiastic and relatively new to Eastern. They are the flip side of the bitter strike against Eastern, which began a year ago and threw thousands of pilots, flight attendants and Machinists out of work. For the newcomers, the dispute that pitted the unions against Eastern owner Frank Lorenzo was an opportunity. ``I wanted to become a flight attendant so bad,'' said Cardenas, 23, who before the strike had worked for Eastern in Bogota, Colombia, as a ticket agent and reservation agent. As part of Lorenzo's cost-cutting strategy, the airline has hired thousands of new employees at lower pay to replace the union strikers. Many of the replacement workers are young, single, without families and mortgages to support _ and not especially receptive to trade unionism. Eastern flight attendants, for example, now earn an average $1,688 a month, down from $2,029 before the strike. ``It's just like any other job; you've got to work your way up,'' Melody replied when asked if she resented the relatively low wages. Insiders estimate that the new employees have cut about 10 years off the average age of Eastern's work force of 20,000: from the mid-40s to the mid-30s. The minimum age for Eastern flight attendants is 18. Even the uniforms for flight attendants are new: navy blue with gold stripes on the sleeves, described as a more professional look replacing the old khaki-colored outfits and red scarves. Female attendants also wear a military-style kepi reminiscent of stewardess uniforms in the mid-1950s: some say the jaunty caps make them an easy target for the jeers of Machinist pickets at airports. Breakfast on Flight 103 is scrambled eggs, hash brown potatoes, tiny sausages, orange juice and a small blueberry muffin. (In first class, it's fancier and includes an omelette and fresh fruit salad.) In the cockpit, there's a mix of Eastern veterans and newcomers. The captain, Jon McClure, has flown for Eastern 22 years. He stayed out for six months before crossing the picket line to return to work. McClure is flying this trip with co-pilot Phil Gibson, 42, and flight engineer Dan Marouf, 34, both hired after the strike started. ``I wanted to get this company going; I wanted to be part of a team,'' said Gibson, who had flown corporate jets for five years before joining Eastern last June. ``I'm not here for the short term. I plan to make this a career.'' McClure, calling the strike ``ill-conceived,'' said that now, new and old pilots are working well together and all the employees are hustling more than before. Asked about Eastern's future prospects, he gazed out the cockpit window at a distant point: ``I'm optimistic, but it could go either way.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday March 4.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Official Confirms London Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford said Wednesday that officials of the seven largest industrial countries met in London this week, but he refused to confirm a report that Japan had requested help in stabilizing the value of the Japanese currency. ``I can't answer questions about current exchange rates,'' Mulford told reporters after an appearance before a congressional panel. He said he attended the Tuesday meeting. Mulford was asked about a report by a Japanese news organization that officials in that country had asked other major industrial countries to keep the yen from falling further. The Kyodo News Service, quoting a Finance Ministry source, said Japan made the request at a meeting of deputy finance minsters from the industrial countries, which are known as the Group of Seven. The seven governments _ the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada _ often work together to buy and sell currencies on the open market to influence their price. The yen has been declining rapidly against the dollar in recent weeks, threatening to ignite inflation in Japan. A decline in the yen also risks worsening the U.S. trade deficit by making American goods more expensive and Japanese goods cheaper. The dollar gained against the yen Wednesday, closing at 149.08 yen in New York, compared with 148.73 yen on Tuesday. Mulford confirmed for reporters that he had attended a G-7 deputies meeting in London on Tuesday. Other sources had said the session was with officials at Mulford's level and not at the ministerial level although Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady was also in London Tuesday. While refusing to confirm that stabilizing the Japanese yen was on the agenda, Mulford said the group did discuss establishment of a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to help foster emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. He said he hoped that the bank could begin operating by the end of this year but that there was no assurance that this timetable could be met. At Wednesday's hearing of a House Banking Committee task force, Mulford said the G-7 countries have been successfully coordinating their domestic policies to foster global prosperity. Mulford told the lawmakers he could not make a statement on the controversial issue of whether the Soviet Union should be allowed to borrow from the new bank. ``We're still in the process of learning from what we've heard,'' he said. The Bush administration had been reported earlier as opposing loans from the bank to the Soviet Union, while other donor governments wanted to permit them. Mulford said the administration is anxious to set up special standards for loans that are not required by other development banks: requirements that borrowers move toward democracy, pluralism, free political parties, elections, the rule of law, human rights and open, market-based economies. He said the U.S. government wants to join the bank and its first concern is how to finance the transition from Communism to economies based on markets. He suggested that if the bank lends chiefly to governments it may promote the existing situation rather than contribute to changing it.

DOC.HEAD: First Boeing 737-500 Delivered
DOC.TEXT: The first Boeing 737-500, the latest version of the world's top-selling commercial jetliner, was delivered Wednesday to Southwest Airlines. Boeing said the 104-passenger plane was flown to Dallas, where the regional carrier is based, 16 days after receiving flight certification from the Federal Aviation Administration. Nineteen customers have ordered a totak 193 737-500s, which cost roughly $25 million each. As of last Thursday, total orders for all models of the twin-engine 737, Boeing's smallest jetliner, amounted to 2,771 planes, said T. Craig Martin of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. The more quiet, efficient and technologically advanced 737-500 replaces the 737-100 and 737-200 versions, which made their first flights in 1967, Martin said. Production of the first two models ended after 1,144 were delivered, the last a 737-200 for Xiamen Airlines of China on Aug. 8, 1988, said Martin. Other versions still in production are the 128-passenger 737-300 and 146-passenger 737-400.

DOC.HEAD: Indictment Could Mean Exxon's Costs For Alaska Spill Will Multiply
DOC.TEXT: Regardless of whether Exxon Corp. ever goes to trial on criminal charges, the oil giant's indictment in connection with its Alaska oil spill could cause Exxon's disaster-related expenses to snowball beyond the $2 billion it already has spent, experts said Wednesday. Dan Riesel, an environmental attorney with the law firm Sive, Paget & Riesel, said a number of outcomes are possible in the Exxon case, including an eventual dismissal of the charges. In the event of a conviction or a plea bargain, however, criminal proceedings against Exxon could benefit those who have filed civil lawsuits and swell Exxon's financial burden, said Riesel, a former environmental prosecutor for the U.S. Attorney's office in New York. ``If Exxon is forced to articulate what it did in a plea bargain process it makes life awfully simple for private plaintiffs and very difficult for Exxon,'' Riesel said. ``Those are admissions and admissions can be used in another proceeding to prove liability.'' A federal grand jury in Alaska handed up a five-count criminal indictment against Exxon on Tuesday for counts stemming from the oil spill by the tanker Exxon Valdez after it hit a reef last March 24 in Alaska's Prince William Sound. The spill of 11 million gallons of oil soiled over 1,000 miles of coastline and killed thousands of fish, birds and other animals. More than 160 civil lawsuits are pending against Exxon by the State of Alaska, environmentalists and private individuals for unspecified damages. The criminal outcome also could result in fines totaling twice the loss to the victim, in this case what it cost to restore the environment to its condition prior to the spill, Riesel said. ``If measured by the cost of rebuilding the ecosystem, then we're talking an astronomical sum _ billions,'' he said. Exxon Chairman Lawrence Rawl said Tuesday that Exxon already has spent more than $2 billion in cleanup costs and has paid out more than $180 million to 13,000 fishermen and other claimants. The company took $1.68 billion in charges against 1989 earnings to cover what it said was both current and estimated future costs for cleanup, environmental and legal expenses. Nevertheless, Tuesday's indictment raised uncertainty about what Exxon's final responsibility would be in the spill. Justice Department officials said the indictment could result in penalties of $700 million or more. But analysts said actual financial impact to the oil giant remained too uncertain to quantify, because Exxon failed to reach a settlement over possible criminal charges. Exxon reportedly had been negotiating a plea agreement with the Justice Department that would have involved the creation of a $500 million environmental restoration fund. ``I doubt it will cost more than what Exxon has already put out,'' said Joseph V. Battipaglia, equities analyst with Gruntal Investment Research. He said, however, ``It's not altogether clear to what extent there will be extraordinary expenses arising from the indictment.'' ``The absence of a plea bargain only keeps the uncertainty,'' said Frank P. Knuettel, analyst for Prudential Bache Securities Inc. Knuettel and other analysts say the company's enormous size insulates it from the financial impact of the spill. ``Exxon is wealthier than a hundred countries in the U.N.,'' said Knuettel. Exxon's stock dropped $1.37{ to $47 on the New York Stock Exchange, in what analysts called a temporary, ``knee-jerk'' reaction to the indictment, which was announced after the market closed Tuesday. The stock generally was expected to improve in 1990. Battipaglia noted the stock remained above the $45 range in which it was trading before the spill. Exxon stock has been relatively flat since the spill. Another uncertainty is the outcome of the trial in Alaska of Joseph Hazelwood, former captain of the Exxon Valdez at the time of the spill. Hazelwood, charged with a felony, criminal mischief and three misdemeanors, is the only person charged criminally in the tanker grounding. Analysts said the amount of damages sought in civil lawsuits likely would climb if Hazelwood is convicted. Many of the lawsuits do not yet specify a damage amount.

DOC.HEAD: VW Chief: Company ``in a Mess'' but Will Stay in U.S. Market
DOC.TEXT: Volkswagen is ``in a mess'' in the United States but has no plans to pull out of the market, the head of the West German company's U.S. operations said Wednesday. ``We are well loved, but we are not well purchased,'' said William J. Young, vice president of Volkswagen United States Inc. ``We have to act better than our performance. We have to become leaders again.'' The company's share of the U.S. market is about 1 percent, its dealer network dropped from 840 to 790 outlets last year and it is nowhere near achieving its goal of selling 200,000 cars in the U.S. this year, Young said. He said he's pinning Volkswagen's hopes on ``Fahrvergnugen,'' which loosely translates to ``driving pleasure.'' Volkswagen is using the word and a stick figure logo in its advertising in an attempt to lure curious consumers into showrooms. In addition to the advertising campaign using the unique word, Volkswagen has broken ranks with its U.S. counterparts and pulled out of the incentive wars. Volkswagen and BMW, another West German automaker, have lowered prices on some of their 1990 model cars instead of offering cash rebates or low-interest financing deals. ``The value of rebates is wearing out,'' Young said. ``The other side of the equation is: What do you do if you don't have them?'' ``You do the same thing as when you didn't have them _ and when you didn't have them you had a better business,'' he said. Young took a swipe at the U.S. Big Three automakers, saying they don't get involved in long-term planning. Volkswagen executives, he said, are making long-term plans. ``What they are saying is, let's develop a long-term strategy so we don't put our heads in the sand like some of the manufacturers in the U.S. market,'' Young said. Young's comments came during the company's U.S. introduction of its Passat mid-size sedan.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Continues Advance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market moved broadly higher Wednesday and blue chips managed to extend this week's winning streak. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose 52.93 points over the prior two sessions, gained an additional 10.13 to close at 2,627.25. The key indicator's advance came despite heavy selling in Exxon stock in the wake of the company's indictment on criminal charges related to last March's oil spill off the Alaskan coast. Periodic rounds of profit-taking pared down the increase in the Dow Jones industrial average. It stood more than 20 points higher at midday before traders decided to sell to collect profits. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 8 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 917 up, 565 down and 495 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board swelled to 184.41 million shares from 152.59 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 218.55 million shares. Market watchers said stocks continued to benefit from improved investor confidence stemming from Wall Street's ability to withstand a recent slump in Tokyo without suffering any apparent ill effects. A continuing recovery in Tokyo from Monday's steep plunge reinforced the positive tone while an upward revision in the government's estimate of economic activity also helped. The government's latest reading on the economy came out before the market opened and it showed the gross national product grew at a 0.9 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of 1989, faster than the 0.5 percent pace previously estimated but still the slowest in more than three years. The Commerce Department said its revised estimate of October-December growth means the GNP _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ rose 3 percent for all of 1989. That was the slowest yearly advance since a 2.7 percent gain in 1986 and followed a 4.4 percent increase in 1988. Analysts said the stock market could bump into resistence due to worries about how corporate profits will fare in the face of a prolonged period of sluggish economic growth. Among active blue chips, International Business Machines rose [ to 103~, American Telephone & Telegraph added [ to 39}, General Electric, moved ahead \ to 61} and General Motors finished off [ at 44~. Exxon, another component of the Dow Jones industrial average, tumbled 1] to 47. American Express jumped 1 to 29[, also in brisk trading. Boeing climbed 2\ to 63~. Future Germany Fund, the newest addition to the growing ranks of single-country mutual funds, led the list of active NYSE stocks on volume of more than 8.6 million shares. The stock closed at 19\ on its first day of trading, above the $18-a-share price for its initial offering of 12.5 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $18.27 billion, or 0.57 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks closed 0.91 higher at 183.07. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.60 to 382.02, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 1.63 to 331.89. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market moved 3.22 higher to 425.83. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index ended the session at 352.90, up 1.50.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern's Atlanta Buildup: Who's in Charge
With BC-Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Here are profiles of Eastern Airlines managers responsible for building up its Atlanta hub, centerpiece of Eastern's bankruptcy restructuring plan: _HAROLD HOLT _ Vice president for airport services, central region; Eastern's highest-ranking manager in Atlanta. Charged with increasing Eastern's daily flights out of Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport to 315 by mid- to late 1990 from about 270 currently. He oversees Eastern's 6,000 pilots, mechanics, flight attendants and other employees based in Atlanta, out of a total company work force of 18,000. Has a staff of six. A 40-year company veteran, he started as a ramp service worker in Atlanta.

_TODD JENNINGS _ Director of flight operations and chief pilot in Atlanta. Responsible for 1,000 or so Atlanta-based pilots. About half were hired since the strike began; the other half are veterans who crossed picket lines. His duties include counseling returning pilots, holding daily briefings. Supervises ``cockpit resource management'' program _ encouraging pilots to take initiative, make decisions. Before the walkout, he was assistant to the former chief pilot in Atlanta, then was promoted in post-strike reorganization. Has been with Eastern for 27 years, beginning as a co-pilot in Charlotte, N.C.

_MARGE CHASON _ Director of in-flight services, supervising around 1,400 flight attendants based in Atlanta. Her department has hired scores of young men and women since the strike (minimum age is 18), and some women in their 50s who had worked as reservation agents for Eastern. Initially she had some concern about absorbing attendants returning from strike (400 to 500), but says there haven't been lasting problems. ``We just opened our arms to them.'' She started with Eastern in 1955 as a flight attendant. After seven years, promoted to supervisory positions in New York, Chicago and Newark, N.J.

_ROBERT COSTALES _ Director of aircraft service center in Atlanta. Directs staff of about 750, including skilled mechanics, sheet metal workers and other maintenance employees. Nearly all employees were hired after Machinists strike began; new hires came from other airlines, military, Lockheed Corp. Jets spend seven to 35 days for maintenance checks and repairs in the hangar, located about three-quarters of a mile from Eastern terminal at Hartsfield. Costales joined Eastern 35 years ago as an apprentice mechanic in Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Poling To Begin 3-Year Stint as Ford Chairman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 2nd graf pvs, The 64-year-old...to CORRECT age of Petersen to 63 sted 65.
DOC.TEXT: Harold Poling begins a three-year term as chairman of Ford Motor Co. on Thursday, a stint some analysts say appears to be a caretaker role while the next chairman is groomed for office. The 64-year-old Poling, who is vice chairman and chief operating officer, succeeds Donald Petersen, 63, as chairman and chief executive. Petersen and Poling have worked closely for the past decade _ during which Ford changed from a struggling, overweight giant that lost $1.5 billion in 1980 to a much leaner company that earned an industry record $5.3 billion eight years later. The relatively limited time Poling will head the company is considered unusual by management standards. ``It's often the case when there has been some kind of trauma,'' said Edward Bowman, deputy dean of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. ``The especially unusual thing about it is that Ford is in especially good shape.'' Bowman, who concentrates his research on chief executive positions, said the Ford board of directors' election of Poling to a limited term as chairman ``would imply that they weren't quite ready in terms of succession planning, that they weren't ready to name somebody else for a normal term.'' Most of the speculation for a longer-term chief executive officer in the mid-1990s and beyond has centered on Allan Gilmour, a Ford executive vice president who on Thursday adds the title of president of the Ford Automotive Group. Petersen joined Ford in 1949 and held a variety of positions in domestic and international product planning, design and marketing before he became president. Poling's Ford career began in 1951 and focused mainly on the financial side of the corporation. Petersen has been credited with freeing designers and engineers in the early 1980s to work together in developing the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable cars of the mid-1980s, which helped lift Ford from the financial doldrums. ``I really think that Petersen made the necessary adjustments in the product plan,'' auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. of New York. ``The key addition he made was to leave product planning to the product planners.'' Poling would do well to follow that lead, Brady said. ``I think he's got to challenge (product planners) with the charge that this is a very intensely competitive game,'' he said. ``That's all he's got to do in the product area.'' Bowman said, ``I think he (Poling) would be a nut in that three-year period to mess with any product decisions.'' Poling has his work cut out for him. The U.S. auto industry is in the depths of a recession that began in October. Companies are wrestling with a way to wean American consumers from rebates and other incentives that have become ingrained in car buying and are eroding profits. Each of the nation's Big Three automakers, General Motors Corp., Ford and Chrysler Corp., are taking steps to eliminate costs and steamline operations, with GM and Chrysler imposing plant shutdowns and layoffs. Brady said Poling can leave his mark by raising productivity at Ford. ``If he can follow through with the productivity increase while the programs continue in the Petersen manner, it will be one of the best one-two punches of all time,'' Brady said. Poling will become the fourth company chairman who was not a member of the Ford family. The two Fords now in company management are cousins William C. Ford Jr., 32, who heads the company's marketing staff, and Edsel Ford II, 41, directors of heavy truck engineering and manufacturing. Both are great-grandsons of company founder Henry Ford.

DOC.HEAD: Cooperating Witnesses in Fraud Scheme Sentenced to Prison
DOC.TEXT: Two key prosecution witnesses in the stock manipulation case against the chairman of now-defunct Haas Securities Corp. were sentenced Wednesday to prison terms of one and three years. The sentencings of former Haas president Stanley Aslanian Jr. and Henry Lorin, a stock promoter, came one day after Haas chairman Eugene Laff was sentenced to five years in prison for manipulating the prices of three over-the-counter stocks. Lorin, 48, who was the president of Henlor Capital Ltd., received the three-year prison term from U.S. District Judge Thomas P. Griesa, who said Lorin played a key role in the scheme. Aslanian, 31, was sentenced to one year in prison and two years probation by another federal judge, Shirley Wohl Kram. Kram said Aslanian's cooperation had been ``meaningful and extensive.'' Lorin and Aslanian, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges, both testified at Laff's trial, which ended in December with his conviction on five counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. The case against Laff stemmed from the government's first fraud investigation after the 1987 market crash. Haas Securities, a brokerage house, collapsed nine days after the crash. The prosecution maintained that the firm's scheme to artificially raise the prices of penny stocks _ inexpensive securities traded over the counter _ couldn't be maintained after the market dropped and the share prices fell. Laff was convicted of being part of a scheme to artificially inflate the penny stock prices by creating a false demand for the shares and then selling out his firm's own stake before the prices collapsed. The stock involved in the scheme were Big O Tires Inc., Flores de New Mexico and T.S. Industries Inc. Lorin is to surrender on April 11 and Aslanian on March 28.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major currencies Wednesday after the government reported the nation's economy grew at a faster-than-expected rate in the fourth quarter of 1989. The dollar traded at an eight-month high against the Japanese yen for the third day despite central bank intervention. Traders said continued concern about the Tokyo stock market depressed the yen. Gold prices were mostly lower. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid for gold at $406.10 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EST, down $2.15 from late Tuesday. The Commerce Department said the U.S. economy grew by 0.9 percent in 1989's fourth quarter, faster than previously estimated but still the slowest pace in more than three years. The revised GNP figure supported the dollar, but was not a major factor because it is a historic number, said Hubert Pedroli, foreign exchange manager for Credit Suisse in New York. ``It only gives us a small indication of what we can expect for 1990, but still, it's an indication in the sense of sustained growth, not recession,'' he said. Pedroli said concern remained about the slump in the Tokyo stock market despite its improvement Wednesday. ``There's still a cloud of uncertainty over there so the yen continues to be weak,'' he said. The Federal Reserve sold dollars in New York to support the yen when it reached the 149.10 level, but the intervention only had a temporary impact, traders said. The dollar was boosted against the West German mark by speculation that a plan to unite the currencies of East and West Germany would produce inflation, traders said. The dollar lost strength as it began its day in Tokyo, falling 0.51 yen to 148.52 yen. But in London, the dollar was quoted higher at 148.75 yen. Later, in New York, the dollar rose to 149.08 yen, up from 148.73 late Tuesday. The dollar has not closed that high against the yen in New York since June 15, when it reached 151.30 yen. The dollar also gained strength against the British pound. In London, the pound fetched $1.6895, cheaper than $1.6915 late Tuesday. In New York, it traded at $1.6752, down from $1.6908 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.7074 West German marks, up from 1.6880; 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.4840; 5.7695 French francs, up from 5.7150; 1,260.75 Italian lire, up from 1,248.75; and 1.1927 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1938. Late rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4900 Swiss francs, up from 1.4857; 5.7300 French francs, up from 5.7010; 1.9070 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8985; 1,250.00 Italian lire, up from 1,245.25; and 1.2072 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1908. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery dropped $1.90 a troy ounce to $406.10. Earlier, gold traded in London at a late bid price of $407.90 a troy ounce, up from $407.25 bid late Tuesday. But in Zurich, the metal fell to a bid price of $407.79 from $411.25 Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.07 to close at a bid $408.92. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.10 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $5.11. In New York, silver for current delivery rose to $5.127 an ounce from $5.075 Tuesday on the Commodity Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Oil Futures Surge To 7-Month High On Technicals, Strong Demand
DOC.TEXT: Soybean oil futures bounded to 7{-month highs Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by bullish chart signals and stronger domestic demand for soybean oil as an alternative to other fats. The rally helped pull soybean futures higher. Corn futures also advanced in Chicago while most wheat futures retreated. On other commodity markets, petroleum futures slipped; precious metals were mixed; cattle futures advanced and pork futures were mixed. Soybean oil settled .20 cent to .65 cent higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in March up .56 cent at 21.22 cents a pound, the highest settlement for a near-month contract since July 7. Soybean futures finished 5 cents to 7{ cents higher with March at $5.66{ a bushel; wheat futures were 1{ cents lower to { cent higher with March at $3.93\ a bushel; corn futures were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with March at $2.47 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 4} cents higher with March at $1.41\ a bushel. Soybean oil has been trending higher since Feb. 9, when the Agriculture Department released a report indicating U.S. stocks of soybean oil are shrinking. Soybean oil opened higher, extending Tuesday's late gains, then faltered at midday only to soar toward the close after the May contract's price broke through resistance at 21.10 cents a pound. The rally appeared to be inspired more by chart signals than supply-and-demand factors, although analysts linked some of the buying to Taiwan's overnight purchase of 23,000 metric tons of soybeans, talk of Iraqi interest in U.S. soybean meal and perceptions that soybean-crushing activity is slowing. After the close, the USDA announced a sale of 23,000 metric tons of soybean oil to Pakistan. Analyst Walter Spilka of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. attributed most of the increased demand for soybean oil to domestic users, including food processors, in the wake of research linking imported alternatives such as palm oil and coconut oil to higher blood cholesterol levels. ``Last year we had a lot of imports of tropical oils but a lot of bakers have now stopped using tropical oils,'' Spilka said. Anne Frick, senior oilseeds analysts with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said some buying interest may have been stirred by the soybean market's failure to fall during February below its January lows, defying ``a well-known seasonal pattern.'' ``That didn't happen this year and I think it gave the bulls more confidence,'' she said. Petroleum futures sank on the New York Mercantile Exchange, extending Tuesday's losses, following the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory report showing increased U.S. supplies of gasoline for the seventh week in a row. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 4 cents to 25 cents lower with April at $21.54 a barrel; heating oil was .70 cent to 1.26 cents lower with March at 57.32 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .10 cent to 1.80 cents lower with March at 55.76 cents a gallon. Gold futures fell for the sixth straight day on New York's Commodity Exchange as stock prices firmed but silver futures advanced, partly recovering from Tuesday's slump to 4{-month lows. Gold futures finished $1.80 to $2.10 lower with April at $408.90 a troy ounce; silver was 3.6 cents to 5.2 cents higher with March at $5.127 a troy ounce. Cattle futures firmed amid expectations for stronger cash markets. Pork futures ended mixed after rallying early in the session on rumors that the United States was on the verge of subsidizing sales of pork to the Soviet Union. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter denied that the United States had made such an offer. Live cattle futures settled .08 cent to .27 cent higher with April at 75.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .40 cent higher with March at 80.40 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .53 cent higher with April at 50.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 51.35 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices fell Wednesday in a second straight day of declines. Analysts attributed the sell-off to bearish sentiment on the final day of trading for March contracts, the apparent onset of warmer weather and high inventories, particularly in heating oil. The April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, lost 4 cents to close at $21.54 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after falling 21 cents a barrel on Tuesday. Later contracts also finished up to 25 cents lower Wednesday. Refined products traded on the New York Merc also fell. Unleaded regular gasoline for delivery in March, which declined 2.27 cent a gallon Tuesday, fell another 1.80 cents to 55.76 cents a gallon. Later contracts had smaller losses. No. 2 heating oil for March delivery fell 0.84 cent a gallon, after dropping 0.89 cent on Moday. Later contracts were down by larger amounts. John Hill, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, said unleaded gasoline was hardest hit Wednesday because of high stocks. ``People are basically saying there's not much room for storage,'' he said. Part of the decline in heating oil prices was attributed to warmer weather that is decreasing demand for the product amid high investories. Hill also said traders expected crude oil prices to crack a technical low level of $21.40 but rose during the day because of some buying interest.

DOC.HEAD: T.J. Maxx Owner Reports Earnings Increase
DOC.TEXT: TJX Cos. Inc. reported Tuesday that the success of its T.J. Maxx off-price retail stores contributed largely to a 49 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit. For the quarter that ended Jan. 27, the company earned $25.18 million, or 36 cents per share, on sales of $618.6 million, compared with earnings of $16.8 million, or 30 cents per share, on sales of $567.2 million in the previous fourth quarter. TJX operates 352 T.J. Maxx and 546 Hit or Miss stores across the country, and also owns the Chadwick's of Boston mail order business. Bernard Cammarata, the company president, said in a statement that T.J. Maxx contributed largely to the company's success, while Hit or Miss had a ``disappointing'' second half, especially the fourth quarter. ``As a specialty store retailer using limited advertising, Hit or Miss found it difficult to overcome the unprecedented level of promotions that prevailed in the fourth quarter,'' he said. For the full year, sales rose 11.9 percent to $2.1 billion from $1.9 billion. The company had net income of $93.8 million, or $1.43 per share, for the last fiscal year, compared with a loss of $167.8 million, or $2.97 per share, the previous year that stemmed from the company's sale of its Zayre stores to Ames Department Stores Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Key Figure in Penny Stock Probe Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A key target in a federal securities probe involving penny stock brokerage founder Meyer Blinder has pleaded guilty and agreed to testify for the government. Authorities said Salt Lake City businessman Michael D. Wright, 30, agreed to cooperate in the prosecution of Blinder, who was indicted last week on charges of manipulating securities in a multibillion-dollar stock swindle. The indictment charges Blinder, 69, of Denver, and four others with conspiring to engage in fraudulent securities trading practices through the firm Blinder, Robinson & Co., once the nation's largest penny stock brokerage. Wright pleaded guilty to three counts of securities fraud. He is to be sentenced May 17. His partner, Arnold L. Kimmes, pleaded guilty to racketeering charges last March and has cooperated with investigators from the Internal Revenue Service and Securities and Exchange Commission. Authorities said Kimmes and Wright formed ``blind pools,'' companies with no assets or corporate history, and paid nominees to list their names as puppet directors. Lawyers and accountants allegedly provided audited financial statements for the businesses, giving the appearance that they were real, according to the plea agreement dated Feb. 22. The companies then were registered with the SEC, and phony offerings were staged with puppet shareholders who bought shares with money supplied by Wright and Kimmes, authorities said. Government authorities contend Blinder controlled the stock supply and demand, using high-pressure sales tactics to peddle the stocks.
