For release Sunday March 4
DOC.HEAD: Descendant of Confederate Leader Plans New Invasion
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Robert E. Lee is plotting an offensive this spring in Tennessee. But instead of leading a fight between Confederate and Union troops, Lee's battle involves spirits. Bob Lee IV, great-grandson of the Civil War general, is in the liquor business. As chairman of the tiny, privately owned A. Smith Bowman Inc. distillery, Lee is taking on a much bigger foe on the opposition's home turf _ Tennessee-based Jack Daniel _ in a bid to double sales of Bowman's Virginia Gentleman bourbon in that state. Lee, 65, has a military leader's reluctance to tell too much. Exactly what is meant by ``double sales?'' He won't say. But he admits his company isn't setting out to become an industry giant. ``We don't need a lot of sales to show an increase because we're not going against a million cases,'' he said. In Virginia, however, Lee's company is as big as his family's name. ``We are the No. 1 alcoholic beverage label in the state,'' he said. That ranking was achieved largely because of Bowman's Virginia Vodka, which sells about 150,000 cases a year in the state. Bowman also has just gone international with an order from Poland for 50,000 cases of vodka, the largest single order for one product in the company's history. Bowman's mainstay, Virginia Gentleman bourbon, is No. 2 in the state behind national leader Jim Beam. Virginia Gentleman also is sold in seven other states from Pennsylvania to North Carolina and a pocket in Atlanta. Two years ago, Bowman introduced its own gin, which now accounts for about 12,000 cases a year. Lee is a born salesman whose accent reflects his New York roots. His father was a Columbia University-educated doctor who practiced in the city. But Lee was sent to private school in Virginia and in 1949 graduated Washington & Lee University in Lexington, where his great-grandfather served as president after the Civil War. After college, he moved to the West Coast and became an advertising executive for the San Francisco Chronicle. Twenty years ago, Lee joined Bowman when his brother-in-law, A. Smith Bowman Jr., asked him to take over sales and marketing duties at the company founded in 1935 by Bowman's father, A. Smith Bowman Sr. ``I basically like sales,'' said Lee, whose first decision at Bowman was to hire a public relations executive and begin traveling around the state to give civic club speeches and newspaper and television interviews to promote Virginia Gentleman. ``I went down to Lynchburg one time and was on a cooking show,'' he said. ``I'd never cooked in my life. But we did it for half an hour and gave away recipes. It was fun.'' Lee, who eventually succeeded the Bowmans as chairman of the nation's oldest family-owned independent bourbon distillery, also played a role in the decision to diversify the firm's products. ``Here we had one product, bourbon,'' he said. ``Nationally, bourbon was not going anywhere.'' Bourbon's share of the liquor market dwindled from 14 percent in 1978 to 10.8 percent in 1988. But the trend was evident early on, and Bowman got into the vodka business in 1982, Lee said. When the company's vodka went on the market, it got a boost from then-Gov. Charles S. Robb, who launched his ``We Have it Made in Virginia'' campaign at the same time. ``That was pure luck,'' Lee said. The company's gin came out two years ago. While Lee has been searching for new directions to take the company, Bowman is not ready to become a major national player in the liquor field, he said. Although sales of bourbon are slumping nationally, Lee said there are still plenty of bourbon drinkers to woo away from competitors. A dozen years ago, Bowman entered into a partnership with a wholesaler in Florida and Texas and attempted for 18 months to sell Virginia Gentleman in those two states. ``It just didn't work,'' Lee said. ``So having done that, we realize we can't go big league like Jim Beam,'' he said. ``We never would have known if we hadn't tried.'' Lee keeps a small bust of Gen. Lee in his office, but most of the family decorations are related to his children, including son Robert E. Lee V, who teaches at a nearby private school. Lee said people always want to hear stories about his great-grandfather. ``But we don't have any special anecdotes in the family about General Lee,'' he said. ``One of the major reasons is that everybody got married late in life. My father never knew his grandfather, and my father was in his 50s when I was born. ``We had a sense of history, but we didn't have anybody sitting in someone's lap telling about something that wasn't in Dr. Freeman's or Bruce Catton's books,'' Lee said of the Pulitzer Prize-winning biography of his great-grandfather by Douglas Southall Freeman and works by Civil War historian Catton. ``That's just the way it was.'' What Lee has in mind for the Tennessee offensive is a taste test, a battle of the bourbons. ``It's going to be Kentucky vs. Tennessee vs. Virginia,'' he said. How far is he willing to go to win? ``A Southern gentleman will go to any lengths to maintain the family honor,'' according to a Bowman brochure. ``A Virginia gentleman will go only to honorable lengths.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday March 4

DOC.HEAD: Ford, Toyota Issue Recalls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Toyota recall.
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp. and Ford Motor Co. on Wednesday recalled some of their mid-1980s cars because of potential cruise control and emissions problems. Toyota spokeswoman Deborah Sanchez-Fair said about 120,000 1983-84 model Camrys and 1984-model Corollas were being recalled because of a cruise control problem that could cause high engine speed. The automaker said it was aware of no accidents or injuries because of the problem. Meanwhile, Ford said it was recalling about 16,000 1986 Ford Escort and EXP and Mercury Lynx cars made for sale in California. The company said emissions from the cars, all equipped with 1.9-liter engines and automatic transmissions, exceed maximum levels for hydrocarbons and oxides of nitrogen set by the California Air Resources Board. Cars made for sale in California have different emission-control systems than cars sold elsewhere. Owners of cars in both recalls will be notified by mail and alterations will be performed free.

DOC.HEAD: Union Says Talks With Greyhound Moving Slowly, Suggests Strike Unavoidable
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs to UPDATE with Greyhound comment; PICKS UP 8th graf, `Greyhound officials...
DOC.TEXT: The union representing Greyhound Lines Inc. bus drivers offered little hope Wednesday that a Friday strike could be averted although low-level talks with management continued. ``There has been progress in some areas, but very little progress in others,'' said Edward M. Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. ``It will be very difficult to achieve our objective _ a fair and equitable contract _ by the March 2 deadline.'' A union spokesman declined to say where progress had been made and which issues remained unresolved. The union, which represents 6,300 bus drivers and 3,075 of the company's office and maintenance workers, has called a strike for 12:01 a.m. Friday, one minute after the current three-year contract expires. Dallas-based Greyhound, which operates the only nationwide intercity bus system, has said it will continue to run a limited schedule if the drivers strike, with plans to build back to full operations by the end of March. Full scale negotiations between the two sides ended last week, although low-level meetings resumed over the weekend in Scottsdale, Ariz. Strait said the current talks were moving at a slow pace. In a statement, Greyhound Executive Vice President P. Anthony Lannie said the union's demand were ``far above the average of company-union negotiated settlements of the last two years.' Greyhound officials declined to comment on the union's remarks, citing an ongoing news blackout covering the talks. The company has said it cannot afford more than the $63 million, three-year pact it is offering. Greyhound estimates the union's proposal would cost $406 million over the life of the contract. Greyhound says it earned about $730,000 on about $1 billion in revenue last year, the first profit since the company was formed in 1987 through the $350 million purchases of Greyhound and Trailways Lines Inc. Prior to the buyout, the union agreed to a 22 percent wage cut, and the company has said the current offer is an attempt to regain that money before the company is able to pay. ``Those people that you owe or will owe money to don't acknowledge that your pay has been cut by 25 percent,'' said union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson. ``It's a difficult situation.'' Although the negotiations are the first since Currey purchased the company, Greyhound went through two acrimonious strikes while still a subsidiary of Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp. A 1983 strike lasted 48 days and was ``an extremely difficult strike,'' Nelson said. There also was a four-day strike in 1974. ``These people know what it's like to go on strike,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fisher-Price Toys To Close Plant, Lay Off 450
DOC.TEXT: Fisher-Price said Wednesday it would close a toy manufacturing plant in the town where the company was founded 60 years ago and lay off 450 employees. Fisher-Price executive vice president David B. Fisher said the layoffs would begin May 15 and the East Aurora plant should be closed by July 1. ``This decision will lower our costs and improve our position in this very competitive market place,'' Fisher said. Fisher-Price, the world's largest maker of infant and preschool toys and juvenile products, said it would keep its corporate headquarters in this village outside Buffalo and plants in Medina and Holland, also in upstate New York. High inventories, production delays, higher costs and supply problems over the last year have hampered Fisher-Price, which posted a $9.5 million operating loss in the final quarter of 1989. Fisher said he expects the company to be ``marginally profitable at best'' in 1990. Overall sales were $800 million in 1989, and Fisher-Price still has an excellent reputation among its customers. A recent national survey of buyer attitudes on product quality rated Fisher-Price toys third behind Mercedes Benz autos and Eastman-Kodak photo products. Reports over the last week have indicated that Fisher-Price would be sold by parent Quaker Oats Co. of Chicago, but Quaker Chairman William D. Smithburg said last week that Fisher-Price was not now on the block. About 1,000 people work at corporate headquarters and 2,000 more at the other plants. Fisher-Price employs about 10,000 people worldwide. None of those laid off, who are semi-skilled workers making $8 to $9 an hour, will be offered jobs at other Fisher-Price operations. The East Aurora plant, which began operation in 1951, makes Fisher-Price's Little People playsets, Bubble Mower and Magic Vac. Those operations will be transferred to the Medina plant and a plant in Murray, Ky. Fisher said the East Aurora plant is the least efficient the company owns because it does not have fabrication, assembly and plastic molding capability in one building.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Chairman To Retire; New North American Philips Head Named
DOC.TEXT: N.V. Philips, the Dutch electronics company, said its president, C.J. van der Klugt, will retire on July 1, 1991. The company said Wednesday that J.D. Timmer, chairman of Philips' consumer electronics division, has been nominated to replace van der Klugt. His nomination will be put before the company's shareholders in the spring of 1991, Philips said from its headquarters in Eindhoven, the Netherlands. Van der Klugt also is chairman of the company's board of management, which has primary responsibility for running the company, and of the company's group management committee, which determines the general policy of the Philips group of companies. Timmer also will be nominated for these posts. Philips also announced that Stephen C. Tumminello has been elected to be presidient, chief executive officer and chairman of the executive management committee of North American Philips Corp., Philips' U.S. arm, effective June 1. Tumminello, who is executive vice president and vice chairman of the executive management committee of North American Philips, succeeds Einar Kloster. Kloster has been elected president and chief executive officer Philips Lighting Holding B.V. of the Netherlands.

DOC.HEAD: Design Show Highlights Engineering Technology
LaserPhoto CX3
DOC.TEXT: Innovations expected to propel the manufacturing industry into the future, including video headsets and floating concrete, are on display at the National Design Engineering Show and Conference. About 25,000 engineers are expected to converge on Chicago's lakefront McCormick Place through Thursday to see new designs from companies such as Dow Chemical Co. and Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co. _ even NASA. Many of the products and materials on display represent minor advances _ a fiber that resists fading just a bit longer, for example. Nevertheless, consumers will feel the effect of the new technology. ``You and I, ultimately, in some way will be related or involved with every single product in this show, whether it's paint on an automobile or the spring in the seat or the knobs to turn on your hi-fi,'' said Robert Rosaler, director of an engineering conference sponsored by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in conjunction with the show. Some new products debuting at the show take a broader step into the future. For example, a Massachusetts company is showing a miniature video display monitor slightly larger than a lipstick. Through the use of a magnifying lens, the one-inch display window produces an image that looks as though it is on a 12-inch screen. ``This is basically the walkman of the future. It's a videoman,'' said Raymond Hoffer, a representative of Reflection Technology of Waltham, Mass. By Christmas, the mini video monitor is due to appear in stores as a component in a 5-by-2 inch paperless pocket fax machine, said Neil Golden, director of sales for Reflection Technology. The 2-ounce terminal can display 25 lines of 80 characters each on a red-and-black screen. It can attach to a headband that positions the video screen a few inches in front of the eyes, allowing a person to look up information while leaving the hands free to work. At least eight other companies plan to use Reflection Technology's monitor in products including a 5-by-3 portable computer and a patient monitor that doctors can wear in the operating room, Golden said. NASA is at the show ``to make the U.S. engineering and scientific community aware that there is NASA technology available that they may use,'' said Walter Heiland, manager of the agency's Technology Utilization Office. The space agency has a history of spinning off its technological advances. For example, NASA's need in the 1960s for a tool that Apollo astronauts could use to scoop up moon rocks, resulted in hand-held cordless vacuum cleaners that eventually reached consumers. More recently, a version of a pump developed for the Viking Mars lander has been implanted in people to deliver medicine such as insulin. 3M is showcasing a lightweight concrete subsitute called Macrolite that weighs about a third as much as the real thing. To illustrate, 3M representatives filled a tub with water and put in two ``concrete'' logs. One sinks. The other, made of the substitute, floats. Developed by 3M in 1986, the lightweight concrete can be used for building in earthquake-prone areas. ``You can build the same high-rise buildings, only much lighter, so when they sway they don't topple over,'' said William Whitcomb, a company representative. 3M says the ceramic substance, pumped with air, is a better insulator than concrete. An 8-inch wall of Macrolite provides the insulating power of 65 inches of concrete, Whitcomb said. Dow Plastics, a division of Midland, Mich.-based Dow, is on hand with a product it has no intention of producing _ a plastic, elliptical lawnmower that cuts a swath about a foot wider than traditional push mowers. Plastic allows a bigger machine that is no tougher to push than steel and aluminum models, said mower designer Robert Cleereman. The idea is to show commercial engineers that plastics _ particularly Dow plastics _ can be used in place of metals and woods, said Cleereman, who also is director of Dow's Materials Engineering Center. ``Here's an example where plastics not only do it as well, they do it better,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Deal to Provide Financing for $2 Billion in Home Mortgages
DOC.TEXT: Sears Mortgage Corp. and the Federal National Mortgage Association on Wednesday announced an agreement that will provide financing for $2 billion in home mortgages. Under the agreement, Sears will originate over the next 12 months a variety of fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages and exchange them for mortgage-backed securities issued by Fannie Mae or sell them to Fannie Mae for cash. Sears Mortgage, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck and Co., originates home mortgages nationwide. Those to be delivered under the deal will consist primarily of new loans, along with some existing home loans. The partnership ``will provide thousands of Americans with affordable home financing,'' said John R. Hayes, senior vice president in charge of Fannie Mae's Midwestern regional office. ``This new supply of mortgage financing will enable Sears to continue to make available to home buyers a wide variety of mortgage loan products at competitive interest rates,'' said Walter C. Kelin Jr., chairman and president of the Sears group. Fannie Mae is a congressionally chartered shareholder-owned company and the nation's largest investor in home mortgages.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 4th-Quarter Profit, Moody's Downgrades Debt Rating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to RECAST and MOVE UP Moody's downgrading; picks up 4th graf pvs, `The ratings ...'
DOC.TEXT: A leading credit rating agency warned Wednesay that Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. may have to sell more assets to meet payments coming due in late 1992 on its $1.6 billion debt. The warning from Moody's Investors Service Inc. came as Harcourt reported that a big gain on the sale of its theme parks helped the publishing and insurance concern earn $316.6 million in the fourth quarter compared with a loss of $53.9 million during same period a year ago. Moody's said that despite the sale of the theme parks and subsequent repayment of bank debt, Harcourt's cash flow from its publishing and insurance properties ``will provide only narrow coverage of anticipated cash interest charges and capital expenditures over the near term.'' As a result, Moody's also lowered its ratings on Harcourt's debt. The ratings agency said that the requirement that Harcourt must pay cash interest and dividends in late 1992 and 1993 ``is likely to necessitate further asset sales and-or debt restructuring.'' It downgraded Harcourt's senior debt rating to B3 from B1 and ratings on other grades of debt were also reduced. The company's debt had been assigned a speculative grade before the action and the reductions indicate the agency feels chances for timely debt repayment have grown riskier. The debt rating is one of the factors that are considered in valuing a company's securities, and a ratings reduction often causes a decline in the market price of a company's bonds. Two calls were placed to Harcourt for comment on Moody's action, but they were not immediately returned. Harcourt amassed a huge debt nearly three years ago when it underwent a massive restructuring in an effort to avoid a hostile takeover by British publisher Robert Maxwell. In the fourth quarter, Harcourt said its earnings per share amounted to $4.22 in contrast to a loss of $1.08 per share a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue slipped 0.7 percent to $301.7 million from $303.8 million a year earlier. The company closed the sale of its six theme parks to Anheuser-Busch Cos. for $1.1 billion in the quarter. It reported a gain on disposal of assets of $309 million in the quarter. It reported net income from continuing operations of $19.5 million for the quarter in contrast to a loss from continuing operations of $54.7 million. For the year, Harcourt said it earned $72.1 million, or 17 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $53.4 million, or $2.03 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the year rose 5.5 percent to $1.34 billion from $1.27 billion a year earlier. The company said it recorded a charge of $176 million in the third quarter, including a $95 million writeoff in its publishing business. In explaining the debt ratings reduction, Moody's boted that repayment of the company's bank debt with proceeds from the theme parks sale had reduced Harcourt's interest costs substantially. It said the company should have enough cash flow to service its cash interest charges and capital spending over the near term because of the deferred cash payment features of some of its debt instruments. But Moody's added, ``It is uncertain that the company will be able to achieve the growth necessary to service its debt and preferred stock once all fixed charges are payable in cash.'' The agency noted that the market value of assets can change and said the after-tax proceeds from sale of Harcourt assets ``at a given point in time may not be sufficient to cover both debt and preferred securities.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Pension Protection Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Senate committee approved legislation Wednesday aimed at providing greater protection of pension payments when companies terminate retirement plans to capture their surplus assets. The legislation by Sens. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, and Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., would impose new standards on pension fund administrators in deciding whether to terminate retirement plans. ``This bill will stop employers from using their workers' pension plans as corporate piggybanks,'' Metzenbaum said in a statement after the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved the bill on a 11-5 vote. Kassebaum and Sen. James Jeffords, R-Vt., joined with the panel's Democratic majority in voting to send the bill to the floor. Surplus pension assets have become a popular target for corporate raiders who acquire a company and quickly end so-called ``defined benefit'' retirement programs to take any excess cash. ``Defined benefit'' programs are administered by trustees or the employer and promise a certain benefit on retirement. So-called ``defined contribution'' plans where the company contributes to an employee's account generally are not at issue, because the employe owns the funds and there is no surplus cash _ when it comes time to retire, the money is turned over the employee or buys an annuity. In general, the legislation would allow a company to strip out surplus pension assets only if is determined to be in the best interests of workers and retirees. The bill requires the company to consider specific issues in making that determination, including whether cost-of-living benefits would be provided to retirees and whether an adequate financial cushion can be maintained in any replacement retirement plan. Metzenbaum has maintained that at least a portion of surplus pension assets should be set aside for cost-of-living adjustments in retirement benefits. The legislation does not require COLAs, but makes it more likely they would be provided, according to supporters of the measure. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. must approve pension fund terminations. However, critics complain that existing law doesn't adequately take into account whether pension beneficiaries will be better or worse off if a corporation takes back excess money from retirement plans. ``Workers who have been promised pensions should be assured those promises will be fulfilled and that their interests will take first place in these situations,'' Kassebaum said. Excess cash can arise in defined-benefit plans in several ways. One common way is the upward revision of estimates of what plan assets can earn. The higher the estimates, the less cash is needed now to meet future obligations.

DOC.HEAD: Government Appeals Board Rejects MCI Complaint
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals board on Wednesday rejected MCI's attempt to challenge part of the multi-billion-dollar telephone contracts the government awarded to AT&T and U.S. Sprint. At issue were changes to one of the two contracts to redesign and provide a pair of voice, data and video telecommunications networks in the 1990s for the government, a project that could total $25 billion over 10 years. In December 1988, the General Services Administration awarded the contract for one network to American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and the other to U.S. Sprint. Losing out was a third bidder, Martin Marietta Corp., whose proposal included a substantial share for MCI Telecommunications Corp. Wednesday's ruling by the GSA Board of Contract Appeals involved a dispute over changes the GSA is permitting U.S. Sprint to make in toll-free services. MCI had complained the modification was outside the scope of the contract and that competition was necessary to satisfy the requirement reflected in the changes. But the board, noting that the modification did not alter the maximum value of the contract, rejected the appeal. ``The government is modernizing its telecommunications system to incorporate technological advancements which permit greater flexibility,'' the board said. ``The modifications represent improvements to toll-free service.'' MCI spokesman John Houser said the company would continue to litigate changes to contracts it considers outside the scope of contracts. ``We weren't totally surprised, but we're disappointed. We kind of saw the writing on the wall on this one, but we thought we'd make a point, which is that they should take a hard look at these, so the interest of competition and the taxpayers is best served,'' Houser said. Last year, the board rejected an MCI challenge to the AT&T award and a federal appeals court later upheld the ruling. The FCC also had rejected MCI charges that AT&T set prices below costs in bidding for the contract.

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Board Decides Against Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp., the multinational chemical company that analysts speculated had been contemplating restructuring, announced Wednesday that it would not take that route. ``Taking into account all the revelant factors ... we believe that Carbide should at this time continue on its present course under its present structure,'' Chairman Robert D. Kennedy said in a statement. Analysts had speculated for some time that the company would restructure to make it better able to fend off any takeover attempt. The company plunged deeply in debt while fending off a hostile takeover in 1986. Kennedy said Carbide had studied several restructuring possibilities but nixed them because they were not beneficial to the company or its shareholders. ``Our criteria have been enhancement of both shareholder value and the strengthening of our core business,'' Kennedy said. ``At this time there is no restructuring alternative that meets both criteria.'' Carbide stock, which soared last week amid rumors of a possible takeover or spinoff, closed 50 cents higher Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange at $24.25. Union Carbide realigned in 1988, forming a holding corporation with three subsidiaries. Analysts had speculated the move could have been a prelude to spinning off one of subsidiaries to raise capital. The three subsidiaries are Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Company Inc., Union Carbide Industrial Gases Inc., and UCAR Carbon Company Inc. David Kernis, a spokesman for Union Carbide, said the strategy aimed to maximize development by decentralizing the company. Kennedy said the company plans to continue along that course but would not rule out other options such as acquisitions, joint ventures and strategic alliances. Kernis refused to say what restructuring options the company considered. Kennedy could not be reached for comment Wednesday night. Carbide earned $573 million last year, down 13 percent from record profits of $662 million in 1988. Sales dipped to $8.32 billion last year from $8.74 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Stock Soars By $6
DOC.TEXT: Stock in Digital Equipment Corp. soared by $6 amid rumors that the world's second-largest computer company might be the target of a takeover bid, but Digital officials refused to comment on the stock activity. Bruce Watts, an analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc. in Boston, said rumors circulated on Wall Street that Mitsubishi Electric Corp. had acquired a large share of Digital stock, and there was speculation it might try to take over the company. Digital stock closed up $6 at $78 on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday. Mitsubishi is one of the world's largest producers of semiconductor memory devices, which are critical in computers. Nikki Richardson, a Digital spokeswoman, said: ``We don't talk about matters of that nature.''

DOC.HEAD: Disney Fuming Over Phony Report of Michael Jackson Picture Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT that release said Jackson was discussing changing record companies sted already changed; CLARIFIES that article in Hollywood Reporter focused on stock deal sted contents of bogus news release; UPDATES with Disney spokesman blaming hoax on someone with a vendetta against unidentified Disney employee; picks up 7th graf, `Separately, Ed ...' A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney Co. scoured Hollywood on Wednesday for the source of a bogus news release that claimed moonwalking megastar Michael Jackson had signed a five-year movie deal with Disney. Disney said it began an investigation to find the author of the release, used as the basis for a story in a trade publication. Among other things, the story said Jackson was negotiating to leave CBS Records for Disney's new Hollywood Records and would design theme park rides for Disney. ``We fully intend to take action against the person or persons responsible,'' Walt Disney Studios Chairman Jeffrey Katzenberg said in a news release. ``This company has a reputation for protecting its name and taking legal action when necessary.'' The bogus information was included in a front-page article Wednesday in the Hollywood Reporter which focused on a stock deal planned by Jackson's father. The paper ran a front-page article Wednesday saying it had been the victim of a hoax. Editor Teri Ritzer said the writer who handled the story had been disciplined. She declined to say whether he had been fired. Disney said the news release, typed on company stationery, was sent to several publications. Spokesman Ed Pine said it appeared to have been motivated by a personal vendetta against a Disney employee and said the hoaxer hadn't been found, but refused to discuss the matter further. Separately, Ed Shaw, a spokesman for the newly formed Jackson Records set up by Michael Jackson's father Joe Jackson, said the elder Jackson had held preliminary talks with several Wall Street brokerages about a possible stock offering for as much as $100 million. Joe Jackson, who steered his children to stardom as the Jackson Five but no longer handles the affairs of Michael or Janet Jackson, wants to use the proceeds of the stock offering chiefly to fund movies starring Michael and Janet, Shaw said. However, Michael Jackson's lawyer, John Branca, said neither he nor his client knew anything about the planned offering. And Shaw acknowledged that neither Michael Jackson nor his sister had agreed to make records or movies for Joe Jackson's company. ``I don't think that any of the Wall Street firms would be interested without the participation of the two megastars,'' he said. The initial Hollywood Reporter story included a description of a movie that Jackson supposedly would make with the troika of Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and Francis Ford Coppola. The outer-space musical, tentatively titled ``Project M,'' was said to be budgeted between $50 million and $60 million. Jackson stars in the 3-D movie ``Captain EO'' at Disneyland, which opened in 1986 and was produced by Lucas, Coppola and Jackson.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Ready to Sell Still-UnFinished Tech Center
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said it's ready to sell its $1 billion, still-unfinished technical center and then lease it back, gaining $800 million in badly needed cash along the way. The move announced Tuesday is seen as a way for the financially struggling No. 3 automaker to raise the money it needs to finance a cost-cutting program that includes thousands of white-collar early retirements. ``It looks to me like the smartest way to do it at the moment,'' said auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. Chrysler on Monday filed papers with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington seeking permission to sell and lease back its Chrysler Technology Center in Auburn Hills, about 25 miles north of Detroit. Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said Tuesday the company would sell the center to the Auburn Hills Trust, which in turn would offer certificates to raise $800 million for Chrysler. The trust then would lease the center to the Auburn Hills Trust Services property management company, which would collect lease payments from Chrysler to repay the $800 million by 2020. ``There are two basic advantages,'' Houston said. ``We can raise more money than we could with a conventional mortgage and we get $800 million for use by the company that's not tied up in the center.'' The money, he said, will go into Chrysler's general operating coffers. The sale-lease arrangement is the latest in a series of moves Chrysler has made to get rid of non-automotive businesses and raise cash. Last September, Chrysler sold nearly half of its stake in Mitsubishi Motors Corp. of Japan and made about $310 million after taxes. Earlier this month, it sold its Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. subsidiary for $825 million. The company has been waging a cost-cutting program to chisel about $1.5 billion from its $26 billion annual budget by the end of the year. That program includes trimming more than 10 percent of the white-collar work force through attrition or early retirement, which costs money. Chrysler reported that it lost $664 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, including $577 million in write-offs for two car assembly plants the company is closing this year. It was the automaker's first quarterly loss since 1982. Chrysler and state government officials broke ground for the 2.5-million-square-foot complex in October 1986. It originally was targeted to be completed this year and house 5,000 employees. Houston said the completion date now is 1993 and the center will house 7,000 workers, most of whom now work at the company's Highland Park headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Nuke Plant Opponents, Proponents Upset With Regulatory Process
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf, `It has ...,' to UPDATE with NRC comment; picks up 9th graf, `If promised ...' Dianne in 7th graf is cq. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CR1
DOC.TEXT: Seabrook nuclear power plant proponents and opponents rarely agree, but both say the regulatory process leading up to Thursday's expected licensing of the plant _ 14 years after groundbreaking _ has been ridiculous. Both sides expect the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to license the $6.5 billion plant owned by a dozen utilities, but opponents promised legal action to keep it idle. ``I never thought it would take this long,'' said former Gov. Meldrim Thomson, a Seabrook supporter who served during 1973-79. ``If any human being could dream up anything worse, they would have to work at it,'' Thomson said. ``We've been told over and over again that we've built the best and safest plant that's ever been built. It's ridiculous that it hasn't been licensed.'' Veteran anti-Seabrook protester Paul Gunter, first arrested at the plant in 1976, is equally critical, but from the opposite viewpoint. ``The regulatory process has been in the hands of a promotional agency rather than a regulatory agency,'' he said. ``(The NRC) has basically pulled Seabrook into operation even though it can't meet the law and protect human safety.'' Dianne Dunfey, another veteran protester, was released from jail last week after serving a five-day term for refusing to pay a fine following a sit-in at Gov. Judd Gregg's office. She called the NRC ``one of the most disreputable of all government agencies.'' ``It has ignored public input,'' said Dunfey, who teaches in Seabrook. ``It either discarded or amended all of its own regulations anytime Seabrook couldn't meet one.'' Asked why the licensing procedure had taken as long as it did, NRC spokesman John Kopeck in Washington, said, ``There was a legal process that it had to go through _ there were a lot of steps that had to be taken ...'' If promised court appeals don't succeed, Seabrook would go through a three-month buildup to full-power operation. The main point in the way of licensing was the federal requirement for evacuation plans for communities within 10 miles of the plant, including six in Massachusetts. Opponents say the area surrounding the plant _ about two miles from popular Hampton Beach and 40 miles north of Boston _ is too densely populated to be evacuated safely in an emergency. ``The regulatory process at the NRC is largely a charade,'' Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., said in a telephone interview Wednesday. ``They have brushed aside concerns about evacuation. Anybody who's been in a traffic jam (near the plant) during the summer knows that in a panic situation, evacuation would be impossible.'' Seabrook proponents, including former Gov. John Sununu, now White House chief of staff, say the plans will work. Sununu declined to comment on the plant this week, but as governor he was a vocal supporter. ``It may be a surprise ... but we run the analogy of an (evacuation) experiment 7:30 each summer day,'' Sununu said during a 1983 debate. ``At 7:30 that beach is crowded ... and at 11 at night that beach is empty.'' While environmental groups and the Massachusetts attorney general fought the evacuation plans, the grassroots Clamshell Alliance staged anti-Seabrook demonstrations that made the plant a national focus of the anti-nuclear movement in the 1970s and '80s. The last major Seabrook demonstration was in October, when 475 people were arrested after scaling the fences. A few opponents began vigils Tuesday at the Statehouse and outside Seabrook. A larger demonstration was to follow the licensing vote. Seabrook's path toward licensing has been a rocky one. Seabrook's lead owner, Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, filed for a permit to build twin, 1,150-megawatt reactors in 1973. The first was to operate commercially in 1979, the second in 1981. Total cost was estimated at $973 million. The NRC approved the permit in 1976, but it was suspended three times in the late 1970s in disputes over radioactive waste and tunnels for cooling water. The first reactor was finished in the mid-1986 at a cost of $4.3 billion; the second, 25 percent complete, was scrapped that year. Since then, financing and operating costs have boosted the cost by $50 million a month, bringing the total by Thursday to $6.5 billion. Public Service filed for bankruptcy in January 1988 under the burden of its Seabrook debt.

DOC.HEAD: Parent of Seized Thrift Files Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: The former parent of Imperial Savings Association sought bankruptcy protection just days after the thrift was seized by federal regulators, who said it was $60.1 million in the red. The government took control of Imperial Savings last week in large part because of problems brought about by its large portfolio of junk bonds. Imperial had invested more than $9.7 billion of its assets in junk bonds. Junk bond prices have plummetted in recent months and thrifts must divest their holdings by 1994 under provisions of last year's savings and loan bailout legislation. Only Columbia Savings and Loan in Beverly Hills has a bigger portfolio of the high-yield, high-risk bonds among thrifts. Imperial's former parent, Imperial Corp. of America, said Wednesday it had filed for Chapter 11 protection in bankruptcy court in San Diego to protect its other subsidiaries. The filing will give it breathing room to come up with a reorganization plan without having to worry about creditors' lawsuits. ``This was a very difficult decision,'' said ICA Chief Executive Lyman Hamilton. ``However, in an effort to protect our bondholders, shareholders and continue our operating businesses, we believe this was a prudent thing to do.'' Imperial Corp. and its former savings and loan subsidiary effectively split Friday when the thrift was taken over by the Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency that manages seized thrifts. Accounts up to $100,000 are federally insured. ``Today's filing by Imperial Corp. in now way affects Imperial Savings or its depositors' savings ... because the two are now independent companies,'' Imperial Savings spokesman Kenn Ulrich said. Imperial Corp. will be forwarding documentation of its assets and liabilities to the court over the next few weeks, said Patrick Shea, a lawyer for the firm representing the corporation in the proceedings. Ulrich said he didn't know what Imperial Corp.'s other subsidiaries were and didn't have any of its financial data available because he started his job just two weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Union Files Class-Action Suit Against Nordstrom Over Wages, Hours
DOC.TEXT: The union representing workers at Nordstrom Inc. filed a class-action lawsuit Wednesday, accusing the clothing retailer of widespread violations of wage and hour laws. The suit was the second to be filed against the upscale clothier in as many days. On Tuesday, a U.S. District Court suit was filed here by three Nordstrom shareholders who alleged they and other stockholders had suffered financial losses because company officials failed to disclose labor problems at the chain. United Food & Commercial Workers Union Locals 1001 and 367 and five current and former Nordstrom employees filed their suit in King County Superior Court. The suit includes in its class approximately 50,000 current and former Nordstrom workers in Washington, Oregon, California, Virginia, Utah and Alaska. The two locals represent about 1,500 Nordstrom workers in the Seattle area. Nationally, Nordstrom has about 60 stores and employs about 30,000. On Feb. 15, the Washington Department of Labor and Industries ruled Nordstrom had violated state laws by failing to pay some employees for time worked outside normal working hours. The state, acting on a complaint filed by the UFCW, found that workers had not been properly compensated for such things as attending meetings, delivering merchandise to other stores and customers, doing inventory work or writing thank-you notes to customers. Nordstrom said Monday it had made a $15 million provision for expected back pay claims by employees and adopted a procedure to handle the claims. The charge against fourth-quarter earnings was cited by the company as one reason why profits fell 34 percent in the period ending Jan. 31. Joe Peterson, Local 1001 president in Seattle, said at the time that the $15 million was far too little and threatened to sue if Nordstrom officials failed to negotiate a back-pay settlement with the union. Union officials have said claims could exceed $200 million in California alone. Nordstrom said claims forms had been sent to sales clerks in states other than Washington. In Washington state, those forms must be reviewed by the state's labor office and by the two union locals. Labor and Industries spokeswoman Karen Jones said Wednesday that the review had not yet taken place, and James Webster, attorney for Local 1001, said, ``They have not come to us to discuss that plan as they said they would in the papers.'' Webster said the union had ``hoped for a settlement from the outset,'' and was still willing to meet with company officials. The union lawsuit repeats the allegations made in the state complaint and alleges other violations of Washington and California labor laws, including that Washington employees were required to buy clothes from Nordstrom to wear at work. In a news release, Nordstrom co-chairman John Nordstrom said the company regretted the lawsuit, saying that once it was filed, ``local court rules place restrictions on our ability to communicate directly with our employees about their claims. This could slow down and perhaps bring to a halt the resolution process.'' Nordstrom said the company will continue trying to compensate for back claims, including seeking court approval to do so. The suit asks the court to order Nordstrom to keep proper employment records and award damages equal to twice the amount of wages unpaid, other damages to be determined at trial, and attorneys' fees. The union has said claims in Washington state may total $30 million to $40 million and run as high as $200 million in California. It had no estimate on likely claims in other states. To date, the union has received about 520 claims from workers worth about $2.5 million.
